HEADLINE: Dow Gains 5.99 as World Rally Continues

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Stock prices kept heading upward yesterday after a big lift on Wednesday from the collapse of the Soviet coup. While the Dow Jones industrial average added only slightly to its previous gains, two other indexes posted record highs.
Earlier, in Europe, markets rallied strongly, picking up the momentum from Wednesday, when many markets closed before the final reports of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's return to power. 
 The Dow gained a slight 5.59 points, to 3,007.38. But the Standard & Poor's 500 index of the most important stocks rose to 391.33, a gain of 0.74 point, and the New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 0.45 point, to 214.34.
Volume on the Big Board was down sharply from Wednesday, with 173 million shares changing hands, compared with 232 million the day before. Advances outnumbered declines, 896 to 698, with 127 issues reaching new highs.
 
Return to Reality
 Several analysts said that the rally that had lofted the Dow 88 points higher on Wednesday had run out of steam and that broader concerns about the domestic economy would again take center stage.
"This is a return to reality, and the reality is that the economic recovery is anemic," said Alan R. Ackerman, executive vice president at Reich & Company.
"World markets rallied overnight and gave the market in the United States some spark at the opening," he added. "But euphoria over the return of Gorbachev settled down, and the market got back to business. The market has been locked in the 2,850-to-3,050 trading range for more than five months and has had difficulty breaking through the upper end of that range."
In London, the Financial Times index of 100 leading shares rose 0.8 percent, the level it was at before the coup, and added a few extra points to set a new closing high of 2,623.01. In France, the CAC-40 jumped 1.5 percent to end at 1,819.13, just a point below its pre-coup level.
In Germany, the Dax index of leading shares jumped 60 points, or 3.8 percent, to 1,630.83, just 20 points below its pre-coup level and well within its recent trading ranges.
And in Japan yesterday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 2.1 percent, to 22,515.77, just 300 points from its level last Friday. Today, however, profit-taking pushed the index down 450.43 points, or 2 percent, to 22,065.34.
 
Day of Gyrations
 The Dow gyrated wildly throughout the day, beginning with a strong rally in the opening minutes of trading. After several rounds of back-and-forth movement however, the Dow stood below its opening level shortly before 4 P.M. for the fourth time in the day before a final, brief rally.
Oil stocks generally gained, based on the belief that American oil companies might now be able to participate in developing the Soviet Union's vast oil reserves. ARCO gained 1 1/8, to 121 5/8; Exxon rose 1/4, to 58 1/2; Mobil rose 1/2, to 66 7/8, and Shell rose 5/8, to 54 1/4.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 0.33 point, to 518.3, a gain of less than one-tenth of a percent. The American Stock Exchange's composite index was up 1.8 points yesterday, to 368.08, a gain of nearly half a percent.
The most active issue on the big board was Salomon, which dropped 2 1/8, to 22 5/8, with four million shares changing hands. The stock is still reeling from the effects of revelations about irregularities at government-debt auctions.
One of the biggest gainers on the Big Board was Metronic, a maker of pacemakers, which was up 4 5/8, to 129 7/8, on improved first quarter-earnings.
Another big gainer was IMC Fertilizer, up 4, to 58 7/8, following an analyst's report that the prospects for grain sales to the Soviet Union brightened with the fall of the coup.
Nearly two-thirds of the Dow's gain yesterday was attributed to three stocks: International Paper, which rose 1 5/8, to 68 3/8, a day after the company completed its acquisition of Leslie Paper; Alcoa, which rose 7/8, to 66 3/8, because analysts said the company was still gaining from news earlier this month of a restructuring, and Chevron, a member of the strong oil group, which rose 3/4, to 71 5/8.

LENGTH: 302 words

HEADLINE: A Breakthrough in Connecticut

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell Weicker's perseverance finally paid off yesterday. The Connecticut legislature, ending a bitter standoff, approved a state income tax. That's a striking advance, bringing an element of fairness to the state's obsolete tax structure and offering hope for a crippled economy.
Before the vote, Connecticut was one of only 10 states without a personal income tax. The state depended for revenue on an 8 percent sales tax -- the nation's highest -- which burdened the poor, as well as on exceptionally high taxes on dividends, interest and capital gains, which was calculated to drive out business and wealth. 
 Faced with a severe deficit almost one-third the size of the state's $7.5 billion budget, Mr. Weicker, elected as an independent, boldly proposed an income tax in February. It's a measure of his courage, and the tenacity of the Democratic and Republican legislators who refused to face up to the problem, that it took three gubernatorial budget vetoes before good sense prevailed.
The budget plan, quickly signed into law, imposes a 4.5 percent tax on all income; the impact on low- and middle-income taxpayers is softened by credits and deductions. It also lowers the sales tax to 6 percent and expands the list of taxable items.
Lobbying was fierce up to the last minute. In the final hours three Democratic Senators, Gary Hale, Marie Herbst and Steven Spellman, honorably switched sides in order to break the embarrassing and damaging deadlock.
The income tax won't guarantee that Connecticut, which faces huge disparities between wealthy suburbs and poor inner cities, will bounce back quickly from its economic problems. But 54 days after the start of its fiscal year, the state at least has a budget that strikes a blow for political responsibility and equity.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Triumph And Decline

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
The extraordinary drama of this week was in one sense a testament to what Mikhail Gorbachev has achieved. Six years ago it was unimaginable that Soviet citizens would join in mass resistance to tyranny. He has opened his people's minds to the possibility of freedom.
But the denouement also showed Mr. Gorbachev's limitations. On his return to power he defended the Communist Party. He turned to the same old party types for acting heads of the K.G.B., Defense and the Interior -- figures like the very men who had joined the coup against him. 
 In his press conference he seemed unwilling or unable to recognize the depth of two political trends accelerated by the coup: the discrediting of Communism and the movement away from centralized power, toward a federation of genuine republics.
The tumult of these days leaves us, then, with an ironic possibility. At the moment of his triumph, history may be leaving Mikhail Gorbachev behind.
In personal terms the press conference was vintage Gorbachev, colorful and convincing. Here was a man who had been isolated for 72 hours, fearing for his life; now, after a sleepless night, he was telling all about it in colloquial language. When the coup leaders demanded that he resign, he said, he told them: "You will never live that long."
But politically he was less convincing. In describing how the coup was undone he focused on himself. He praised the Russian people, but without really conveying a sense of their achievement in standing up to armed troops and the secret police. He praised Boris Yeltsin, but again without fully measuring the importance of his resistance to the coup.
Soviet journalists in the room applauded the reference to Mr. Yeltsin. That unusual gesture was a reminder of the political reality that Mr. Gorbachev seemed to ignore: After this week's events the president of the Russian Republic has strong public support and will expect corresponding influence.
Mr. Yeltsin may well have expected to be consulted about reconstruction of the Soviet Government after the coup. But Mr. Gorbachev apparently did not talk to him before making the key appointments.
Skepticism was evident in the first question at the press conference after Mr. Gorbachev's long opening statement. Why had he, last year, appointed the kind of people who would plot against him? In reply, a BBC commentator pointed out, he gave no real reason and no indication that he would make future appointments differently.
(The BBC had superb coverage of the Soviet crisis. Americans who heard it may have agreed with Mr. Gorbachev, who said his aides had fixed up old radios in his vacation home so they could hear foreign broadcasts, "BBC best of all.")
Then Mr. Gorbachev was asked whether he would give up his stewardship of the Communist Party. His answer was a long, defensive statement about the ideals of Socialism.
"To say that the October Revolution was a catastrophe would be wrong," he said. It was fine until Stalinism spoiled it. "We shouldn't confuse one thing with another."
Millions of his countrymen, more all the time, fervently disagree with his defense of Communism. The reality to them is not his utopian vision but a sucking bureaucracy, a non-functioning economy, a poisoned land.
After the last week anyone should be wary of making predictions about the Soviet Union. But there is strong reason now to think that it will move toward decentralization, private property and democracy -- move, if need be, with Mr. Gorbachev reduced to a marginal role.
To say such things is not easy, because Mikhail Gorbachev has accomplished so much. He freed the outlying states of the Soviet empire. He got out of Afghanistan. He reached an entente with the West in crucial areas of the world. Most important, he encouraged his people to think and speak for themselves.
The makers of the coup underestimated that last achievement. It is a perfect symbol that after they fell thousands of people in Moscow marched on the Lubyanka, the headquarters of the K.G.B., where Stalin's prominent victims were shot. As the crowd chanted, the huge bronze statue of Feliks Dzerzhinsky, the Polish aristocrat who founded Lenin's secret police and started the reign of terror, was pulled down.

HEADLINE: Send Help -- and Plenty of It

BYLINE: By Richard Burt; Richard Burt was Ambassador to West Germany during the Reagan Administration.

 BODY:
It is tempting to sit back and luxuriate in the clear victory for democratic change in the Soviet Union. But this would be a major mistake. The failed coup was not only a close call for the Soviet Union; it was also a wake-up call for the United States and its Western partners.
A successful coup would not only have scuttled reform in the Soviet Union. It would probably have also meant the end of the new Start treaty, complicated the Mideast peace process and perhaps halted the Soviet military withdrawal from Eastern Europe. 
 Fortunately, we have been spared all this. But no one should assume that political and economic reform are now assured in the Soviet Union. Further crises surely lie ahead. Accordingly, the United States and other Western countries need to think again about their approach to encouraging change in the Soviet Union.
Western conservative skepticism about him -- doubts that extend to some extent into the Bush Administration -- needs to be replaced by unambiguous support for the man and his program. President Gorbachev was and remains the man presiding over the transformation of Soviet society.
At the same time, the U.S. will have to get used to dealing with the heroes of the moment -- Boris Yeltsin and heads of the other republics -- whose authority will be strengthened and legitimized in the new union treaty.
Perhaps the most important task for Americans now is to commit to substantial economic assistance. That was the recommendation of a team of Harvard and Soviet specialists that recently proposed a step-by-step aid package.
But most policy makers and experts had argued that economic aid and credits were premature, that the Soviets had not demonstrated a sufficient commitment to political and economic reform. Indeed, even after this week's events, some Bush Administration officials expressed this view.
It is true that only the Soviets themselves can transform their republics into modern, efficient industrial democracies. But there are several steps we should consider taking. One would be to convene an extraordinary Group of Seven summit meeting, perhaps in Berlin, where the cold war began and ended, with both Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin invited as guests.
The purpose of the summit would not only be to provide reinforced political help for the two leaders, but to discuss a much more far-reaching program for economic support than the one agreed to in London.
Such a program might consist of increased technical assistance in energy, transportation and agriculture; economic aid, perhaps in the form of balance-of-payments assistance, a currency stabilization fund and, finally, credits to promote increased investment by Western companies.
It would also be important to get Western business and academic experts involved, perhaps by asking them, together with the U.S. Government, to take the lead in establishing a "democracy corps."
Hundreds and maybe thousands of American business people and academics would work for a year or two in the Soviet Union, helping with the huge task of creating local democratic institutions and a market economy.
This idea and other recommendations for aid are controversial. Many U.S. conservatives remain skeptical of the prospects for change in the Soviet Union, while liberals would rather spend money on domestic programs.
But a Republican Administration might be prepared to exercise greater vision if it believed that a Democratic-controlled Congress was prepared to support such an economic assistance package.
The Soviet people have showed their courage and commitment to change. How can we do less?

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues in Moderate Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities posted modest gains in fairly active trading yesterday, as the tension of the last few days drained out of the credit markets.
"The Salomon scandal and the Soviet crisis have sort of prevented people from really focusing on the market for the last week or so," one government bond trader said. "But now people are feeling more comfortable, and getting involved in the market for fundamental reasons." 
 Market participants said that for the first time in the last several sessions retail accounts were actively buying long-term bonds.
"There is some demand for long paper for the first time in a long time," the trader said. "That in turn is creating trading opportunities in all maturities."
 
Note Auctions Next Week
 With auctions of new two-year and five-year Treasury notes expected next week, dealers said that market participants were paring exposures in shorter-term maturities and buying longer-dated issues.
The surge of supply of new shorter-term issues actually began yesterday, when the Treasury auctioned $12.5 billion worth of new one-year bills.
The bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.36 percent, more than half a percentage point below the 5.88 percent average rate at the last one-year bill sale on July 25. It is the lowest rate on a one-year bill in nearly 5 years. On Aug. 28, 1986, the Treasury sold one-year bills at an average discount rate of 5.33 percent.
A jump in initial claims for unemployment insurance for the week ended Aug. 10 surprised some analysts, but the 22,000 increase, to 430,000, had only a momentary impact on prices in the credit markets. It was the second straight week that initial claims showed an increase.
 
Little Reaction to Money Supply
 Market participants also showed little reaction to weekly money supply figures, even though the growth was weaker than most Wall Street economists had expected.
For the week ended Aug. 12, the Federal Reserve Board reported that two of the three money measures it follows posted declines. The third, broadest measure, M-3, rose by $1.8 billion.
M-2, the measure most closely tracked by the Fed, fell by $3 billion in the week, putting the aggregate below the 2.5 percent yearly growth target that is at the low end of the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent.
Most analysts had expected a much more modest, $1 billion fall in M-2.
Nevertheless, economists said that continuing weakness in M-2 growth would not, when viewed in isolation, prompt the Fed to ease monetary policy.
"There probably isn't too much the Fed can do at the moment to boost it," said Wayne Smith, an economist at Reid Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn. The weak money numbers "will provide good support" in justifying an easing move, Mr. Smith added, but the Fed "won't move on that sort of a number alone."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 29/32, up 5/32, to yield 8.04 percent, down from 8.05 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 100 23/32, up 2/32, to yield 7.77 percent. The 7 5/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 102 22/32, up 2/32, to yield 7.21 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 5/32, down 1/32, to yield 6.22 percent.
Rates on outstanding short-term Treasury bills moved slightly higher.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.28 percent, up one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.29 percent.
A number of new issues were offered in the market for investment-grade corporate securities.
Among the issuers was Toys R Us, which offered $200 million worth of 30-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 8 3/4 percent securities were priced at $100, or par, 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
South Carolina Electric and Gas offered $155 million worth of 30-year securities through underwriters led by Paine Webber.
The 8 7/8 percent securities, which mature Aug. 15, 2021, were priced at $98.70, to yield 9 percent, 96 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged in light trading.
Municipal bond traders said that prices of most widely quoted tax-exempt issues rose by about 1/8 point. Activity was light, they said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
JAPAN RELUCTANT ABOUT SOVIET AID

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu hailed the collapse of the coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and lifted a freeze on Japan's aid to the SovietUnion today, as Japanese officials took steps to blunt a renewed campaign for increased international aid to Moscow.
 Government officials expressed concern that Japan will be expected to provide financial support for the Soviet Union if the West decides to bolster Mr. Gorbachev's Government, without respect for Japan's strong reservations. 
Japan has been trying to persuade Moscow to return four northern islands seized in the waning days of World War II. Mr. Kaifu has insisted that Japan will back only limited technical and humanitarian aid to the Soviets until this issue is resolved.
 "Of course, Japan is very much interested in the global situation, but the reality is that as far as Soviet policy toward Japan has gone, there have been no substantial changes during Gorbachev's term, so I don't see any radical changes now," said Kinya Niizeki, a former Ambassador to Moscow.
 
Calls for Heavy Aid
 Already, France, Italy and Germany have issued new calls for large-scale international aid to the Soviet Union, arguing that an improving economy would help to stabilize the transition to democracy and a market economy. But after meeting in Brussels with NATO officials on Wednesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d reiterated the American position that money will do nothing until Mr. Gorbachev opens the Soviet economy.
 Japan has been pleased by the American position but realizes, Government officials said, that there is likely to be greater impetus to the efforts to give Mr. Gorbachev some more visible form of support than he has been provided so far by the West.
 Koji Watanabe, a Deputy Foreign Minister, has been sent to London and Washington to convey Japan's views and to make certain that they are considered as the West deliberates.
 
Promoting the G-7's Role
 Another important sign of concern on this issue has been Japan's repeated calls for consultations through the Group of Seven, a largely economic-oriented gathering of the world's seven largest industrialized countries.
 Neither the United States nor other members of the group have shown much interest in transforming this body into a political forum for managing East-West issues. But the G-7 includes Japan, while the traditional forum for dealing with the Soviet Union, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, does not.
 "Japan wants to avoid a situation where NATO writes a prescription for how it wants to deal with the situation, and Japan is just sent a bill later," said Yukio Okamoto, a former senior Foreign Ministry official who was involved in Japan's response to the Persian Gulf crisis.

HEADLINE: Pocone Journal;
An Exaltation of Alligators, in a Swamp of Trouble

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POCONE, Brazil

 BODY:
Crocodiles slither off river banks. Marsh deer crash through the brush. At sunset, trees fill with a primeval profusion of tropical birds. Flooding an area nearly the size of Britain, the Pantanal (the name means great swamp) is the world's largest wetland.
Ever since 16th-century colonists introduced cattle with rot-resistant hooves, the Pantanal has been the isolated preserve of a few hundred cowboys maintaining herds of cattle in balance with nature. But now new forces of change are gnawing destructively at the edges of this vast wilderness in the heart of South America. About 80 percent of the Pantanal is in Brazil, with the remainder in Bolivia and Paraguay. 
 "The threats to the Pantanal come from outside: soy farming, gold mining, cheap tourism," said Valdo de Luiz, a grizzled rancher who recently opened a hotel to beat the loneliness of living in Pocone, a Massachusetts-sized administrative territory where cows far outnumber people.
 
An Exaltation of Fauna
 In the surrounding savannah, a soy boom in the 1980's turned this frontier state, Mato Grosso, into Brazil's fourth-largest soybean producer.
But a stiff price has been paid: large quantities of fertilizers and pesticides washed through this fragile ecosystem, which is home to 232 types of fish and 650 species of birds. Causing more visible damage, deforestation of river banks for farming has caused severe erosion and silting in the Pantanal river system.
"Twenty years ago, a 40-ton barge could navigate the Taquari River," said Nilson de Barros, president of a private landowners group, Society for the Defense of the Pantanal. Discussing one of several major rivers in the swamp, he said: "Now a four-ton barge has tremendous problems."
 
Chasing What Glitters
 A gold rush has drawn 300,000 miners to the state, but pollution controls have yet to follow. To separate gold from dirt and rock, miners use large quantities of highly toxic mercury, which is later dumped into rivers that flush the Pantanal basin.
Pinpointing another source of water pollution, a recent survey of the 70 municipalities in the Pantanal watershed found that none of them have sewage treatment plants.
The Pantanal's wildlife is also under attack. With alligator shoes, belts and handbags in high demand in Europe, Japan and the United States, poachers smuggle a million illegally harvested skins out of the Pantanal every year. In some areas, scores of alligator carcasses have been discovered, only their tails missing. The tails have become a delicacy in some European restaurants.
"Four alligators makes one pair of shoes," Miguel A. Castelino, a nature guide, said as visitors admired a group of them sunning themselves on a muddy bank of the Pixaim River.
 
'Change of Attitude'
 The number of tourists to the Pantanal exploded from 15,000 in mid-1980 to 150,000 this year. One factor boosting tourism was "Pantanal," a hit television soap opera that enchanted audiences 1,000 miles from here, in Brazil's coastal cities. The drama alternated the region's heart-stopping scenery with heart-pounding underwater love scenes.
But as in Brazil's other endangered wilderness, the Amazon rain forest, awareness is growing about the need to reconcile human development with nature preservation in the Pantanal.
In one incentive to action, world environmental attention will focus next June on Brazil when it plays host to the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development.
"There has been a tremendous change of attitude by the local authorities," said Janice S. Wiles, Brazil program officer for the World Wildlife Fund. Ms. Wiles is working with environmental officials to set up safeguards for a proposed $200 million World Bank loan for agricultural development to Mato Grosso state.
Most preservation efforts in the Pantanal seek to work with economic forces, not against them. In the 1980's, the authorities tried to repress alligator poaching through police raids. Although the forestry police won a few shootouts, they found themselves outgunned and outwitted by poachers equipped with radios, submachine guns and light planes.
In a new tack, officials this year authorized the export of skins from alligators bred in hatcheries. Under an experimental system, five Pantanal breeders are collecting alligator eggs in the wild, where only 7 percent of the eggs survive. In hatcheries, protected from predators, 99 percent of the eggs survive. Breeders are required to return 10 percent of any baby alligators to the wild.
In one year, an alligator bred in captivity will provide a smooth skin, largely free of blemishes. In contrast, wild alligators reach maturity in three years, often under rough conditions that damage their skin.
"We are going to compete with the illegal, wild skins," said Mr. Barros, who served until last year as Environment Secretary for Mato Grosso do Sul, a state that includes half of Brazil's Pantanal. He predicted that by 1995, regional hatcheries would export 150,000 captive-bred skins.
 
Jaguars Under Siege
 In Mato Grosso do Sul, a Government ban on fishing during the egg-laying season helped fish stocks rebound after overfishing by sportsmen. Anonymous letter writers have alerted the authorities to abuses ranging from illegal deforestation to expeditions of trophy hunters shooting jaguars, an endangered species.
A regional research-exchange plan has been signed by universities in Brazil, Bolivia and Paraguay, three countries lapped by the Pantanal waters. Last year, Mato Grosso do Sul started an environmental-exchange program with Florida, which is trying to save the Everglades.
"They are spending a fortune to restore the Everglades," Mr. Barros said of the diked and drained Florida marshland, one sixth as big as the Pantanal. "The Everglades are an example of what we shouldn't do."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 30, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 23 about environmental destruction in the Pantanal region of Brazil referred incorrectly to a species being depleted by poachers. A zoo curator has pointed out, in a letter received Sept. 16, that the animals are Yacare caimans, an endangered species belonging to the alligator family, not alligators, which are not endangered and are legally farmed for their skins. Research on the issue by the writer of the article was delayed by his absence from South America.

HEADLINE: Ciba-Geigy Profits Up

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: BASEL, Switzerland, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Ciba-Geigy A.G., the drug and chemical conglomerate, said today that its earnings rose in the first half of this year and its net operating profit in the whole of 1991 would improve from last year's 1.03 billion Swiss francs, or $682 million.
"Sales performance in the first quarter, the improvements in productivity and the development of exchange rates encourage us to make the statement that the profit for 1991 is expected to exceed that of the previous year," the company said in a statement. 
 Ciba-Geigy, which does about a third of its business in the United States, said profit in the first half rose despite worse economic conditions than in the comparable period a year earlier.
Profit after tax in the six months to June 30 rose to 1.27 billion francs, or $834 million, from 1.22 billion, or $801 million, last year.
Sales were little changed at 10.95 billion francs, or $7.25 billion, compared with 10.91 billion, or $7.22 billion.
Cash flow increased to 1.83 billion francs, or $1.20 billion, from 1.75 billion, or $1.15 billion.
"The favorable growth in pharmaceutical and agricultural sales and internal measures taken to increase productivity were the main reasons for the improvement," it said.
Compared with the first quarter this year, the results for the second quarter were markedly better, although the modest economic upturn so far had only minimally affected the major customer markets in Europe and the United States, it added.

HEADLINE: U.S. Vehicle Sales Dropped 10.2% in Mid-August

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 10.2 percent in mid-August, reflecting somewhat weaker demand in the United States auto market than analysts had expected.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales from Aug. 11 to 20 was 6.1 million, a drop from 6.2 million in early August, and a sharp decline from the rates of 6.7 million in June and 6.8 million in July. 
 Analysts said they had anticipated a lower annual selling rate for August, because of strong fleet sales earlier in the summer, particularly by the General Motors Corporation.
 
'More Severe' Than Expected
 "We expected there would be some payback for June and July," said Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. "But that payback is proving to be somewhat more severe than what we were looking for."
Stephen Girsky, an auto analyst at Paine Webber in New York, said the latest figures suggested that "the retail demand is still soft and the recovery in auto sales is still slow." He said a lack of confidence among consumers was delaying any recovery by the auto industry.
Mr. Heinbach and Mr. Girsky had been forecasting annual sales rates through August and September of approximately 6.6 million units.
Michael Bowyer, who tracks the auto industry for Duff & Phelps in Chicago, agreed that consumer confidence remained a problem.
"It's difficult to take the temperature of the economy right now, and consumers are having trouble as well," he said. "They're in a 'hold back' response with cars, which are one of the most deferrable expenditures there are."
 
Fourth-Quarter Gain Expected
 Mr. Bowyer said he did not expect the United States auto market to start showing sales improvements over last year until the middle of the fourth quarter.
Mr. Heinbach of Merrill Lynch noted that car dealer inventories were low and that some sales might have been lost because of spot shortages.
Manufacturers with American operations sold 143,480 domestically built cars in the Aug. 11-20 period, a decline of 10.7 percent from a year ago. Sales of vehicles classified as light trucks, which account for about one-third of all vehicles sold, declined 9.5 percent.
Overall sales of cars and light trucks by the domestic Big Three declined 12.8 percent in mid-August. The Japanese auto makers that produce cars in the United States posted a 7.0 percent increase.
 
G.M. Car Sales Off 13.4%
 General Motors, the industry leader, reported that it sold 60,710 cars in mid-August, or 13.4 percent fewer than a year earlier. The company sold 36,137 light trucks, a drop of 16.2 percent. Oldsmobile and Buick were the only two G.M. divisions to post higher sales, because of strong demand for the redesigned Buick Park Avenue and Oldsmobile 98.
The Ford Motor Company sold 37,970 cars, a drop of 10.5 percent, and 28,883 light trucks, a decline of 20.9 percent.
Sales for the Chrysler Corporation were estimated by Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter, at 13,000 cars, a drop of 27 percent from last year's figure. Its light-truck sales were estimated at 21,200 for the 11-day period, up 24 percent. Chrysler reports its sales on a monthly basis only.
The Honda Motor Corporation was the only member of the Japanese Big Three to show an increase over last year. Honda's car sales rose 21.6 percent, to 14,983, in mid-August.
The Nissan Motor Company's car sales fell 19.7 percent, to 2,512, while truck sales dropped 5.7 percent, to 3,486. The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales of cars fell 4.8 percent, to 9,946.

HEADLINE: U.S. Issues Plunge on Durables Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An extremely strong reading on the economy sent the credit market reeling yesterday, and prices of Treasury securities plummeted in moderately active trading.
The reported 10.7 percent increase in durable goods orders for July, the largest monthly rise in nearly 21 years, caught analysts by surprise. Even though much of the increase resulted from a big increase in aircraft orders, economists said the report strongly suggested the manufacturing sector was on the road to recovery. 
 "These numbers blow away the notion that we are going to have a double dip recession," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Inc.
Some analysts have been concerned that the tepid, though positive, signs of recovery visible in recent weeks might be on the wane, and that after a quarter of slightly positive growth the economy might begin to contract again in the third quarter.
 
Order Backlog Rises
 Excluding transportation orders, the data showed that new orders rose a strong 6 percent last month. As important, some economists say, was a 1.4 percent increase in backlogs of new orders, the first increase in four months. Economists watch this series closely because manufacturers do not tend to begin adding to employment rolls until order backlogs begin to mount.
Analysts cautioned against reading too much into one strong report. Indeed, auto sales data released yesterday, which showed that sales were a disappointing 6.1 million units at an annual rate for the middle 10 days of August, provided evidence that the recovery would be mild.
"The car sales numbers were quite pathetic," Mr. Yardeni said, "and suggest the recovery will not be as strong as the durable goods report implied."
Nevertheless, analysts and traders said the durable goods report was strong enough to dissuade the Federal Reserve Board from easing monetary policy in the near term.
 
Influence on the Fed
 "The broad-based power in the durables numbers should cause the Fed to do nothing for a period of time," one government securities trader said. "If the Fed had been looking to ease for arcane money supply reasons, they have probably lost a window."
Traders did not seem to consider the import of the auto sales figures because prices of Treasury securities, which fell sharply after the durable goods report, never recovered.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 late yesterday, down 7/8 point, to yield 8.12 percent, up from 8.04 percent late Thursday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 5/8, down 5/8 point, to yield 7.86 percent.
Prices of the new two-year and five-year notes to be sold at auction next week also got hammered.
By late in the day, the new two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.43 percent. Late Thursday the issue was offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 6.26 percent.
 
Yields Are Up
 Meanwhile, the five-year notes were offered in late when-issued trading yesterday at a price to yield 7.39 percent, compared with 7.25 percent late Thursday.
The prospect of no immediate move by the Fed to lower short-term interest rates caused Treasury bill rates to move sharply higher.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.36 percent, up 8 basis points, or eight-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 15 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.44 percent. And one-year bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.47 percent, up 13 basis points.
The sharp selloff in the Treasury market did not cause a similar plunge in other fixed-income markets.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues fell by 1/4 point to 1/2 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by 1/4 point to 3/8 point in quiet trading.

HEADLINE: Kerry Sees Help on Americans Missing in Asia

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The leaders of Vietnam and Cambodia have renewed pledges of an "open inquiry" to resolve rapidly the fates of Americans listed as missing in action in those Southeast Asian nations, Senator John Kerry said today.
After a weeklong visit to Vietnam and Cambodia, Mr. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, said the two Communist countries had promised to allow United States helicopters to take part in the search. They also pledged to welcome Americans making their own inquiries and to give unprecedented access to a newly formed Senate committee investigating the possibility that some of the missing Americans are still alive, he said. 
 "I think it is very significant that they are willing to have that kind of intrusion, that kind of open inquiry," Mr. Kerry told a news conference. "It seems to me at first blush that they are extraordinarily committed to make that happen."
 
Met With Many Officials
 During his trip to Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam and Phnom Penh in Cambodia, Mr. Kerry met with Do Muoi, head of Vietnam's Communist Party, Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia and a number of other officials in both countries.
Mr. Kerry's comments echoed those of United States officials who say that Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos have significantly stepped up cooperation on the issue of 2,273 Americans listed as missing in Southeast Asia.
Vietnam is eager for diplomatic relations with Washington and the lifting of a United States trade embargo hampering recovery of that country's ruinous economy.
Mr. Kerry, a highly decorated Vietnam War veteran, said he made the trip to lay the groundwork for an effort by the 12-member Senate committee he heads. Mr. Kerry said he also planned to visit Laos.
 
Did Some Stay Behind?
 Mr. Kerry indicated that he thought a small number of Americans may have stayed behind in Vietnam of their own free will, but he declined to give details.
"It is very difficult to comprehend the rationale for a government to formally be holding somebody, and I saw nothing while I was there to change my mind about creating a rationale," he said when asked about possible American prisoners of war in Indochina.
Mr. Kerry said Vietnamese leaders agreed to allow a small United States team, based in Hanoi, which is searching for missing Americans to have more logistical support, including helicopters. He said three to four American helicopters may be sent to Vietnam to assist the search, with the Vietnamese doing the flying.
He said this would allow quicker movement to areas where "live sightings" of Americans are reported.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Sharp Climb On Durable Goods Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved sharply higher yesterday, helped by a report on orders for durable goods that indicated the economy was returning to health.
The Commerce Department said orders for durables soared 10.7 percent in July, with gains in almost every major industry group. 
 The figures caught the foreign exchange markets by surprise, as economists had predicted a 2 percent gain. "The numbers were staggering in terms of expectations," said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York.
The figures provided evidence that the economy was regaining strength. Economists warned that the surge in orders probably could not be sustained in coming months, but they added that the increase was a sign that the economy would not fall back into recession.
The report heartened foreign exchange traders because it raised the possibility that the Federal Reserve would be under less pressure to lower interest rates to restart the economy. The dollar, like other currencies, is supported by stable or higher interest rates.
Yesterday's report gave the dollar new strength after declines in the last few days. The currency surged on Monday after news of the Soviet coup, then lost ground when it appeared that the takeover by hard-liners had failed. The dollar is viewed as a relatively safe investment during international turmoil.
The British pound fell to $1.6775 in New York yesterday from $1.6935 late Thursday. In earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.6738 from $1.6975.
Against the German mark, the dollar strengthened after a volatile week, closing at 1.7475 marks, up from 1.7295.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen, closing at 136.90 yen in New York, up from 136.60 late Thursday. In Tokyo overnight, before the durable goods figures were released, the dollar fell by 0.05 yen, to 136.70. It was quoted higher in London, at 136.75 yen.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, were: 1.5275 Swiss francs, up from 1.5090; 5.9345 French francs, up from 5.8795, 1,304.75 Italian lire, up from 1,293.75, and 1.14415 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14325.
In the precious metals markets, gold fell 90 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to $353.40 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $353.50, down $1.

HEADLINE: Fed's Meeting in July Backed a Neutral Policy

BYLINE: By AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers voted last month to maintain a neutral monetary policy that did not favor further interest rate cuts to stimulate the economy, according to minutes of their meeting released today.
Nevertheless, less than a month later the Fed cut short-term interest rates out of concern that the economy's nascent recovery might falter. At its latest policy meeting this week, a similar resolution favoring a neutral policy on rates was believed to have been adopted, but comments by Fed officials have suggested that with inflation dropping the Fed has the room to ease rates further if needed to stimulate the economy. Raising rates, for the time being, appeared to be out of the quetion. 
 The minutes of that meeting, held on Tuesday, will not be released until Oct. 4.
The minutes of the July 2-3 meeting reported that "an upturn in economic activity had begun in recent months." At the same time, the minutes continued, "excluding food and energy items, increases in consumer prices had been small in recent months."
Thus, the Fed policy makers believed "that at this juncture an unchanged policy course offered the greatest promise of reconciling the committee's goals of sustaining the nascent business recovery while also fostering further progress against inflation."
 
A Unanimous Vote
 The vote to maintain current policy was 10 to 0.
Until last March, the Fed's policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, had favored a bias toward lower rates to stimulate the economy. It had voted at that time to adopt a neutral policy that would permit the Fed to act according to economic developments.
Since then, the Bush Administration and many private economists have called on the central bank to cut rates further to insure the economic recovery.
Indeed, after the release of several weaker-than-expected reports in late July and early August, the Fed on Aug. 6 permitted the key Federal funds rate to fall to 5.5 percent from 5.75 percent. The rate is the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans and has been lowered nine times since the recession began in July 1990.
The Federal Open Market Committee, composed of the Fed board members in Washington and five of the Fed's 12 regional bank presidents, meets eight times a year to formulate monetary policy. The board has two vacancies.
 
Stance on Money Supply
 The minutes of the July 2-3 meeting also show that the committee voted 10 to 0 to continue the 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent target range for money supply growth for the remainder of 1991.
But two members who voted to maintain the target for the rest of the year voted to reduce the range in 1992 as a hedge against inflation. They were Wayne D. Angell, a governor, and Robert P. Black, president of the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank.
A reduction in the target would tend to push interest rates higher, dampening both inflation and growth.
The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, had told Congress in mid-July of the policy makers' decision to extend the target range. But he said the extension was provisional and would provide sufficient leeway to allow monetary tightening in reaction to any unexpected resurgence of inflation or monetary easing to help a faltering recovery.

HEADLINE: Realty Family In Bankruptcy

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Aug. 23

 BODY:
The Tamposi family, one of New Hampshire's largest real estate developers, filed for bankruptcy protection today after a deal with creditors collapsed.
The six children of the real estate developer Samuel Tamposi Sr., who is not involved in the bankruptcy filing, list about $106 million in debt on real estate investments in southern New Hampshire. 
 The family said it had been working since April to structure a debt plan that asked the banks not to sue or foreclose for four and a half years while they sell the real estate.
The Tamposis reportedly planned to sell off more than 100 properties, including office buildings, condominium projects and offices.
"Unfortunately, we learned yesterday that a few of our many lenders are unwilling to accept the plan as the best means of resolving our indebtedness," Samuel Tamposi Jr., president of the Tamposi Company, said today in a statement.
Rather than give some creditors preferential treatment, the family decided to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, he said, which will allow it to reorganize while fending off creditors.
The Tamposis are among several New England developers to default on loans in the recession. Property values have plunged, causing problems for builders, banks and many other businesses.

HEADLINE: A Public Apartment Tower May Now Be a Private One

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
A state appeals court has ruled that New York City can no longer block Columbus Park Towers on the West Side of Manhattan from withdrawing from a state-subsidized middle-income housing program and converting to a private cooperative apartment project.
In a 3-to-2 ruling on Thursday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court said the city was required to approve the conversion, even though it opposed it. 
 Columbus Park Towers, a 162-apartment co-op building at 100 West 94th Street, is part of a sprawling mixed-income housing development in a designated urban renewal area bounded by West 87th and 97th Streets and Amsterdam Avenue and Central Park West.
Because of its location on an urban renewal tract, the city had argued that any so-called privatization of the project would be counter to the city's original urban-renewal goals.
 
Wider Impact Seen
 Marvin Wexler, a lawyer who represented Columbus Park Towers, said the ruling was "significant." A lawyer for the city said the ruling could affect as many as 10 other similar middle-income housing projects that are seeking to become private cooperatives.
A spokesman for Felice L. Michetti, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, said Ms. Michetti would have no comment until she had read the court's ruling. But an assistant Corporation Counsel for the city said the ruling would be appealed to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals.
At issue are so-called Mitchell-Lama housing projects in the city that were approved by the Legislature 36 years ago. They extended tax breaks and other financial incentives to private developers who built rental and semi-cooperative apartment buildings for middle-income residents.
Projects that began after May 1, 1959, were given the option of withdrawing from the state program after 20 years. Columbus qualified for this option, since it was begun in 1963.
But the city opposed the withdrawal, and its opposition was upheld in December by Justice Bruce Wright of State Supreme Court.
 
40-Year Wait Sought
 The appeals court, however, reversed Justice Wright's decision yesterday and ordered the city to withdraw its objection.
A majority of the court disagreed with the city's contention that "privatization" would defy the intent of urban renewal, saying "there is simply no evidence that it was the planner's overall conception to freeze the socio-economic make-up of the West Side for 40 years." That was how much time the city wanted Columbus to wait before converting to private status.
Moreover, the court said that the city's argument that residents of the building would "reap a windfall" by acquiring their apartments at a fraction of their market value did not hold in the face of the current decline in real-estate values.
Lawyers on both sides said they expeated the issue to be finally decided by the Court of Appeals.
The majority decision was written by Justice Richard W. Wallach. Concurring with him were Justices Joseph P. Sullivan and George Bundy Smith. Justices Betty Weinberg Ellerin and David Ross dissented.
Housing officials said there are 421 Mitchell-Lama projects with 170,000 apartments in the city, some of them rentals and some co-ops. Last year, 20 of them had been withdrawn from the state program and 20 others had withdrawal applications pending.

HEADLINE: Sale of Midtown Office Tower May Be Bad Sign for Market

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In a potential real-estate deal sending shivers through New York's already depressed office market, Citicorp, the city's largest lender to developers, said yesterday that it was negotiating the sale of a vacant 42-story office tower that it holds in foreclosure to Bertelsmann A.G. The sale would most likely be at a loss.
Bertelsmann, the diversified German concern whose United States holdings include RCA Records and Bantam Doubleday Bell, the publishing concern, confirmed the negotiations. 
 If a deal is struck, the price would almost certainly be far below the $250 million mortgage that Citicorp holds on the building. Banking industry analysts say that if Citicorp is considering selling a major building at a large loss, then other banks are likely to be considering similar deals on foreclosed properties, cumulatively undermining Manhattan office prices.
The potential "is to put a real damper on any kind of recovery in prices" in the Manhattan office market, said Michael Giliberto, a real-estate analyst for Salomon Brothers.
 
Large Portfolios of Losers
 The vacant building, rising above Times Square at 1540 Broadway, is a sleek glass tower which was completed in 1989. It came onto the market after the city had sunk into recession, following the ebullience of the 1980's, when more than a dozen other new office towers were added nearby because of city zoning incentives.
In addition to Citicorp, other major lenders including the Chase Manhattan Corporation and Chemical Bank are burdened with large portfolios of nonperforming real-estate loans and smaller but still troublesome blocks of vacant office space held in foreclosure.
Although New York City so far has not had foreclosures and distress sales on the same scale as the Southwest, "we could see the same kind of overhang develop," Mr. Giliberto of Salomon Brothers said.
Trish Heimers, a spokeswoman for Bertelsmann, said yesterday that its "goal is to find the lowest possible cost of occupancy." The company has 2,000 Manhattan employees, now split between leased offices on the Avenue of the Americas and on Fifth Avenue. One benefit of acquiring a building would be to have staff in one place, she said.
 
Initial Offer of $100 Million?
 Nonetheless, Ms. Heimers said the company was "in no rush" and was "talking to a lot of people."
At Citicorp, Ann Luzatto, a company spokeswoman, said, "We are in discussion with Bertelsmann and others," whom she declined to identify.
Both companies declined comment on a report in The Wall Street Journal yesterday that Bertelsmann had made an initial bid of $100 million, but real-estate industry executives who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that they believed the offer had been made and rejected.
Still, analysts said that if Citicorp is intent on selling, it must accept the reality of a seriously ailing market.
 
'May Break a Logjam'
 The company's foreclosed real estate is "a drag on morale and a drag on management time," said George M. Salem of Prudential Securities.
"I think Citicorp is coming to the realization that waiting may be even more expensive" than selling at a steep discount, he said, adding that a major sale like one at 1540 Broadway "may break a logjam" at several banks.
Nonperforming real-estate loans by major New York banks have been growing rapidly. Citicorp said yesterday that its nonperforming loans on commercial property totaled $2.8 billion, with $169 million held in foreclosure.
But Mr. Salem said the numbers were far higher because of a "weird method" of accounting used by the bank in which real-estate loans are sometimes counted as commercial loans. In an analysis he conducted, Citicorp's nonperforming commercial real-estate loans totaled $5.9 billion, with $2.3 billion in foreclosure. He said the Chase Manhattan Bank had $3 billion in loans, with $800 million in foreclosure, and Chemical Bank had $1.8 billion, with $700 million in foreclosure.
Complicating sales of foreclosed properties, particularly when they involve large losses, is the kind of international loan syndication adopted in the 1980's. Since the loans are shared by banks, insurance companies and others around the world, several parties must agree on a price.
On 1540 Broadway, Citicorp was the lead lender, but syndicated about 75 percent among 16 Japanese lenders.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
Britain to Assemble Group of 7 for Soviet Aid Talks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Prime Minister John Major will convene senior officials of seven leading industrial nations next week to discuss what might be done to further economic and political reform in the Soviet Union, a spokesman for Mr. Major said today.
Mr. Major called the meeting after the failure of the coup by Soviet hard-liners opposed to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Major is now chairman of the Group of Seven, which includes the United States, Canada, Japan, Germany, France, Italy and Britain. 
 No date or place was set for the meeting, although officials at Downing Street said they expected it would take place in London.
In July, Mr. Gorbachev met with President Bush, Mr. Major and the other five leaders in London, where the seven promised to give the Soviet Union increased trade and technical assistance but stopped short of direct economic aid.
 
Major's Vow to Gorbachev
 Western leaders said at the time that the Soviet Union had to demonstrate a stronger commitment to real structural reform in the Soviet economy and political system.
But on Thursday, after Mr. Gorbachev had been restored to power and the coup attempt toppled, British officials said that Mr. Major had promised President Gorbachev that he would do whatever he could to speed up the Soviet leader's reform agenda.
He promised Mr. Gorbachev he would speak on the telephone with other Group of Seven leaders, to help shape a joint response to the new situation in the Soviet Union, a British official said.
A Downing Street spokesman said today that the talks next week are intended to "discuss and assess the situation in the Soviet Union and to carry matters forward."
Until now, Britain, like the United States, has ruled out direct cash assistance to the Soviet Union in favor of technical aid and closer ties to international agencies like the World Bank.
 
Aid Rise From Europe Sought
 Other nations, like Germany, have pushed for a stronger commitment to economic assistance.
Earlier today, the European Community said the Soviet Ambassador to Brussels had passed on a message from Mr. Gorbachev, requesting that President Jacques Delors provide a "significant increase" in the community's aid to Moscow.
British officials said the meeting next week definitely would consist of senior technical officials who have no power of their own to make decisions but rather report back to their capitals.
 
GERMANS URGE TALKS ON SOVIETS
BONN, Aug. 23 (Special to The New York Times) -- German officials today urged leaders of other industrial nations to convene a special meeting to discuss new help for the Soviet Union.
"The aid from the West must be as massive as the aid from Germany has been so far," said Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann. "The past few days should have provided enough motivation."
In a radio interview and subsequent news conference, Mr. Mollemann suggested that leaders of the world's seven leading industrial powers, who met last month in London, should reassemble with President Gorbachev and leaders of Soviet republics.
"If a new summit were called," he said, "and the Soviet republics were given a greater role, then we could go beyond general declarations of intent and agree on a specific course."
At such a meeting, Mr. Mollemann said, the Soviet Union would be expected to present "a reform policy worthy of the name" that breaks decisively with "old Communist thinking."
Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said he supported the call for a new Group of Seven meeting. He also urged that European Community leaders hold a separate meeting with leaders of formerly Communist countries in Eastern Europe. Such a meeting, he said, would be "the right signal" for countries worried about the durability of their new friendships with the West.
Although Mr. Mollemann declined to name countries that he believed were not contributing enough to the Soviet Union, Mr. Genscher singled out the United States and Japan.
Germany has provided more than $30 billion in aid to the Soviet Union since 1989.
Germany's economy, also burdened with the high costs of German unification, can no longer support such massive outlays. Yet Germans are convinced that without a large and immediate infusion of cash, the Soviet Union is headed for more instability.
"Supporting the development of democracy in the Soviet Union is not only in the interest of the Soviet Union, but of all the world's nations," said Dieter Vogel, chief spokesman for Chancellor Helmut Kohl, at a news conference today. "We need a comprehensive plan involving all Western industrial countries. It can't be only Germany."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
The Day's Highlights

 BODY:

Sweeping Away the Old Order
 SHAKEUP IN THE KREMLIN: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, yielding to the ascendancy of the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, in the aftermath of the failed coup, replaced the Soviet Government. Page 1. 
 ROUT FOR THE COMMUNISTS: The Communist Party, for decades the bulwark of the Soviet state, was put to a humiliating rout, as party bosses and organizations across the country either defected or were locked out of their offices. Page 1.
SOBERING TIME FOR GORBACHEV: President Gorbachev's appearance before the Russian Parliament was meant as a show of gratitude and solidarity. But he often seemed less a President returned to power than a co-conspirator in the dock of a political tribunal. Page 1.
OLD-LINE PAPERS SUSPENDED: President Yeltsin ordered the suspension of Pravda and five other Communist Party newspapers and the seizure of their property on the territory of his Russian republic. Page 8.
 
Shock Waves in the Republics
LENIN'S DEMISE IN ESTONIA: The people of Estonia's capital, Tallinn, flocked to Communist Party headquarters. They stood there and laughed, staring at the empty pedestal from which a statue of Lenin had just been removed. Page 1.
CELEBRATION IN LITHUANIA: Lithuanians, sensing that full independence could be at hand, turned a rally commemorating the Nazi-Soviet pact that propelled them into the Soviet Union into a candle-lit celebration. There were anti-Communist actions in other republics as well. Page 8.
 
An Awed World Reacts
PRAISE FROM THE WHITE HOUSE: President Bush said the Soviet Union was moving rapidly toward "the objectives that we want" and praised the Government shakeup in Moscow. Page 9.
INDUSTRIAL NATIONS TO MEET: Prime Minister John Major of Britain plans to convene senior officials of seven leading industrial nations next week to discuss what might be done to further economic and political reform in the Soviet Union. Page 9.
'GREAT VICTORY,' SAYS U.S. ENVOY: Ambassador Bob Strauss, who rushed to the Soviet Union at the height of coup but refused to present his credentials to the coup government, said, "The forces that the United States feels so strongly about have had a great victory." Page 8.
LONG-TERM NUCLEAR ANXIETY: Bush Administration officials sought to minimize reports that President Gorbachev lost control of Soviet nuclear forces during the coup, but expressed concern about the long-term stability of Moscow's vast nuclear arsenal. Page 9.
EVENTS MAY ECLIPSE 1917: George F. Kennan, one of the leading American historians of the Soviet Union, said he believed that the events surrounding the failed coup in Moscow eclipsed the Russian Revolution in importance. Page 9.

HEADLINE: Tax War, the Sequel, May Play in Connecticut

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Almost the only sounds in the Capitol today, finally still after its 53-day budget siege, were the first threats of Election-Day revenge against legislators who voted for a Connecticut income tax.
Those noises echo the great protest of 1971, when angry voters forced the repeal of a newly enacted income tax. In the weeks before smaller paychecks end the abstract nature of this debate and possibly amplify the rumblings, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and others bound to the tax can only hope that the storm will be swift in passing and that events will prove them right. 
 The immediate challenge for his independent administration, and for the Democrats and Republicans who supported him, is withstanding the protests until Mr. Weicker's long-term solution to the state's financial problems has a chance to be proved wise through long-term results.
Today Mr. Weicker offered a matter-of-fact resolve to weather any public storm, now that he had won the tax and budget he wanted from the General Assembly. "This is not a popularity contest, and I think everyone understood that from Day One," he said. "We're either right or wrong."
On a day when radio talk shows were crowded with callers complaining about the income tax and a taxpayers' group released its first list of legislators it plans to punish for voting for the tax, Mr. Weicker went so far as to say he saw no need to appeal for public support.
An income tax had been openly debated for months, he said, and no one is ever happy about paying more taxes. Instead, he presented the same blunt implacable logic with which he shaped the long tax debate in the Legislature.
"I'm not a tax reformer," he said. "I'm not an income-tax man." The tax question, he said, had been "driven by the numbers," budget numbers that did not add up in the end without the added, predictable revenue of an income tax.
Others, however, say a long education process is needed, both to make residents understand their share of the new tax and to make clear the alternatives. In some cases, that process can be as simple as guiding someone through a tax chart. In others, it may require either a sophisticated grasp of economics or a leap of faith.
"I suppose everyone is doing their own calculations today to see what they will pay as a family, and I guess they're going to have to wait to see if the price is worth it," said John J. Droney Jr., who as state Democratic chairman opposed an income tax while a majority of his legislators voted for it.
The long budget deadlock was fired by a series of emotional debating points, and in the short term, those points may strike home soon for people finding their paychecks reduced by tax withholding.
Opponents, for example, objected to using a tax on wages to cut taxes on business; Mr. Weicker argued that the state's high business taxes had to be cut to stimulate the economy and save jobs. Business interests supported the Governor without swaying any of the votes of their usual allies in the Legislature.
Business is generally pleased with the budget, which will cut business taxes, cuts spending this year and includes controls on future spending, said Peter M. Gioia, the director of research for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, which represents 6,600 businesses in the state.
 
Just 3 Votes
 The education process, from the association's perspective, involves the argument that the tax on salaries may save people's jobs. "Many of our members have not been able to give pay raises or have given much smaller pay raises than in the past because they are struggling to survive," he said. "Others have left the state."
If opponents to the income tax argue that it will hurt consumer spending, he said, "Losing your job, or fear of losing your job, does that a lot more."
More immediate concerns make Representative Richard Foley Jr., the state Republican chairman, say he believes there is a good chance of a strong tax protest developing in the next several months. First of all, he said, the margin of victory for such a major shift in taxes was razor thin: 3 votes out of the 187 members of the House and Senate.
"The entire political world now revolves around three votes," he said.
Just as important, he said, were the drawn-out fights over local budgets this spring and summer, as towns and cities faced their own budget crises. In one case, a regional school district had to put budgets to nine referendums before winning approval.
"If you don't want to pay an extra $50 or $100 in your local property tax," Mr. Foley said, "you're not going to be happy paying an additional $1,000 in income tax."
Mr. Weicker may have the luxury of standing firm against public protests, giving his budget time to prove its soundness. In any case, he early on declared his willingness to be a one-term governor.
But Democrats, who provided most of the votes for the income tax, face a more complicated challenge. Even though many Democrats joined Republicans in opposing the tax to the end, their party is likely to be identified with it.
 
Making Sure It Works
 That puts Democrats in the position of arguing that they showed courage and leadership when it was needed, and of doing what is necessary in the next year to make sure Mr. Weicker's budget achieves its goals.
"The party has to make sure this system works," Mr. Droney said. "They have to be prepared to take another look at it next year. They have to be ever vigilant that they don't spend any more, that they don't raise any more taxes. And they have to be prepared to take the credit for doing a difficult job under difficult circumstances."

HEADLINE: 4 Shoe Plants in Missouri to Close

BYLINE: By AP

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The Brown Shoe Company, the nation's leading maker of women's shoes, said today that it would close four plants in Missouri and lay off 1,400 factory workers within three months. The St. Louis-based company cited the recession and the shift to imported shoes.
Brown, founded in 1878 and the maker of the Buster Brown line of shoes for children, said it had watched imported shoes gradually take over the women's shoe industry in the United States. 
 "The impact of free-market politics on small factory towns in Missouri has been devastating, as imported women's shoes now claim well over 90 percent of the market," said B. A. Bridgewater, chairman, president and chief executive of Brown.
Brown said it had closed 23 plants since 1970. It now has 22 -- 13 in Missouri, 5 in Tennessee, 1 in Arkansas and 3 in Canada -- and employs 9,000 workers.

HEADLINE: Rise in Durable Orders Is Steepest in 21 Years

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
New orders to factories for long-lasting goods leaped 10.7 percent in July, the biggest increase in nearly 21 years, the Commerce Department said today.
The orders for durable goods are a leading but erratic indicator of the nation's investment spending and industrial production. Economists cautiously greeted today's unexpectedly strong increase as an indication that the economy may be in less danger of slipping back into a recession only a few months after it began growing again. 
 "A lot of people think we were poised for a double-dip recession, and these figures really negate that," said Marilyn C. Schaya, a money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a New York investment bank.
 
Interest Rates Climb
 The stock market rallied on the encouraging report, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 32.87 points to a new high of 3,040.25. But concern that the evidence of economic strength might lead to higher inflation sent prices of Treasury securities plummeting and interest rates climbing. [Page 47.]
The good news on durable goods overshadowed reports from auto makers that sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 10.2 percent in mid-August. [Page 40.]
Still, Mrs. Schaya and other economists cautioned that durable goods orders were among the most volatile statistics that the Commerce Department issues, and that the July increase followed a 1 percent decrease in June.
The surge of orders in July could be followed by a 5 or 6 percent drop in August because so many orders for needed products have now been placed, but the long-term trend has been one of solid monthly increases, said Thomas F. Carpenter, the chief economist at ASB Capital Management, a money management company in Washington.
The July rise in orders, which had been expected to be as small as 1 or 2 percent, "is going to mean that probably starting on Monday we're all going to come to work with a higher growth rate in mind," he added.
Gordon R. Richards, an economist at the National Association of Manufacturers in Washington, said the July surge was unlikely to be repeated in the coming months. But he added that together with other recent economic data, "what it suggests is businesses are retooling in expectation of stable growth."
 
Some Weakness Indicated
 Despite the strength of the July orders, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates in order to curb the possibility of inflation heating up, Mr. Richards and other economists said. The Fed has tended to avoid reacting to any single monthly indicator, and some other economic statistics, including an early August jump in the number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits, have indicated some weakness in the recovery.
Inflation has been easing, and that gave the Fed the room it needed earlier this month to lower short-term interest rates. The Fed appears to be following a policy now that favors holding rates steady or reducing them to keep the nascent recovery going.
Durable goods, as defined by the Commerce Department, are manufactured items that last more than three years, and include everything from filing cabinets to aircraft carriers. Much of the volatility of the orders stems from the inclusion of transportation and military equipment contracts that tend to be very large but are sporadic and reflect production that may be spread out over many years.
New orders for transportation equipment soared 24.5 percent in July after rising only 4.4 percent in June and shrinking 2.5 percent in May. New military equipment orders climbed 17.1 percent in July after dropping 12.7 percent in June.
 
Categories Partly Overlap
 The Commerce Department's categories for transportation and military equipment orders partly overlap, so that it is difficult to calculate the increase in all other goods, which may be a better indicator of overall investment spending. Mrs. Schaya of Donaldson, Lufkin said the increase was between 5 and 7 percent, however, depending on how much overlap is assumed.
The Commerce Department said that excluding just transportation, the orders still rose a strong 6 percent. Excluding just military orders, orders rose 10.3 percent.
The large increase announced today was consistent with recent industrial production statistics showing a strong revival this year of the American manufacturing sector, said John D. Mueller, the chief economist at Lehrman Bell Mueller Cannon Inc., a financial consulting firm in Arlington, Va. The Federal Reserve announced on Aug. 16 that output from the nation's factories, mines and utilities grew in July for the fourth straight month.
 
Smallest in Eight Years
 The Commerce Department announced the same day that the trade deficit in June was only $4.02 billion, the smallest amount in eight years. Much of the improvement in the trade deficit has come as the deficit in manufactured goods has withered in the last two years.
The July increase in new orders for durable goods was the largest such rise since an 11.2 percent gain in December 1970. New orders totaled $129.9 billion, up $12.6 billion from June.
There were increases last month in all of the durable goods sectors that the Commerce Department tracks, except for lumber and wood products. Orders of nonmilitary capital goods, which consist heavily of factory equipment to make other products, rose 21.5 percent.
New orders for electronic and other electrical equipment climbed 12.6 percent last month after a 9.1 percent drop in June.
These figures show that American businesses are replenishing their inventories, another indication that the nation's executives are feeling confident that the recession may be over, Mr. Carpenter of ASB Capital Management said.
