HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
Radicals' Proud Moment

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Boris N. Yeltsin and his minions were riding high on their victory today, grilling a humbled Mikhail S. Gorbachev, shaping the composition of the next Government, shutting down hostile newspapers and suspending the Russian Communist Party.
But even as they savored the spoils of a decisive victory over a system that had resisted them so long, it was far from clear that their ascendance would translate into the radical transformation of Soviet society that has been their goal. 
 The lesson of anti-Communist revolutions past was that the sweet taste of victory was inevitably followed by the bitter reassertion of hard realities. The fall of the Berlin wall was followed by the bankruptcy of eastern Germany. Czechoslovakia faced dismemberment, Romania remained chaotic.
 
New Dangers
 And this country, whether under the restored Russian tricolor or the hammer and sickle, was still a beggared land with only a marginal experience of democracy, a widely divided populace and an economy in tatters.
There were new dangers, too: Mr. Gorbachev was still capable of applying brakes to radical reform. A newly ascendant Russian leadership stood to touch off a wave of seperatism. The window of opportunity opened by the failed coup could rapidly close when the hangover sets in.
Mr. Yeltsin himself was setting questionable precedents by decreeing the closing of newspapers and suspending the Russian Communist Party, and the anti-Communist fervor underscored the weakness of the fledgling democratic institutions. Mr. Yeltsin's following had been united largely in opposition to the Communists, and it could yet splinter under the pressure of hard decisions.
For now, in the immediate aftermah of the ignominious collapse of the old commissars' coup, there seemed no limit to the possibilities before the victorious collection of reformers, nationalists, intellectuals and democrats ranged behind the burly back of Mr. Yeltsin.
 
Gorbachev Isolated
 The K.G.B. was under siege, the military was docile, the police were under a Yeltsinite, the Communist Party no longer had the wherewithal to resist the long-gathering fury of the nation and President Gorbachev was isolated.
But even as the victors celebrated, the challenges were evident.
There was Mr. Gorbachev. Brought before the Russian Parliament in what was meant as a show of gratitude and solidarity for his deliverance by the Russian leaders, he soon came to appear less a president than a co-conspirator in the dock at a political tribunal.
Though he repeatedly said "we reformers" and spoke of the need to maintain unity "in the ranks of democrats," he made clear he was not prepared to cast his lot unequivocally with the radical reformers.
He talked of continuing with his Government's weak economic program, he maneuvered to keep his own people in Government, he defended the "peasants, workers and intelligentsia" of the Communist Party, and he sought to depict the coup as aimed against him personally and not as an onslaught by the system with which he had been allied and organized by those he had appointed.
Soon heckling spread through the hall, and Mr. Yeltsin, openly asserting his power over an old rival, repeatedly prompted and corrected Mr. Gorbachev, even ordering him in prosecutorial tones to read out notes from a closed meeting of the Council of Ministers at which minister after minister was revealed to have embraced the state of emergency or condoned it.
The sparring suggested that even if the balance of forces had dramatically tilted toward Mr. Yeltsin, a new relationship had yet to take shape between the old rivals and Mr. Gorbachev was not yet ready to assume a ceremonial role.
And for all of Mr. Yeltsin's new authority, Mr. Gorbachev still commanded considerable powers as federal President, capable at least of impeding the passage of that with which he disagreed.
That possibility alarmed advocates of radical reform who believed that the moment had to be seized immediately if it was not to be lost.
 
'Ready Now to Accept Sacrifice'
 "People who stood three nights in the rain to protect Yeltsin are ready now to accept sacrifice," argued Sergei A. Zverev, a member of the economic research center led by the radical economist Grigory A. Yavlinsky, with whom Mr. Yeltsin had held vigil in the threatened Russian Parliament during the coup. "But the window will not be open forever."
The heckling of Mr. Gorbachev and the shouts of "resign, resign" as he drove away from the parliament testified to the mood of disappointed expectations.
It began on Wednesday night, when on his return from the Crimea Mr. Gorbachev did not come directly to the Russian Parliament where the resistance to the coup was centered. And it turned more sour over the full day that passed before he came.
"If he had come that night, we would have carried him on our shoulders," Mr. Zverev said. "Instead he started saying that he is still a Communist. He missed a great opportunity."
 
'He Is Lucky He Survived'
 Mr. Gorbachev's performance was also seen as a failure to appreciate the real significance of the coup.
"What Mikhail Sergeyevich failed to understand is that all his power and the power of the bureaucracy is supported by four whales -- the military industrial complex, the K.G.B., the army and the bureaucracy," said Dr. Vyacheslav Fyodorov, a prominent eye surgeon and a Russian deputy.
"Until he destroys them, not without our help, his power is ephemeral. Any moment, as soon as he stops serving them, they will wipe him out. He is lucky that he survived. But instead of eliminating the chance of a repetition, he is dreaming of some strange reformation."
Yet if Mr. Gorbachev disappointed the Yeltsinites by affirming old socialist loyalty and clinging to old programs, the newly ascendant forces had yet to shape their own clear agenda. Mr. Yeltsin had adopted for Russia a version of the radical "500-day" economic program that Mr. Gorbachev had earlier rejected. But until the new union treaty became binding, he still lacked the levers or powers to put it in effect.
 
Dangers in the Streets
 The other potential dangers rose from the streets. Though a wave of anti-Communist fervor was inevitable in the heat of the moment, it was only Mr. Gorbachev who cautioned that the passions undermined the political tolerance that the reformers had so ardently demanded.
Mr. Yeltsin, instead of urging caution, seemed to fan the flames by closing down hostile Communist newspapers and demonstratively signing a decree to suspend the Russian Communist Party while Mr. Gorbachev was still at the podium.
Beyond that was the repeated claim of victory for the Russian republic. One of the disclosures at the parliament session was that Mr. Gorbachev had agreed that the federal Prime Minister would always be a Russian citizen, and that news, combined with the vast new influence of the Russian Government on the Kremlin, seemed likely to fan secessionist sentiments in the other republics.
And yet, arrayed against all these challenges was the sense that the people had finally overcome what had been the major obstacles to real freedom and real change.
For all the dangers and threats inherent in a time of revolutionary change, a nation that was despairing of its ability to finally shake off its 70-year yoke had finally done it, and that at a moment when it desperately required a morale boost.
"If we could do this," argued an engineer outside the Russian Parliament, "I think we can do the rest."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
Stock prices soared to new heights on the heels of a surprisingly robust durable goods report. The Dow vaulted to a record 3,040.25, up 32.87 for the day and 72.23 for the week. While Wednesday's huge run-up, which put the Dow within striking range of the summit, was Wall Street's sigh of relief at the turn of Soviet events, this rally was clearly built on the strength of domestic data. [39.] 
 The credit market was sent reeling by an extremely strong reading on the economy, and prices of Treasury securities plummeted in moderately active trading. [47.]
The dollar moved sharply higher, helped by the report on orders for durable goods. [48.]
Coffee futures prices spurted higher amid rumors of a halt in Brazilian exports. [48.]
 
 The Economy
The F.D.I.C.'s financial condition is weaker than previously estimated, and the deposit insurance agency will need additional money from the Government within a few months, the G.A.O. said. By the end of the year, the bank insurance fund "will likely be insolvent" but will still have the cash needed to pay depositors of failed banks, the accounting office said. [39.]
New orders for durable goods leaped 10.7 percent in July, the biggest increase in nearly 21 years, the Commerce Department said. The durable-goods number is a leading but erratic indicator of investment spending and industrial production, and economists saw the report as a sign that the economy may be in less danger of slipping back into recession. [39.]
As the economy limps out of a recession, a spurt of layoffs, hiring freezes and corporate mergers is hitting some of the biggest engines of the 80's expansion: service companies, government and high-tech manufacturing. [39.]
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 10.2 percent in mid-August, reflecting somewhat weaker demand in the U.S. auto market than analysts had expected. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales from Aug. 11 to 20 was 6.1 million. [40.]
Federal Reserve policy makers voted last month to maintain a neutral monetary policy that did not favor further interest-rate cuts to stimulate the economy, minutes of their meeting show. [42.]
 
 Companies
The Salomon scandal has ended another executive's career with the firm. Donald M. Feuerstein, the firm's chief legal counsel, resigned under pressure from Warren E. Buffett. [39.]
American Isuzu Motors awarded its estimated $90 million advertising account to Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein in one of the summer's most closely followed reviews. [39.]
P. A. Bergner filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The operator of Carson Pirie Scott, Bergner's and Boston Store cited its high debt and declining sales. [41.]
NCNB's proposed acquisition of C&S/Sovran was a triumphant event for Charlotte, N.C., a city with a historic longing for recognition. [10.]
Citicorp said it was negotiating the sale to Bertelsmann of a vacant 42-story office tower in Manhattan, probably at a loss. [28.]
 
 International
Brazil's Government, desperate to stave off fiscal collapse and runaway inflation, wants radical changes to the Constitution to rein in spending, raise taxes and encourage investment. [42.]
The U.S. will give China a second chance to reduce its import barriers instead of starting an inquiry that could lead to mandatory trade sanctions, the Bush Administration announced. [40.]
 
 Today's Columns
Owners of closely held businesses and their tax advisers are cheering because the I.R.S. has just done an unusual about-face, or nearly so, on regulations for S corporations. Your Taxes. [40.]
A genetic test designed to help breed cows that produce more milk, as well as milk with better cheese-making characteristics, has been patented. Patents. [40.]

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
Ever-Faster Flow of Events In Moscow Are Joy to Bush

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 23

 BODY:
President Bush said today that the Soviet Union was moving more rapidly toward "the objectives that we want," and he praised the Government shake-up in Moscow, which reversed decisions that had drawn criticism on Thursday from the Bush Administration.
"The people appear to be moving toward the objectives of United States foreign policy and, in the process, toward democracy, freedom, self-determination -- all of these things," Mr. Bush said, adding, "Clearly, we are in extraordinary times." 
 In another astonishing day in which American officials watched events unfold at a pace that exceeded their most optimistic expectations, the Administration was starting to come to grips with the certainty that the old formulas of power in the Soviet Union, and thus that country's relationship with the outside world, would change.
That will likely mean changes in American policies, including decisions about increasing economic aid, revising Washington's relationships with the republics and a reassessment of its cautious stand on the Baltic independence movement. The President will be pressed on economic aid in two meetings here next week with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada and Prime Minister John Major of Britain.
Mr. Bush refused to comment today on the individual appointments made by the Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian Federation.
As Mr. Bush finished the first of two rounds of golf today, he said, "It's not for me or anybody else in my Administration to make a lot of comments each time there's a personnel change."
On Thursday, aides said Mr. Bush had been annoyed by news reports about his Administration's concerns on Mr. Gorbachev's decisions to appoint or retain several officials regarded by Washington as Soviet hard-liners or members of the conspiracy to overthrow the Soviet President.
Today, Mr. Bush, who is always careful not to be seen as criticizing the actions of other world leaders with whom he does business, and especially of Mr. Gorbachev, ordered his staff not to comment on the upheaval in the Soviet Government.
On Thursday a senior Administration official had sharply criticized Mr. Gorbachev for appointing General Mikhail A. Moiseyev as Defense Minister. American officials said the General may have played a part in the attempted coup. They said they were relieved today when he was replaced by Col. Gen. Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, but they were careful not to comment about the shift in public.
"We just can't indulge in that," Mr. Bush said, expressing annoyance at reporters who asked him to comment on the events in Moscow.
But Mr. Bush said movement toward democracy seemed to be accelerating in the Soviet Union. "I think when we see that enormous outpouring of democracy, for democracy, and the enormous support for freedom, it's bound to be a manifestation of the real will of the people there, and that is all very positive," he said.
Mr. Bush also shrugged off Mr. Gorbachev's defense of the Communist Party. He said: "As you know, there are many reformers that have stayed in the party. There are many that have left. And I think what's more important than labels is what kind of performance we see from now on."
But Administration officials said the President and his advisers had been disappointed to watch Mr. Gorbachev proclaim his continued allegiance to the party on Thursday. Today, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said in an interview broadcast on the Cable News Network that Mr. Gorbachev's loyalty to the party "doesn't indicate at this stage that he's grasped the reality of the need to reform and reform quickly."
While officials here said they could not predict the course of events in the Soviet Union, including the political longevity of Mr. Gorbachev himself, they said they were unconcerned about any changes in Soviet foreign policy.
Officials said they did not expect the dismissal of Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh to sour the new sense of cooperation in Soviet-American foreign relations. If anything, they said, they expected Soviet foreign policy to be even more to Washington's liking as democratic change accelerates in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Bessmertnykh had been a major player in the Soviet-American peacemaking effort in the Middle East, particularly the complicated diplomacy and negotiations that led to the plan in July to hold an Arab-Israeli peace conference. There had been speculation that his departure could complicate those efforts.
 
Call From Bessmertnykh
 But Mr. Bush said, "No, I don't think it means all that." He said that Mr. Bessmertnykh had telephoned Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d this morning to tell him he was resigning at Mr. Gorbachev's request, and that Mr. Bessmertnykh "told Baker it had no implications" for the Middle East peace process.
Administration officials took pains to say there would be no immediate major changes in American policy toward the Soviet Union while that country was sorting out its political future. Mr. Bush's initial public silence today was intended, in part, to avoid saying anything that could complicate Mr. Gorbachev's efforts to find a new accommodation with Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of the other republics.
But the United States is going to be hard-pressed to stick to its refusal to increase financial aid to Moscow if the current upheaval produces real progress toward free-market reforms. Mr. Mulroney, who arrives on Sunday for an overnight stay, and Mr. Major, who will be here on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, have called for greater economic assistance to the Soviet Union.
The significant increase in the powers of Mr. Yeltsin is also forcing the United States to confront more squarely the issue of how it will deal with the Soviet republics. Mr. Bush has already acknowledged that his relationship with Mr. Yeltsin has changed significantly.
The lightning pace of events today did produce at least one subtle shift in American policy.
Mr. Bush and his aides had moved quickly on Thursday to put some pressure on the newly reinstated Mr. Gorbachev to move forward with political and economic changes. But by today, those efforts had largely ceased.
 
'They're Doing It for Us'
 "We don't have to do anything because they're doing it for us," one official said. "Yeltsin's firing people and shutting down party offices and Gorbachev is going along with it."
Officials said it was becoming increasingly clear that Mr. Gorbachev must go along with the tide of change in his country and then find some way to gain control of it, or risk being swept away by it.
"Brushed aside may be too strong right now, but either Gorbachev is going to take the lead in the reform process or his position is going to become very much weaker very fast," one official said. He added, "That may happen anyway."
Another official said Mr. Gorbachev's post as President of the Soviet Union was in danger of "becoming irrelevant."
The official said: "I think what you have in response to the attempted coup is a true revolution, political revolution, and very likely the death throes of the party. And the bottom line is that Yeltsin clearly has the upper hand in this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President George Bush praised the Government shake-up in Moscow Thursday that reversed decisions that his Administration had criticized. He answered questions after playing golf yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
The 3 New Top Security Appointees

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

 BODY:

Vadim V. Bakatin
Chairman of K.G.B. 
 Vadim V. Bakatin, who takes over the K.G.B. without any known background in the intelligence and internal security agency, is among the most liberal figures in the Soviet leadership. His appointment appears to presage a major overhaul of the agency and the dismantling of much of its secret police operations, American officials say.
Administration officials expressed enthusiasm for Mr. Bakatin's appointment, characterizing him as a man of great intelligence and candor who has repeatedly shown loyalty to the cause of reform even when his progressiveness stood in the way of his career advancement.
Mr. Bakatin had been one of the main proponents of glasnost and perestroika until he was dismissed as Interior Minister late last year during a resurgence of the right in the Communist Party. He is known as an proponent of due process of law and of radical economic reforms, including the attraction of foreign investment and the steady elimination of subsidies and price controls.
"He is going to clean up the K.G.B., no doubt about it," said an Administration official who monitors Soviet intelligence agencies. "He'll get rid of the cowboys and insist the K.G.B. follows the law."
 
Promoted U.S. Exchanges
 As Interior Minister, Mr. Bakatin promoted personnel exchanges between his ministry and the United States Justice Department, as well as between Soviet and American local police forces.
Condoleezza Rice, a political scientist at Stanford University, said, "He sought out Western ideas on how police forces should behave in a democracy." Ms. Rice, who met Mr. Bakatin briefly last year when she served as a staff member in the National Security Council, said, "He is open and outgoing and easy to talk to."
A civil engineer by training, Mr. Bakatin comes to the K.G.B. as an outsider to the security force, although he has spent most of his career in law enforcement. As Interior Minister he worked closely with the K.G.B. fighting crime and corruption, but Western analysts said he had never been a member of the K.G.B. and had no known record of political repression.
Born in 1937 into a middle-class family in the Siberian coal mining town of Kiselevsk, Mr. Bakatin graduated from a technical institute and worked on several construction projects before he went to work for the Communist Party in the early 1960's.
 
Taste for Things Western
 He is known for his taste for things Western -- ranging from his love for tennis to a fondness for be-bop jazz, the Beatles and Elvis Presley.
Mr. Bakatin worked his way through the ranks of several regional party organs before he was promoted by Mr. Andropov to be an inspector of the Communist Party Central Committee. He returned to regional party work in 1985, serving as first secretary of the party in the cities of Kirov and Kemerovo.
His active support for Mr. Gorbachev led to his appointment as Interior Minister in 1990. Though he was removed from his post, he continued to serve as a member of the Soviet Security Council.
In an interview with the Soviet press in May, Mr. Bakatin identified himself as a "radical centrist."
Mr. Bakatin ran against Boris N. Yeltsin for President of the Russian federated republic, campaigning for even more radical change, but came in third place in the election.
 
Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov
Defense Minister
 Col. Gen. Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, the new Defense Minister, had been commander of the Soviet Air Force, and his refusal to obey orders from the coup committee helped bring about its downfall.
One of his first acts as Defense Minister was to resign from the Communist Party.
Administration officials said they were pleased with General Shaposhnikov's appointment because he seemed to be the kind of officer who would support a sweeping reform of the Soviet economy and reducing the size of the Soviet military. In speeches over the last year, they said, he has argued in favor of giving priority to economic development as a matter of national security.
American officials compliment him for accepting the demise of the Warsaw Pact as a development that could not be avoided, and they say they believe that he will work to remove Communist Party influence from the armed forces. "He can be expected to move toward a smaller, more professional military," an Administration official said.
 
Approved by Yeltsin
 A State Department official said his appointment was approved by Mr. Yeltsin because "Yeltsin believes he will support what needs to be done to the military, a reduction in the size and a conversion to an all volunteer force."
Stephen Foye, an analyst of the Soviet military for Radio Free Europe, said General Shaposhnikov "is very forward-looking."
"He has spoken very favorably of increased competition in the defense industries," he said.
An American military intelligence official described the general as "hard-charging, a fighter pilot's fighter pilot." He reportedly works about 75 hours a week, but is also known for hard living, including chain smoking and hefty eating.
 
Unusually Young for Post
 At age 49, he is unusually young to have risen to the Soviet high command, a point American analysts make to explain his fresh approach to many issues. He was born in 1942 in a small Russian village to a working-class family. At age 21, he joined the Communist Party and graduated from the Kharkov Aviation Institute, after which he served as an air force pilot.
After serving in East Germany, he was appointed first deputy commander of the air force in 1988, and then was elected to a seat on the Communist Party Central Committee. He was promoted to air force commander in July 1990. His principal priorities for the service were better training and more efficient and economical equipment.
 
'Substantial Cuts' Seen
 "His appointment probably means a more rapid transition that could bring substantial cuts in the armed forces and less holding back by the old guard," he said.
General Shaposhnikov's ascendency does not mean that conservatives will no longer have a place in the military.
His new principal deputy, the General Staff chief, is Gen. Vladimir Lobov, a hard-liner who has long called on the Soviet Union to seek military superiority over the West. Last posted as Chief of Staff of the Warsaw Pact military alliance, he is one of the Soviet Union's leading strategic theorists. General Lobov, who is 56, has tended to bend his political philosophy with the leadership and has not overtly opposed President Gorbachev.
The new No. 3 man in the armed forces, the Deputy Defense Minister, is Lieut. Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, 43, a liberal. As commander of Soviet paratroops, he refused to deploy his forces in support of the coup committee this week. He served for five years in Afghanistan during the war, an experience that apparently made him skeptical about deploying military force abroad.
 
Viktor P. Barannikov
Interior Minister
 Viktor P. Barannikov, the new Interior Minister, is a close ally of Mr. Yeltsin, who has long worked to make the Russian police independent of the central Soviet authorities.
In his former post as chief of the Russian federation's Interior Ministry, Mr. Barannikov concentrated on criminal investigations and eradicated Communist Party cells from his agency. Administration officials said they expected him to continue his reform policies. "His priority will be to make an effective crime-fighting unit out of the Interior Ministry as opposed to an instrument of internal repression," an Administration official said.
Mr. Yeltsin promoted Mr. Barannikov, who at the time was first deputy minister of internal affairs in the Russian republic, to become the chief police officer in his Government late last year.
 
Least Known to Washington
 Of the new appointees, he is the least well known to the Bush Administration. A State Department official said it was not even known whether he is married or has children. He is believed to have been born in 1941, and he has been involved in regional and national police work since 1961.
American officials said they were pleased about his appointment because he struggled in his former post against hard-liners in the Soviet Interior Ministry who wanted to subordinate his agency. He insisted that the militia of the Russian federation be commanded by Mr. Yeltsin and not by Moscow.

HEADLINE: Devices That Try to Outwit Shoplifters

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Now you see them, now you don't. To protect their merchandise from shoplifters, retailers are using increasingly sophisticated security devices. Some are covert and designed to catch thieves; others are overt and designed to deter theft.
"One of the things that promotes shoplifting is the belief that it is not a consumer's problem," said Richard Feinberg, director of the Retail Institute at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind. "But part of the price you pay for a suit is the cost to the store in dealing with shoplifting." 
 According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, there were 1.2 million shoplifting incidents reported last year, up from 1.1 million in 1989. Shoplifting now accounts for 16 percent of all reported larcenies.
Shrinkage, the term used by retailers to refer primarily to both shoplifting and thefts by employees, is equal to about 2 percent of sales in the average department store, according to the National Retail Federation, a trade association in New York. A third of all shrinkage is due to shoplifting. Next week, the federation and three other organizations will release the results of a survey on store security at the International Security Conference in New York.
 
Highest Rate: Accessories
 As might be expected, some store departments have a higher shrinkage rate than others. A loss-prevention survey by Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm, shows that the highest rate, 7.6 percent, occurs in women's fashion accessories and costume jewelry, usually small items easily concealed and carried out of a store.
In contrast, the shrinkage rate for women's apparel is 2.4 percent; for men's apparel and shoes it is 1.8 percent. In hard goods, the shrinkage rate for records, compact disks and videotapes is 4.1 percent; for radios, televisions and stereos, it is 3.4 percent.
Among the reasons cited for shoplifting these days are the growth in the number of drug abusers, who steal to support their habit; the reduction in uniformed and plainclothes security guards and the fact that expensive items are more frequently displayed openly, said Peter Berlin, who heads a retail consulting company bearing his name in Jericho, L.I.
Paul Marcus, the chairman of Securus, an installer of security systems in Denver, mentioned another reason: the recession. "When times get tougher, people steal more," he said.
Although there are hundreds of devices that help stop shoplifting, like observation mirrors, three major categories of security devices are used: electronic article surveillance, closed-circuit television and cables attached to locks and chains. While equipment in each category has long been in use, improvements and new inventions are continually added to retailers' security systems.
 
Beeping Tags
 Electronic article surveillance refers to the security tags clamped to merchandise, typically clothing. If the tag is not removed by the cashier, it will make an alarm go off when the merchandise is carried past sensors at the store's exits. Versions of the tags emit a nonwashable ink that spreads over the garment if the tag is improperly removed either in or out of the store.
One of the newest devices is a tag made by the Sensormatic Electronics Corporation; it is called Tell Tag and it beeps when tampered with. The beeping activates an alarm, which may frighten off the shoplifter and also warns store employees that a shoplifter is at work.
Then there are weight-sensing devices that sound an alarm when merchandise is removed from or added to a shelf or rack.
For example, the Protron, made by Protex International, activates a recording that shoppers can hear -- "Someone will be with you in a moment," or something similar -- whenever an item weighing three ounces or more is added or removed from a display. The Protron also sends an electronic message to the nearest sales clerk that someone is at a particular display and should be watched.
Closed-circuit cameras -- seen or unseen, black and white or color, with or without videotape -- are also used by retailers. Most often, they hang from the ceiling in plastic spheres, but they also fit into track lighting and behind wall panels. Many cameras can tilt, zoom and pan, following a shopper -- or shoplifter -- when directed to do so.
Security experts disagree on the value of closed-circuit television in foiling shoplifting. Roger A. Speyer, president of the PSA Security Network in Denver, said security "is pretty much a function of observation and the most effective way to do that is by closed-circuit television."
But Kurt Barnard, who publishes Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, a newsletter in New York, thinks these systems are useful only when "somebody watches what the cameras sees, and someone isn't always watching the monitor."
Probably the most unusual housing for a closed-circuit camera is a mannequin called Anne Droid. Not only does it contain a camera behind its glass eyes, but a microphone can be mounted behind its nose to eavesdrop on conversations nearby.
Cable systems, some mechanical and some electronic, lock up the merchandise to prevent its removal. Some locking devices are incorporated in fixtures, displays or wall systems, while others use flexible cables to keep the items secure.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tell Tag, below left, is attached to merchandise and beeps when it is tampered with, alerting store employees that a theft might be occurring. Anne Droid, at right, is a store mannequin that contains a camera and microphone for detecting shoplifting. (Sensormatic Electronics; Surveillance Systems)

HEADLINE: Wichita Tires of Spotlight on Abortion Protesters

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 23

 BODY:
This heartland city of 300,000 people has grown weary, its normally sturdy shoulders and spirit beginning to sag under the weight of an unwelcome and unaccustomed national spotlight accompanying the disruptive anti-abortion demonstrations that began six weeks ago.
Such turmoil seems out of place in Wichita, a city of churches, minor league baseball and friendly people. While it has many of the problems of large cities, it is a good place to raise children, everyone from the hotel bellmen to the Mayor say. 
 And until July, it was best known for being the hub of light-aircraft manufacturing. In Detroit they make cars. In Wichita they make planes, the big three being the Boeing Company, the Cessna Aircraft Company and the Beech Aircraft Corporation.
It is also the birthplace of Pizza Hut and the White Castle hamburger, although the tiny White Castle sandwiches are not available here. The company left town years ago, said F. Tim Witsman, the president of Wichita's Chamber of Commerce.
 
Appeals Court Backs Judge
 But the protests, led by the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, have put Wichita on the map.
"Nobody knew we were here before," the chamber's spokesman, Roger N. Wilson, said.
And today the protesters continued to defy a Federal judge by blocking the gates of one of the city's three abortion clinics. About 84 were arrested, pushing the total number of arrests to about 2,580.
The judge's order was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver. But the appeals court said it would hear arguments by the anti-abortion group against the judge's order that protesters post a $100,000 bond against property damage and his jailing of three of the leaders for failing to do so.
Residents here say they can not recall a time of such discontent on their streets, a time of divided families and congregations, of splintered friendships and shaken love.
Some here worry that the city's reputation has been badly injured at a time when it is struggling to polish its image and revive its dying downtown.
But abortion opponents say it gives prominence to their cause. Operation Rescue was drawn to Wichita in part by the fact that it is one of the only cities in which women can obtain abortions in the final three months of pregnancy.
Most seem to agree that the demonstrations have caused deep divisions, and while they look forward to a time of healing they do not know when that time will come.
The next 48 hours, some fear, could be the most volatile of this painful summer on the Kansas prairie.
Thousands of people on both sides of the fight over abortion are scheduled to converge on the city this weekend for rallies, separated only by a day and a few blocks.
 
Fear of 'a Lot of Trouble'
 It is a prospect that makes Steven A. Smith, the managing editor of The Wichita Eagle, nervous.
"Because of the proximity of the rallies in both time and location, I'm just worried that some wacko from either side is going to do something that will start a lot of trouble," he said.
The protests began on July 15. Since then, hundreds of abortion opponents have been in and out of the city.
But this weekend will be the first time a significant number of out-of-town supporters of the clinics are expected to be here.
So far there have been no serious confrontations between the two sides, a glimmer of hope the city's leaders quickly point to when discussing the impact of the summer of protests and the coming rallies.
"There's been no bloodshed," said Mr. Wilson of the chamber of commerce. "It's been handled. People around the country will say, 'O.K. Wichita had its trial by fire and it came through relatively unscathed.' This is just six weeks of nuisance."
 
'Very Severe' Effect
 But it has been much more than a nuisance to Celeste Holeman, 31 years old, and her friends at Bank IV in downtown Wichita.
"We talk about it just about every break time," Ms. Holeman said. "We've got a pro-lifer in our group. It gets pretty heated."
Another worker at the bank, Kathy Murphy, 23, said, "I think the whole thing has given us a lot of bad publicity we don't need."
Ms. Murphy said she had just returned from a recent trip through Missouri and several people there had asked her "are you from where all those abortionists are?"
"I'm getting tired of talking about it," she said.
Kelly Beltz, the 34-year-old manager of the Taco Tico fast-food resturant in downtown Wichita said the protests' impact had been "very severe."
"It's caused a lot of division in the community," he said. "It's an issue that has split families. It's split people who used to work well together. People who used to come in here in groups, now those groups are fragmented."
"As a businessman, I have to respect both sides," he said. "But I don't think this is doing us a damn bit of good. No positive footage has ever come out of a war zone. This has caused a lot ofwounds. I want to know who's going to be here to patch them up."
 
Plans to Leave Town
 Leaders of Operation Rescue say that after the weekend rally the organization will leave town, passing the baton to local residents.
Although the protests have overshadowed the city for weeks, there are other issues and concerns here like school reform and development.
The downtown area is struggling and appears nearly deserted after 5 P.M. The major department stores are long gone, their buildings largely abandoned.
There are gangs and drugs and drive-by shootings and a growing concern about public safety.
But the economy is healthy. The unemployment rate is 4.6 percent in the three-county Wichita area.
Mr. Witsman said that while much of the country was losing manufacturing jobs Wichita was not.
The hourly industrial wage in the city as of May averaged $12.49 compared to $11.15 nationwide. The high wages are largely due to the unionized aircraft plants. Overall, the city's work force is about 10 percent unionized.
Born as a trading post on the Chisholm Trail, Wichita grew into a rowdy cow town in the 1870's.
But the region filled with farms, and churches began to crowd out the saloons and brothels that had gained nationwide notoriety for the city. Wichita went through a series of boomtown phases -- milling, meatpacking, real estate, oil -- before settling into a pattern of quiet respectability.
Now that quiet has been shattered, and hundreds of people from across the country have arrived over the last few days for this weekend's rallies.
Supporters of a woman's right to choose to have an abortion will hold their rally first on Saturady in a park along the Big Arkansas River, which runs slowly through downtown. It is just blocks from a hotel where most of the out of town abortion opponents are staying.
The abortion opponents will hold their rally on Sunday.
The management of the local minor league team, the Wichita Wranglers, tried to do something to ease the tension a few weeks ago.
"There was a lot of tension in the city then, so we held a 'protesters night' out at the ball park," Brad Eldridge, the team's business manager, said the other night. "We invited all the protesters on both sides to lay down their signs and come on out and watch a game and relax."
About 100 people showed up for the free tickets.
Asked how the club knew they were real protesters, Mr. Eldridge said, "We took their word. This is Wichita."

A young anti-abortion protester was photographed after being arrested yesterday. At least 84 adults and children were taken into custody. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Banking Lifts Charlotte, City on the Rise, to the Top

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 23

 BODY:
This is still the home of the Billy Graham Parkway, the Charlotte Motor Speedway and the Jim Bakker fraud trials. Outsiders still confuse this city with Charleston to the south and Charlottesville to the north.
But when Charlotte woke up one day last month to find itself being touted as America's third largest banking center, displacing Los Angeles, it marked a historic juncture, not just for Charlotte but also for the South. From its glistening skyline and button-down corporate culture to its blend of big-time religion and civic boosterism, Charlotte's rise is very much the story of the rebirth of the South. 
 For Charlotte, the locally based NCNB Corporation's proposed acquisition of the C&S/Sovran Corporation of Atlanta to form a $118 billion bank that would operate in nine states would leave the city's banks with assets surpassed only by New York and San Francisco. It was a triumphant event for a city with a historic longing for recognition of almost any kind.
"When I came here in 1959 a cousin in Richmond told me Charlotte's a wonderful place," said Thomas Storrs, NCNB's chairman emeritus and the predecessor of the current chairman, Hugh McColl Jr. "She said the best way to summarize Charlotte is to say that if the Russians bomb us and the first wave of bombs that comes over doesn't include one for Charlotte, they will be very much disappointed."
 
A Psychological Landmark
 For the South, long forced to go elsewhere for capital, the merger that will form what is to be called Nationsbank is both an economic and a psychological landmark. With last week's proposed merger of the San Francisco-based BankAmerica Corporation and the Security Pacific Corporation, Nationsbank would be the nation's fourth largest bank, after Citicorp, BankAmerica and Chemical, which announced its merger with Manufacturers Hanover last month.
"Charlotte fundamentally has not had a new idea in 120 years, and that's not necessarily a criticism," said Dan Morrill, a professor of history at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "It's been wanting the Yankees to recognize that we're not second-class citizens, that we are people of prestige and power and influence, and we have truly risen again. They've been saying that ever since the 1870's, and now it is clearly beginning more and more to be the truth."
Charlotte, the seat of Mecklenburg County, was incorporated in 1768 and named for Queen Charlotte, the wife of King George III of England. Its economy grew first with gold, discovered in 1799, then cotton, and then companies serving the textile industry.
Charlotte's modern history bears an uncanny resemblance to that of Atlanta, long considered the dominant city of the South. Both grew as lushly wooded railroad crossroads. Both had local editors, Henry Grady in Atlanta and D. A. Tompkins in Charlotte, who preached a gospel of New South economic development.
Both cities grew as commercial and financial centers not dependent on a single industry. Both prided themselves on the degree to which business and government worked together. And both, seeing integration as inevitable and civic strife as bad for business, integrated peacefully under the leadership of the city's business elites.
"Charlotte achieves its meaning primarily from what it aspires to be, not what it's been, and I think the same is true of Atlanta," Professor Morrill said. "If somebody moved from Atlanta to Charlotte, they could take up life without even missing a beat."
The difference between them was that Atlanta's railroad connections were better, and its drum beating and entrepreneurial zeal established it as the South's commercial center; until recently Charlotte played the same role only for the textile belt of the Carolinas.
The population of Charlotte, 417,621 after a recent annexation, now exceeds Atlanta's, which the 1990 census put at 394,017. But the Atlanta metropolitan area of 2.8 million people, the nation's 12th largest, is more than twice the size of Charlotte's 1.2 million.
 
A Powerhouse in Banking
 There is one area, however, where Charlotte has long had an edge on Atlanta. Because of North Carolina's liberal banking laws, which allowed banks to form networks of branches throughout the state, its banks became powerhouses first across North Carolina and then branched out into lucrative markets like Florida and Texas.
It is difficult to be sure whether the hardheaded dynamism of the banks created the city or whether the pro-business tradition created the banks. But what has emerged is a prosperous city that mirrors the culture of the emerging cities of the South.
The current recession has cooled the explosive growth that left Charlotte with an unemployment rate of 2.9 percent in 1989 and 3 percent in 1990. Unemployment now stands at 5.5 percent. While the city's economy generally remains healthy, the slowdown has deflated some of the sense of invulnerability that Charlotte took on in the last 15 years, when companies like I.B.M. flocked here.
Like Atlanta or Dallas, Charlotte is not shaped by a river or port or any other defining force of geography. Nor does it carry the grand history of Charleston, New Orleans or the other early urban powers of the South. Instead, it has become almost the generic New South city, with its endless expanse of neat subdivisions, poor black neighborhoods largely out of sight, and a downtown of designer skyscrapers, bustling by day, deserted at night. Instead of geography or history, it is dominated by the two enduring forces of the South -- commerce and religion.
 
A Presbyterian Heritage
 "Religion really plays a remarkable role in Charlotte, more so in Charlotte than any city in which I've lived," said the Rev. Bill Wood, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, the oldest of about 440 churches in the city, more than 400 of them Protestant.
"That Presbyterian -- really sort of Calvinistic -- heritage has been part of the city," Mr. Wood continued. "I think all of us will say there's an element of greed and materialism that runs strong in our contemporary culture, and we're not isolated from that. But I think that's tempered by a sense to use wealth and power in constructive ways, as well as just sort of self-aggrandizement. And I think that happens for the most part in Charlotte."
One result is a high degree of unanimity, whether in seeking sports franchises like the Charlotte Hornets of the National Basketball Association, backing the public schools, luring industry or building inner-city housing. Another is a fixation on the city's image, from deciding to give the city's downtown the more perky appellation of "uptown," or being sure visitors know that the Bakker trials were held here but that the disgraced evangelist conducted his business just over the border in South Carolina.
Ever alert to marketing possibilities, Charlotte has come up with a figure indicating that while its population ranks 33d among the nation's cities, the 5.7 million people living within a 100-mile radius of the city make it the nation's fifth largest urban area.
At its best, as in the effort to desegregate schools that has made them among the most integrated in the country, Charlotte's aspirations have produced a city that seems to work in places where others fail.
"The people who come here want to make it work," said Harvey Gantt, the black architect who failed to unseat Senator Jesse Helms last year but who was twice elected mayor of a city that is more than 70 percent white.
"You have an unusual culture where there's a strong relationship between business and government," the former Mayor said. "The ethic of this town is hard work and the idea that anyone can go anywhere if they work hard enough."
 
'It's a City of Babbitts'
 To others, the flip side of the city's aggressiveness is a place that struts too much and crows too loudly, particularly when it is bragging about being "international" and "world class," the mantras of every up-and-coming American city.
"Charlotte is 90 percent foam and 10 percent beer," said Robert Raiford, a local radio commentator who bills himself as Charlotte's curmudgeon at large. "It's a city of Babbitts."
Mr. Raiford said that despite its economic successes, Charlotte still took its cultural cues from the North.
"It's made up of a bunch of local yokels who've seen 'Breakfast at Tiffany's' too many times, and they want to make Charlotte a city like that, a sterile sort of Manhattan," he said. "Let's face it, the performing arts here is stock car racing."
But skeptics like Mr. Raiford are hard to find in Charlotte, even in black neighborhoods. Few cities in the South have had as amicable a racial history or have made greater efforts to make a multiracial city work, whether in the schools or in city-backed efforts to build low-income housing.
"Race relations in this community really are good," said Vanessa Greene, executive director of the Afro-American Cultural Center. "Charlotte is a community that's not afraid to confront its problems."
The most appealing thing about Charlotte may be an optimism and a naivete borne of urban success and rural roots.
 
High Cost of Prosperity
 "There is a kind of special sense you have in Charlotte that you're in an unusual moment of history," said Mr. Wood, the Presbyterian pastor. "Things are happening now and you know that it will never be quite this way again. It's got to level off. But there is this sense that there's almost a Camelot quality to the city today."
Still, Charlotte's prosperity has not come without costs, and there are widespread fears that the city is in danger of losing some of the things that have made it successful.
The crime rate is soaring, with murders at a record pace and three times as many felony charges as there were 10 years ago. Homeless people are a haunting presence in the city's downtown. Private school enrollment is growing amid widespread fear that the public school system, despite its success with integration, has become mired in mediocrity. Traffic problems are bad and getting worse.
There are occasional doubts, particularly during a business slump, whether Charlotte can handle those problems better than most other cities. But there is also a refreshing sense, reflective of the camp-revival sensibilities of much of the South, that solutions are not out of reach.
"We haven't built enough housing, we haven't done all we can with job training and the school system," said Mr. Gantt, the former Mayor. "But we still keep moving in that direction. One of the things I like about this place, notwithstanding all the boosterism, is that there's a continual debate about our priorities. At least this is a place that's still willing to keep talking about its problems."

HEADLINE: Dr. Chassin: Promising, Untested

 BODY:
Just when public and private funding began to run dry in the 1980's, the twin epidemics of AIDS and drug abuse put costly new pressures on New York's health care system. That made a firm grasp of economics and regulation essential to the job of state health commissioner.
On that ground, Dr. Mark Chassin, Governor Cuomo's choice to take over the job now, looks well qualified. His capacity to fill the job's political dimension remains to be tested. 
 The resignation of Dr. David Axelrod, who suffered a stroke in February, left a large gap. During his 12 years as Health Commissioner, he demonstrated uncommon integrity and common sense. He resisted efforts to invade the privacy of AIDS patients, and campaigned for, among other things, bans on smoking and set new rules giving hospital interns reasonable working hours and better supervision.
Beyond those issues, he cared passionately about New York's most serious and chronic health problem: the lack of adequate primary care.
Most people rely on a family doctor for routine check-ups, prenatal and pediatric services and treatment of illness in its early stages. But as family doctors abandoned poor neighborhoods, more and more patients were forced to rely on expensive hospital emergency rooms or outpatient clinics for such care; increasing numbers simply go without it, seeking help only when illness becomes too advanced to ignore. By then, of course, it is usually far more complicated and far more costly to treat.
While New York's health commissioner has no authority to build clinics on his own, he wields enormous power: he regulates rates at which the big public and private health insurance plans reimburse hospitals, doctors and clinics. The commissioner can advance policy goals by the way he manipulates those rates -- like increasing the reimbursement amounts a hospital might claim to finance a new satellite primary care clinic, reducing those for superfluous new equipment.
There will be hearings on Dr. Chassin's nomination, but the evidence so far is that he has the intellectual equipment to handle the challenges. His experience as a Federal Medicare administrator in the late 70's and then as a RAND researcher gives him sophisticated knowledge of economic and policy issues. Such knowledge, capable of saving the state millions in health costs, easily justifies Governor Cuomo's decision to sweeten the salary of $98,399 authorized for the commissioner with an additional $61,601 for heading a research institute.
Still, the job requires more than intellect. Health care politics in New York involves powerful hospitals, the doctors' medical society, employee unions, an aggressive lobby for AIDS patients and other constituencies.
Even when fiscal pressures caused politics to heat up, Dr. Axelrod stood up for fairness and the public interest, often in the face of furious opposition. That record leaves a powerful challenge for any successor. Dr. Chassin's substantive background makes him a welcome choice. But how well he meets the challenge depends heavily on principled political strength -- the Governor's and, as he grows in office, his own.

HEADLINE: Source of Jobs in 80's Fizzles in 90's

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
As the economy limps out of a recession, a spurt of layoffs, hiring freezes and corporate mergers is hitting some of the biggest engines of the 80's expansion: service companies, government and high-tech manufacturing.
The job dearth is also a portent that the 90's may produce new jobs at the slowest rate since the 1950's, say economists at Data Resources/McGraw-Hill. 
 In some ways, the hesitation to hire at the beginning of a recovery is not unusual. Companies also chopped thousands of jobs early in the last recovery and postponed hiring for several months after the end of the 1981-82 recession. Indeed, once growth resumed in the 80's, employers hired 20 million new hands. Even now, most indicators of future hiring are flashing green, if weakly.
 
Cost Cutting Called Essential
 But what's different now is that some of the most expansive -- and in some cases competitive -- parts of the economy are doing the pruning. Governments generally cannot raise taxes fast enough to keep up the hiring pace of the 80's. Formerly youthful growth industries like computers have matured. And, like autos, steel and textiles a decade ago, many service industries are now struggling with flat productivity, bloated costs and stiff competition. "Cost cutting has become essential for survival," said Stephen Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley.
"We've got to do this forever, "said Gerald A. Blumberg, senior vice president of human resources at Du Pont, referring to a drive to cut costs by $1 billion, which will shrink the company's head count by thousands.
In the military industry, payroll cuts are likely to stretch for years. "Our world market share is shrinking at the same time defense budgets are shrinking," said Ken Cannestra, president of the Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Group in Marietta, Ga. "It's changed the way we think about hiring. You're going to see a steady decrease for a few more years."
A computer industry consultant, Ulric Weil, said the situation in that industry echoed what was happening in defense: "Digesting excess manufacturing capacity means closing some facilities. It also means shifting from the left to the right foot, recognizing that computers have become a commodity. The rosy, golden early 80's are gone for good."
Over all, the restructuring of certain industries, along with modest growth in the number of working Americans, points to sluggish job growth. Forecasters at Data Resources/McGraw Hill predict that payrolls will grow at an average rate of 1.1 percent a year in the 90's, compared with 1.7 percent in the 80's. While service companies are likely to generate almost all of the additional jobs, they will do so at less than half the rate of the 80's.
"One unusual aspect of this recession is that service-producing industries were hit as hard as they were," said Jack Bregger, assistant commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Total payroll jobs declined just half as much in the latest recession as in the 1981-82 recession, and manufacturing employment shrank by just one-third as much, 4 percent compared with 11 percent. Despite the addition of 287,000 health care jobs, service industries lost hundreds of thousands of jobs, more than in any other recession.
 
Government Jobs Declining
 Now in the early stages of a recovery, job growth in services is lagging behind earlier rebounds. Goverment payrolls, which held steady until spring, are now shrinking.
If the old engines are sputtering, who will churn out the modest stream of jobs that economists expect? Nobody really knows. As Mr. Steinberg at Merrill Lynch put it, "If the economy had depended on Fortune 500 companies to create new jobs, none would have been created." Roseanne Cahn, an economist at First Boston, added, "Shrinking industries are visible; growth industries aren't."
An example from the hard-pressed auto insurance business will drive that point home. High-cost insurance giants like Aetna, Cigna and Travelers are cutting thousands of jobs as they pull back from an unprofitable business. But David A. Simmons, president of the Tulsa General Insurance Agency, is planning to expand his staff by 10 to 15 percent this year, just as he did last year.
His secret? Tulsa General is busy installing machines similar to automated bank teller machines in supermarkets and shopping malls that let customers buy auto liability insurance in minutes without ever talking to an insurance agent, who usually collected 15 to 20 percent commissions on each policy. So far, each machine has been logging 35 quotes and selling 8 to 10 policies a day. "Now, no agent could do that much business, said Mr. Simmons, who added that there was still plenty of work in processing the policies at the home office.
 
Settling for Less
 But the old job generators of the 80's still suffer. College recruiting at Merrill Lynch, said Launton F. Simkins, director of human resource development, is off by more than 50 percent from 1987. "I think we're going to continue to consolidate and downsize," he said. These days, newly minted B.A.'s and M.B.A.'s at Baruch College in New York City, the biggest taxpayer-financed business school in the nation, are more willing to join small companies, take more junior positions and move out of New York, said Richard Brody, director of job placement. He also noted that they were getting few offers to join the civil service.
Even fast-food chains, which absorbed teen-agers the way french fries soak up oil, just aren't hiring as many people. In the two worst recessions of the postwar era, this industry added a few hundred thousand hamburger flippers and counter helpers. But in the most recent recession the head count barely stayed even.
"There's no question that the rate of growth will be substantilly slower in the 90's," said Carl Steidtmann at Management Horizons of Cincinnati, a consulting firm. "The business is saturated. So there's a constant pressure to improve productivity."
 
White Collar Jobs Affected
 Although executive headhunters at Korn-Ferry recently reported "strong signs that the recession in senior executive jobs is easing," the biggest losers are likely to be white-collar workers, especially those who labor in back offices. There is "a lasting threat to job security," said Mitchell Fromstein, president of Manpower Inc., a temporary help concern based in Milwaukee. "White-collar workers haven't had to deal with that."
"Adminstrators aren't in demand," said Burke Stimson, a spokesman for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, referring to plans to eliminate thousands of jobs in the wake of A.T.& T.'s acquisition of the NCR Corporation. "The white-collar contingent and the meeting-goers aren't in demand. People who pass memos back and forth aren't in demand."
A number of bankers, many of whom joined the business in the clubby days before financial deregulation, are learning the hard way. "There's an enormous amount of excess in the system today," said Michael R. Zucchini, executive vice president of the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group and the bank's chief information officer. Mr. Zucchini is helping to fold the failed $13 billion Bank of New England into the $20 billion Fleet. "Most banks want to do this type of consolidation," he said.
A big chunk of the savings that Fleet is striving for -- cutting the costs of the combined operations in half -- is coming from merging back-office computer and accounts-processing operations, which should eventually eliminate more than 1,000 jobs, many of them supervisory.
The drive to consolidate computer operations also hurt computer makers. Such customers cut their spending on information technology last year, said Morgan Stanley's Mr. Roach, who added that service companies as a whole spent less on information technology than they had since 1975.
The fallout is devastating. The Digital Equipment Corporation used to hire thousands of new hands a year, said Russ Johnson, manager of United States staffing and planning. Now the company, which dropped 8,000 jobs last year, is said to be planning similar cuts this year. "We've still got a way to go," Mr. Johnson said. "I hate to say this is always going to be this way, but these are systemic changes."
All this pain for individual workers may produce some gain for the economy. Signs of at least a temporary spurt in productivity came last month when the Government reported that output per hour perked up at a 1.9 percent rate last spring as payrolls shrank and production swelled.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 4, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Aug. 24 about the job outlook in the service sector misstated actions by the Cigna Corporation. Cigna did not cut thousands of jobs when it began to phase out its auto insurance business; employees were transferred to other parts of the company.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 857 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
AMERICAN CASSANDRA: The Life of Dorothy Thompson, by Peter Kurth. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) By the late 1930's, when The New York Herald Tribune gave her a column next to Walter Lippmann's, Dorothy Thompson had become so influential a journalist that Time magazine said she was the country's second most popular woman, after Eleanor Roosevelt. Readers "will be pleased to meet a fascinating, driven and indomitable woman who richly deserves this fine biography," Thomas Griffith said here last year.
LIKE LIFE, by Lorrie Moore. (Plume, $8.95.) In one of these stories about people stranded by love, a playwright whose girlfriend has left him becomes obsessed by the idea that he is being poisoned by truck fumes in his apartment above a sex shop in Times Square. In 1990 our reviewer, Stephen McCauley, praised Lorrie Moore for "the accuracy of her observations, the lyricism of many of her descriptions and the wry view of behavior wryly expressed." She has written "a rewarding, even exhilarating book." 
 THE MOTHER TONGUE: English & How It Got That Way, by Bill Bryson. (Avon, $9.95.) An American journalist tells how an obscure Anglo-Saxon tongue acquired a weird mix of Scandinavian and Norman vocabulary and a Latinate grammar and spread like a computer virus throughout the world. "What an engaging tour guide he is," Burt Hochberg said here last year. "We can't help sharing his pleasure in turning up odd, interesting facts or in pointing out grammatical blunders committed by famous grammarians."
A PLACE I'VE NEVER BEEN, by David Leavitt. (Penguin, $8.95.) The love triangles in these short stories consist of a complicated array of gender permutations, Wendy Martin said in The Book Review last year. "Mr. Leavitt has the wonderful ability to lead the reader to examine heterosexist assumptions without becoming polemical."
LONGING FOR DARKNESS. Tara and the Black Madonna: A Ten-Year Journey, by China Galland. (Penguin, $12.95.) Giving up Roman Catholicism for Buddhism, the author makes pilgrimages to Tibet, Eastern Europe, Texas and New Mexico seeking a spiritual link between the Virgin Mary and the goddess Tara. Last year our reviewer, Carol Zaleski, called this book a "heartfelt account of a search for the feminine face of God."
MOTHER EARTH FATHER SKY, by Sue Harrison. (Avon, $5.99.) After the other members of her village are massacred, a teen-age girl and her little brother set out on a journey to find her grandfather's tribe. Sue Harrison "expertly frames dramatic events with depictions of prehistoric life in the Aleutian Islands," Katherine Ramsland said here in 1990.
TEACHERS AT WORK: Achieving Success in Our Schools, by Susan Moore Johnson. (Basic Books, $12.95.) One of the most important ways to improve education, the author discovered in interviews with teachers, is to make the country's rundown classrooms less depressing places to work in. Last year our reviewer, Joan Countryman, called this book "a fine account of the physical, organizational, sociological, economic, political, cultural and psychological features of an adult's day at school."
CURRENT AFFAIRS, by Barbara Raskin. (Ivy, $5.95.) Two sisters -- a glamorous journalist who claims to have slept with Fidel Castro and a social worker who runs a homeless shelter -- come across secret documents linking the Iran-contra affair to the Washington drug trade. Last year our reviewer, Linda Wertheimer, said the novel is "stylish and slangy, written in a wild and wordy prose that is engaging and catchy."
WHEN THE WORLD WAS WHOLE: Three Centuries of Memories, by Charles Fenyvesi. (Penguin, $10.95.) Drawing on the records and recollections of his relatives, Charles Fenyvesi chronicles his Hungarian family's rise under the Hapsburgs, its fall in World War I and its near extinction under the Nazis. He has written "a family and social history that is both enchanting and devastating," Jeff Kisseloff said here last year.
MADENSKY SQUARE, by Eva Ibbotson. (Avon, $4.50.) Told from the point of view of a 36-year-old dressmaker, this romantic novel centers on life in Vienna on the eve of World War I. In 1989 our reviewer, Katrinka Blickle, said Eva Ibbotson "has fine-tuned -- and perhaps even enlarged -- the genre."
BOUND TO LEAD: The Changing Nature of American Power, by Joseph S. Nye Jr. (Basic Books, $10.95.) An expert on international affairs at Harvard argues that when all factors are taken into account -- economic, cultural and technological as well as military -- the United States is still No. 1. In 1990 our reviewer, Michael R. Beschloss, said this book is a welcome corrective to scholars like Paul Kennedy who say America is overextended and in decline.
A CITY OF STRANGERS, by Robert Barnard. (Dell, $4.50.) In a Yorkshire town, the beer-guzzling patriarch of a family that makes the Simpsons seem genteel is killed by a firebomb. Last year our reviewer, Josh Rubins, said, "The result is as good an example as any of the humorous mystery novel at its unpretentious best: playful but far from giddy, perfectly poised between drollery . . . and the stern realities of crime and punishment."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 23; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1423 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Italy, Land of Art Treasures Just Out of Visitors' View

BYLINE: By ALEXANDER STILLE; Alexander Stille, an American journalist living in Rome, writes frequently about Italian subjects.

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
Several times this summer, the usual throng of Japanese, German and American tourists has made the pilgrimage from Rome to Tivoli to see the villa of the Roman emperor Hadrian only to be turned away by a sign saying: "Closed for lack of personnel." Although there are 43 guards assigned to the villa, the staff had trouble mustering the minimum of seven needed to open the gates.
 The same scene has been played out across Italy this summer at dozens of major monuments and museums. Even the Roman Forum, the heart of ancient Rome, has been forced to shut its gates on occasion. As the weather heats up and the tourists arrive in force, the guards needed to watch over Italy's art treasures simply vanish. 
 Italy's most widely visited museum, the Uffizi in Florence, has had to keep about a third of its rooms closed during the tourist season. Each day, curators count up the number of guards who have bothered to show up to work, and calculate how many rooms they can open and for how long. Tourists can still see Leonardo and Botticelli, but forget about Bronzino, Perugino, Giorgione or Bellini. The museum crisis is becoming as much an Italian summer ritual as the Palio horse race in Siena or the Spoleto Music Festival.
The phantom museum guards are only the most obvious byproduct of the bloated and sclerotic bureaucracy that governs Italy's national museum system. Museums here have virtually no autonomy, and every decision, from restoring a painting to hiring an extra worker, must pass through the Ministry of Culture in Rome. Moreover, the ministry is subject to the whims and dizzying intrigues of Italy's continual Government crises: there have been five ministers in the last five years, which means that important decisions are often held up for months.
The result: crumbling buildings, filthy paintings, lack of catalogues and research, endless restoration projects and frequent thefts. Things have reached the point that 49 percent of Italy's 1,673 museums are currently closed -- and this number does not include the ones that close on the odd day when no one shows up for work.
 "The problem is not a lack of personnel," says Senator Luigi Covatta, undersecretary of the Ministry of Culture and the man responsible for running the museum system. "There are plenty of guards. The problem is that they are state employees who enjoy a whole series of privileges."
Like all state employees, museum guards are entitled by law to two weeks of thermal baths above and beyond their usual seven weeks of paid vacation. Others disappear for weeks or months at a time, thanks to medical certificates. And when Senator Covatta threatened to fire custodians at the Brera in Milan for refusing to observe union work rules, he was taken to court for anti-union activity. The case is pending.
 The situation at the Brera encapsulates the problem. In the Alice in Wonderland world of Italian bureaucracy, the museum's dearth of custodians actually worsened after their number was nearly tripled in 1986. "At the Brera in 1986, 40 custodians managed to keep open 38 rooms; now in 1991, with 108 guards, they can only keep open 27 rooms," says Senator Covatta.
 Last year, museum guards at the Brera were absent for a total of 8,673 days, three months apiece. Because they are state run, northern Italian museums like the Brera hire guards through a Government system that gives preference to unemployed workers from southern Italy, most of whom consider assignment to cities like Milan extreme hardship. Guards generally make only about $1,000 a month, and those from the south frequently cannot afford to take their families with them. As a result, they return home at the first opportunity.
 For many years the Brera had been open only in the morning and was able to show only about two-thirds of its collection. The increase in guards in 1986, instead of solving the problem, began the battle of Brera. The new guards complained about the lack of ventilation in the museum, called in a local health authority and obtained an extraordinary concession: for every hour of work, they would get a half-hour break. This was called decanting, following the practice of allowing wine to breathe. With the decanting policy in place, along with thermal baths and sick days, the museum abandoned its plan to stay open in the afternoon.
 This spring, Senator Covatta and the Brera's director decided to try again. In May, the custodians' union agreed to abandon the decanting policy. But the guards at the Brera rebelled and threatened to take over the museum. According to their spokesman, Stefano Esposito, in an interview with Panorama magazine, the Government and the national union had "signed an agreement over our heads, without even consulting us." The next day, the Ministry of Culture ordered the museum closed and threatened to man it with volunteers and conscientious objectors. The wildcat strike lasted for only a day.
 For the moment, a truce has been reached. The guards have agreed to work in the afternoon starting in the fall, and the museum is trying to meet their demand for an employee cafeteria.
 But the custodian problem is only a symptom. "The underlying problem is an antiquated, state-run system," says Senator Covatta. "The individual museums have no autonomy. Furthermore, our museums are in beautiful but very old palaces, whose restoration is complex and expensive."
 For virtually every expense, the director of a museum must turn to the regional superintendent of culture, who, in turn, must turn to Rome. "Sometimes by the time the money arrives it's too late to spend it, and it has to go back to Rome," says Federico Zeri, an art historian and a onetime trustee of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif. Money appropriated in a given year must be spent by the end of that year, so that if funds don't reach a museum by late in the year, they have to be returned to the Government. As a result, many building and restoration projects start and stop with the unpredictable ebb and flow of funds.
Work at the Gallery of the Villa Borghese in Rome has dragged on for more than 10 years, making its masterly collection of Bernini, Caravaggio and Titian difficult, and often impossible, to see. The National Roman Museum, with Rome's principal collection of ancient art, has been mostly closed for the same period. Work proceeds on both with no clear end in sight.
 The Ministry of Culture is only one of the national bureaucracies with which museums must contend. It distributes funds, but the Ministry of Finance is in charge of collecting the money museums make in admissions and sales. "A museum like the Uffizi does not even have a balance sheet," says Senator Covatta. "It has no control over what it earns." For this reason, museum directors have no economic incentive to attract the public, put on special exhibitions, publish catalogues or stay open longer hours.
 Also, because the Ministry of Culture is low in the political pecking order, museums often have less space than they need -- or even than they are allotted. The national museum at the Barberini Palace, with perhaps Rome's most important painting collection, has about half the space it is entitled to because it shares a floor with an army social club. "This club, which does nothing but give parties, was supposed to be evicted in 1951, and here we are 40 years later," says Mr. Zeri, the art historian. The reason, say some, is simple: the Minister of Defense has more power than the Minister of Culture.
 Senator Covatta, although a political appointee, favors decentralization and privatization of the system. His idea is that the largest museums would become almost completely autonomous, each run by its own separate foundation. The works of art would remain in the public domain, but such services as guarding the museum and running the bookstore would be contracted out to private companies.
 "Italy doesn't seem to realize that art and antiquities are the country's greatest resource -- what oil is to Saudi Arabia," says Adriano D'Offizi, director of Hadrian's villa. "Four hundred thousand people come through here every year, and we could double the number easily and do it properly if we had the means."
 So far, reactions to Senator Covatta's decentralization plan have been positive, but it has not yet entered the political arena. As he well knows, the Government could fall at any minute, and in the division of spoils among the governing parties, his job could be bargained away.
