PUB-DATE: August 25, 1991

SECTION: Section 2; Page 23; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1205 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Bold Images That Show Why the 20's Roared

BYLINE: By Michael Kimmelman

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
The Chrysler Building rose above the streets of New York and the Bugatti Royale cruised the streets of Europe. Lindbergh flew solo in his single-engine "Spirit of St. Louis" across an ocean plied by a new generation of gigantic luxury liners. Spectacular utopian dreams were conceived to rejuvenate a continent ravaged by a war of unprecedented brutality. From London and Vienna to New York and Chicago, the working masses who had transformed the cities of the 19th century into the metropolises of the 20th called for widespread social reforms. At the same time, a wave of conservatism resounded in the French "rappel a l'ordre," or call to order, and in the Neo-Classicism of artists like Picasso and de Chirico.
 Only an exhibition as enormous and ambitious and exhilarating as "The 1920's: Age of the Metropolis," here at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, through Nov. 10, could begin to do its sprawling subject justice. 
 No show can encapsulate a decade, and this one retraces the familiar steps, from Expressionism through Dadaism, Constructivism and the Bauhaus, Art Deco and cafe society. And yet by bringing under one roof so much diverse and remarkable material, it goes a long way toward outlining the overarching characteristics of the period. A kind of grandiose folly, "The 1920's" seems uncannily matched to a decade that spawned Hugh Ferriss's vision of the city of the future and Le Corbusier's scheme to destroy Paris and rebuild it as a series of skyscrapers and plazas.
Accompanied by an appropriately gigantic 638-page catalogue, the exhibition brings together some 700 works by almost 300 artists. Paintings, photographs, furniture, sculptures, decorative arts, drawings and architectural models have been culled from scores of public and private collections around the world. Rooms have been set aside in which to view films and hear music from the period. The museum's permanent holdings have been taken down so that every inch of display space can be given over to what is the largest exhibition that this institution has ever mounted. (It will not travel.)
 Among the most memorable works in the show are the elaborate architectural and sculptural reconstructions, including the grottolike room from Kurt Schwitters's home; the model for Vladimir Tatlin's "Monument to the Third International"; Laszlo Moholy-Nagy's "Light-Space Modulator," and Theo van Doesburg's flower room from the Villa de Noailles. To one side of the entrance to the exhibition there is even a De Havilland 60X Moth airplane, which has somehow miraculously been squeezed through the museum's doors. After all this, the gleaming 1927 Bugatti convertible in one of the later galleries seems almost mundane.
 An international team of curators, under the leadership of Jean Clair, director of the Musee Picasso in Paris, has focused the exhibition on three cities of primary significance -- Berlin, Paris and New York, with the section on Berlin the densest and most impressive. The organizers have been careful to point out instances in which other places, including Russia and the Netherlands, played important roles in the cultural legacy of the decade. "The 1920's" is as much an exhibition about the social history of the period as it is about art history, and it begins with posters, and with gripping prints by Otto Dix, that evoke the devastation of World War I. The show includes sections on images of the working classes, utopia, cabaret society and mechanization.
 The result is a richly textured image of the era. It is one thing to consider drawings for set designs and photographs from the futuristic Fritz Lang film, "Metropolis," as reminders of the extraordinary technological advances made by the movie industry during the decade. But it is another thing to see them, as they are here, in the context of Rudolf Belling's "Sculpture 23" and paintings by the Cologne Progressives, like Franz Wilhelm Seiwert and Heinrich Hoerle. Lang clearly followed the path of these other artists, who had depicted the workers in the new industries as machines. The 1920's was the decade that coined the word robot, and Machine Mary from the 1926 film is a steel cousin to Belling's bronze sculpture of three years earlier.
 It is still another thing to consider "Metropolis" against the backdrop of the grandiose urban development schemes of German architects like Hans Poelzig, Bruno Taut, Walter Gropius and Ludwig Hilberseimer, schemes that sought to renew, both physically and spiritually, a country devastated by the war. Lang's vision of the city, in many ways prescient, looks downright tame beside Wenzel Hablik's wild proposals for towers and domes made of glass, a material considered to be symbolic of purity.
 Tamara de Lempicka's Art Deco portraits fit neatly in a section on cabaret society, but in the broad context of the exhibition they also raise the issue of the "new" woman who in the 1920's finally won a share of independence. She is epitomized by de Lempicka's suave painting of the Duchesse de La Salle in pants and riding boots.
 From de Lempicka it is not a big leap to the work of the American artist Guy Pene du Bois, whose sharply contoured, highly simplified image of "Mr. and Mrs. Chester Dale Dining Out" in turn recalls Leger's "Mechanic." From Leger it is another short hop to the abstract paintings of Le Corbusier, with their emphases on orderliness and control, ideas central to the 1920's and even implicit by their absence in the work of the Dadaists and Surrealists.
 And so on. The show seems always circling back on itself, reprising and expanding on themes that bridge the boundaries between one culture and another, that amend the cliches about pessimistic Berlin, optimistic New York and nonchalant Paris. Reginald Marsh's paintings of New York look familiar after a work like "Silk Stocking Counter" by the French painter Yves Alix. Charles Demuth's sober meditations on industrialism seem almost like variations on the works of the German painter Karl Volker.
 "The 1920's" presents works by dozens of lesser-known or long-forgotten artists, including Volker and Alix, which round out the picture of the period. The show is also full of first-rate objects. Among the especially fine group of decorative works are a sumptuous cabinet of ebony, mother of pearl and silver from 1927 by Louis Sue and Andre Mare, and a wrought-iron and brass five-panel screen by Edgar William Brandt and Henri Favier, which is a masterpiece of intricate design. The level of handicraft reached spectacular heights in France during a decade known for the idealistic attempts by German, Dutch and Russian designers of the Bauhaus, De Stijl and Constructivist movements to exploit the new industrial technologies.
The 1920's really began with the end of World War I and ended with the beginning of the Depression. Between hope and despair was a decade of social, cultural, sexual and economic upheaval carried out at a pace to match the new cars and planes, and in a world made to seem smaller by these innovations. "It was a little alarming -- this shrinkage," wrote Virginia Woolf in 1928. One of the lessons of this splendid exhibition is how familiar that era seems.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Tax Collectors Lean On the Out-of-Towners

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
TRAVELERS who sense that their vacation dollars are sliding out of their wallets faster than planned are not suffering a delusion. An economical $50 hotel room in the United States actually costs an average of $54.20 with tax, and that does not count a sales tax on the video you rented or an 8.5 percent tax on the four breakfasts you put on the room bill. Across the country, every travel expense costs 2 percent to 19 percent more than is listed on the rate card, menu or ticket.
The residents of a city pay its sales taxes, of course, but visitors' sensations that everyone is taking a bite as they swim by is not incorrect: surcharges, surtaxes and extra fees fall heavily upon nonresidents, who are not likely to see huge signs: "Welcome to Columbus, where you'll pay 15.75 percent tax on your hotel room." 
 "It's a trend," said Aubrey C. King, who is working on a travel industry committee researching the subject. "People think it's safe to tax travelers where they don't vote."
Mr. King's committee, the Travel and Tourism Government Affairs Council, which is sponsored by 33 tourism groups, conspicuously the Travel Industry Association in Washington, D.C., has gathered data on these add-ons and has estimated how much taxes have risen in the last seven years.
Measured in 1989 dollars, he estimated, travel taxes and fees rose from $32.4 billion in 1984 to $36.4 billion in 1989, a rise of $4 billion. His research indicated that of the 1989 total, $20.4 billion went to the Federal Government; $10.4 billion went to state governments and $5.5 billion to localities. It is not clear how much of this has to do with a rise in the tax rate and how much with a rise in prices and expansion in the travel industry. Travel by foreigners to the United States increased by 6 percent a year from 1984 to 1988, and domestic travel also rose, though somewhat less.
The committee research surveyed the 50 states and came up with these figures: State and local taxes on hotel rooms now average 8.4 percent; on restaurant meals, 8.5 percent; on admissions, 2.9 percent; on rental cars or campsite rentals, 2.7 percent.
Mr. King said that the committee believed that the Federal Government did not have a clear picture of the way travel taxes are accumulating. "We estimate that 15 to 20 percent of the new revenues that developed in the 1990 budget reconciliation process falls upon travelers," he said. Among the increases he listed for last year was the rise in the air ticket tax to 10 percent from 8 percent and a rise to 14 cents from 9 cents in the Federal gasoline tax.
 
Still Other Charges
 There is more. On May 13, a $2 Agriculture Department fee was imposed on all airline passengers arriving on the United States mainland from overseas. Like the 10 percent Federal tax, it is added to the price of the ticket. This fee, which also grew out of the 1990 budget agreement, is intended to pay for the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, the agency charged with protecting against plant and tree pests and animal disease from overseas.
On Aug. 1, the Agriculture fee was to have been extended to passengers from Hawaii and Puerto Rico, but this step has been postponed until Oct. 1; bills have been introduced to keep the fee from being imposed on domestic travel. The Air Transport Association, whose members are airlines, wants the whole fee repealed or at least reduced to $1.
Caree VanderLinden of the inspection service said that the new tax was also applied to trucks and trains coming from Mexico. The yield from passengers arriving from overseas, she said, was expected to be $50 million annually.
Another tax, called the "passenger facility charge," essentially a user fee for airports, is on the way next year. It could add as much as $12 to the price of a ticket: $1, $2 or $3 for each departure from or connection at a United States airport, with a maximum of four fees per ticket.
In June, the Federal Aviation Administration adopted rules permitting the collection of this tax;the agency or city that operates an airport gets the yield and may use it for certain approved airport improvements.
The tax is added to the price of the ticket, except for tickets sold overseas; in such cases, the fee will be collected in cash at the airport, a process familiar to overseas travelers. The airlines, for their trouble, are allowed to keep 12 cents for each fee collected in the first three years; 8 cents after that. Initially, the airlines are also allowed to keep the interest on all the money they have collected and must hold until an airport gets its improvement plan approved and is authorized to spend the money.
 
Adverse Impact
 The accompanying chart shows increases in total taxes on hotel rooms since 1984 for all 16 cities that the National Conference of State Legislatures says have double-digit rates. Here are breakdowns on how some of these taxes are distributed.
Orlando, Fla.: 10 percent or 8 percent, depending on the county: 6 percent state sales tax, plus a 4 percent "resort" tax on hotel-condo rooms in Osceola County and Orange County, where Disney World is situated; in Seminole County, this is 2 percent.
New York: 19.25 percent plus $ 2: 8.25 percent state and city sales tax, plus 6 percent city occupancy tax, plus 5 percent state occupancy tax if room costs more than $100, plus $2 city tax for rooms over $40.
New Orleans: 11 percent plus $1, $2 or $ 3: 4 percent for the Superdome, 2 percent for the Convention Center, 2 percent to the state general fund, 1.5 percent to Orleans Parish school board and 1.5 percent to the city fund, plus city occupancy tax of $1 a night on hotels up to 299 rooms; $2 a night, 300 to 999 rooms, and $3 a night, 1,000 rooms and above.
San Francisco: 11 percent city sales tax for rooms occupied less than 30 days; there is no state sales tax on rooms.
Columbus, Ohio: 5.75 percent city sales tax plus 10 percent state bed tax.
Chicago: 12.4 percent: 6 percent state occupancy tax, 3 percent city hotel tax, 2 percent sports facility tax, 1.1 special events fund and 0.3 collection fund.
Meanwhile, people in the travel industry worry that the taxes will kill the source of the golden tourism egg. Said Mr. King of the trade group: "We are very concerned about its impact on travel, including travelers from abroad."

HEADLINE: After a Long Slump, Home Sales Rise

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
SALES of houses, co-ops and condominiums in the New York metropolitan area, still near the bottom of a slump that has been longer and deeper than any since before World War II, have improved steadily since the spring in what analysts say is the beginning of a slow recovery.
Throughout the region, real estate executives say sales volume surged in March, reflecting a decline in interest rates and a sense of economic euphoria that accompanied the resolution of the war in the Persian Gulf. Sales for April, May and June were sharply higher than the year earlier. 
 Since then, sales have tapered off in a pattern that is typical of sluggish summer activity, but remain stronger than a year ago. Prices, after dropping more than 30 percent since 1988, show no signs of rising, and indeed continue to sink slightly in many communities.
A result is that buyers, though still cautious and choosy, are committing themselves in growing numbers. First-time buyers, who have watched housing values sink for three years, now represent the strongest segment of the market in many communities and neighborhoods.
"The kind of places I like have come down to what I can afford," said Lisa Rosenberg, a Manhattan lawyer who bought her first home. She looked at 50 apartments before buying a large one-bedroom apartment on King Street, just south of Greenwich Village, in July.
For sellers, the long slump has given rise to a new calculus in housing finance. They may accept less than their house was worth in the recent past, but they pay less for whatever they are buying in replacement.
"Think of it as bartering," said Hal Rose, a Brooklyn medical-laboratory executive who accepted $25,000 less for a two-bedroom Brooklyn Heights co-op than he paid for it in 1986. But he said he also paid $35,000 less than was being asked for a three-story Park Slope town house.
While analysts differ over the the direction of prices -- many expect them to begin rising gradually this year -- there is broad consensus that the increased pace of sales will continue into the fall and winter.
"We have seen continuous, month-by-month improvement in sales, and conditions are in place for further recovery," said Eugene Sherman, senior economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.
One factor that should bolster sales is a reduction in interest rates, which have dropped nearly one percentage point since January, to an average of just under 9.4 percent for fixed, 30-year mortgages. By the end of the year, Mr. Sherman predicted, the rate could fall to 8.75 percent.
Analysts say the increase in home sales during the first half of the year was in part due to pent-up demand created during the second half of 1990. Sales in that period slowed to a virtual standstill amid a rash of layoffs, dire predictions of fiscal problems for the city and suburbs alike, and Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Still, the recent flurry of buying appears to reflect more than a temporary game of catch-up. In Manhattan, brokers report a sharp increase in sales of expensive condominiums to foreign buyers, led by Italians, French, Germans and Brazilians. Analysts say the foreigners have seized on the low value of the dollar compared to their currencies to make real estate investments.
More importantly, the analysts say, the steep slide in home values has made New York City and its suburbs, still one of the nation's most expensive housing markets, much more affordable than it was in the late 1980's. That means more first-time buyers are entering the market, and more people who want to buy something better are making their moves.
"I am losing on the sale, but making up for it on the other end," said Mr. Rose, whose wife, Lisa, gave birth to their second child on July 5. They moved into their Park Slope town house only two weeks before the birth, and he said he was happy with the move on both family and financial grounds.
"Too many people in this market are simply focusing on how much they would lose by selling, and not how much they save by buying," he said.
MS. ROSENTHAL paid $170,000 for her co-op on King Street, which fills a full floor of a rowhouse. In her protracted search, which began in 1988, she said she saw several smaller, less attractive one-bedroom co-ops for which the owners were asking over $200,000.
And in Bergenfield, N.J., Laurie Greenberg, an advertising sales executive and another first time buyer plans to close in September on a three-bedroom, expanded Cape Cod with a large deck. She looked at 30 houses, she said, and one reason she is buying now is that she found a fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage at only 9 percent interest.
Across the region, surveys by real estate companies and housing analysts reflect sharply increased activity in recent months.
* In Westchester County, sales of detached one-family homes were stronger in April, May and June than in any comparable period since 1981, according to the county's Board of Realtors, which said buyers closed on 960 houses. Nonetheless, it said the median price of the houses, $287,500, continued a long decline, from $290,000 a year earlier and $298,000 two years earlier.
It also said condominium and co-op sales remained weak, and prices declined. "I think its a bit to early to be sure we've turned the corner," said Merritt Mitchell, president of the Westchester Multiple Listing Service. "I'm hopeful we have."
* In Fairfield County, Conn., a bloated inventory of unsold homes was shrinking during the second quarter in many communities. A study by the William Pitt Real Estate Company, based in Stamford, found 753 houses listed in Greenwich, down from 864 the year before; 2,384 houses available in Bridgeport, down from 2,821 the year before, and 726 houses listed in Stamford, down from 880 the year before.
It said sales volume in most of the county had increased. Still, it found median prices sinking in more than half the communities it surveyed, with particularly large declines of 18.7 percent in Darien and 11.6 percent in Norwalk.
* In Northern New Jersey, including Bergen, Morris, Hudson and Passaic Counties, the pace of home sales increased 30 percent in the second quarter, to 122 a week from 91 a week the year earlier, according to a study by Higgins Realtors, based in Hillsdale. It counted the number of deposits made and sales contracts signed each week.
Nonetheless, it found that the average sale price, $234,000, was down 3 percent from the year before. William F. Higgins, president of the firm, said he expected prices to erode further, partly because of the high number of foreclosed properties being brought on the market by lenders and employment cuts in the banking and insurance industries.
Data on the New York City market are more sketchy, largely because a major part of the market is in co-op sales, which are not reported to city and state authorities and made a part of the public record in the way house sales are. Nonetheless, several city real estate firms said sales had increased sharply starting in March.
In a survey of sales at 46 of Manhattan's most expensive condominium buildings, the Ambrose-Mar Elia Company said the number of apartments sold jumped 47 percent, to 147, during the first half of the year compared with the year-earlier period.
Jean Luban, vice president of the firm, said that more than half the sales were to foreign buyers but that, in contrast to the late 80's, these did not include investors from Japan. Instead, she said the foreign buyers included companies and individuals from Europe and South America who regard dollar-based investments in general, and Manhattan real estate in particular, as safe havens.
The William B. May Company, with offices on the Upper East Side, Greenwich Village, Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope and the Westchester community of Irvington, said it sold 30 percent more apartments in the first half of this year than it did a year ago. Because the average price of the apartments declined, the dollar volume increased by only 10 percent.
Stribling Real Estate, a Manhattan broker that specializes in expensive co-ops on the Upper East and West Sides, said its sales since March have been 300 percent higher than during the same period last year. "We are dazed and happy," said Betsy Dean, the firm's president.
And Richard Cantor Inc., based in SoHo, said sales in May, June and July were 25 percent above a year ago.
"Barring any serious new problems in the city's economy, we have have passed the low of this market," said Richard Cantor, the firm's president. "The oversupply has been removed from the inventory and we are looking for listings."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: U.D.C. in the Neighborhoods;
Aid Sprinkles

 BODY:
The New York State Urban Development Corporation is more often identified with giant undertakings than neighborhood-sized projects. But under its 10-month-old Urban and Community Development Program, $5 million is to be awarded to "highly distressed areas" for storefront improvements, feasibility studies and project planning.
Among the latest recipients are the Canarsie Neighborhood Development Association in Brooklyn, which has been awarded up to $50,000 to study improvements to the Rockaway Parkway, Glenwood Road and Flatlands Avenue commercial strips. 
 Another grant, up to $90,000, is to go to the Abyssinian Development Corporation, an offshoot of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, at 132 Odell Clark Place (West 138th Street). It is to be used to study a redevelopment of the adjacent Renaissance Ballroom and New Lafayette Theater, on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, as a commercial complex and catering facility.
"One of the more important things about the program is that it's statewide," said Jan Levy, a spokeswoman for the Urban Development Corporation. "It can help them as much in Horseheads or Elmira as in Harlem or Canarsie."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 15 Years in Queens;
Outdoor Market Getting Indoor Home

 BODY:
A 15-year-old Queens institution, the Outdoor Farmers Market, held three days a week in downtown Jamaica, is about to get a permanent indoor home. A 26,000-square-foot building scheduled for completion in November will house its produce, plants and flower sellers, as well as a 300-seat, two-story food court with 14 outlets.
The project is on 160th Street just north of Jamaica Avenue. It is being financed with $4.3 million in public and private funds raised by the New York City Economic Development Corporation and a private group in Jamaica, the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, which will operate the market. 
 The steel-and-glass building, designed by James McCullar, a Manhattan architect, is meant to be used all year, and will have large roll gates that will be left open during good weather.
Described by Mr. McCullar as the oldest of its kind in New York City, the market attracts farmers from throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and as many as 5,000 shoppers on market days -- Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays. During most of its history, it was held in an open lot on Jamaica Avenue a block south of the construction site. That site was claimed for a new office building.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Exchanges Headquarters;
A Two-in-One Structure With a 'Trading Box' Slab

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
TO the delight of New York officials in desperate need of any development news -- and the dismay of downtown neighbors who see another oversized tower in the works -- the New York Exchanges Headquarters project is taking form.
Designed for the New York Mercantile Exchange, Commodity Exchange, Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, New York Cotton Exchange and New York Futures Exchange, the 1.2 million-square-foot structure is to rise on the block bounded by West, Warren, Greenwich and Murray Streets. It is to be developed by Tishman Speyer Properties of Manhattan and completed in 1994. 
 As planned, the Exchanges Headquarters would be two structures in one. The base would be a 120-foot-high slab called the "trading box," which would encompass two trading floors with a total of 55,000 square feet of space and room for expansion to 100,000 square feet -- four times the size of the trading area now in use at Four World Trade Center. On the east end would be a 47-story office tower, with floors of about 21,000 square feet. At 730 feet in height, it would be equivalent to a skyscraper with 55 floors. There would also be a 400-space garage.
Some 660,000 square feet would be set aside for member firms and companies that do business with them. And 340,000 square feet of service and office space would be used by the exchanges themselves.
The architects are Kevin Roche, John Dinkeloo & Associates, of Hamden, Conn. J. P. Morgan & Company of Manhattan is the financial adviser. Leasing is to be managed by the New York office of LaSalle Partners, which is based in Chicago. The managing director of the project is Amy L. Benenson.
Through its Economic Development Corporation, New York City is to contribute $55 million toward the total construction bill, about $450 million. The New York State Urban Development Corporation is contributing $45 million. Tax and rent benefits worth at least $42.5 million were also awarded to keep the exchanges from moving to the Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City.
The project would be built on a city-owned parking lot in the Washington Street Urban Renewal Area. In the late 1980's, it was designated as the headquarters site for Drexel Burnham Lambert, a deal that fell apart shortly before Drexel did.
Earlier this month, the board of directors of the Urban Development Corporation approved a general project plan for the Exchanges Headquarters. Also, the project began its seven-month trip through the city's land-use review procedure.
Opposition has already been voiced. "I think there is a lot of skepticism as to why they need a building of this size, with vacancy rates in lower Manhattan running at approximately 20 percent," said Paul Goldstein, district manager of Community Board 1. "It's unfortunate that the city had a gun held to its head by the exchanges and felt compelled to give away the store to retain them."
He said the matter was even more sensitive because the tower would rise just west of a residential neighborhood, directly across the street from Public School 234 and only two blocks from Washington Market Park.
ACCORDING to the draft environmental impact statement prepared for the Urban Development Corporation, the "project would cause a significant noise impact" at a noise-monitoring station next to the school and would have "significant traffic impact" at 15 intersections in the area and at the Holland Tunnel entrance. The statement includes proposed mitigations.
More traffic "may increase local carbon monoxide levels," the impact statement said, but the predicted maximum eight-hour concentration levels would still fall within national air-quality standards at the eight monitoring sites in the study area.
The economic price would be high if the exchanges left the city, according to the statement, prepared by Allee King Rosen & Fleming and Philip Habib & Associates.
"Relocation of the industry could lead to a decrease of more than $1 billion in direct economic activity, more than 8,611 commodities industry jobs and more than $75 million in city and state taxes," the document said. "While the industry does not have a large employment base, it makes a substantial contribution to the city and state economies and is important to the city as a focus of national and international finance. Moreover, the industry's focus on national and international commerce make it independent of regional and municipal economic conditions. It is therefore critical to the city and state to assist the industry in staying and growing."
Besides a 20-year occupancy commitment by the exchanges, the statement noted such benefits as 1,620 construction jobs, $28 million in construction-related tax revenues, the potential for growth in employment in the commodities industries and, in time, "substantial increases in ground rent and payments in lieu of real estate taxes."
As for those increased rent and tax payments, however, the city will be waiting quite a while. Rent on the "trading box" will be abated for the first 20 years of the 99-year lease. After that, full rent would be due. For that portion occupied by exchange offices and member firms, there will be an exemption of 80 percent for the first two years after occupancy, 50 percent for the next two years and 20 percent for the next two years. After that, full rent would be due.
The exchanges would not be liable for real estate taxes as such, but rather payments in lieu of taxes. On the portion occupied by the "trading box," however, such payments will be excused for the first 20 years of operation. After that, full payment would be due. For their administrative offices, the exchanges will make no payments in the first two years of occupancy. In the third year, they would pay the equivalent of 25 percent of real-estate taxes. This would rise by increments of 7.5 percent for the next 10 years until it reached the full amount.
Member firms -- those with seats on an exchange -- who commit to space before the closing would be entitled to an exemption of all but 25 percent of their payments in lieu of taxes in the first three years of occupancy. After that, the amount due would rise by increments of 7.5 percent annually until it reached 100 percent in the 13th year.
The project would be exempt from sales taxes and mortgage-recording taxes connected with construction. And the exchanges would be exempt from sales tax for 20 years on any capital improvements.
This is not the first time that the exchanges have been close to developing an ambitious new project in lower Manhattan. In 1985, Mr. Roche was the designer of a 1.2 million-square-foot structure, with a 100,000-square-foot trading floor, that was to have been built on a platform over the ramp to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. The plan was abandoned in 1987 because of its complexity and cost.
More than a dozen other sites were considered, but each failed to meet one or more of the exchanges' key criteria: room enough for a vast and virtually column-free trading floor, with adjacent space for exchange offices and member firms; closeness to the rest of the financial-service industry in lower Manhattan; lowest possible building and operating costs and early availability.
Timing was critical in preventing the exchanges from taking advantage of a site in Battery Park City bounded by Murray, West and Vesey Streets and North End Avenue (cater-corner from the parcel now under consideration). Under its contract with the Reichmann family, developers of the World Financial Center, the Battery Park City Authority is prevented from seeking commercial zoning on that site until 1994.
In the last analysis, Harborside "offered an almost ideal physical configuration, lower development and operating costs, and the opportunity to begin construction at a relatively early date," the impact statement said. But the lower Manhattan parcel "presented the best opportunity in New York City to maximize satisfaction of all criteria," the document said, and the state and city incentives "substantially reduced the economic advantages of the New Jersey site."

HEADLINE: Challenging Residency as Job Requirement

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE recent settlement of a suit filed by the N.A.A.C.P. against the City of Clifton has renewed the debate over whether municipal employees should be required to live in the towns and cities where they work.
On one level, the debate centers around contentions by the N.A.A.C.P. that the requirements are racially disciminatory. On another, the issue revolves around a question of fairness to municipal workers. Some of the unions that represent uniformed employees argue that the laws should be scrapped, while those that represent clerical workers and laborers assert that the rules should be expanded to include employees like teachers, police officers and firefighters and should be enforced more vigorously. 
 Agreeing with the blue-collar workers are municipal officials who say the requirements are justified because employees who live where they work have a greater stake in the community.
The debate has taken on a particular urgency because many municipalities, battling rising property taxes, increased costs and stagnant development, are struggling to stave the exodus of their highest-paid residents.
The civil rights advocates contend that residency requirements can lead to racial discrimination, particularly in towns that have few minority residents but are near cities with large minority populations. .
"We found that blacks and Hispanics from urban areas were categorically being denied employment in suburban towns because of residency requirements," said Keith M. Jones, president of the New Jersey chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
He said, for example, that a person who lived in Newark would essentially be barred from municipal employment in nearby Harrison because Harrison residents were given preference for jobs there.
As a result, Mr. Jones said, the N.A.A.C.P. filed lawsuits against seven North Jersey municipalities that had predominantly white populations yet were adjacent to urban areas with large minority populations. The suits sought to force the municipalities to rescind their residency requirements. The municipalities that were sued were Bayonne, Millburn, Kearny, West Orange, Fort Lee, Harrison and Clifton.
"From our standpoint, it was a classic civil rights issue," Mr. Jones said.
Only the Harrison case has gone to trial. In that case, a State Superior Court judge ruled that the residency requirement was discriminatory and invalid, but allowed officials to impose a 15-mile radius requirement in its place.
In the Clifton case, the city and the N.A.A.C.P., reacting in part to the Harrison decision, entered an agreement rescinding the residency requirement and imposing a 15-mile radius requirement in its place.
According to Sam Monchak, a lawyer who represented Clifton in the lawsuit, the total population of the city is about 71,000, while about 1,000 of Clifton's residents are black. There are no blacks in the Police or Fire Departments, Mr. Monchak said, and only eight blacks working in other city departments.
Under the terms of the agreement establishing the 15-mile radius, minority members and others who live in Passaic and Essex Counties will now be eligible for Clifton jobs.
Mr. Monchak said that notwithstanding the settlement, Clifton's prior policy of giving job preference to residents was not unusual. "Practically every large municipality in New Jersey has adopted a resident preference law," he said.
Roger L. Kemp, Clifton's City Manager, said resident preference and residency requirement laws were beneficial to communities. He said workers were usually more committed to their jobs if they lived in town and were more likely to contribute to the economic life of a community if they spent their paychecks there and paid municipal taxes.
In addition, he said, public safety employees who live in the municipality they serve are more likely to be available in emergencies. "We would virtually have them in a law-enforcement capacity for 24 hours a day," Mr. Kemp said.
Under current state law, municipalities are free to establish residency restrictions for most public employees. Some, for example, require employees to live in the city at the time of appointment and then continue to live there for as long as they are employed.
Others allow nonresidents to be hired, but require that they become residents within a certain time. Still others limit job opportunities to residents, but then allow employees to move out after a specific time.
Teachers, however, are exempt from all residency requirements by state law. And though police officers and firefighters can be required to live within a city at their appointment, municipalities are prohibited from making residence mandatory for such employees after they are hired.
As a result, many teachers and public safety employees -- often some of the highest-paid employees of a municipality -- live outside the communities they serve.
In Trenton, for instance, a substantial majority of firefighters live outside the city.
"We're finding that more and more of our people don't live in the city," said Deputy Fire Chief Dennis Keenan. Nearly 80 percent of the rank-and-file firefighters live outside the city, he said, and only three of Trenton's 13 top-ranking officers live within it.
And that, Mr. Keenan said, can cause problems. "When we get a second or third alarm, we activate reserve companies to cover the rest of the city," he said. "But when a fellow lives 45 miles away, by the time he gets out of his house and gets here, it's too late."
 
Relying on Volunteers
 Mr. Keenan said that as a result, "we have to rely more and more on the volunteer departments on the outskirts of the city to come in and help."
He said that Trenton had a residency law for police officers and firefighters but that law "really doesn't mean anything."
Since police officers and firefighters cannot be required to live within city limits after they are hired, many simply establish residences in Trenton in order to obtain jobsand move out after they are sworn in.
"We've had cases where two or three people have rented a small apartment, and they establish that as their residence," he said. "You go there, and everything points to the fact that that's where they live -- they even change their driver's license and voting registration -- but you know in your heart that they're not going to be there two months after they're appointed."
In Camden, as many as 90 percent of the city's 275 firefighters live outside the city, said Capt. Joseph Marini. The city, like most of the state's large municipalities, has a residency ordinance.
 
'It's a Farce'
 "It's a farce," Captain Marini said. "The day after they appoint you, you can move out."
Captain Marini, who has been in the Camden Fire Department for 15 years, moved out of the city nine years ago.
"I had to move out," he said. "My house was burglarized four times, my mother was mugged, my sister was mugged and my car was stolen twice. There was no quality of life here. It was like living in Beirut."
Given that residency requirements, in practice, do not prevent police officers, firefighters and teachers from living where they want, there has been little inducement in recent years for those municipal employees to tinker with the status quo.
But in light of the recent efforts by the N.A.A.C.P. to eliminate residency requirements in some towns, and the resulting court ruling and out-of-court settlement setting radius restrictions for employees, some union officials say it is now time to push for an "across the board" statewide policy abolishing all residency requirements for uniformed employees.
"I think that we should push for legislation that would make all towns open for competitive examinations," said John Gerow, president of the Newark firefighters' union. Mr. Gerow said he would call for the drafting of such legislation and would search for a sponsor at the International Association of Fire Fighters' annual meeting in September.
Such legislation, he said, would make any state resident eligible to take any municipality's examination for firefighter.
Union officials representing clerical workers and laborers, however, say that residency requirements should not be eliminated, but should be expanded and more strictly enforced.
 
Question of Fairness
 "If residency's going to be applied one way, it should be applied all ways," said Richard M. Riggs, president of Camden County Council 10 Civil Service Association, the union that represents county and municipal workers in Camden County and the City of Camden.
Mr. Riggs said he believed that if nonuniformed municipal workers were required to be residents to keep their jobs, the same should apply to other city employees like teachers and public safety employees.
"To me, one of the biggest problems of the municipalities is that the higher wage-earners don't live in the city and therefore aren't paying taxes or spending money there," Mr. Riggs said. That, he said, has worked to erode the economic base of the inner cities.
Dr. George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of urban planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, said residency requirements tended to create a sense of "genuine community" among residents and employees of a municipality.
"The problem when municipal employees live elsewhere is that they really have no feeling for the community other than as an employee," Dr. Sternlieb said. "They may indeed even be alienated from the community."
Residents agree that their towns would be better served if employees had a greater stake in the life of the community by being residents.
 
'Just Burns You Out'
 "When cops and firemen and teachers live in the community where they work, they take more pride in the community," said Mercedes Babot, a Union City homeowner.
"The police can care less if 20 people are on a street corner making noise because they're not going to hear it when they're back in their nice little homes in Bergen County," Ms. Babot said. "And aren't police officers supposed to be on duty 24 hours a day?"
But Terence Gordon, president of Union City's police officers' union, said such expectations were unreasonable. "You're paying a police officer for eight hours," he said, "you're not paying him for 24 hours a day. So why should we be obligated to stay here 24 hours a day?
"Working in the city and living in the city just burns you out," Mr. Gordon said. "I've lived here all my life, but I'm trying to move out now."

HEADLINE: Sunday Brunch;
Chinatown Dim Sum: A Meal You Build Yourself

 BODY:
Dim sum remains one of the popular brunch choices downtown, and Chinatown is responding with more dim sum restaurants than ever. Over time, aficionados of this genre get to know particular restaurants, each of which has particular dim sum specialties. Some diners hop from place to place in constructing a meal. Here are four good examples of Chinatown's dim sum styles. 
Mandarin Court
61 Mott Street, at Canal Street, (212) 608-3838 -- Dim sum is fun, adventurous and economical: You can order as much or as little as you want and pay accordingly. Mandarin Court is one of the hottest dim sum spots in Chinatown. It is clean and contemporary, with pastel walls, sparkling tiles, sleek black tables and an open kitchen in front. On Sunday, the selection on the dim sum cart is fresh and varied. The dumplings are brightly seasoned and light, filled with sweet shrimp, scallops or delicious sweet-and-sour pork. Other options are turnip cake with Chinese sausage, roasted cubes of eggplant with a sweet hoisin sauce and fried scallops with a black pepper sauce. Some dishes on the menu emphasize minimal frying and lighter sauces: a seafood assortment in a pineapple boat, jumbo shrimp with mango and shrimp and scallops with pine nuts. For dessert, there are vanilla tapioca pudding, black sesame rolls and coconut Jell-O. Dim sum is $1.50 an item, and main courses range from $5.95 to $14.95. Sunday hours are 8 A.M. to midnight; dim sum is served from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M. (Diner's Journal, Feb. 3, 1989.)

 
HSF
 46 Bowery, Canal Street, (212) 374-1319 -- This clattering and colorful restaurant buzzes all day long, from its dim sum breakfast until midnight. The dining room is a gastronomic roller derby, with waiters spinning around the room behind carts overloaded with small portions of dumplings, roast duck, shredded chicken and all manner of shrimp, squid, pork, fish and pastries. The turnover at HSF is fast and furious, so the food is generally hot and fresh when you get it. Dishes on the regular menu include Peking duck, orange beef or chicken and whole roasted sea bass with a sweet-and-sour sauce. Dim sum ranges from $1.60 to $2.75 an item; main courses are $6.95 to $16.95. On Sundays dim sum is from 7:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. (Article, Dec. 23, 1988.) A branch of HSF offers a similar range of food at 578 Second Avenue, between 31st and 32d Streets, (212) 689-6969.

 
King Fung
 20 Elizabeth Street, at Canal Street, (212) 964-5256 -- This restaurant is about as close as you can get in New York to the feeling of a boisterous and colorful establishment in Hong Kong. Large circular tables may be occupied by three or four generations. This can be an amusing place if you are in the right mood, and some dishes on the budget-priced menu are first-rate. On Sundays, a dim sum menu is served for breakfast and lunch. The selection includes beef balls with watercress, steamed pork with bacon, fried shrimp, pork and vegetable dumplings and sweet-and-sour spareribs. Also on the menu are delicious whole Peking duck with pancakes, baked lobster Chinese style with soy sauce, scallions and black beans and whole roasted flounder with a ginger-scallion sauce. Dim sum items range from $1.60 to $2; main courses are $5 to $13. Sunday hours are 8 A.M. to 11 P.M., and dim sum is served from 8 A.M. to 2 P.M. (Article, Dec. 23, 1988.)

 
Oriental Pearl
 103-105 Mott Street, at Canal Street, (212) 219-8388 -- The main dining room at this sprawling 500-seat party palace is a carnival of ceramic statues, dragons with flashing eyes and colored lights. Oriental Pearl serves superior and wide-ranging dim sum for brunch with fried and steamed dumplings (shrimp, scallop, chicken and ham), shrimp cake with chives and spareribs with black bean sauce. Other selections on the regular menu include deep-fried shrimp with walnuts, scallops with black pepper sauce and broccoli, braised goose and taro root casserole and braised duck with mixed vegetables. For dessert, there is the traditional semisweet red bean soup or fruit. Dim sum is $1.60 to $2.95 an item; main courses are $6.95 to $14.95. Sunday service is from 8 A.M. to 11 P.M.; dim sum is served from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. (Review, April 28, 1989.)
 
 This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times, and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.
The Times Restaurant Line offers capsule reviews by cuisine, price and location (New York City and suburbs), from articles published in the last 18 months. Touch-tone telephones only: 1-900-988-0101 (75 a minute).

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Caution in the Coup's Aftermath

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
It is not quite the same as the Berlin Wall coming down. But the collapse of the hard-line coup in the Soviet Union last week is expected to send a new surge of confidence though Europe, giving some lift to the stock markets in the countries that will play a role in economic development of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
"It is the definitive death of Communism. The political risk of Communism has diminished, and that changes the whole outlook for Europe," said David Roche, international strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company in London. 
 Mr. Roche, who interrupted his vacation because of the coup, is now heading for the Soviet Union. But before he left London, he added to his portfolio to reflect the week's events, buying stocks like Mannesmann in Germany.
The return of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the political victory won by Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin and the humiliating defeat of the old-line Communists mean two things for the equity markets: The general risk factor added on for turmoil in the Soviet Union, especially in markets in Germany and Austria, is lower. Many stocks now will not look as expensive as they might have. And the outlook for capital gains from the development of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe is a little better again -- and a bit better balanced.
Market analysts don't expect a headlong rush of often unthinking buying that the market experienced after the Berlin Wall cracked in October 1989. In the sober reassessment since then, investors have learned how long and how risky the wait for those gains might be.
And analysts are quick to point out that the victory is a fragile one. The Soviet economy is in a shambles. If the economic reform does not bear some fruit quickly or if Mr. Gorbachev does not move fast enough, the mood and politics in the country could deteriorate rapidly.
But in the post-coup Soviet Union, with Boris Yeltsin playing a larger, if not equal political role, Mr. Gorbachev will have to move toward real economic development rather than try some faulty hybrid as before. Because of this change, analysts say, investments in the Soviet Union and investments in the companies that invest in the Soviet Union will all look more attractive.
Mr. Roche's bullishness isn't entirely new. In the case of Germany, he is talking his own book a little. He was increasing his investments in Germany earlier this year when many other brokers and fund managers were staying away and telling others to do so.
Still, there's no denying the sudden new allure. "I am sufficiently confident, and this brings us to a more bullish stance," Mr. Roche said.
A flow of capital toward Europe because of the dramatic events in the Soviet Union could also affect investment outlooks in the United States, some analysts believe. For one thing, it could take away some support from the stock markets. It could also weaken the dollar some in the near term.
"How much more potential is there in the U.S. market now compared to Europe over the next couple of months?" asked Jeffrey Loper of A.G. Edwards. His answer: None.
Other analysts also are noting that despite the euphoria following the failed coup, many of the same tired problems that financial markets faced before are still there. And these should not be forgotten.
One is that some markets are still expensive, including the United States and Germany. On the day of the coup, following a burst of panic selling that sent markets sharply down, analysts said that many markets looked better priced as a result of the declines. With the run-up in prices after the Soviet troops withdrew from Moscow and the coup leaders fled, that price advantage has all but evaporated.
By week's end, most of the major markets around the world had regained most or all of their lost ground. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,040.25, up 72.23 points since the coup. In London, the FT-SE 100 index closed at 2,640.7, a new record high and up 19.7 points since the coup. France's CAC-40 closed at 1,833.45, 13.14 points over the pre-coup level. Germany's DAX 30 index, which was hit the hardest, closed at 1,627.24, just 26.09 points below last Friday's level. Only in Japan, where the Nikkei 225 fell 450.43 Friday, did the index end far below (749 points) the pre-coup level.
Second, despite the Soviet events, the risk of higher interest rates in Germany has not gone away. The Bundesbank rate rise on August 15 clearly left room for ratcheting German rates up another notch.
Also, Japan is still in trouble. Granted, the Nikkei looks less expensive at its present levels, which are not too far above the lows hit during the Persian Gulf crisis. But the country's stock and bank scandals have undermined investor confidence. Tokyo analysts continue to speculate that the scandals could widen and that eventually Japan's Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, might have to resign.
Finally, the failed coup did nothing to alleviate the global shortage of capital. And if the West now begins to put more money into the Soviet Union, which appears to be a necessary element for success in the post-coup environment, it will only add to the strain.

HEADLINE: It Isn't the Paul Mozer They Knew

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Those who worked closely with Paul W. Mozer during his dazzling 12-year career at Salomon Brothers say they are shocked and baffled by the pivotal role he played in the bond scandal.
Though he traded Government securities with gusto, Mr. Mozer was not perceived, before this month, as a man who would cross the line into illegal or unethical activity. Many of Mr. Mozer's former colleagues said they were reserving judgement until he tells his story. Mr. Mozer, through his attorney, Lee Richards, has declined to comment. 
 But if, as the firm contends, Mr. Mozer submitted illegal bids at Treasury auctions, none of his former colleagues said they could understand why.
Mr. Mozer, a short, soft-spoken man who was the head of Salomon's Government bond desk until being dismissed last weekend, attacked his work as aggressively as he hit tennis balls on the private court outside his spacious weekend home in Sands Point, L.I.
"He runs down every ball he can," said one Salomon trader, who, like the six other current and former Salomon employees interviewed , insisted on anonymity. "He plays until he's exhausted." The trader said Mr. Mozer never resorted to cheating on line calls to win a match. "If anything," the trader said, "he's too lenient to the other guy."
"It's difficult for me to imagine he broke the law," said one Salomon trader. "It's not difficult for me to imagine that he would trade in an aggressive fashion within the boundaries of the law."
Paul William Mozer, who was born on April 23, 1955 in New York City, showed promise at an early age. A second-grade classmate at St. Mary's elementary school in Manhasset, L.I., who also became a Government bond trader, recalled that "he was one of the brightest kids in the class."
One of eight children raised by Robert Mozer, a labor lawyer, and his wife, Patricia, Mr. Mozer once had dreams of becoming a rock-and-roll drummer. He kept his hair long and straggly and enrolled at the Berklee College of Music in Boston in the fall of 1973. But though his interest in rock music has persisted -- a picture of guitar legend Jimi Hendrix was prominently affixed to the side of his desk at Salomon -- he soon decided that he had little talent. He transferred to Whitman College, in Walla Walla, Wash., where he majored in economics, edited the school newspaper and graduated in 1977.
After earning his master's degree at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern, Mr. Mozer joined Salomon's Chicago office. "Many people didn't like him," said one trader who worked with Mr. Mozer early on. "He set very high standards for himself. He expected a lot from other people."
In the summer of 1983, Mr. Mozer's life underwent two dramatic changes. In June, he married Francine Lee, whom he had met in the Salomon training program four years earlier (and who is now a principal in the fixed-income division at Morgan Stanley & Company).
Then, one month after his wedding, Mr. Mozer was transferred to the Government bond desk of Salomon's New York office.
There, he was admired for his intellect, his mastery of the markets, his shepherding of young traders and his composure under immense pressure. "I think, in the entire world of bond trading, he considered himself the best there is," one former colleague said. "And I think he is every bit as good as he assumed himself to be."
As a current Salomon employee put it, "This was not driven by personal gain, if this is true. There's a game here. And it was a desire to win the game."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
How Can We Save New York City?

 BODY:

Ron Silver
Actor and president of the Creative Coalition. 

Reestablish faith in the city's ability to improve things. We are overwhelmed by cynicism and a feeling that we can't do anything. We are able to overcome. There's a lot we could do: Start by reforming the State Legislature. It's corrupt to the bone. Limit legislative terms. Get people reinvolved in city politics. Find a creative solution to the city's racial problems. Get the Federal Government to assume responsibility for Medicaid. Revitalize Midtown. The main thing is to reduce cynicism. A lot of people think New York is a failed enterprise. It isn't.
 
Leonard Stern
Chairman of the Hartz Group.
 
The city has to send a signal to its two crucial industries -- tourism and people in commercial offices -- that New York is safe and attractive. The central business district is roughly the same as the central tourist district. That district has to be kept clean and safe. That's not expensive; it would probably cost less that $50 million a year. It would take a political will, because the outer boroughs would want a share of the budget, but the fact is, most businessmen and most tourists don't visit the outer boroughs.

Richard Ravitch
President of the Citizen's Budget Commission.
 
We must have a five-year fiscal plan involving the city and state that reflects trying honestly for credible, balanced budgets. They would have to include reductions in services and the allocation of the revenue burden, if necessary, to the largest tax base. The city and state have to work in a partnership.
 
Lloyd A. Williams
President of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce.
 
All city employees, especially uniformed employees, must be residents of New York City. Law enforcement officers, in particular, are on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week, but they're only on duty in the city during the workweek. That means that upwards of 70 percent of their call time goes to their own community. There is an economic spinoff of having a police officer living on the block. People feel safer; they will spend more in their neighborhood.

Lady Miss Kier and DJ Dmitry
Members of the rock group Deee-lite.

Instead of warehousing vacant city property with the hope of selling it in a depressed market, encourage the expansion of the homesteading program for hardworking, serious New Yorkers. There are thousands of applicants who are willing to be involved in a 4- to 5-year homesteading program who are turned down because of city policies. It's a permanent solution to homelessness that will boost morale.

Thomas B. Stoddard
Executive director, Lambda Legal Defense Fund.
 
If New York City really wishes to assure its future, it must face up to the issue of poverty. The city should concentrate its efforts on children. Remake the public school system.

Sung Soo Kim
President of the Korean-American Small Business Service Center of New York.

New York's 195,000 small businesses are the backbone of the city: the prime source of neighborhood manpower, taxes -- and they are the first steps of livelihood for new immigrants. City government has made us a cash cow. We need risk-taking, creative leadership rather than a caretaker government.

Danny Wintrode
Hairdresser.
 
If there were more severe punishments, there would be less money spent on jails. The money could be put into more beneficial means of bringing the city back.

We have to try to regain the city's blue-collar economy by recreating a major port in New York. We can do that by reconnecting the city to the rest of the United States by rail freight. Everything now is transported from New York by truck, and the cost of getting freight in and out of the city by truck is tremendous. It has probably cost us 800,000 to 900,000 jobs in the last 25 years. Despite our natural geographic advantages, the Port of New York lags behind Baltimore and Norfolk, Va.

A tax cut would give us a reason to party.

 New York is is a first-world city but it is also a third-world city. We need a program to stimulate new small businesses, especially in production industries. City and state government should identify native skills and match them with industrial and market needs; persuade banks to make guaranteed low-interest loans, and impose commercial rent control to make cheap space available.

"Penn and Teller Rot in Hell" is at the John Houseman theater in New York.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference/The Soviet Coup;
Getting the News By Electronic Mail

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
When Esther Dyson got to her Manhattan office early last Monday she found a fax from friends in Siberia saying that despite the political situation, their trip was continuing. Ms. Dyson, publisher of Release 1.0, a leading computer industry newsletter, didn't think anything of it until she got an electronic mail message a few minutes later referring to the dramatic turn of events in Moscow. Then she decided she had better read the newspapers.
Ms. Dyson has a particular stake in the continuing success of Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost and perestroika. 
 In 1989, she traveled to the Soviet Union to make contacts with people from the country's fledgling personal computer industry. Since then, she has been back to Eastern Europe more than a dozen times in what has become something of a personal crusade. Her goal: to transplant the entrepreneurship of the American PC business to the nascent capitalist economies of the Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries.
Ms. Dyson first wrote extensively about developments in Soviet software design, and now publishes Rel-East, a version of her newsletter oriented to Eastern Europe.
She also invited a Soviet group to attend her annual computer industry conference in the United States in 1989. Last year, she held an Eastern European version of the conference in Budapest. The meeting, called the East-West High-Tech Forum, attracted nearly 200 computer executives from throughout Europe and the United States. Ms. Dyson has scheduled a second conference for Warsaw in November.
The failed coup will have a positive impact on Western investors, said Ms. Dyson, who is 40 years old and runs her various enterprises through a company called Edventure Holdings Inc.
"Most of the business people who are over there are delighted that they've put their money in," she said. "Now the stuff people were scared of has happened and has been shown not to be a threat."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference/The Soviet Coup;
The Kremlinologist of Oil

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The coup in Moscow last week briefly revived Kremlinology, the pre-glasnost art of interpreting the Soviet Union from the scattered clues that emerge from a totalitarian facade. One of the experts to whom the American press and the business community turned for guidance was Thane Gustafson, a Georgetown University professor of government.
Mr. Gustafson said that he began his study of Soviet politics in 1964, the year Khrushchev fell, and as a result, "I felt right at home" last week. 
 Mr. Gustafson's specialty is the oil industry, which provides about 70 percent of the Soviet Union's foreign exchange and has lately been in sharp decline.
In a recent book on Soviet oil, "Crisis Amid Plenty," Mr. Gustafson wrote that efforts to maintain production in the late 1970's had sucked up most of the Soviet Union's capital, causing stagnation in the rest of Soviet industry.
Oil continues to be near the heart of the Soviet Union's problems. It is a key source of tension between the republics and the central government over who should control its development. And twice in the last year, Mr. Gustafson said, authorities have "bought off" restive oil workers with extra allocations of imported food and manufactured goods, to the resentment of other workers.
Mr. Gustafson, who is 47, started in the Soviet energy field as an analyst at the Rand Corporation, getting interested when Ronald Reagan put an embargo on natural gas pipeline technology in 1981 after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.
Later, he headed Soviet studies at Georgetown's Center for Strategic and International Studies. A graduate of the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana, where he studied political science and chemistry, and a Peace Corps volunteer in the Ivory Coast, he spent the 1970's at Harvard, first getting a doctorate in political science and then teaching.
This month, he began a leave of absence from Georgetown to become the director of Soviet studies at Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: Continental, Still Digesting General Tire, Battles Pirelli

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

DATELINE: HANOVER, Germany

 BODY:
Heinrich Huinink, director of tire research at Continental A.G., boasts about the state-of-the-art computer equipment used to design the company's next generation of tires. And he's proud of Continental's commitment to spend 5 percent of its sales -- more than most tire companies -- on research and development this year. But when asked about the tire maker's expenditures for next year, Mr. Huinink hedges: "That all depends on what happens with our company."
Such reservations are fairly common these days at the world's fourth-largest tire producer. While consolidation in the $50 billion global tire industry has reduced capacity by 15 percent in the last decade, tire prices have continued to sag. Continental is still struggling with its 1987 acquisition of General Tire of Akron, Ohio, whose losses cut Continental's earnings by more than half last year, to $62.7 million on sales approaching $6 billion. 
 The biggest uncertainty stems from a year-long takeover tussle with Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy, the world's fifth-largest tire maker. The Pirelli question has divided the Continental board; cost a chief executive, who refused to consider the proposal, his job; demoralized the work force and left customers in the lurch.
Now, the problems sit squarely in the lap of Hubertus von Grunberg, who took over as Continental's chief executive last month. The 48-year-old Mr. von Grunberg, formerly president and chief executive of ITT Automotive Inc., is not forthcoming about just how he plans to see Continental through its crisis, although the need for clarity is undeniable.
"Uncertainty about Continental's future has the risk of costing us management talent in every rank," Mr. von Grunberg said. "And if our people don't get frustrated and insecure enough to quit, they are certainly too concerned about the future of their jobs to care about beating the competition and serving the customer."
Mr. von Grunberg says he intends to meet with customers to assure them of the company's stability. Otherwise, he said, "our customers might feel they prefer Michelin and Goodyear."
But his most pressing mission is to resolve the Pirelli affair. "We have to get this thing settled one way or another," he said.
People at Continental are sure Mr. von Grunberg is more partial to some sort of cooperative agreement than to a merger. The idea of taking on additional debt at a time when tire prices are weak and General Tire is still a drain is not very appealing. And few of the other tire mergers of the late 80's have yet to pay off in increased profits.

BUT Mr. von Grunberg may have trouble keeping Continental independent. Pirelli has been a tenacious suitor. Last September, itproposed that the German tire maker buy its tire business in an unusually convoluted and complex deal for roughly 2 billion deutsche marks, more than $1 billion. Although the German company would be financing the takeover, Pirelli would have had controlling interest of Continental. It contends that because neither company holds more than 8 percent of the world tire market, a merger is necessary for survival. A merger, it claims, would create total, one-time cost savings of more than $600 million.
Horst Urban, then Continental's chief executive, rejected the proposal, claiming that projected savings were vastly exaggerated. Besides, he said, Continental was already achieving efficiency on its own with recent acquisitions in Sweden, Portugal and Britain and expansions in western and eastern Europe. It is now talking with producers in Czechoslovakia and Poland about alliances.
Spurned, Pirelli formed an investor group to buy a controlling interest in Continental's stock. It now holds 5 percent of Continental's shares and claims that another 46 percent are in friendly hands.
In response, the German tire maker put together its own backers to form a defense pool that includes Daimler-Benz, Allianz and Volkswagen, which together hold 25 percent of Continental's stock.
In a major victory for Pirelli, Continental's shareholders refused at the annual meeting earlier this year to approve an amendment to the German tire maker's bylaws limiting voting rights to shareholders with at least a 5 percent share. And when Mr. Urban threatened to resign unless the board supported every effort to deter Pirelli, the directors, apparently unhappy with what they saw as an uncompromising attitude, accepted his resignation.
To be sure, a combination of Continental and Pirelli would create some notable strengths. Continental is particularly strong in central and eastern Europe and has a significant foothold in North America -- all areas where Pirelli is relatively weak. And Continental is the leading supplier of both truck and passenger tires to Mercedes, Volkswagon and BMW, supplying about 40 percent of their needs.
Pirelli, in turn, dominates the Italian and southern European markets and has an important position in South America. It has also carved a sizable piece of the high-performance niche -- it supplies about 15 percent of the worldwide market for racing and sports-car tires.
But Mr. Urban, chief executive of Continental for four of his 17 years with the company, argued that some of Pirelli's plants were in worse shape than Continental's and that combining the two companies would provide more problems than it might solve. "The tire market is going down everywhere in the world because of heavy cost problems, overcapacity and major losses," he said in a recent interview. "Any student of business knows that you don't do such a combination under such weak economic circumstances. It should be done when the market is in an upswing."
Continental executives were also discouraged by the results of other giant combinations in the industry. In large part because of its 1988 acquisition of the Chicago-based Firestone Tire & Rubber Company, Japan's Bridgestone saw its earnings fall by half last year. Investments by Groupe Michelin of France into modernizing and streamlining Uniroyal-Goodrich of Akron, which it bought in 1989, contributed to a big loss in 1990.
With its aging plants and less-than-stellar efficiency, General Tire has also been a drag on Continental's earnings. Without General Tire's losses, Continental's decline in earnings would have been relatively minor. (Even so, Continental's earnings have still been better than most of its rivals.) Declining auto output and price competition in the United States is expected to translate into a $100 million loss at General Tire this year.
"Continental also tried very hard to move General more aggressively into selling their brand labels into the replacement market and de-emphasizing private labels," said Harry W. Millis, an independent tire analyst in Akron. "That didn't work very well."
Pirelli has similar problems. Outbid by Bridgestone in an effort to buy Firestone, Pirelli settled instead for Armstrong Tire -- at the time, the fifth-largest American tire producer. Pirelli's earnings dropped 52 percent last year, leading to a management shakeup. In June, Pirelli's board forced out the managing director and the general manager of its tire sector.
Together, the mergers have done little to restore the industry to health. Mr. Millis estimates that there is still about 20 percent excess capacity in North America and 15 percent in Europe. As a result, car producers, hit by sagging demand in the United States and some areas of Europe, have been able to drive down tire prices by more than 20 percent in the last year.
And a merger of Pirelli and Continental would do little to reduce overcapacity because the two companies' operations have little overlap. "There is no reason to believe that the combination would bring any more control over pricing than any of the other mergers," said Stephen M. Reitman, an analyst with UBS Phillips & Drew Ltd. in London.

MEANWHILE, Mr. von Grunberg's appointment has sent mixed signals about the board's intentions. Mr. Urban's ouster signaled to many that Continental wanted to further explore talks with Pirelli. Still, Mr. von Grunberg's vast experience as a senior industrial executive makes it unlikely that he would be summoned to prepare Continental to submit to a merger.
For his part, Mr. von Grunberg grudgingly admits that there are economies of scale to be achieved from some form of combination. "There are probably some ways in which there could be benefits from some sort of cooperation," he said.
There are those who agree. "Depending on what a combination represents," said Stanley C. Gault, chairman of Goodyear, "it could result in a stronger competitor."
Mr. von Grunberg insists that he was attracted to the job largely by the prospect of Continental's independence. "On the other hand," he said, "once you take a job, you can only look forward and not be too selfish. You have to live up to your responsibility to the shareholders, the customers and the employees. If I am convinced that their best interest requires me to be in a situation that is not ideal for myself, I would consider accepting it."
 
 
 
A NEW MAN TAKES ON THE ITALIAN CHALLENGE
 While Hubertus von Grunberg talks as though he is willing to consider all possible linkages with Pirelli, he is a man who, at the same time, speaks enthusiastically about the prospect of leading an independent Continental. "The tire industry, to put it mildly, is not the world's most profitable industrial segment," he said. "And this was one of the challenges in taking this job."
Mr. von Grunberg was born in 1943 in Swinemunde, East Prussia, which is now part of Poland. He studied mathematics and physics at the University of Cologne and joined ITT Automotive Inc. in 1971 at its brake-making subsidiary, Alfred Teves G.m.b.H. in Frankfurt.
He brings to Continental a reputation as a top-notch industrial manager with extensive experience in both the international and German automotive markets. Before becoming president and chief executive of ITT, he worked in Brazil and in the United States in various industrial management jobs with the company.
"Mr. von Grunberg is an internationally minded executive who is completely familiar with the automotive business in Europe and America," said Dennis Phillips, a spokesman for Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt. "Given the brutal international competition and price wars in the tire market, that is a good thing for Continental. The trend in the tire business is clearly toward internationalization, and I think he was picked to take them in that direction."
Although many analysts have insisted that his appointment signaled a shift in Continental's attitude toward a merger, Mr. von Grunberg is vehement about the fact that he has no hidden agenda. "There are no marching orders, no hidden agenda," he added. "I am truly open to anything."
