HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
More Eggs, in Balanced Baskets

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Investors, if you're agonizing over which mutual fund to buy, relax: Picking a single fund isn't nearly as important as building a solid portfolio of funds.
Funds, investing as they do in various securities, are diverse by nature. Putting your money in a variety of them, then, just adds to the diversity, smoothing out rough market ups and downs. The two keys: allocating assets to suit your wants and needs, and taking the long view -- a particularly important exercise as volatility becomes a fixture in the financial markets. 
 The idea behind asset allocation is simple: dividing a portfolio among a variety of investments to reduce risk and increase total return. "Most people tend to ignore the whole concept," said Gerald W. Perritt, an investment adviser and editor of the Mutual Fund Letter in Chicago. In fact, many investors own a hodge-podge of funds bought at various times without much thought as to how the agglomeration of funds complement each other.
As for the long view, it may be a rare bird who bought in 1926 and held through 1990, but as the chart shows, there are distinct patterns among investments.
All the broad categories beat inflation in the 65-year period covered, but some a lot more than others. The basic investing rule: the greater the risk, the greater the return. Low-risk United States Government bonds earned only 1.7 percent each year after inflation. That is why investment advisers urge long-term investors to keep a big chunk of their holdings in higher-risk, higher-yield stocks. In that category, the highest-risk is small-company stocks, which outdid inflation by 13.9 percentage points. Careful, though. The return is skewed by a whopping 142.9 percent gain recorded in 1933; so if you weren't invested as the Depression ended, you missed a bit.
On the other hand, while a bust year in stocks can make the slow-but-steady bond look like a good thing, bonds are actually riskier than stocks in some shorter periods, according to Kenneth E. Gregory, an investment adviser in San Francisco and editor of the L/G No-Load Fund Analyst. Over 50 five-year periods since 1929, some of which overlap each other in part, stocks returned 7.2 percent after inflation. Bonds gained only six-tenths of 1 percent and trailed inflation 40 percent of the time. Meanwhile, stocks trailed inflation only 20 percent of the time and beat bonds in 82 percent of the periods.
All depends, of course, on the chunk of money available to invest and your stomach for risk. For conservative investors who can tolerate occasional yearly losses of 5 percent, the best bet is a portfolio of one-third stocks and two-thirds bonds, Mr. Gregory says. For investors who can tolerate a rare year when losses exceed 10 percent -- say, once every 25 years -- stocks should make up 70 percent of the portfolio, he says.
Mr. Perritt recommends that investors split their holdings among six types of assets: domestic and international stocks and bonds, gold and money-market funds.
As a rule of thumb, two or three funds in each of the six basic categories is plenty. By getting into too many, investors end up owning the entire market. And for market rates of return, investors are better off buying index funds because they usually have much lower expenses.
The returns for different classes of assets rarely move in tandem, meaning you can choose how to balance one likely performance against another. Mr. Parritt built a matrix to illustrate the point. A score of 1 means that two investments tend to move in tandem. The farther from 1, the more diverse the movements.
He found a relatively high correlation of .66 between foreign and domestic stocks, and a lesser correlation of .50 between foreign bonds and United States Government bonds. Domestic stocks and bonds scored .40, and small-company stock versus large capitalization stocks, .70.
Domestic bonds and gold have a correlation of minus .30 percent, meaning they tend to move in opposite directions. Thus, Mr. Perrit recommends that bond fund investors keep a small amount of their portfolios in gold funds, as insurance.
Mr. Gregory says that within the stock-fund portion of the portfolio, investors may also want to consider mixing investment styles. For middle-of-the road investors, he would divide stock fund holdings among four categories.
Among value funds, Mr. Gregory likes Gabelli Asset, Selected American Shares, and Mutual Beacon. Among small-company funds, he likes GIT Equity Special, Nicholas Limited Edition and Babson Enterprise. He also recommends three aggressive earnings growth funds -- Brandywine, 20th Century Heritage, Janus Venture -- and one conservative growth fund -- Counsellors Capital Appreciation.
After constructing a portfolio of funds, an investor should monitor its progress and adjust it as needed -- selling that which has appreciated most, buying that which hasn't yet performed. Mr. Perritt says once a year is enough; anything more than quarterly smacks of overactive trading.

HEADLINE: The Strange Case of the Czech Crown

 BODY:
To the Editor:
News media reports imply that politicians in Czechoslovakia are holding up conversion to a free-market economy for fear of being tossed out of office. I recently made a one-week trip for a scientific conference in Prague (where I studied medicine 50 years ago) and saw a different and far more complex reality. 
 The new regime in Prague contains no Communists and is eager to add free exchange of goods to the unhampered free exchange of ideas. The problem is how to bridge the gulf between an economy operating in Czechoslovak crowns and the economies of the Western countries.
Internally, the economy is capable of feeding its people and maintaining a high level of artistic, literary and scientific output. A professor at Charles University and his working wife can live and entertain foreign visitors in his pleasant home at a salary of 5,000 crowns a month, buying new hardbound books for 35 crowns, paying 2 crowns for the Prague subway or other public transportation. Internally, 1 crown is about equal to $1.
However, the rate of exchange is 30 crowns to $1. A daily newspaper printed in Western Europe costs 35 crowns.
To introduce free exchange of goods with Western Europe would require raising Czechoslovak salaries and prices thirtyfold to maintain the current standard of living. Not only foreign investments, but also foreign cash would be needed for such a move. If we truly believe a free market economy solves the problems introduced by Communism, small Czechoslovakia would be an ideal laboratory for proving that proposition.
The Czechoslovaks have a democratic tradition going back to Jan Hus, burned at the stake in 1415 for preaching in Czech against the sale of indulgences by papal representatives in Prague. Czechoslovakia was a model capitalistic democracy during its independence (1918-38). Its 12 million people have the reputation of being hard-working realists.
The necessary foreign funds would be a fraction of the $100 billion said to be needed to save the Soviet economy. At a cost of, say, $9 billion, a Czechoslovak Marshall Plan would be a virtually sure bet to serve as a model for conversion to a free market economy in neighboring Poland, Hungary and the Soviet Union.
The onetime expenditure would equal 3 percent of our annual military budget.
 
GEORGE BRECHER
Berkeley, Calif., Aug. 4, 1991

HEADLINE: No, India Can't Keep Up With Japan, but Neither Can the U.S.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Aug. 6 report on the changes made in India by the new Prime Minister, P. V. Narasimha Rao, contains misleading implications. 
 You describe the "hallowed traditions" on which modern India was founded as "mainly the virtues of state socialism." This is inaccurate. India has always been a capitalist democracy. Leaders like Jawaharlal Nehru were avowed socialists, but socialists in the Western European sense: committed democrats who believed in state intervention to humanize some of the ills of capitalism.
More important, you describe India's economy as in "desperate straits," or as a "collapsing system." India indeed has a serious balance-of-payment problem, but such descriptions are nonsense. India's economy grew at nearly 5 percent a year through the 1980's, including last year. Industrial growth in this period was well above 7 percent, nearing 8 percent in 1990. Inflation has been high by Indian standards (approximately 9 percent a year in 1985-90), but minuscule compared with, say, many Latin American countries.
Exports have grown at more than 5 percent a year in the last decade, and domestic food production has been satisfactory. This is not a dazzling performance, and much is wrong with the Indian economy: an inefficient public sector, excessive government controls, large budget deficits and massive poverty. But this does not add up to a collapsing economy.
You lament India's economic performance compared with its "dynamic Asian neighbors." If Japan and the East Asian dragons are the global growth yardstick, India pales in comparison -- but so does the United States and much of the rest of the world. In the third world, India's economic performance is middling, rather than poor; well behind East Asia's, but it compares very favorably with much of Africa's and, during the debt-ridden 1980's, was better than that of most Latin American countries.
It is fashionable to tie "economic failure" to government intervention and socialism, and to look to market liberalism and unobtrusive states for "economic success." The reality is more complex.
 
ATUL KOHLI
Prof. of Politics & Intl. Affairs, Woodrow Wilson School, Princeton U.
Princeton, N.J., Aug. 12, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: PLAN TO DEVELOP AMAZON A FAILURE

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARIQUEMES, Brazil

 BODY:
Fifteen years ago, Maria Luisa de Oliveira Dias hiked down a jungle trail here to claim a 250-acre wood lot under an ambitious plan to colonize the Amazon.
Today, she wishes she had never left her home in southern Brazil. Plantings of corn and rice withered in the sandy soil. Rubber trees never produced latex. And coffee prices are so low that income this year for her family of four adults will be less than $1,000. 
 A decade after the World Bank helped pave a road through a stretch of wilderness that became Rondonia state, Brazil's most ambitious Amazon colonization plan has failed.
"People are abandoning the countryside," Francisco Jose Silveira Pereira, the state Environmental Secretary, said in the state capital, Porto Velho. "In 1980, Rondonia was 70 percent rural. Today, it is 60 percent urban."
 
Lured by Promises
 In the 1970's and 1980's, Government promises of free land lured more than 100,000 farm families from overcrowded areas of southern Brazil, the nation's breadbasket. In the ensuing land rush, about one quarter of Rondonia was stripped of trees, and imported disease decimated the Indian population, which dropped from 35,000 in 1965 to 6,000 today.
But countering Government predictions, only 9 percent of this Colorado-sized state proved capable of sustaining agriculture. Today, Mr. Pereira estimated, about 60 percent of the cleared area is being lost to brush and secondary growth forest.
"For the first time, you drive around the colonization areas and see abandoned farms and 'for sale' signs," said John O. Browder, a regional planning professor at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, who has been studying one municipality, Rolim de Moura, for the last decade. "Overgrown fields are now the dominant feature of the rural landscape."
 
The Season for Burning
 Wim Groenveld, a Dutch ecologist who runs an environmental study center in Porto Velho, said: "There are not many new roads opening up, not many new settlements. The newcomers have seen it is not worthwhile." Indeed, as the annual burning season now begins in the Western Amazon, the acrid wood scent hanging in the air comes largely from landowners' burning brush to keep fields open for pastureland.
From the open door of a helicopter flying on a recent afternoon near Porto Velho, a wall of fire and smoke could be seen advancing across a field cluttered with bushes and scrub trees.
"That's all second growth," Alberto Paraguassu, state coordinator of a federal Amazon fire-prevention program, shouted over the clattering rotors of the helicopter rented by Brazil's Environmental Protection Agency.
Indeed, world concern over Amazon deforestation has reached here, accelerating an end to Rondonia's frenetic, frontier atmosphere.
 
Frustrated by Controls
 Citing environmentl pollution, Rondonia's new Governor, Osvaldo Piana, shut down mining operations in two areas this month: gold mining by 300 barges on a 125-mile section of the Madeira River near Porto Velho and tin mining here at Bom Futuro, the world's largest tin mine.
"The Government doesn't let us cut the timber," Jose Scarmocin, a tin mine operator, complained, echoing a growing frustration with environmental controls. "Now we can't work the mine. What can we do?"
Logging continues in areas where Indian leaders have sold timber rights, largely in reserves of the Surui and of the Cinta Larga. But the state government is installing a satellite monitoring system to detect invasions of Indian lands. To help analysts of satellite photographs, boundary lines that cross forest are to be demarcated by clearings spaced every mile.
"The Surui are addicted to timber sales," said Mr. Pereira, whose environmental reponsibilities include Indian affairs. "But the Uru-eu-wau-wau ask us to get the white man out of their area."
Contributing to grumbling by some white settlers, the 700 survivors of the Uru-eu-wau-wau tribe are winning legal recognition of rights to a 7,075-square-mile reserve.
"Today, agriculture in the state is practically bankrupt, and in the mining sector, there is total anarchy with mines abruptly closed," the state's largest newspaper, O Estadao, complained in a front-page editorial. "Now we are suffering from this plague of the 'untouchable Amazon forest.' "

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Riverfront Clubs Bloom

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE

 BODY:
FINANCING difficulties may be stalling much of the residential and office development on the Delaware River, but a former industrial area is blossoming with new restaurants and nightclubs.
One of the new clubs, the $1 million Katmandu, an outdoor restaurant and bar, was a response to the recession by two developers, Lance Silver and Stuart Harting of Philadelphia. It opened in mid- May on Delaware Avenue. A Katmandu partner, David Preefer, said recreation is a natural use for the river's edge about a mile east of the central business district. 
 Farther north on Delaware Avenue, the Beach Club, a bar and restaurant, has a sandy volleyball court in the shadow of a former sugar refinery and dormant warehouse stores.
And Dale Lalwani, owner of the neighboring Aztec Club, plans to build a restaurant and miniature golf course in the section of Delaware Avenue north of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge. Mr. Lalwani refitted a former warehouse as a 6,600-square-foot dance club complete with a smoke-breathing dragon. He said he felt the area "would be the next to develop because overhead is low and parking is not a problem."
South of the bridge, bracketing the 37-acre, mixed-use Penn's Landing site, one of two high-rise housing projects Portside and Liberty Landing, appears highly doubtful. The developer of the projected 286-unit Portside residential condominium, Asbell & Associates of Philadelphia, once the lead partner in the Penn's Landing complex, for the present plans to build only a $6 million floating restaurant at Penn's Landing.
Down payments by Portside condominium buyers have been returned and Asbell is suing its lender, Equibank, saying it failed to honor a commitment to provide working capital and loan extensions for the project. Portside itself is on the back burner because of a lack of funds.
The $300 million Liberty Landing, a mixed-use project, is being redesigned by its developers, a consortium of riverfront landowners, to moderate its elements as well as what it will ask for its apartments.
Rick Widerman, director of urban leasing for Bell Atlantic Properties, said his firm is developing a master plan for the four piers it owns north of the bridge. He said the nightclubs have made the waterfront a regular part of Philadelphia life.
"A funny thing has happened," Mr. Widerman said. "The time for the waterfront has arrived, but the time for large-scale development has passed."

HEADLINE: TENSION IN BROOKLYN;
For Young Blacks, Alienation and a Growing Despair Turn Into Rage

BYLINE: By Felicia R. Lee; This article is based on reporting by Felicia R. Lee and Sara Rimer and was written by Ms. Lee.

 BODY:
It was late at night in the Albany Houses project in Crown Heights when a group of young black men got the word that a white man had killed a black child.
"Someone said, 'let's go,' " said Lance, a 19-year-old resident of the project who refused to give his last name. He and his friends headed for Utica Avenue and President Street, the scene of the car accident that had killed the child. "I helped flip over a police car," Lance said. "It made me feel like I scored a point. One of the guys I was with yelled at one of the cops that was there, 'You want to see how strong the black man is?' "
 
A Chance to Express Rage
 For Lance and for many others in Crown Heights last week, the disturbance was a chance to express their rage. 
 Some of the more than 30 young black Crown Heights residents interviewed on Friday said they had thrown rocks and bottles in protest over the death on Monday of Gavin Cato, the black child hit by a car driven by a Hasidic Jew. Others said they were retaliating against the police because of unfair treatment in the past. Some said it was simply something to do on a summer night.
Others did not participate in the violence but said they were in the streets to protest the circumstances of their lives: the joblessness, the poor schools, the ever-present violence. They said they felt alienated from most New Yorkers.
 A few said that they had stayed home, that they condemned the violence and that they were trying to continue with their everyday lives.
 
Grievances Against Whites
 But in conversation after conversation, men and women in their early 20's, teen-agers and younger children expressed the feeling that "they" -- meaning whites in general -- have lives vastly superior to their own.
They contend this is true because white people get special breaks and because blacks are discriminated against. For them, the relative prosperity of the Hasidim -- the white people with whom they are in closest contact -- bears out that notion.
Young men talked of white women clutching their purses when they approached, of joblessness, of police brutality and of the lack of fathers in families. Young women talked of men who took out their frustrations on them, of the pains of early motherhood and of schools where they did not learn much except low self-esteem. Both men and women said they felt that they had far fewer opportunities than white people, and that they believed people outside their community looked down on them.
 
'When We See Blue, We Get Mad'
 For many, the greatest enemy of all are the police, because they are considered the symbol of a repressive and hostile white society.
"I'm sorry; I just don't like white people," Lance said. A graduate of Boys and Girls High and the father of two, Lance said he learned to hate whites in prison in upstate New York, where he said he was recently released after serving nearly two years for attempted murder. Most of the guards were white, he said, and they treated him badly.
"We're black," said Jeff, a 20-year-old born in Martinique who grew up and lives in Crown Heights. He would also not give his last name. "When we see blue, we get mad."
"There's a lot of things people don't know," said Jeff, a high school dropout who reads the works of Marcus Garvey and Malcolm X. "The jails are awful and they're full of young black kids," he said. "This isn't against the Jews. It's against the police."
 
The Views of a Group of Boys
 Seven boys, 12 to 14 years old, were sitting on a stoop in the neighborhood Friday afternoon, talking and laughing about the last few nights. They bragged about throwing rocks and bottles. None gave their names.
"It made me feel strong because we were with a lot of black people," a 12-year-old said.
"It was fun, throwing bottles at the cops," a 13-year-old said. The boys said they had studied the civil rights movement in school, but they seemed to have little identification with it. Asked what they thought of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a 13-year-old said: "I don't admire him. He let black people get beat up."
On an ordinary summer night, the boys said, they would have been home watching television or hanging out on the stoop. The disturbance gave them something to do.
Indeed, there are very few things for youths to do in the neighborhood. "You'd like to go to the park and take out some frustration on the basketball court, but there are no rims on the court," said Henry Rice, a 22-year-old who said he escaped his environment by joining the Coast Guard, where he is now in the Reserves.
"Some of these people have nothing to lose, so they go for it," he said. "I have a lot of lose. I have a daughter. I can't do her any good in jail."
A 12-year-old, who said she had hurled bricks at the police, described most of the rioters as boys trying to act like men.
"But they not no men," she insisted. "They treat females like dirt. You get a baby by these guys and the next day they don't know your name."
 
Violence Hits Many Families
 Mr. Rice said many young rioters were not afraid of the police or anyone else. He said many had seen their friends and family members killed on the streets of Brooklyn.
As for the contention that they are destroying their own community, Mr. Rice said many young adults had little regard for the graffiti-scarred and gang-infested places they are forced to call home.
Many of those interviewed lead lives almost as insular as those of the Hasidic Jews, whose religion severely circumscribes their interaction with society. Poverty and segregation mean that many young blacks do not know any white people, that some have never traveled to Manhattan or visited a museum, and that many do not know anyone they consider successful.
"We can't win for losing with this system," said Monique Peterson, 19, who was hit in the ankle by a brick during one riot. "I don't know too many people making it out there."
Others said few public officials visit their neighborhoods except when something bad happens, and they have few opportunities to express their feelings about anything. The recession that has hurt middle-class New Yorkers has devastated their already-struggling neighborhood and cut off Federal dollars for youth programs and community development.
"It's hell," said Scott Coleman, an unemployed 20-year-old. "Unemployment, first of all. As soon as they see you with a dark complexion, you're no good. If you're a black baby, you're marked.
"I was raised by just my mother," Mr. Coleman said. "My father was down south in Alabama. No visits, no support. I didn't go no further than high school. My mind wasn't set to it. I just didn't feel I was ready for it."
Mr. Coleman recalled that as a ninth-grader at George Wingate High School, he was arrested, charged with assault and held in jail for hours. Even though he was released after the police acknowledged that they had arrested the wrong person, he said he felt sullied and vulnerable.
"All the police knew that it was a black man in a black skin," he said of his arrest. "People are just tired of it -- tired of feeling they're being pushed around. It's a shame you've got to wait for something like this to happen to express your feelings."
For Tracy Belton, who grew up in Crown Heights with her mother and three brothers -- she has not seen her father in 10 years -- the disturbance was a political protest. She did not particpate in the violence, but she was angry because of her belief that Hasidic Jews get preferential treatment.
Ms. Belton, a 21-year-old junior at Long Island University, concedes that for others it was simply a chance to express anger against the police.
"There can be a group of guys on the corner and a cop car can go by and throw people against the wall and arrest them for no reason," Ms. Belton said. She said things became so bad that two of the brothers left New York City for South Carolina.
 
Rare Chance to Be Heard
 Jeff, who dreams of being a hotel manager in Martinique, said a meeting at Medgar Evers College that called Friday by the Crown Heights Youth Collective provided him with a rare chance to be heard.
"The American Dream is something you see on TV," he said. "But you can't have it. I've worked in restaurants, doing housekeeping, construction, making $200 a week. Some of my friends are making $200 a day selling drugs. Who's the better man?"
Jeff seemed sad, as did many of the other young people interviewed.
"I'm lost," he said as he walked away. "I don't know what I'm doing."

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
GORBACHEV QUITS AS PARTY HEAD; ENDS COMMUNISM'S 74-YEAR REIGN

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 24

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev resigned today as the head of the Communist Party, disbanded its leadership and in effect banned the once monolithic party from any role in ruling the vast country over which it had held iron control for more than seven decades.
With Communism under brutal assault across the Soviet Union and his own leadership in shambles in the aftermath of a coup attempt, Mr. Gorbachev abandoned his efforts to defend party leaders who had obviously collaborated in the putsch and finally dealt the party a fatal blow. 
 By doing so, Mr. Gorbachev seemed to be seeking some way of remaining a credible political force, something that would have been impossible if he had not repudiated the party.
 
Committee Replaces Cabinet
 In a series of terse statements and decrees read on the evening television program "Vremya," the President also ordered the Cabinet of Ministers, the inner government council, to resign. He then created a committee headed by the Premier of the Russian federated republic, Ivan Silayev, a close aide of the republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, to take charge of the national economy.
This was part of an arrangement worked out by Mr. Yeltsin, who has emerged as the country's leading political figure since the coup attempt.
The committee includes Grigory V. Yavlinsky, a leading advocate of radical economic change in the country, auguring the long-awaited introduction of a sharp turn to a free-market economy. Other members of the committee are Arkady Volsky, head of an association of private and state-owned enterprise, and Yuri Luzhkov, a supporter of fundamental change who is head of the Moscow city council.
 
Surrender to Liberals
 The moves, announced at the end of another day filled with emotional and fast-paced developments arising from the coup, signaled a virtually complete surrender by Mr. Gorbachev to the liberal and democratic forces who had defied the coup and rescued him.
The actions were accompanied by continued turmoil in the Soviet republics, as Mr. Yeltsin accorded formal recognition to the independence of two more Baltic republics and the Parliament of the Ukraine, the nation's second-largest republic, delcared its independence and set a referendum for Dec. 1 to endorse it.
Mr. Gorbachev also ordered the Soviet Parliament to take all Communist Party property into custody until its future was decided "in strict compliance with Soviet and republican law."
Mr. Gorbachev did not disband the Communist Party, nor did he say he was resigning from the party himself. But in sweeping out its leadership, handing its vast properties to the mercies of democratically elected parliaments and thrusting it out of all federal government and security organs, he in effect decapitated the 15 million-member organization and left it to find its own place in the new order.
The dramatic gesture followed a broad campaign against the party that had already seen its headquarters sealed in Moscow and across the entire country, its major newspapers closed and its organization banned entirely in Moldavia and the Baltic republics. Leningrad had sealed off the party headquarters at the Smolny Institute, a site charged with symbolism as the place where Lenin had his first headquarters.
In Moscow, Mr. Yeltsin, the acknowledged leader of the liberal and democratic forces now in ascendance, issued a decree sealing the archives of the K.G.B., the Interior Ministry and the military.
Mr. Gorbachev's actions came after an emotion-charged day in which tens of thousands of Muscovites turned out to bury three men killed in the coup, The nationally televised ceremonies seemed almost a funeral for the old order.
Against this background, Mr. Gorbachev's announcement, read by a newsreader on the evening television news, had the quality of a full surrender by the old order.

 
 In the statement read over television after he reportedly met with the party leadership for several hours in an undisclosed location, since the Central Committee building was now not in his hands, Mr. Gorbachev based his actions on the party leadership's complicity or silence during the coup.

 
 "The Secretariat, the Politburo and the Communist Party's Central Committee did not take a stand against the coup d'etat," the statement began. "The Central Committee did not manage to take a firm position of condemnation and opposition. It did not inspire Communists to fight against the trampling of constitutional law.
"Among the conspirators were members of the party leadership," it said. "A number of party committees and the mass media supported the action of the state criminals. This placed millions of Communists in a false position."
But the President also defended the rank-and-file membership, as he had done twice since his return from house arrest in the Crimea, in effect appealing to the nation not to carry out a witch hunt against all party members.
"Many members of the party refused to collaborate with the conspirators, condemned the coup and joined in the fight against it," he said. "No one has the right to blame all Communists, and I, as President, consider it my duty to defend them as citizens from unfounded accusations."
 
Central Committee Disbanded
 In this situation, Mr. Gorbachev continued, the Central Committee, whose 300 members make up the inner circle of the party, "must take the difficult but honest decision to disband itself."
The fate of republican and local organizations, he continued, "should be decided by themselves."
He then declared: "I consider it no longer possible to continue to carry out my duties as General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, and I relinquish corresponding authority."
Mr. Gorbachev concluded with the hope that "democratically minded Communists" would work toward the creation of a new party "capable, together with all progressive forces, of actively joining in the continuation of fundamental democratic reforms for the sake of working people."
In a pair of decrees read after the announcement, Mr. Gorbachev dealt what was in effect the death blow to the party.
 
All Parties Are Curbed
 He ordered an end to all actions by political parties and movements in the military, the security forces, the K.G.B. and the apparatus of government. All members of political parties and political movements, he decreed, could continue their political activities only outside these organs and on their own time.
In a second decree, Mr. Gorbachev ordered parliamentary deputies to take custody of all property of the Communist Party. Its ultimate fate, he said, would be decided according to the laws of the Soviet Union and the republics.
That in effect opened the way for the nationalization of all the party's vast holdings, since Russia and many other republics have already signaled their intention to seize party property. These include innumerable office buildings, luxury hotels, printing plants, residences and vacation homes, many of which have been put to commercial use in recent years to compensate for falling membership and to earn hard currency for party coffers.
The wealth of a party that argued so fervently at the same time against privatization or private property was a major source of growing public wrath with the Communists.
 
Entrenched in Government
 The death knell of the party as the dominant force in the Soviet Union sounded after a long and tortuous decline during the six years of Mr. Gorbachev's perestroika, during which it steadily lost authority but remained entrenched in virtually every branch of the central Government.
Only a month ago, Mr. Gorbachev presided at a Central Committee meeting at which virtually every hallowed principle of the party was jettisoned, down to the sanctity of Marxism-Leninism.
All the while Mr. Gorbachev himself continued to cling to the faith in which he was raised, arguing again and again that he was born a Communist and would die a Communist. Even when his closest advisors, men like Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Aleksandr A. Yakovlev, were denounced and quit the party, he remained at its helm, arguing that it could be renewed.
And even in the immediate aftermath of the coup, at his first new conference and in an appearance before the Russian Parliament, Mr. Gorbachev declared that he remained loyal to "socialist choice," that not all Communists could be held repsonsible.
 
A Historic Force Collapses
 Though long in coming, the stripping of the party of its last grips on Soviet power signaled the end of an experiment that began in the flames of the Russian Revolution and spread to become a dominant historic force in the shaping of the 20th century, eventually giving in to the corrupting forces of unchallenged power, and under Stalin the Communist Party turned into an instrument of terror, repression and totalitarian control.
Last in a long line of leaders who believed in the possibility of returning the party to what was seen as its original purity, Mr. Gorbachev came to power in 1985 promising to inject openness and democracy into the party. But the forces he set loose soon began to prey on his own support.
Instead of presiding over the renewal of the party, Mr. Gorbachev ended up presiding over its extended death throes as one after another its legends and prerogatives fell. In the end, the party turned on Mr. Gorbachev himself, as his comrades engineered the coup,
Finally forced to disband the party leadership and to purge his Government, Mr. Gorbachev in effect left himself with no source of power, unless he can find some in the Soviet Parliament when it meets next week. But in the rout of Kremlin forces after the coup, it was unlikely that many deputies could be mustered to oppose the steamroller of the Yeltsin supporters.
The inclusion of Mr. Volsky, an ally of Mr. Gorbachev, in the new economic team was viewed as a bow to the President. But Mr. Volsky has also been an advocate of market reform and has maintained close contacts with liberal forces.
The appointment of Mr. Silayev as chairman of a committee to manage the national economy was viewed as a prelude to his nomination as prime minister when the Soviet Parliament convenes.
The inclusion of Mr. Yavlinsky signaled that the new government would move rapidly toward the radical reforms that the young economist had proposed in the "500 day" plan rejected by Mr. Gorbachev a year ago, and in the program he had prepared more recently with a group of Harvard political scientists. Both plans set a course for the rapid adoption of a market economy, denationalization of state-owned enterprises and intensified cooperation with the West.
Mr. Gorbachev's surprise resignation as party chief came after Robert Strauss, the new American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, presented his credentials to the Soviet leader. He was received by Mr. Gorbachev in the Kremlin, where the two men had a chat. Mr. Strauss, who declined to say what he discussed with Mr. Gorbachev, is expected to return to the United States before formally taking up his position in September.
 The day's events followed on an unabating flood of consequences from the brief seizure of power by old-guard leaders in the Kremlin. In something of a prelude to Mr. Gorbachev's action, Mr. Yeltsin and other republic leaders continued their relentless move against the old order. Having already closed Pravda and other party newspapers, Mr. Yeltsin announced late Saturday that he was taking charge of all government communications on Russian territory, including telephones and "coded information," a phrase he did not explain.
 Earlier in the day, Mr. Yeltsin had ordered officials of the Russian republic to take custody of all K.G.B. and law-enforcement archives.
 That act would further undercut the effectiveness of the central government, since all Kremlin communciations would by involved.
 
Ukraine Declares Independence
 In the Ukraine, the parliament decided by an overwhelming vote of 321 to 2, with 6 abstentions, to declare independence, calling a referendum for Dec. 1 to give the measure its certain public support. Even before the referendum, the resolution declared only Ukrainian law valid on Ukrainian territory and the Ukraine sovereign over its resources, in effect stripping a republic of 50 million away from the Kremlin's control.
 At the same time, Mr. Yeltsin recognized the independence proclaimed by Estonia and Latvia, as he had before with Lithuania.

HEADLINE: Health Insurers, in Trying to Save, Find New Costs in Managing Care

BYLINE: By GLENN KRAMON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARSIPPANY, N.J.

 BODY:
Eager to slow runaway medical expenses, the nation's health insurers are competing to offer services that press doctors for discounts and, to the distress of some physicians and patients, freely second-guess medical decisions.
But a look at this rapidly spreading approach, known as managed care, makes clear that saving money costs money. And critics say the cost of saving money is too high. 
 Many health economists consider managed care the nation's most realistic chance for containing medical expenses and insuring high-quality care. So do a great many employers, which buy much of the health insurance and ultimately pay many of the bills.
 
'Best Answer' Challenged
 The health insurance industry, which once paid medical bills almost unquestioningly, hopes the more aggressive role in which it is recasting itself -- through operations like that of Prudential Insurance here -- will help stave off calls for a Government-run insurance system like Canada's. Such a system could put the industry out of business or reduce its role.
"Managed care is the best answer we know of today both in restraining cost increases and improving the quality of service and of clinical care," said Samuel H. Havens, a senior vice president at Prudential, the nation's largest commercial health insurer.
But critics contend that a hodgepodge of competing insurers can never be fully efficient at controlling costs. They also say that managed care adds a new administrative layer to the already complex health-insurance system, creating many jobs that did not exist a decade ago and costing billions of dollars a year more than it should.
"Reducing our administrative costs to the levels of Canada would save enough money not only to cover all the uninsured but to improve coverage of everyone else by reducing or eliminating out-of-pocket payments," said Dr. Steffie Woolhandler, an assistant professor at the Harvard Medical School. She co-wrote a report on administrative costs in the two countries that appeared in the May 2 issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.
 
Fears of Big Brother
 To hear some American doctors tell it, Big Brother is alive and well and working in the insurance business. They contend that the managed-care system not only interferes with their medical judgments, sometimes with disastrous consequences, but that it also limits their patients' freedom to choose their doctors.
A typical day at Prudential's managed-care operation offered a glimpse of such an approach. In one case at the spacious new buildings housing the company's northern New Jersey division, a medical director concluded that a proposed breast reduction was not medically necessary and that the patient would have to pay the whole bill.
In another case, a Prudential nurse telephoned a doctor to suggest that he perform a gynecological operation at a surgery center in Prudential's medical network rather than the hospital proposed for it, where a smaller portion of the bill would be covered.
Staff members were out signing up a pediatric neurologist and an orthopedic surgeon for Prudential's network; doctors must agree in writing to offer discounts on their regular prices and cooperate with Prudential's reviewers. Meanwhile, marketing people were looking for more companies willing to enroll their employees in the network.
 
Millions Are Affected
 Managed care already embraces tens of millions of Americans. And with Congress considering how to rescue a health-care system in crisis, managed- care operations would play a central role in many prominent proposals for change, which involve extending and supplementing private insurance.
The heart of this strategy is organizing networks of doctors, hospitals, laboratories, pharmacies and other medical providers. The idea is to contain costs by not only securing a better price -- typically from 10 to 30 percent off the regular charge of a doctor or hospital -- but also deterring treatment the insurer deems inappropriate.
In some managed-care programs, patients are covered only if they are treated by doctors and hospitals in the network. Others allow a patient to go outside the network but then pay a lower share of the bill.
This is strong medicine for doctors and patients accustomed to unquestioned independence.
 
Doctors' Resistance Weakening
 But doctors' resistance is weakening as more networks are organized and more employers sign up their workers. Some of the networks are classic health maintenance organizations, which receive a prearranged monthly fee for each employee enrolled and either employ doctors or contract with them for full-time service. Others, known as independent practice associations, preferred provider organizations and network models, sign up doctors who also accept patients from other sources.
Along with Prudential, insurance giants, including Metropolitan Life Insurance, Cigna, Aetna Life and Casualty and Travelers, as well as some smaller commercial carriers, are introducing networks of various kinds and advertising them in a big way. So are some nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
Insurers are not the only ones getting into the act. Humana Inc., the big health-care company, has organized networks in 24 states and is expanding to other areas. U.S. Healthcare Inc., a publicly traded company, is building a network in the Northeast. Many other networks -- some set up by doctors or hospitals, some by large corporations -- have also been organized.
 
Formidable Competition
 All of these groups face formidable competition from long-established health maintenance organizations. The largest, Kaiser Permanente, has more than five million members on the West Coast and is expanding eastward.
Many insurance experts argue that such competition will be good for Americans. "Competition between relatively large, competent, efficiency- minded systems like Kaiser and Prudential leads to innovations and improvements you don't get when the government takes over," said Alain C. Enthoven, a professor of management at the Stanford Business School.
A number of employers large and small report that programs like Prudential's have already cut the growth in their medical costs somewhat -- typically from increases of 20 percent a year to increases of 10 or 15 percent, or less for huge employers like the Southwestern Bell Corporation and the Marriott Corporation.
 
Administration Costs
 But the savings do not come cheaply. Managed-care networks typically raise administrative costs by an amount equal to about 5 percent of the employer's medical bill. And it is far from certain that in the long run the private insurers' competing armies will hold down costs enough to satisfy clients.
Indeed, some critics prefer a system like Canada's, where provincial governments pay medical bills for everyone, using federal and provincial tax dollars. These critics say Canada's system is simpler and less expensive to run and can exert more leverage over what doctors and hospitals are paid. Dr. Woolhandler of Harvard cited a General Accounting Office report issued in June that concluded that a shift to a Canadian-style system would save up to $67 billion on insurance overhead and hospital and physician administrative costs.
 
Canada's Cost Advantage
 All told, she estimates, administration amounts to about 24 percent of total health-care spending in the United States -- or more than $175 billion this year -- versus about 11 percent in Canada, based on data for 1987.
While aspects of managed care, like scrutiny of medical decisions, might still exist in a national insurance system, the existence of many private insurers creates inefficiencies that could be eliminated by a single national program, Dr. Woolhandler asserted. For one thing, each United States insurer must set up its own claims-processing center in a region, and each must devote a lot of time to determining who is eligible for what coverage. Competing insurers also spend a lot on marketing.
Managed care pursued by so many different insurers means extra paperwork for doctors and hospitals as well.
 
Concerns of the A.M.A.
 "Managed care can be a help or a hassle, but most of the time it's a hassle," said Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president at the American Medical Association.
Surveys of employees using the managed-care networks have shown that the vast majority are satisfied, although some complain because they want a doctor who is not in the network or because they must keep changing physicians as doctors join and leave the network. In a few instances, medical reviewers' interference -- like recommending that a patient leave the hospital before the doctor thinks he is ready -- has had tragic results.
 
Managed-Care Bureaucracy
 To look at the Prudential health-care system is to see a program that must spend more to save more. Nationwide, Prudential's network covers about a million people (including some employees of The New York Times).
The managed-care and claims-processing operation based in Parsippany, which handles the 110,000 people Prudential covers in northern New Jersey, alone employs about 200 people, many of whom would not be needed in a national health system. And this group does not include the support staff at the company, the middlemen between the insurer and the employer, or the extra people hired by doctors, hospitals and employers to handle their paperwork.
Even ignoring the administrative costs of managed care, the American system has trouble holding down costs because no insurer by itself has the power to bargain down prices significantly, said Henry J. Aaron, director of the Economic Studies Program at the Brookings Institution.
In the system Mr. Aaron proposes, the Government alone would negotiate physician fees and hospital budgets.
 
Prediction by Insurers
 Private insurers concede that their system of competing managed-care networks may not hold down prices the way the Government could, and can entail higher administrative costs. But Mr. Havens of Prudential predicted that as managed-care programs become more trusted and sophisticated, they will begin to save more, benefiting patients through reviews of their cases. Also, employers will increasingly tell their insurers to pay nothing on bills incurred outside the network, he predicted, which will lower administrative costs, though it may leave many patients less happy.
And they will tell the insurers more and more to limit the network to the physicians who agree to provide treatment for a fixed monthly amount, as opposed to a fee for each procedure completed. That would lower costs and further reduce paperwork.
What is more, as competition among insurers forces some out of the market, the survivors will have more customers and therefore more leverage in negotiating with doctors and hospitals.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Growth of Managed-care," tracks enrollment in health maintenance organizations, 1984-1990 (Sources: Interstudy; G.H.A.A. (1990) (pg. 28)
 
Chart: "Spending in the Name of Saving"
 
In an effort to contain medical costs and improve quality, insurers have set up managed-care programs that are more complex and sometimes more expensive than previous claims-processing operations. Here is a look at the workings of Prudential's operation in Parsippany, which covers 110,000 members in northern New Jersey.
 
Eight representatives recruit physcians, hospitials and other providers for Prudential's network on the basis of credentials, convenience to members and willingness to accept the insurer's price and be reviewed by its staff.
 
Fifteen salespeople sell the networks to employers - directly, through brokers and agents to whom Prudential pays a commission, or through consultants hired by the employer.
 
Twenty-seven representatives staff the phone banks to answer questions and complaints about the networks from patients.
 
Eighteen nurses review treatments proposed by physicians, comparing them with medical protocol to determine appropriateness. An important part of the work is the review of care in catastrophic cases - like patietns with cancer, AIDS, disability from a stroke or an extremely premature baby.
 
One full-time medical director reviews questionable cases referred by the nurses for a final recommendation on whether the insurer will pay for the treatment. The patient or doctor may appeal a ruling.
 
Four part-time medical directors on contract help screen the credentials of physicians being considered for the network, evaluate to determine whether they were handled properly and consult with doctors in the network.
 
About 100 people examine and type claims into a computer, referring questionable ones to the medical staff. (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: Morgantown Journal;
Urban Planners Glimpse Future on Rural Campus

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.

 BODY:
While outsiders might think of the coal train as this state's contribution to the transportation arts, a visit to West Virginia University brings a surprise.
Snaking around the sprawling campus is a state-of-the-art people mover, a 3.3-mile stretch of electric cars run by computers that nearly 20 years after its groundbreaking continues to draw oohs and aahs and would-be imitators from around the world. 
 Next week, a delegation of Japanese land planners will join a very long list of transportation pilgrims who have come to this seldom-celebrated campus hoping to glimpse their own future.
For students of transportation engineering, the lessons the system offers have to do with things like "off-line capability." But for students of America, its lessons include a simpler one: the country's continuing ability to resist regional stereotype and produce surprises.
"People who come in from outside aren't so much overwhelmed at the technology of the thing; they're just surprised to find it here," said Greg Moore, 21 years old, the managing editor of the campus newspaper, The Daily Athenaeum.
The roots of the system date from the late 1960's when the imagination of a professor met up with the needs of politicians. Captivated by advances in computer technology, Prof. Samy Elias began to wonder whether a computer could drive a whole transportation system, eliminating the need for drivers.
At the time, even automated elevators were still a novelty in some parts of the country. Unsure whether the public would dare ride cars that travel 30 miles an hour without drivers, Professor Elias conducted public opinion surveys as well as feasibility studies on technology and cost.
At the same time, the Department of Transportation was in its idealistic youth and top officials were aghast at the problems of automobile congestion. They had great hopes for a technological breakthrough that could revolutionize mass transit.
Add in the fact that the late local Congressman, Harley O. Staggers Sr., was the chairman of the House transportation committee, and a Federal project was born. The Federal Government paid for 80 percent of the $138 million system and the Boeing Corporation built it.
Rushing for a dedication before the 1972 election, President Richard M. Nixon sent his daughter, Tricia, to a ribbon-cutting ceremony in late October, where one of the cars on the the not-quite-ready-for-prime-time system broke down.
Since then it has carried 35 million passengers more than 12 million miles, with no accidents and scarcely a graffito. And it grows cheaper to run with age. It cost $2.5 million to run in 1980 and the same 10 years later, despite inflation.
Personal Rapid Transit, or PRT, as it is known, was the world's first mass transit system driven entirely by computers, said Professor Elias, who now teaches at the University of Nebraska at Lincoln. About 40 others have followed, including those in various airports and in downtown Miami and Detroit.
But the West Virginia system is still the only one in the world that offers nonstop service, Professor Elias said. That is, if you are at the Morgantown equivalent of 96th Street, heading for Times Square, push a button and within five minutes an electric-powered car arrives to take you there directly, with no intermediate stops.
Cars are dispatched only after a waiting passenger pushes a button.
There are five stations, and the cars, which can seat 8 and hold up to 13 others, run on wheels, not rails, along an elevated track. System engineers say the average wait for a car is 3.5 minutes. Operators in a control room monitor 27 safety features on each car and if one seems in danger -- say by traveling too fast -- the system automatically shuts down.
Much celebrated, the system has been imitated less often than its designers hoped. Professor Elias argues that the Federal Government ran out of money to subsidize construction. But others say plans for similar systems have also been thwarted by a lack of demand as Americans remain reluctant to abandon their cars.
The cars have made their way into campus lore. There was the time someone saw a man aboard in a ski mask, waving a gun. Control room engineers re-routed the car to a maintenance depot, where security guards rushed in with drawn guns, only to find a startled young dramatist on his way home from a school play.
There were a rash of fire extinguisher thefts, and a young man once threatened to kiss a woman passenger, but did not. This is what passes for crime in West Virginia.
Students, who pay $45 for semester-long passes, find the PRT useful not only for getting places but for offering alibis when they don't. "It's usually on time, but if you're late for class it's, 'The PRT was late,' " said Julie Trevana, 21, a senior.
Not long ago, the little cars were winning over new admirers, as clusters of parents were getting their first rides.
"I think it's a fantastic idea," said Rich Good, whose daughter is entering the university this year. He praised the cars' security and convenience, and their beautiful view of the coal barges working the Monongahela River.
Then he explained what, for a parent, may be the system's greatest appeal. "It eliminates the need for cars," he said.

HEADLINE: In Utah, Prosperity Is Making Room for Diversity

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
In recent years, Utah has become a darling of corporate employers, who cherish its labor pool: young, well-educated, non-union and reared with the hard-work ethos of the pervasive Mormon faith.
But a funny thing has happened on the way to the economic boom here. As newcomers have discovered life at the foot of the Wasatch Range and decided to stay, the region has become much more diverse. 
 The state's capital, long regarded as an insular, homogenous community that tended to view change with suspicion, today is marked by profound change, as the city's identity, and its skyline, take a bolder new shape. Utah remains one of the most Republican and conservative states, but many say alternative viewpoints are getting a better hearing politically and culturally these days.
 
'Remarkable Change'
 "We've seen remarkable change here in the last 20 years," said Mayor Palmer DePaulis, an Italian-American Catholic and a Democrat, who is expected to run for governor next year.
"We're not quite Greenwich Village, but we've gone from a small-town mentality to a much more cosmopolitan community with a far greater global perspective."
Mormons once accounted for more than 70 percent of the population of Salt Lake County, but they now make up less than half. The balance includes significant Irish Catholic and Greek Orthodox populations.
For the first time in its 141-year history, the University of Utah has named a non-Mormon, Arthur Smith, to lead it.
Deedee Corradini has begun a campaign to become the city's first female mayor. She is not a Mormon and neither are two of the other three candidates.
And since last year, people in Utah can buy liquor by the drink.
To be sure, Utah has hardly lost its conservative bearings. The state Legislature in January passed one of the nation's most restrictive abortion laws. But last week Utah officials ordered a stay on the measure, choosing to wait and see how a similarly restrictive measure in Louisiana fares in the courts.
The state also has a right-to-work law, which narrowly limits unionization. The average wage, $10.70 an hour, is second only to New Mexico's average wage, of $9.30, as the lowest in the West.
And Utah's spending for education ranks toward the bottom among states, even though the adult literacy level, at 94 percent, is among the highest in the nation.
 
Economic Rebound
 In the first half of the 1980's, after the energy boom of the previous decade, Utah's economy went bust, as the oil, gas and coal industries slumped. But in the last four years, the economy has rebounded, with big gains in the service sector, principally in telecommunications. Utah is now home to 180 computer software companies, including a leader in the field, the Wordperfect Corporation, which designs and manufactures personal computer programs near Provo.
While the nation's economy has shrunk in the current recession, job growth in Utah has averaged about 4 percent in the last two years.
Since 1980, Utah's population has grown nearly 18 percent, to 1.7 million, a result of an influx of newcomers and the high birth rate among Mormons.
With plentiful workers, the state has been able to recruit large corporate employers, including Delta Air Lines, which established a western hub in Salt Lake City, and Sears' Discover Card unit, which has an operations center here.
Some financial magazines have lauded Utah as among the nation's most attractive places for employers, pointing to its moderate personal and corporate tax rates and pro-business climate. In such ratings, note also is taken of the hard-work ethic of the state's large, young labor pool (Utah's median age of 25.7 years is the youngest in the nation). In 1990, Fortune magazine ranked Salt Lake City as the best spot in the nation for companies to locate.
In today's global economy, one of Utah's biggest assets is the high number of people here who speak a foreign language. It helped to persuade American Express to base a travelers' check service center here, where calls are handled in 36 languages.
The high level of literacy in foreign languages stems largely from the Mormon practice of sending young people as missionaries around the world. Diane Calder, for example, spent two years proselytizing in Chile and returned with a fluency in Spanish. Her language skills landed her a job with American Express.
"Since I lived in rural Chile, I learned the everyday language that people speak," said Ms. Calder, a 28-year-old native of Salt Lake City, who works with Spanish-speaking customers. "It's not the textbook style, so people feel more comfortable when we talk."
Such Mormon missionaries have returned here with a worldly perspective that seems to have helped to enrich and broaden the city. For Ms. Calder and her friends, who have lived in Japan, Sweden and South Korea, among other places, conversations routinely get around to foreign affairs. In addition, a significant number of Mormons from other countries, especially in Asia, have moved here in recent years.
"Mormons and non-Mormons, or gentiles, as they call us, have co-existed here for a lot of years," said Mickey Gallivan, an Irish-Catholic and a fifth-generation Utahan. "But today there seems to be a greater acceptance in Salt Lake City, and of each other. When I was a kid, the first thing a lot of us wanted to do when we grew up, was to leave. I don't see that now."
Mr. Gallivan, a publicist who worked on the Salt Lake City bid to be the host if the the 1998 Winter Olympics, said the effort helped to foster greater unity in the city. Its bid lost narrowly to Nagano, Japan, but Salt Lake City will be the American nominee for the 2002 games.
"It's a different Salt Lake City than I moved to nine years ago," said Forrest Collins, the general manager of the Green Street Social Club, a bar, who moved here from San Francisco. "A lot of people are discovering Utah."
At the city's recent jazz and blues festival, the pulsating, bare-wire rhythms electrified a packed crowd of Salt Lakers. Many of the revelers were dancing in the aisles.
Kathleen Sullivan, a Harvard Law professor, had traveled to Utah for a seminar on justice and liberty. But she also took in the blues festival, and she said she sensed the quickening beat of this desert city.
"Hardly the image of tight-lipped Puritanism," she said.

HEADLINE: The New Revolution;
The West Must Be Quick on Its Feet

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the last five years, the United States has had to refashion the central tenets of its foreign policy as the cold war came to an end and a new kind of Soviet Union began to evolve. But until last week, that formidable task was eased by one constant element in the rapidly changing equation -- the unitary if frequently troubled leadership of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
The tumult of the last six days has ended Mr. Gorbachev's primacy and with it, apparently, a thousand-year tradition of concentrating absolute power in one man or woman. For policy makers in Washington and other Western capitals, the problem now is how to deal with yet another radically different Soviet Union, one whose very shape, whose policies and principles are unclear, but whose complexity is assured by the success of the Russian people for the first time in substituting the popular will for the tyranny of czar and dictator. 
 Mikhail Gorbachev opened Soviet society, closed by terror for decades, to intellectual free trade, but he stumbled over the next steps in transforming his nation -- the creation of a true multiparty society and the establishment of a market economy. A major question is whether George Bush, who has shown a sure-footed skill in managing United States relations with Mr. Gorbachev, will do as well in the testing time to come.
At meetings in London and in Maine this week, the West will start exploring a new policy on aid, on relations with the fractious republics, on the new leadership itself.
 
Blame for Gorbachev
 A sharp shift in emphasis is already clear in Europe, however, especially in Germany. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, an early Gorbachev champion, predicted that the Baltic republics would soon win freedom, regardless of Mr. Gorbachev's position. And Otto Lambsdorf, another influential foreign-policy leader, blamed Mr. Gorbachev for "great failures" in not moving quickly enough on economic reform.
The change is likely to renew the debate that Mr. Bush, in alliance with the Japanese and Canadian leaders, won at the July economic summit conference in London, warding off quick, large-scale direct financial aid to Moscow. While Mr. Bush continues to favor waiting for evidence of comprehensive reform, some of his European partners do not. Jurgen Mollemann, the German economics minister, said it was urgent for the West "to give the Soviet Union more and faster help," and President Francois Mitterrand of France agreed, commenting that "now we have to make a much bigger effort than we have made so far."
Even Prime Minister John Major of Great Britain has begun to edge toward the Franco-German stance. As the current chairman of the Group of Seven industrialized nations, he summoned senior officials of the summit nations to a meeting in London this week to ponder possible changes in the group's positions. He urged that the Soviets be given "not just cash but assistance on how to do things, how to establish private enterprises, how to set up a stock exhange, how to operate a market."
Mr. Major is to meet Mr. Bush this week in Maine, where they will no doubt discuss a common position.
Over time, the collapse of the coup should accelerate trends in the Soviet Union that the United States wishes to encourage. The Old Guard is gone if not forgotten. The military, most of whose leaders chose the wrong side, will be in no position to demand as large a share of scarce financial resources, to try to subvert or delay arms control agreements or to lobby for continuing support for Afghan Communists. The K.G.B.'s capacity for mischief has been reduced if not eliminated.
Beyond that, economic reform in the Soviet Union will almost certainly accelerate rapidly, rendering moot as it does the debate over when the West should make a major financial move. But in the interim Mr. Bush is likely to find himself under pressure..
 
A Way to Participate
 "I think it's wrong to wait any longer," said Robert Hunter of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, who was a key foreign-policy adviser in the Carter White House. "I'd like to see a democracy fund of say, $10 billion. Use it for grain credits or whatever, but let's get out in front and show we want to be a participant, not just an onlooker, and help those brave people."
Economists argue that much of the money would be wasted if it was committed too soon. But a major financial commitment by the United States, along with the Western allies, could be as much a political as an economic act, a carefully calculated attempt to keep the winds of history blowing and the tides of change flowing democracy's way.
George F. Kennan, the diplomat and scholar who conceived the American policy of containment in response to Soviet expansionism after World War II, described last week's coup and countercoup as "a turning point of the most momentous historical significance," exceeding in import even the Bolshevik revolution of 1917. In dealing with its consequences, he said on the MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour on public television, the United States would do well to remember an admonitory comment by John Quincy Adams and not overreach.
"She is the well-wisher to the freedom and independence of all," Adams said of the United States on July 4, 1821. "She is the champion and vindicator only of her own."
Mr. Bush is proceeding in his characteristically cautious way. His favored word, used again last week, is "prudent." He refused to jump to the conclusion that the coup could not be reversed, he insisted that it was up to the Soviets, and not to him, to "sort it out" in terms of new cabinet members and other officials and he would not be drawn into comparing the relative strengths of Mr. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, the hero of the resistance against the neo-Stalinist junta.
But such restraint cannot last forever. Decisions will have to be made. It matters enormously to the United States and its allies, to cite just one question among many, who ends up with the keys to the nuclear weapons once the seemingly inevitable breakup of the Soviet empire has been completed.
The most immediate problem for the Western leaders is managing the relationship with Mr. Gorbachev and simultaneously, perhaps more important, dealing with with Mr. Yeltsin, who has emerged as something more than President of the Russian federated republic if not yet as the leader of the Soviet Union.
It would be simplistic to suggest that it is time to choose up sides; both men have roles, at least for now, and both have strengths. But if it was ever possible for Mr. Bush to deal comfortably with Mr. Yeltsin in a decidedly secondary level, it is possible no more; as the political analyst William Schneider pointed out, Mr. Gorbachev now derives his political legitimacy from Mr. Yeltsin, not vice versa.
Indeed, on Friday, Mr. Gorbachev seemed to defer to Mr. Yeltsin as he accepted without cavil the decrees of the Russian leader and the actions, some of them of dubious legality, of Yeltsin allies on the Moscow City Council. And it was Mr. Yeltsin, by all accounts, who forced the dismissal of members of the Soviet Government, some of whom Mr. Gorbachev would have preferred to keep.
Edmund Wilson called his history of the Russian revolution "To the Finland Station," after the terminal in Petrograd (now Leningrad) where Lenin arrived to take charge of the uprising. To pursue the metaphor, there seems a strong possibility that Mr. Gorbachev has missed the train of counterrevolution.
Mr. Yeltsin has been popularly elected, and in a landslide to boot; Mr. Gorbachev has never run for office. Mr. Yeltsin began moving to outlaw the Communist Party even as Mr. Gorbachev, its leader, clinged to the idea that the party could be a force for change. As it happened, Mr. Gorbachev was forced to change, resigning as chief of the party late yesterday. Mr. Yeltsin favors immediate independence for the Baltic states; Mr. Gorbachev resists. Mr. Yeltsin a free-market man; Mr. Gorbachev, not yet.
In other words, Mr. Yeltsin stands for the things most Americans stand for, so he is now President Bush's natural ally. So far, though, Mr. Bush has refrained from embracing the Russian's position on matters like the Baltics, straddling the issue by supporting independence but not demanding it now. The continuing fear within the Administration, especially in its more conservative circles, is that sudden freedom for the Baltic states might set off explosive demands in other republics, intensify nationalist animosities and lead to civil war or chaos.

HEADLINE: TAIWANESE TO END USE OF DRIFT NETS

BYLINE: By AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Taiwan has promised to comply with a United Nations ban on fishing with drift nets in the North Pacific Ocean, winning cautious praise from United States officials.
The Taiwanese Government, under threat of American trade sanctions, announced Friday that it would end the use of the nets, which stretch as far as 30 miles and snare all marine life in their path, beginning next July 1. 
 Representatives Jolene Unsoeld and John Miller, both from Washington State, said they welcomed the news, but expressed concern that Taiwan had broken past promises to halt the use of the nets.
"We need more than words," said Ms. Unsoeld, a Democrat. "Now is the time to step up the pressure, not breathe a sigh of relief."
 
Looking for Proof
 She said she was looking for "proof that Taiwan would stop destructive drift-netting, especially given its history of saying one thing on drift nets and then doing the exact opposite."
Albert Lin, a spokesman for Taiwan's Coordination Council for North American Affairs in Washington, said Taiwan had indicated in the past that it respected the spirit of the pending drift-net prohibitions but had not previously committed itself to the ban in international waters.
Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations. Mr. Lin is the information officer for the council that acts as an informal Taiwanese Embassy in Washington.
The Bush Administration put Taiwan and South Korea on notice last week that they may face trade sanctions because they continued to fish with the nets.
United States Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher attested to Taiwan's violations in a formal certification message to President Bush on Aug. 14, clearing the way for Mr. Bush to impose tariffs or an embargo on Taiwanese and South Korean seafood products.
 
Response to Threats Denied
 Mr. Lin said Friday's announcement was "not directly" tied to the threats of trade sanctions.
"In the past we said we respected the U.N. resolution in principle, but did not make the final decision," he said. "This is the first time we are making an official announcement."
Roddy Moscoso, a spokesman for the United States National Marine Fisheries Service, said Taiwan was the first drift-netting nation to publicly announce its intent to abide by the resolution.
"Certainly we are pleased," Mr. Moscoso said. But, he said, "this announcement does not change the status of the certification of the drift-net violations."
The United States Government has no statistics on Taiwanese and Korean drift nets. However, the marine fisheries service reported that in 1990, 10 percent of Japan's drift-net fleet killed 1,758 whales and dolphins, 253,288 tuna, 81,956 blue sharks, 30,464 sea birds and more than 3 million other noncommercial fish, including some salmon tagged from hatcheries in the Columbia River basin.
Japan has the world's largest drift-net fleet with about 450 vessels in the North Pacific. South Korea and Taiwan each have about 150 there.
Mr. Miller, a Republican, said he shared Ms. Unsoeld's concern that Taiwan may not follow through with its promise.
"But we should welcome the announcement," he said in a telephone interview from Seattle. "It is a positive step. It is going to increase the pressure on Korea and Japan."
"I think what this tells us is that when we threaten to take certain action like banning some of their imports into this country, that it does bring results," he said.
