HEADLINE: At Farmers' Markets, the Crush of Customers Is Expanding

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
NOW that coupons are being accepted at farmers' markets in New York State, tens of thousands of low-income families have joined the regular customers at farmers' markets, "helping themselves and New York State farmers," said Commissioner Richard McGuire of the Department of Agriculture and Markets.
Under the 1991 New York State farmers' market coupon program, 66,900 low-income families enrolled in the Social Supplement Food Program for Women, Infants and Children receive $20 in coupons redeemable at 83 farmers' markets in the state. And for the first time this year an additional 5,000 low-income elderly are receiving $10 in coupons. 
 At the farmers' market in downtown Getty Square in Yonkers, Florence Schmidt, the market manager, has noticed the new customers.
 
Most Successful Year
 "We have been operating for seven years with five upstate farmers," Mrs. Schmidt said. "Most of them come back year after year. This is the most successful year we have had, and I believe it's because more coupons have been alloted."
The Getty Square market is open from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. Thursdays from July to mid-November.
The coupons have made it possible for more families in the supplemental food program to buy fruits and vegetables, Mrs. Schmidt said, adding, "Mothers rave about the fresh produce and the wide selection, which they rarely get a chance to buy."
Farmers are reimbursed for the coupons by market sponsors, using checks drawn on special bank accounts established with Federal and state funds. Any farmer selling fresh fruits and vegetables at an authorized farmers' market may participate.
"The coupon program has been successful in expanding the access of low-income families to fresh produce," Mr. McGuire said, explaining that the program gives vouchers to low-income families to buy fruit and vegetables that other Federal programs do not cover.
The farmers' markets in Westchester, of course, already had a strong following. After the new Peekskill farmers' Market opened on July 13, for example, Patricia Esposito, the manager, said, "I didn't realize people would get so excited about a head of lettuce. We've had far more business than we anticipated. Customers start lining up at 7:30 A.M. even though our official opening time is 8 o'clock."
Ms. Esposito, the executive director of the Peekskill/Cortlandt Chamber of Commerce, said that plans for this new market had been in the works for two years and were conceived as a way to revitalize downtown Peekskill.
The Peekskill market -- which is open from 8 A.M. to 2 P.M. Saturdays from mid-July to early November -- has also drawn "a lot of customers from upscale towns like Chappaqua, Pound Ridge and all of northern Westchester," Ms. Esposito said. "You only have to bite into a fresh peach to know why.
"We've also tried to make the market a lively place that attracts people. Ours is more than a produce stand. For instance, we have a vineyard: Prejan Vineyard from Syracuse sells wares here. We also have stands that sell special breads, roasted nuts and dried fruits, jams and honey and other goodies."
Farmer-to-consumer direct marketing in New York State accounts for more than $112 million a year in retail farm income, and New York State farmers' markets make up an important part of that trade, Mr. McGuire said, adding that more than 1,000 farm families depend on farmers' markets to sell their produce.
More and more people like Myra Fransen and Karen Steefel also depend on farmers' markets for their weekly shopping.
On a recent Friday, at the Green Seasons farmers' Market in New Rochelle, they could choose organic eggs, cheeses, bunches of fragrant basil, deep red tomatoes, new potatoes, first-of-the-season McIntosh apples, loaves of whole wheat and honey breads, blueberry pies and bouquets of marigolds and zinnias.
 
'I Feel Much Healthier'
 At the market, which is open from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. from early July to mid-November, Ms. Fransen was buying eggs and cheddar cheese from David Wengerd of the Amish Farms.
"I love this market," she said. "I come every Friday, because I know I'm getting much better value for my money when I buy quality food here. Fresh food is very important to me. I feel much healthier when I eat well."
Ms. Steefel, with her baby strapped in a pouch on her back, said she, too, was a regular patron.
 
Supporting the Farmers
 "The market is so interesting," she said. "It's always an adventure. I love the variety. You never know what you're going to find. I've had all kinds of herbs, white eggplant and raspberries in season. I strongly feel that unless we support small farmers they will disappear. And our choices will be limited to what the mammoth agricultural industries decide to grow."
An added attraction of the market, Ms. Fransen said, is the opportunity to talk to the farmers. "When I first started coming here, I was mainly interested in nutrition," she said, "but when farmers told me that customers like myself were helping to support small family farms, I felt good."
One such farmer, Werner Kohlmier of Kohlmier Farm in Hopewell Junction, leaves home at 4:30 A.M. in order to bring fruit, vegetables and loaves of bread baked by his mother to market in New Rochelle.
 
Dependent on the Markets
 Kohlmier Farm, with 200 acres of vegetables under cultivation, is largely dependent on farmers' markets to sell what they grow, he said.
"But the market is more than selling," said Mr. Kohlmier, who works the family farm with his father, Norbert. "Farming is demanding; you don't get much of a chance to meet people. What helps to make it all worthwhile is talking to customers. Many of ours are regulars who come back year after year. And when they tell me how much they appreciate what we grow, it's like a shot in the arm."
Mr. Kohlmier also listens closely to customers' requests. "We grow what they want. Herbs, for example. We got into herbs a couple of years ago, and we grow a dozen different varieties. Also, we grow pot plants, which we sell in season."
 
Profitable for Farmers
 David Wengerd, along with 25 members of his family, runs Amish Farms in Bloomsbury, Pa. In addition to the market in New Rochelle, the Wengerd clan sells corn, herbs, all types of lettuce, tomatoes, potatoes, squash, beans, peppers, eggplants and eggs, pies, cheeses, honey and jam at 24 other farmers' markets each week.
"How do we do? Very well," said Mr. Wengerd. "About 400 percent better than we'd be doing selling wholesale. It's the difference of getting 25 cents a pound for selling tomatoes, for instance, to a supplier, or getting $1 a pound when we sell them directly to the customer."
Mr. Wengerd said that at the largest farmers' market in the area, Greenmarket in Manhattan's Union Square, farmers can make up to $10,000 a day.
 
'A 'Win-Win Situation'
 "It's a win-win situation. Everybody benefits," said Robert A. Lewis, chief marketing representative of New York State Department of Agriculture and Marketing in Brooklyn, who provides assistance to Westchester farmers' markets.
"Because there are no middlemen and transportation costs are low, consumers are able to get fresh fruits and vegetables at prices that are 5 to 30 percent lower than at retail stores."
Without the markets, Mr. Lewis said, many family farms, too small to produce volume crops, would be forced to sell.

HEADLINE: Canon's Proposed Move Upsets Brookville

BYLINE: By LISA BETH PULITZER

 BODY:
IN 1940, Nassau County had 439 farms. Today there are six, five of them north of Jericho Turnpike. The vast farming region called Cedar Swamp has gone from farmland to home for horse breeders and yacht owners.
Now the Village of Brookville, one of 11 incorporated villages that make up Cedar Swamp, faces a crossroads.
Canon U.S.A. Inc., the Japanese-owned camera and electronics company, is negotiating to buy 100 acres of choice property on Northern Boulevard from the financially strapped New York Institute of Technology for its headquarters. 
 The property now houses the de Seversky Center, once the Winston Frederick Churchill Guest house and now used for corporate conferences, weddings and a gourmet dining club. The center is named for Alexander P. de Seversky, a World War I flying ace who played a role in the invention of the helicopter and was a founder of the college.
Canon, now in Lake Success and previously bound for a large site in the redevelopment of Roosevelt Raceway, is trying to persuade the Village of Brookville to rezone the property from five-acre residential use to commercial use. Commercial zoning would permit Canon to use the land for conferences, training, education, research, administration and general office buildings. Many residents of Brookville and surrounding villages oppose changing the zoning. They fear it could pave the way for other commercial properties along the vast grassy strip.
"I don't want to see the commercialization of the whole stretch of Northern Boulevard from Greenvale to Cold Spring Harbor," said Ed Dugan, a former member of the Brookville Planning Board. The corporate counsel for Canon, Jay Cook, said the company "won't purchase the property until any necessary amendments to zoning or approval to allow us to build are granted." Canon last week revised its initial presentation to address residents' concerns about parking and traffic. The plan still has to go before the Village Board, the first step in a lengthy process.
Canon would have up to 1,500 employees on the new site, and parking for them would be in a two-level underground garage. In a slumping economy, with major employers reducing their work force, keeping the company on Long Island would have major significance for Long Island.
When it decided to move from Lake Success, Canon chose a site at the former Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury and paid an estimated $1 million an acre. But after almost four years of delays and inquiries questioning the propriety of the deal between the Town of Hempstead and the raceway, the company decided to look elsewhere.
"That deal is dead," Mr. Cook said. "We have no further interest in that property. We are concentrating solely on the site we have chosen in Brookville."
The cost for the 100 acres in Brookville is estimated at $200,000 an acre. Canon outlined its original proposal on July 17 to a meeting of the Village Board. The plan showed development of 5 percent of the parcel, leaving 95 acres as green belts. "That's impossible," a lawyer representing the Brookville Taxpayers Association, Robert Forchelli, said. "The five acres they say will be utilized is really a footprint of two buildings, three stories tall, that calculate out to up to 650,000 square feet. That's larger than one tower at EAB Plaza in Uniondale. In order to provide parking for a building of that magnitude, you will need 27 acres of parking."
Other people at the meeting said they were concerned that pollution from the employees' cars could seep into a prime aquifer, as well as sewage systems.
The architect for Canon, Angelo Corva, said: "The meeting was strictly informational. There was no plan, only a concept. We wanted to get the public's input. Now we are continuing to move along, preparing a more hard-line program with more specifics that will meet the concerns of the people."
The new plan calls for the use of 11.2 acres of land, approximately double the existing facility, and that new buildings would total 600,000 square feet, with no building taller than the existing mansion. The main access would be at the existing entrance to New York Tech, on 25A and serviced by a traffic light.
 For more than 20 years, Brookville has resisted plans for commercial building in the village. Mayor Michael Galgano said he had agreed to hear the Canon proposal and would meet with the Board of Trustees on the plan because of the problems at New York Tech and because 70 percent of the village taxes pay for services like fire and police protection. Half the land in the village is not taxable.
Canon would be the first major taxable contributor to the village, Mr. Galgano said. Canon would also pay taxes to the Town of Oyster Bay and Nassau County, as well as to the Jericho School District, one of three school systems covering the Brookvilles.
 
Plight of Institute
 The president of New York Tech, Dr. Matthew Schure, said selling the property, which includes the Guest house and a small private home occupied by the manager of the Guest house, would "make a very big impact on reducing the school's budget."
If Brookville does not approve the rezoning, the school says, it will deal with whatever constraints the village imposes, but it still wants to sell the site.
"We have major assets in real estate," Dr. Schure said. "All of the property that is not currently being used for academic purposes will be sold to reduce long-term debt."
One option for the village is to expand the special-use permit for New York Tech, limiting additional development by Canon. Although New York Tech is tax exempt, it gives $16,500 a year to the village.
According to a calculation from county assessments, the de Seversky Center, if taxable, would generate $25,000 a year for the village before any additional building on the property.
A vice president of the taxpayers' group, Steven Glazer, said the village tax was the smallest part of homeowners' taxes, about 10 percent. He said that if the area remained residential, "homes built on the site would go back into our tax roll, adding money to the village and children to our schools."
Mr. Glazer added that two schools, North Shore and Locust Valley, would not see tax benefits from Canon. He added that his group wanted Canon to remain in Nassau County, "but please put your headquarters in a commercial area."
 
'Clean and Reasonably Compatible'
 The supporters of Canon include the Long Island Association, and Lee Koppelman, head of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
"You have a public institution in need of some cash relief, perhaps in order to survive," the president of the Long Island Association, James Larocca, said, "and a corporate prospect that is clean and reasonably compatible."
But the president of the Birchwood Civic Association in Jericho, David Diamond, said, "Long Island has for too long allowed commercial development in an area that should be reserved for residential."
Mr. Larocca added: "What's particularly attractive is that Canon will be so completely buffered from the surrounding community. The open space will be preserved, and the headquarters will be set back from the road."
"The land-use planning," Mr. Koppelman said, "makes this an extremely promising endeavor." He said Canon would also create jobs for the region.
Some adjacent villages do not agree. The Upper Brookville Board of Trustees passed a resolution against the Canon plan and has sent a letter to Mr. Galgano stating its opposition.
Byam K. Stevens Jr., the Mayor of Muttontown, another of the six villages that share the Police Department with the Village of Brookville, also sent a letter to Mr. Galgano explaining that although he understood the attraction of Canon as a taxpayer, he believed that the residents of the area would prefer to pay higher taxes in lieu of commercial entities.
 
Stress at Northern Boulevard
 Laurence Werfel of Old Brookville, an architect with Werfel & Associates, said in an interview that he was concerned about the traffic impact. "The traffic situation available to serve that site is the intersection at Glen Cove Road and Northern Boulevard, which is now the second-most-used-corner in Nassau. To add to the impact of that corner would affect the Village of East Hills, the City of Glen Cove, all the Brookvilles and Old Westbury."
Mayor Gil Colombo of Old Westbury said that although his village did not have a position on the Canon plan, it was concerned about added traffic on Whitney Lane, a country road used by students of C. W. Post College and New York Tech.
The Village Administrator, Victoria Siegal, of East Hills said, "Our major concern is additional traffic on Route 25A."
Jericho and Brookville residents are concerned over the effects on Route 107, a two-lane road that grinds to a standstill during rush hour. Canon is studying the traffic problem and has hired Walter Dunn of Dunn Engineering Associates to examine the situation. Although the study is in the preliminary stages, Mr. Dunn said, "There are some problems at existing traffic flows during the A.M. and P.M. hours."
He said additional lanes might be needed near the intersection of Glen Cove Road and Northern Boulevard.
Another step may be to stagger employees' work hours.
 
May Be Prime Source for Future
 The heavy traffic could also affect aquifers. According to the bicounty planning coordinator of the Long Island Planning Board, Edith Tannenbaum, the property is in a ground-water protection area.
"It is a portion of the deep-recharge area, a relatively undeveloped portion in comparison with the rest of Nassau County," she said. "The water in this area has been rated good to excellent and could be the prime source for the future of Long Island."
Ms. Tannenbaum said the residues from a large number of cars could create an impermeable surface, making it difficult for rain water to filter into the ground.
Mr. Koppelman said that he had been a main researcher in studying aquifers on the Island and that the Canon site would not create a problem, because "it isn't even in the area I am most concerned with."
To complicate the issue, a lake that is a water-recharge basin is on the property. The county bought it from New York Tech for $150,000. Storm water goes through the soil, where it is purified, and then into the aquifers, said a spokesman for the county, Ken Cyner. The lake covers two to three acres, not including a 50-foot easement.
The de Seversky parcel was rezoned in the winter from two-acre residential to five-acre residential classification after a study by Fredrich P. Clark Associates, a planning and consulting firm in Rye, had recommended that all large vacant tracts in the village be rezoned to higher categories.
The Village of Brookville commissioned the $58,500 study.
"The reason for the rezoning is twofold," Mayor Galgano said. "One, open-space preservation, and the second, to recognize the aquifer located under the North Shore's green belt."
Al Bianco of Brookville, a developer who owns 58 acres of the property catercorner to the de Seversky parcel on Northern Boulevard, stood up at the meeting last month to back the Canon proposal. He drew a parallel between Canon and the Villa Banfi headquarters in Old Brookville.
"The two are totally different," said Mayor F. Reed Anthony of Old Brookville.
Villa Banfi is operating under a special-use permit limiting the wine-and-spirits importer to 56 employees at the site at any time. Banfi restored an unused mansion, replanted the property and added a modern wing for its marketing division. It also uses 75 acres to produce Old Brookville Chardonnay, the only Long Island wine produced in Nassau County.
 
'Elegant New Level of Nimbyism'
 Since the Long Island Association has come out in support of Canon, "we have had some reaction to our support for the proposal in an elegant new level of Nimbyism," for the not-in-my-backyard reaction, Mr. Larocca said, explaining that most of the opposition has been from developers who had aggressively developed other areas of the Island but did not want additional building in their own neighborhoods.
Mr. Dugan of Brookville said: "The North Shore is the only place preserved for residential housing. Once we allow one commercial entity, there's no stopping it. Soon every 10-acre plot would possibly be a commercial site, and once corporations see the money saved by purchasing residentially zoned property as opposed to far more expensive commercial property, we'll have developers running here looking for property."
"It happened in Brooklyn and now in Little Neck and even Great Neck, along Northern Boulevard," the founder of the Cedar Swamp Historical Society, John Peterkin, said. "Who's to say that by the year 2000 that doesn't happen here?"
Mayor Galgano and the village trustees have not indicated their feelings on the Canon plan other than to say, "It is worthy of exploration." Mr. Galgano sent a letter to all residents summarizing the last meeting and saying that Canon and New York Tech had requested that no action be taken for the time being, allowing them to present a more cohesive plan to the board and residents.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
For the Seville Fair, the Old Geodesic Dome Trick

BYLINE: By Thomas S. Hines; Thomas S. Hines teaches cultural and architectural history at the University of California at Los Angeles.

 BODY:
In the best of all possible worlds, the United States pavilion at Expo '92 in Seville would be an elegant and sophisticated building. It would be a graceful bow from the leading nation that rose from the lands Columbus discovered when he set sail from Palos de la Frontera 500 years ago. But that building is not going to appear. A design that met those requirements has been scrapped in favor of two tired geodesic domes that have been retrieved from a Government warehouse and plunked down on the United States site. Writing about it in The Wall Street Journal, the American reporter Amy Gamerman said: "Expo watchers are laughing up their sleeves at the cheapo hybrid pavilion, dubbing it 'Twin Peaks.' It will look especially mingy on the enormous U.S. site."
 While Spain will hold center stage as host of the world's fair, beginning next April, the United States is the designated guest of honor. It would seem that the country would have seized the moment. Yet all signs point to a potential national embarrassment, with plans for America's presentation of itself botched and compromised by bureaucratic bungling and a lack of vision. 
 Plans for the American Pavilion at Seville '92 began with appropriately ambitious visions. President Reagan wrote to King Juan Carlos promising a strong American presence. On Nov. 28, 1989, President Bush confirmed this commitment in a letter to Bruce Gelb, then director of the United States Information Agency, the body that oversees American participation in international fairs. "I am confident," the President wrote, "that when the nations of the world gather in Spain to mark the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage to the New World, the United States will have an exhibition that represents the energy and genius of our people."
 A panel appointed by the agency -- and composed largely of Government exhibition designers and administrators -- culled, from more than 70 entries, design proposals submitted by nine prestigious American firms: Arquitectonica; Davis, Brody & Associates; Holt Hinshaw Pfau Jones; Barton Myers Associates; Cesar Pelli & Associates; Antoine Predock; Site; Venturi & Scott-Brown, and a team effort by Frank Gehry and Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Ultimately, Gehry and S.O.M. joined Arquitectonica and Venturi & Scott-Brown to design a pavilion that would express American national and architectural diversity.
 Most of these imaginative, go-for-broke schemes came in well above the construction budget of $7.5 million. Even adding $10 million for inflation, designer and consulting fees, landscaping and exhibition installation costs, the sum was paltry compared to the $80 million projected for the Japanese pavilion and $40 million that financially pressed Britain had already appropriated.
 Although the panel ranked Antoine Predock's design first, Bruce Gelb chose the Barton Myers design, which was ranked second, as being "more feasible." Myers proposed a village of forms that could be contracted or expanded depending on the extent to which the budget could be augmented by increased appropriations or by contributions from the private sector. Roger Lewis, the only architect on the jury, says it was "thoughtfully conceived, thoroughly developed and slickly presented," with the "right mix of architectural potency, exhibition practicality and technical feasibility."
 Visitors would enter the pavilion through a wall of gently cascading water, symbolizing the Atlantic Ocean, and proceed via ramps and garden walks to the various exhibition spaces to "Rediscover America."
 In view of the national deficit, the recession and the limited exhibition budget, Myers had chosen not to go for a monumental structure on the scale of Edward Stone's 1958 pavilion at Brussels or even of Fuller's dome at Montreal. "Times had changed," Mr. Myers says. "That sort of statement wasn't necessary or appropriate. Here we could represent America in another way. Instead of being big and bombastic, our design tried to be gracious and elegant." Three large "sails" would allude to the caravels of Columbus and would track the sun as shading devices. At night, both the sails and the water wall would serve as a scrim upon which multiple images of "rediscovered America" would be projected. To ameliorate the 110-degree-plus temperatures, 50 outdoor cooling towers reminiscent of Don Judd sculptures would represent the 50 states.
 In 1989, the Bush Administration's budget for the 1990 fiscal year included money to build the pavilion. But for political reasons, the chairmen of the House and Senate Appropriations subcommittees -- Representative Neal Smith, Democrat of Iowa, and Senator Ernest Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina -- held up the request. The stumbling block was a disagreement with Mr. Gelb over his cost-cutting proposal to eliminate the Lao, Slovene and Uzbek languages from Voice of America broadcasts. Until Mr. Gelb relented and restored the languages, the American pavilion was held hostage.
 On Feb. 20, 1990, Senator Hollings wrote to Mr. Gelb that he should "be advised that Seville has no priority with me. Our highest priority has to be getting the agency's basic funding stabilized and not worrying about fairs." A week earlier, The New York Times had quoted Representative Smith as saying: "I don't have anything against world's fairs, but I don't think the Federal Government should be paying for them."
 After the loss of a crucial year that should have been spent in construction, Myers's $7.5 million construction estimate had risen, after spiraling inflation and dollar-peseta fluctuations, to $17,220,000, according to Allen Bryant, the Navy project manager, with overall costs estimated at $24,600,000. Congress belatedly appropriated $13 million, a fraction of the U.S.I.A.'s total expenditures of $926 million for the same fiscal year. When contractors' bids for the Myers design came in, the United States ranked 38th in total pavilion costs among the approximately 100 countries participating. In the Americas, Canada seemed to have no trouble raising adequate funds; the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico was also moving ahead with an impressive pavilion, as were most of the Latin American countries. At least some of Columbus's discovered lands would be adequately represented.
 In January, Frederick Bush, the newly appointed American Commissioner-General for Expo '92, and an experienced fund raiser for George Bush's Presidential campaign, concluded that additional funds were not forthcoming and decided suddenly to abandon the Myers proposal. To fill the vacuum, he retrieved from agency warehouses two geodesic domes that the U.S.I.A. had been using since the 1970's for small trade fairs. At this point Barry Howard, one of the two exhibition designers, resigned in protest. A disappointed Barton Myers stayed on reluctantly as consultant to the U.S.I.A., his name no longer attached to the remnants of his original design. Pale vestiges of his water wall and shade sails survived, though in different sizes and locations and without the elegant village of structures that gave them meaning.
When the ax fell on his pavilion design, Mr. Myers's protestations went unheeded. No one on the design team was able to get through to President Bush, then preoccupied with the gulf war. At this point, Frederick Bush also shifted ground philosophically. "We decided that the architecture is really not the reason people are coming to Expo," he said in May. "We're not there to build a monument to the architect; we're there to build U.S. tourism." It is difficult to understand Mr. Bush's implicit argument that good architecture and tourism are incompatible.
 How the United States pavilion at Expo '92 will turn out is a matter of conjecture. Frederick Bush is optimistic about finishing the task on time and under budget. The geodesic frames, he says, will be reclad. The exhibits, moreover, are being paid for entirely from corporate coffers, with no Federal monies expended on "content." The pavilion centerpiece will be a film by General Motors, which Mr. Bush insists will be a "wonderful surprise." Once again we are faced with the question of whether what is good for General Motors is good for the country. Those who pay the bills do get to tell the story, and while that story may be skillfully presented, it will still be GM's vision of America.
 It is a lost opportunity for the country and for architecture.

HEADLINE: New Mortgage Rules Help New Buyers

BYLINE: By JUDY GLASS

 BODY:
THE softening real-estate market and low-interest mortgages are making it easier for first-time buyers to buy houses on the Island.
"Smaller starter houses are what's moving," the chairwoman of the Affordable Housing Committee at the Long Island Board of Realtors, Barbara Roberts. Ms. Roberts is also a broker at the John Flynn Realty Corporation in Kings Park. 
 Almost 2,000 State of New York Mortgage Agency loans at a fixed rate of 8.4 percent loans have been written in the last year. Until last year the mortgages, which call for 5 percent down payments, were of little use on the Island because the caps on house prices and buyers' incomes were too low for the market, Miss Roberts said. Last year the state raised the limits.
Suffolk County has led the state, receiving 1,413 state loans. Nassau County is third, with 527.
The loans are intended is to assist low- and moderate-income families and help economically depressed areas.
"Sonyma does a huge amount of business in Suffolk County because we have aggressive lenders there, and the county has been very aggressive about affordable housing," said Toni Langkau, director of marketing and community development for the mortgage agency.
The price limit for resales in Nassau and Suffolk is $148,900. For a new single-family house the cap is $176,200.
 
More Than 19,000 Listings
 If a house is in a "target area" that the Federal and state governments have designated for extra assistance, the maximum is $182,000 for an existing house and $201,300 for a new house.
"The drop in real-estate prices during the recession has built the inventory of houses that qualify," Miss Roberts said. Her board held two housing fairs in the spring.
The Multiple Listing Service has 7,351 houses, co-ops and condos for sale at less than $150,000 and 12,562 for less than $160,000.
An abode, which can also be a co-op, condo or mobile home, has to be a full-time residence in the state and meet rules on size and condition.
A single person or couple buying for the first time is defined as not having had an ownership interest in a primary residence for the three years before the mortgage. The buyer cannot earn more than $54,500 a year if the house is in a nontarget area or more than $65,400 if the house is in a target area.
A buyer has to have a steady job, a good credit background, a 5 percent down payment, approximately 7 percent of the purchase price for closing costs and private mortgage insurance, if the down payment is less than 20 percent of the price.
The limits are higher for the prices on multiple-family houses and larger families' incomes.
Most loans are to couples and families buying single-family houses, Miss Roberts said.
Lenders want to give loans to people who have the willingness and ability to pay them off, said Karen Klee, president of the Long Island Association of Professional Mortgage Women and operations manager of the Sears Mortgage Company in Melville.
The lenders' market, including savings and loan institutions, banks and private lenders, is very competitive on Long Island, Miss Klee said.
"Buyers who cannot qualify for a Sonyma should shop around," she said. Federal Housing Administration and Veterans Administration mortgages are at 9.5 percent.
Sears, like all Sonyma lenders, will help determine prospective buyers' qualifications.
Most lenders, including Sonyma, use a "28-36 guideline" to measure the ability to buy a house, Miss Klee said. A family's monthly housing expenses, which include principal, interest, insurance and taxes, should not exceed 28 percent of the gross monthly income. Other debts like credit cards, car loans and school loans should not exceed 36 percent of the gross monthly income.
 
'In Better Correlation'
 "Since 1987 Sonyma has rejected only 6 percent of the files submitted for review, a process that takes place after the contract has been signed," said Jonn N. Stano, vice president and director of the single-family program for the State of New York Mortgage Agency.
Purchase prices and income levels, which vary across the state, "are in better correlation on Long Island" than in the area of New York City, Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties, he said, adding that there were few low-priced houses in those areas.
The state established Mr. Stano's agency in 1970. The Federal Home Loan Bank Boards set the limits on incomes and prices because the low-interest mortgages are financed through the tax-exempt bonds.
"High taxes are a major problem on Long Island," said Maria Ferrer, owner of Realty World-Maria Ferrer Inc. in East Islip, which has placed about 30 state mortgages in the last three years. "Sonyma mortgages are for the needy. But people who meet the income limits still may not be able to afford the monthly costs."
Recently she said a young couple with a combined income of $65,000 who had $30,000 for a down payment had to forgo a $149,000 house in Islip because the taxes were $5,100 a year.
Anne Colleran, an insurance supervisor at Royal Insurance in Bohemia, bought a three-bedroom house in a target area of Central Islip for $110,000 with a state mortgage that Miss Ferrer helped obtain.
 
On $45,000-a-Year Salary
 "I was really scared about the prospect of buying a house by myself," Ms. Colleran said. "But I was also tired of paying Uncle Sam high taxes on my $45,000-a-year salary while I was renting."
She put down $9,000, even though 5 percent was required. The closing costs, including bank points, were $6,500. With taxes of $2,700, her monthly payments are $1,065. The process took 60 days.
"So many brokers are afraid that the Sonyma process takes too long," Miss Ferrer said. "But it doesn't if you have a well-constructed package."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: JERRY FRANKLIN;
Mandates Evolve for Public Television

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE

 BODY:
WHEN Jerry Franklin became president and chief executive officer of Connecticut Public Broadcasting six years ago, he said, he found a "non-aggressive station." Worse, CPTV was commonly called "sleepy TV" by the public, and had a market penetration of only 30 percent of the state's population. Not only did the station have an identity crisis, in some areas of the state it was also competing with WGBH of Boston and WNET of New York.
The Connecticut Public Broadcasting system consists of Channel 24 in Hartford, Channel 49 in Fairfield County, Channel 53 in Norwich, Channel 65 in New Haven and Channel 12 in Waterbury as well as FM radio stations in Middlefield, Norwich and Stamford. The CPTV guide, which appears in Connecticut Magazine, is produced by the station, as is its own Applause Guide. A profit-making production company called the Corporate Video Center is a subsidiary in Stamford. Mr. Franklin has turned things around for Connecticut Public Broadcasting. Now, 60 percent of the state's viewers tune in to their home station, according to Nielsen surveys. 
 A new complex for Channel 49, in the Stamford Center for the Arts, is due to begin operations this fall. And in the past four years CPTV has been nominated more than 30 times for regional Emmy awards and has won 11 for local documentaries.
Since CPTV is dependent on private and corporate donations as well as being a recipient of substantial state funds -- and all these sources have had to decrease their support with the recession -- Mr. Franklin has had to change the way he does business, he said.
From his office in the CPTV studios in Hartford, Mr. Franklin, who is 43 years old, answered some questions about the problems facing the state's public television stations. Here are some excerpts from the conversation.
Q. When did CPTV begin to feel the adverse effects of the economy?
A. We started sweating bullets two and a half years ago. We started this recession earlier. I have eliminated 40 positions during that two-and-a-half-year period. We have 100 employees now. We think we are the bottom of the curve. We see signs of improvement in all areas except the state.
Q. What do you hope to receive from the state?
A. We were supposed to get $1.2 million; that was in the Governor's budget. That's been reduced to a million. Our total budget is $16 million. It was a painful cut. We don't have any margins or cash reserves.
Q. What would happen if the $1 million grant were to be eliminated?
A. I could not cut $1 million out of this budget and operate. We'd have to sign off some of our stations. In December, if funding doesn't deteriorate further, we will sign on a third radio station. We need $80,000 to activate it.
Q. How have individual and corporate contributions been affected?
A. The number of memberships is leveling off, but we're getting more money from existing members. Our membership support is about $350,000 below last year. Corporate support is flat. This year we are about $300,000 below last year in corporate support.
Q. How has this affected CPTV's programming?
A. We're redefining. We'll do about 50 percent less of local documentaries this year. The state cutback is one reason. Arts programming will be even less. Companies are very willing to do environment and education, but arts programming has been a very tough sell. In the old days I could start spending against a contract. Now I have to have the cash.
Q. What part does the Corporate Video Center play in CPTV's overall financial picture?
A. This is a wholly-owned, for-profit subsidiary. The parent company is Connecticut Broadcasting Inc. The for-profit company exists for one reason: to generate a profit. Those profits are transferred, usually on a quarterly basis, to the parent company. I give Reagan credit for that. We provide videos for Fortune 500 companies, training films, videos for annual meetings. That's a good business for us. It's a little soft this year. We're under budget. This year the for-profit subsidiary will contribute about $300,000.
Q. What does the future hold in terms of programming?
A. We don't think for a moment that we will become the 'GBH or 'NET of Connecticut. But we believe that national programming is a part of who we are. For example, we're totally in synch with the new PBS, if you take a look in terms of where PBS is going with children's programming. Children's programming is one of our mandates. We had said four years ago that we wanted to get into producing programs for children.
"Barney," a life-sized purple dinosaur, already existed in the home video market. CPTV was awarded a $2.25 million grant by PBS and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting to produce a 30-part series for preschoolers. We're going into production this month. Barney will premiere in April 1992 on all PBS stations. It has the potential of being the biggest children's program since "Sesame Street."
Q. Do CPTV's Connecticut documentaries air nationally?
A. We say that we are a national institution. We take part of Connecticut and share it with the nation. We did that last year with "Lighthouses of New England," "The Nautilus" and "Swim Across the Sound." Seven to eight projects air nationally each year.
Q. Besides children's programming, what else is important to CPTV?
A. The other area of importance to us is science programming. The citizens of Connecticut think of CPTV as their science-environmental-nature station. We're riding down the science rail.
We have the most popular science series on PBS -- "Scientific American Frontiers." We get $2 million from GTE to do those shows. It's a prime-time PBS series. We're more excited by the fact that 20 million students used that in their classrooms last year.
No one has that kind of classroom penetration. We want two or three others like that -- smart programs.
Q. What does your new partnership with the National Science Foundation involve?
A. We're going to try to use television to persuade parents that there is a desperate need for better ways to teach science and math in the classroom. For example, we will visit a high school in Bridgeport, go into a science class and show you the less-than-state-of-the-art laboratories and antiquated teaching facilities. Then we'll go across the street to a high-tech, engineering-based, computer-based, laser-equipment-type company to show you the kind of students this company needs. It's going to be a yearlong series of vignettes, two- to four-minute pieces that will run throughout our schedule.
Q. Has CPTV been controversial?
A. We like to influence public opinion: it's our mission. We did about 35 different documentaries on Connecticut issues. One of them was called "Bloodsports?" We wanted to look at the issue of the rights of hunters and the animal-rights activists. To use a cliche, we had both groups mad at us, so I guess it was balanced. In the McNeil-Lehrer tradition we covered all sides of the issue.
We did "Connecticut's Drug Web"; that was controversial, as was "The Other Connecticut," which showed the two sides of Connecticut, the rich and the poor. That turned some heads. We put them smack in the middle of prime time, to make people squirm. We did a show on "children killing children." That had a positive impact on the legislature. There's a law on the books that parents are responsible for their kids' actions. We did the same thing on the environment. The E.P.A. uses our documentaries.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jerry Franklin, president and chief executive officer of Connecticut Public Broadcasting. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 8; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1190 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Riverside, Calif.;
The Welcome Mat's Out for 'Granny Flats'

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: RIVERSIDE, CALIF.

 BODY:
AMONG the fruits of a special zoning law in this desert community 70 miles east of Los Angeles is an 800-square-foot apartment in the backyard of Anthony and Darla Riggio, which the couple built last year as a home for Mr. Riggio's retirement-age parents.
Under Riverside's so-called "Granny Flats" ordinance, which encourages the construction of apartments on the lots of existing single-family homes, the Riggios applied for and received a permit to build the unit. Mr. Riggio, a former roofer who drives a delivery route, spent five months and $40,000 building the free-standing apartment with the help of friends and contractors. 
 Set 40 feet behind the existing house, the new apartment allows the elder Riggios to remain independent. "They keep to themselves, and they are farther away from us than our neighbors," Mrs. Riggio said.
Riverside is unusual among American cities for the creation of zoning, enacted in 1983, that allows accessory apartments, which are self-contained units with separate entrances and kitchens.
Yet even in California, where state law protects such apartments from being outlawed by local governments, the practice remains unpopular in many communities, and restrictions are common.
Some homeowners see such apartments as a source of extra income or an alternative to old-age homes for aging relatives. They may also represent a way to adapt existing housing to the changing nature of American households, said Tom Cook, deputy director of the California Department of Housing and Community Development in Sacramento.
A 1950's-style one-family home that formerly housed two parents and three children may now be "divided among a single mother, her child and an elderly person," he said.
Many urban planners consider rental units in homes a valuable resource in a nation with a shrinking amount of land to house a growing population. A report released last June by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, "Not in My Backyard: Removing Barriers to Affordable Housing" called accessory apartments "an easily attainable and relatively inexpensive" strategy for increasing the amount of affordable housing.
Patrick Hare, a planning consultant in Washington, contends that accessory apartments could increase the stock of rental housing nationally by 14 percent if the units were legal everywhere. Since the units typically rent for below-market rates, Mr. Hare said he considers accessory apartments a potential source of affordable housing.
Yet both political and practical problems cast shadows on the future of accessory apartments.
Despite the economic and social benefits that planners like Mr. Hare perceive in accessory apartments, such units are often political hot potatoes. Neighborhood residents often think of the units as adding both to the density and the traffic of their neighborhoods, and fear a decline in property values.
When the Riggios held a routine public hearing in the course of applying for a special permit to build their apartment, a dissenting neighbor "said we wanted to make the neighborhood into a ghetto, like East L.A.," Mrs. Riggio recalled.
While Mr. Hare said no evidence exists that accessory apartments harm property values, many communities in California continue to discourage such units, even if communities cannnot ban them outright.
Eliza Shefler, a resident of Albany, a small town directly north of Berkeley, has repeatedly tried and failed to legalize an existing 400-square-foot rental apartment behind her house.
Ms. Shefler, a masseuse and musician, has found herself a reluctant lightning rod in a land-use furor. Earlier this year, the City Council threw out an earlier decision by the Planning Commission approving the apartment. Ms. Shefler tried again, this time describing the unit as an "affordable" housing unit and citing a state law forbidding cities from turning down affordable projects, if local housing codes do not comply with state law.
Albany's housing codes indeed do not comply with California law, but city officials nonetheless turned away Ms. Shefler's challenge, citing a possible "negative impact on public health and safety" from increased on-street parking.
"I have not given up," Ms. Shefler saId, "but they are really giving me a hard time."
Most typical are parking requirements that are difficult or impossible to comply with, like those in Albany, which require two off-street parking spaces for every dwelling -- meaning that homeowners like Ms. Shefler must find space for four off-street spaces, two spaces for herself and two for her tenant.
Even Riverside's "Granny Flat" ordinance is restrictive: the units are limited to people aged 60 and older and homeowners must pay a nonrefundable filing fee of $2,500 for a permit.
Communities must do more to promote accessory apartments beyond mere legalization, Mr. Hare, the planning consultant, said. Homeowners who are otherwise willing to build the units may find themselves with little information or support about the rental marketplace or how to price the unit. Homeowners, he said, "need someone who will say, 'here is how you get financing, here is where you can go to get a tenant.' "
But John Trauth, executive director of the Development Fund, a nonprofit housing research group in San Francisco, called Mr. Hare's marketing notion "naive."
Mr. Trauth cited his own experience in conducting a marketing program to sell homeowners on the idea of "granny flats."
Called the Double Unit Opportunity Program, it offered architectural assistance and feasibility studies to homeowners in four Northern California counties and in the city of Berkeley.
But Mr. Trauth said the results were mixed. Many homeowners who started out wanting to build accessory units later lost heart when they became aware of the time, expense and trouble involved. Mr. Trauth acknowledged that such units "are quite difficult to do." He was able to help in the creation of only 42 out of a goal of 100.
"As a program to create a lot of affordable housing," he said, "this was not the one."
For homeowners less handy than Mr. Riggio, who was able to build his accessory apartment largely by himself, an easier route may be new homes already equipped with rental units.
The concept is being tested in the 1,000-acre Laguna West subdivision in Sacramento County, 11 miles south of the state capital. A newly crafted zoning code allows granny flats atop detached garages.
"We have nothing to lose by offering buyers something that makes a lot of sense," said Phil Angelides, president of River West Developments of Sacramento, which plans to sell land to developers for a maximum of 3,370 one-family homes and apartments.
Although no "granny flats" have yet been built in the subdivision, Mr. Angelides said 25 percent of potential buyers have expressed interest in buying homes with separate apartments.
Moreover, buyers who now say no to accessory apartments can build them in the future. "If they don't want 'granny flats' in 1991," Mr. Angelides said of buyers, "they'll want them in the year 2000, when their parents are 70."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anthony and Darla Riggio and his parents, Frank and Noralee, with apartment in Riverside, Calif. (Michael Tweed for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1059 words

HEADLINE: The Democrats Get Their Chance

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is director of Soviet and East European studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Soviet Union came out of this week's coup in the uncertain state that follows peaceful revolution: The institutions of the old order were discredited, but still standing. The insurgents enjoyed immense moral authority, but did not know who would follow their orders.
This ambiguity could not last. The gentlemanly coalition between Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin that many experts -- and President Bush himself -- believed would be the best basis for reform began to dissolve almost immediately. 
 Cooperation between the two leaders would, of course, have matched the immediate post-revolutionary pattern of most of Eastern Europe after 1989. In Poland, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski remained president for more than a year after he agreed to the formation of a Solidarity cabinet. For months after the Berlin wall came down, East Germany had a coalition Government under a Communist prime minister. Even President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia picked a Communist prime minister.
The slow change-over in Eastern Europe reflected the near-total passivity with which the old order yielded to the democratic revolution. The army and the police had largely stayed indoors. Leaving the machinery of government temporarily in place, to be slowly remade, seemed safe enough. It was in any case hard to replace an entire bureaucracy overnight.
Meanwhile the Communist Party was left to wither slowly, until elections -- held within six months in almost every country of Eastern Europe -- swept it away.
Mr. Gorbachev would have been lucky to be offered a partnership on the Eastern European model: some inelegant combination of General Jaruzelski and Gregor Gysi, the man who became leader of the East German Communist Party when no one else would take the job.
But the role of Communist junior partner was certain to be more precarious than in Eastern Europe, and Mr. Gorbachev made matters worse by wanting for more. Gregor Gysi's clothes look painfully small to the father of perestroika.
The first problem was the remaking of the Soviet state. Nowhere in Eastern Europe was there anything like this week's coup. We may laugh at the plotters for their bumbling, but let us recall who they were: the leaders of every single major institution of the Soviet state, without exception. Those who turned the coup back, leaders and crowds alike, inevitably demanded that these institutions be dismantled.
Mr. Gorbachev, by contrast, tried to focus attention on personnel -- rooting out those who took part in or supported the coup, instead of breaking the system they represented. There was the same evasiveness in his initial statements that no time should be lost in returning to the business of reform.
From the moment the junta fell, Boris Yeltsin pursued a different agenda. He wanted extensive formal checks on the military and the K.G.B., a renegotiation of the union treaty to win new rights for the republics and other measures that cut the central Soviet bureaucracy down to size. Many of these steps were taken in the usual manner of a victorious revolutionary leader -- by decree. If Mr. Yeltsin envisioned a partnership with Mr. Gorbachev, its prime purpose was to destroy his partner's power base.
A far more dangerous problem for Mr. Gorbachev was the surge of anti-Communist anger. The party stayed behind the scenes during the coup, but Mr. Yeltsin immediately labeled it one of the principal villains. He declared it "must be removed from power" and clearly meant it. Once he suspended the Communist Party of the Russian republic, the unionwide party was clearly going to be next.
For Mr. Gorbachev, even resigning from his post as party leader may now be inadequate. It will not be forgotten that in his first statements after being released he took exactly the same line he had taken at the last meeting of the Central Committee in July: that is, his goal was to purify the party by driving the hard-liners out. Mr. Gorbachev's outlandish claim that the party can be a living force for perestroika increased the risk that he would be caught in a political confrontation over its future. The crowds in the street may soon turn their wrath not just on the party, but on him.
For Mr. Yeltsin, much more is at stake than personal rivalry (although he plainly enjoys Mr. Gorbachev's comeuppance). He has to fashion a political program that will weather the hard economic times ahead. He knows that in Eastern Europe only one democratic government has fallen since 1989 -- the Solidarity cabinet formed by Tadeusz Mazowiecki two years ago this month. Having carried out a convulsive economic reform, Mr. Mazowiecki was gravely weakened by the charge that too many Communists had been kept on, enriching themselves in the course of privatization. (Even Western aid did not help him.)
Mr. Yeltsin has to do what Mr. Mazowiecki proved unable to do -- sustain popular belief that, despite hardship, a real revolution has taken place. He will be helped by the fact that he has the commanding style of Lech Walesa, the man who brought Mr. Mazowiecki down. But, beyond style, he will be helped most by the substance of Mr. Walesa's radical anti-Communist message. Only this provides the legitimacy that can carry a new regime forward.
The failure of this week's coup will at last put an end to discussion, by both Soviet and Western analysts, of the "Pinochet model." This was the comparison between the Soviet Union and other states, like Chile or South Korea, that made a breakthrough to democracy after a long period of military rule. Exponents of this neo-authoritarian fantasy insisted that only a very repressive Soviet regime could deal with the social tensions created by rapid marketization. A government of liberal reformers would be unable to hold the country together.
The coup exposed a huge problem with the Pinochet scheme: The only institutions able to enforce it had no interest in liberal results. Yet it is still unclear whether the other half of the neo-authoritarian argument is right. Can a democratic government run the Soviet Union where dictatorship failed? In rallying the people, Boris Yeltsin and his allies have given the most hopeful imaginable answer. They have shown that in a revolution -- and, what is now even more important, in its aftermath -- force is not the only form of power.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: EUROPE (95%); GERMANY (92%); EASTERN EUROPE (91%); UNITED STATES (79%); POLAND (79%); CENTRAL EUROPE (57%); 

CITY: BERLIN, GERMANY (79%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: ;UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS EUROPE (95%); GERMANY (92%); EASTERN EUROPE (91%); UNITED STATES (79%); POLAND (79%); CENTRAL EUROPE (57%); BERLIN, GERMANY (79%);

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1615 words

HEADLINE: Zapped!

BYLINE: By Todd Gitlin; Todd Gitlin, the author of "Inside Prime Time" and "The Sixties: Years of Hope, Days of Rage," is a professor of sociology at the University of California, Berkeley.

 BODY:

THREE BLIND MICE
How the Networks Lost Their Way.
By Ken Auletta.
656 pp. New York:
Random House.
$25.  
 Once upon a time, there was an American Century. Bread was white, menace was red, computers were I.B.M., cars were General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, and television was CBS, NBC and ABC. But the world has been rewired, and the mighty, after trumpeting great plans, are in decline. At the networks, as elsewhere, capitalism continues its mission of what the economist Joseph Schumpeter called "creative destruction." In "Three Blind Mice," Ken Auletta aims to take us behind the scenes and show us just how creative -- and hilarious and wasteful -- are the means of destruction and self-destruction.
By 1984, when Mr. Auletta's story begins, jaded network audiences were already slipping away to local and cable competitors, and so, therefore, were advertisers' dollars. In 1976, 92 percent of households watching television in prime time were tuned to one of the networks, Mr. Auletta reports; by 1984, that figure had shrunk to 75 percent. (In 1991, it hovers around 60 percent.) The old titans -- William S. Paley at CBS and Leonard Goldenson at ABC -- were fading, and new cable competitors were looming on the horizon. The more homes acquired cable and videocassette recorders, the more network profits shrank.
Enter America's most impressive innovation of the 1980's: Wall Street ingenuity. The old guard at the networks knew it was only a matter of time before corporate raiders put them in play. CBS, ABC and NBC's proprietor, RCA, were vulnerable, their stocks believed to be undervalued. Investors like Donald Trump and T. Boone Pickens were trading large blocs of RCA stock. Ted Turner, Ivan Boesky and even Jesse Helms -- who in 1985 aided a group of conservative investors in an effort to buy a controlling interest -- cast their eyes on what CBS people had long called "Mr. Paley's candy store." Each network wanted a big protector -- an investor with plenty of cash. But any protector big enough to keep predators at bay was also big enough to gobble up the company itself.
So it was that in the course of 1985 and 1986, the Big Three television networks were bought out -- ABC by Capital Cities, a chain of television and radio stations; CBS by the billionaire Laurence A. Tisch and his brother, Preston Robert, who had made money in hotels, theaters, oil tankers and clever trading; NBC (and the rest of RCA) by General Electric. The new proprietors came in bent on controlling costs. Eventually they ended up doing what came naturally to the networks: throwing money at the Hollywood studios or the National Football League to produce more hit programs.
Laurence Tisch, whom the aging William Paley perhaps inadvertently called "Larry Kitsch" at a 1987 meeting, proved himself a particular piker. For openers he closed down CBS's high-tech lab and its minority-advancement program, along with the bargain store that served employees and two of the five kitchens that served nine private dining rooms. Mr. Tisch even griped about the cost of a bagel at the Beverly Hills Hotel. He conducted CBS meetings with an eye on the Financial News Network's stock quotations. He wielded what looked to him like a scalpel and looked to the network's news division like an ax. Within a few years, with CBS badly lagging in the ratings, Mr. Tisch overcompensated by wildly overbidding for sports.
For their part, Mr. Auletta reports, NBC's new General Electric bosses, while less colorful, also came on like newsbusters. "We will not operate this business with both belt and suspenders," read a memo from NBC's new president, Robert Wright. News would now be expected to make money. At ABC, meanwhile, the grand acquisitors from Cap Cities introduced themselves with party games, like passing out halves of 10-dollar bills to executives at a management retreat with instructions to find the matching half. The Cap Cities executives quickly learned that the light hand imposes layoffs more smoothly than the heavy.
Mr. Auletta, a columnist for The Daily News and the author of "Greed and Glory on Wall Street" and "The Underclass," had remarkable access to these goings-on. The principals let him wander the corridors, attend sales and affiliate meetings and brainstorming sessions about prime time schedules. He was a fly on the wall when Laurence Tisch paid court to the fading emperor of schlock, Aaron Spelling, father of "Charlie's Angels" and "The Love Boat" among other hits, and the two men exchanged awkward small talk.
Often the fly is on the right wall at the right time. Mr. Auletta catches the frantically upbeat style of the network sales force, the anger of the affiliates, the priceless moment when Mr. Spelling pitches to Brandon Tartikoff, at the time NBC's chief programmer, his one-sentence idea for a new series: "Student nurses in Dallas in the summer and the air conditioning doesn't work so they sweat a lot!" ("It's a 40 share!" said Mr. Tartikoff, using industry jargon for a hugely popular program. "Let's do it!") At such moments, Mr. Auletta approaches the Balzacian satirical force that writing about television demands.
But over all, "Three Blind Mice" lacks a sense of proportion. For scores of pages, the fly buzzes around the trivia of office politics. Like a sports announcer frightened of dead air, Mr. Auletta clogs his story with stray statistics. Details, pungent the first time, get repeated like twitches of the dying dinosaur's tail. We are flooded with ineffectual and inept atmospherics: the wife of Lawrence Grossman, the head of NBC news, had "dark eyes" that "moved about like sentries"; General Electric's chairman and chief executive officer, Jack Welch, had "eyes like pale blue moons in a clear sky." It isn't enough that the author sets up a conflict -- between Thomas Wyman, the chairman of CBS, and Laurence Tisch, the white knight turned takeover artist, or between Mr. Grossman and NBC's new corporate owners; he must take the reader through every telephone conversation in which the principals diagnose the last meeting, every meeting preparing the next meeting. When he does build up suspense, he often enough explodes it with a little-did-they-know flash-forward.
The result often reads like an interminable mini-series, as if length were truth. At the same time, there are important figures who get only the shortest of shrift -- like Roone Arledge, the president of ABC News and Sports, who laments, "I don't see anyone with a dream or vision or concept of what television ought to be." But although we learn the name of the restaurant where Mr. Arledge worries, Mr. Auletta fails to explore what that "dream or vision or concept" might be. By the same token, he fails to scrutinize the outgoing ABC president Fred Pierce's example of "vision": his kitchsy coverage of the Statue of Liberty bicentennial extravaganza.
Admirably, Mr. Auletta writes that he set out "to avoid . . . romanticiz[ing] the past in order to sharpen the portrait of current villains." But this habit of network chroniclers is hard to kick. Even his subtitle, "How the Networks Lost Their Way," implies that the networks were once on their way, when, in fact, their longtime success was largely a function of oligopoly.
The revered Mr. Paley, known for his "Tiffany network," programmed more like K Mart. (If he is to be congratulated for "All in the Family," mustn't he also be blamed for "The Beverly Hillbillies"?) The diversification (such as the purchase of the Yankees in 1966) that cost CBS many a pretty penny was Paley's doing. Laurence Tisch may be a technological naif who doesn't grasp the importance of innovation, but according to Sally Bedell Smith's recent biography, "In All His Glory," Paley's career is also littered with faulty technological decisions.
Indeed, Mr. Auletta repeatedly takes at face value what his informants tell him about the results of the network takeovers. An ABC producer complains: "There are whole parts of the world we don't cover because it's not cost-effective. We have not covered Haiti in the last four months." But in the glorious 1970's whole years went by when countries like Nicaragua and El Salvador, both in the throes of civil war, received not an instant of coverage on network news. One also wonders: Would CBS's programs be any different from what they are today if General Electric had bought CBS and the Tisch brothers had bought NBC? Did the networks differ significantly in their coverage of the the Persian Gulf war?
Arguably the answer to these questions is no, in which case the profiles and foibles of corporate bigwigs don't matter so much. General Electric's Jack Welch may be the Roman Catholic son of a featherbedding railroad worker, NBC's Bob Wright the Roman Catholic son of an engineer and Laurence Tisch the Jewish son of a clothing manufacturer from Bensonhurst, but their different origins seem to have produced similarly ham-handed management styles.
At his best, Mr. Auletta knows that character is not the whole of corporate destiny. He lucidly explains the structural forces operating on the industry -- notably the finances of network-affiliate relations and the networks' futile efforts to get the Federal Communications Commission to revise the rules that restrict them from sharing in the multibillion-dollar syndication market. And for all his piety before the cliche that "a mass medium creates a sense of community," he gives us ample reason to marvel, not that the networks are losing their grip on that community, but that they kept it as long as they did, and that a great nation accorded them the right to do so.

HEADLINE: Don't Extend Free-Trade Pact to Mexico

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Free-Trade Accord Is Enticing Canadian Companies to U.S." (front page, Aug. 9) stops short of presenting what would occur if the United States free-trade accord with Canada were extended to Mexico. There would be a stampede of United States companies to benefit from the truly low wage scales prevalent there, plus the low taxes and lax, if any, government regulation on the environment and social welfare. 
 Thousands in the United States would be unemployed. What could they be retrained for? Massive social, political and economic problems would result.
Canada is slowly and painfully starting to realize its mistake. If Quebec secedes, the rest of the country will have no choice except to be a United States satellite, officially or not. Canada, with 25 million inhabitants, lost its leverage in trading with the United States when trade and tariff barriers were removed and American goods could enter without the tariffs that had previously protected Canadian jobs and industry.
Let us pray that the concern for America's domestic problems will cause this country's leaders to realize that the accord with Mexico could bring massive problems affecting every aspect of our life, and not for the good.
 
ALAN PALL
New Hyde Park, L.I., Aug. 9, 1991

HEADLINE: Coup Barely Slowed Visiting U.S. Investors

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
For a group of American money managers seeking investment opportunities in the Soviet Union last week, it was business as usual, despite the tanks.
"Everyone, on all sides of the conflict, was demonstrating that the business arrangements they were making would continue, regardless of the coup," Dean LeBaron, the leader of the American group, said yesterday in a telephone interview from his summer home in New London, N.H. "The association between politics and economics is more in the eyes of Westerners than the Soviets." 
 Mr. LeBaron, the chief executive of Batterymarch Financial Management in Boston, has been spending a lot of time in the Soviet Union meeting with politicians and officials of companies that are to be privatized. A group he headed arrived in Moscow on Sunday, Aug. 18, the day before the short-lived coup was disclosed.
Throughout the week, the group met with government and business officials in Moscow, Kiev and Leningrad, seeing a society try, successfully for the most part, to function as normal even while hard-line Communists seized power and then lost it. The Americans flew home on Friday, using the same private planes that had flown them around the Soviet Union.
"Even while the coup was in place," added Dennis A. Tito, the president of Wilshire Associates, a pension consulting firm and a member of the group, "the commitment of all the people we met continued to be very solid in moving toward a market economy." Mr. Tito was interviewed by telephone yesterday from his home in Santa Monica, Calif.
Mr. LeBaron, who hopes to invest about $200 million from a Batterymarch fund in a group of Soviet companies this fall, said he thought the eventual makeup of the Government in the Soviet Union would have had little impact on the opening of the country to Western capital.
"Politics matter some, but it is not the overwhelming thing," he said. "The Soviet Union needed us before this coup, and still needs us now."
Aleksandr N. Kuznetsov, an official of a Leningrad company in which Batterymarch plans to invest, said he thought economic reform would have been set back if the coup had succeeded. "These persons," he said of the coup leaders, "were eager to keep all of the ties with the Western countries in their hands." That, he said, would have made joint ventures much more difficult to arrange.
But Mr. Kuznetsov, who was staying with Mr. LeBaron in New London, is now optimistic about the chances for Soviet economic reform -- in part because of the promotion of Ivan Silayev, a Russian republic official who signed the degree for a free economic zone this summer, making possible foreign investments. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev named Mr. Silayev on Saturday to head a committee to take charge of the national economy.
Mr. Kuznetsov is deputy director in charge of research and development for Leningrad Optical and Mechanical Enterprises. He is to become head of a Leningrad Optical venture that will seek to develop export markets for telescopes and other optical products.
That company, Mr. LeBaron said, will get investments both from a Western optical maker and from Batterymarch's new Soviet Companies Fund, in which institutional investors are participating. Mr. Kuznetsov is scheduled to present plans for the company to a meeting of the Boston Society of Securities Analysts on Wednesday, in the first such presentation in the United States by a Soviet firm.
Batterymarch has a seven-person office in Moscow, devoted to looking for opportunities, largely among companies that were involved in making products for the military. "The military sector has the best management, the best access to resources," Mr. LeBaron said.
 
Other Companies Attract Interest
 Besides Leningrad Optical, Mr. LeBaron named two other companies in which he was committed to investing. One was Leninitz, a Leningrad-based company that he said was the "closest thing to a Soviet analog to General Electric," with interests ranging from high-technology items to consumer goods and including a growing operation in financial services.
The other is an amalgam of Kiev Aircraft Production Works and the Tupelev Design Bureau. He said Kiev Aircraft would stop making its flagship product -- the largest military cargo plane in the world -- and concentrate on a 100-seat commercial aircraft, to be available in both jet and turbo-prop models. The two enterprises are being combined because Tupelev had designed the planes that Kiev built, he said.
In each case, Mr. LeBaron said, Batterymarch is attempting to find a Western partner to provide investments and marketing help. In addition, the Soviet Companies Fund will make direct investments in the firms.
When Mr. LeBaron and his colleagues were in Kiev on Wednesday, they met with officials of the Ukrainian government, who said they were determined to declare their independence from the Soviet Union but stressed that their intention should not affect investment plans, Mr. LeBaron said. The Ukrainian Parliament did declare independence on Saturday and set a referendum on the issue for Dec. 1.
 
'We First Noticed Tanks'
 Mr. LeBaron said his group heard that Mr. Gorbachev had been replaced while they were having breakfast on Monday at a house used by Batterymarch in Moscow. Later that day, when the group met with officials of a company on the outskirts of Moscow, "we first noticed tanks guarding a power station, and it was not until that point that we began thinking this was more than a normal change of Government." The first announcements had simply said Mr. Gorbachev was ill and was being replaced by his vice president.
Mr. LeBaron said that as the group continued its meetings during the week, only one of dozens of companies, a maker of subway cars, canceled a scheduled appointment.
"We had appointments with high officials of the Soviet, Russian and Ukrainian governments. "Everyone went to a great deal of effort to meet with us, to send the impression that everything would continue," Mr. LeBaron said.
When they met with officials of the Russian government, he said, "we knew they had come out from the Parliament building, where they were heavily armed." But he said the meetings were conducted on the assumption that business would continue.
In Leningrad on Thursday, he said, meetings went on as scheduled, but there was a growing sense of glee in the population as word spread that the coup had failed. "The air struck me, sort of like the air in this country after the Desert Storm war," he said. "There was a very high level of euphoria."
