HEADLINE: Blocs Seen Replacing Free Trade

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 25

 BODY:
In an unusually blunt discussion, economists and central bank officials from various countries expressed concern over the weekend that the regional trading blocs emerging in Europe, North America and Asia could eventually destroy the world's free-trade system.
A few of those attending the Federal Reserve's annual summer conference, including the keynote speaker, went a step further. They argued that the 40-year-old free-trade system, in which more than 90 nations jointly agree to lower tariffs simultaneously, had outlived its usefulness and should give way to these regional trading blocs. The blocs can use tariffs to keep out imports from nations that are not members.
 
Europe, North America Cited
 These economists said that the European Community and the emerging United States-Mexico-Canada trading zone were already proving more effective than the older free-trade system, known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, on two important counts. The blocs are generating huge increases in trade among neighboring countries, which are natural trading partners anyway. And, the economists said, regional blocs are becoming a way to exclude Japanese competitors, whose products receive equal treatment in the free-trade system. 
 "We should not backslide from the lower worldwide tariffs that have been negotiated, but the levers for going forward are broken," Paul R. Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said in the keynote address. "In the real world," he said, the trend toward regional trading blocs "is as good as we are going to get."
The conventional wisdom, often offered by the Bush Administration, is that trading blocs should supplement multilateral trade when all nations reduce tariffs and other import barriers. But those attending the two-day conference in Grand Teton National Park, organized by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, did not challenge the contention that the GATT free-trade system, under which most of the world's countries have jointly agreed every decade or so to lower tariffs, could begin to fade under pressure from the trading blocs.
 
U.S. Position Described >
 This year, the group of more than 100 economic experts included such influential officials as Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve; Jacques de Larosiere, governor of the Bank of France, and Andrew D. Crockett, executive director of the Bank of England.
Even an Administration official, Michael R. Darby, Commerce Department Under Secretary for economic affairs, acknowledged the threat that trading blocs pose to the free-trade system. "It is a problem that has to be dealt with, and it is being addressed," Mr. Darby said.
The Administration is committed in particular to promoting worldwide trade through the current GATT effort to reduce tariffs, called the Uruguay Round. These negotiations are stalled because the European Community refuses to reduce barriers to agricultural imports.
Summarizing the discussion here, Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said, "I worry about regional trading areas, presumably justified in the first instance as liberalizing trade," but potentially capable of blocking it.
Mr. de Larosiere agreed that the three emerging trading zones, in Western Europe, North America and Asia, "raised fears, and rightly so, that these blocs-in-formation will close themselves off from external partners."
That would happen if tariffs were used to exclude imports from outside these blocs.
 
Criticizing and Defending Japan
 Many of those at the conference did not take kindly to Professor Krugman's surprising observation that trading zones are a useful way to compete against Japan. Japan is often perceived as not playing by the same trading rules as other industrial nations.
Professor Krugman said that belief "has done a great deal to undermine the perceived effectivness and legitimacy of the GATT in the United States and Europe." He added, "So the great advantage of regional pacts is that they can exclude Japan."
One of those with whom the remark did not sit well was Mr. de Larosiere. Such national antagonisms afflicted France and Germany after World War II, he replied, but their political leaders, Charles de Gaulle and Konrad Adenauer, defused the anger. He said polticians today should similarly defuse the anti-Japan sentiment.
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, warned that anti-Japan sentiment, if it lasted, would result in serious trade conflicts. And Yoshio Suzuki, vice chairman of the Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo, appealed for understanding of Japan.
The emerging East Asian bloc, Mr. Suzuki said, "is not an effort to form a trading bloc, but rather to form a negotiating bloc with enough leverage to negotiate entry to the United States and the European Community." He added, "We fear the regional trade bloc trend."
But Mr. Suzuki's appeal did not meet with much sympathy from Lawrence Summers, chief economist for the World Bank in Washington. He said the GATT-style free trade sought by Mr. Suzuki failed to deal effectively with quotas and other nontariff rules that restrict imports into Japan and the United States.
 
Drawbacks of the Bloc System
 Much of the debate centered on the drawbacks of the emerging system in which European countries trade primarily among themselves, and the United States, Canada and Mexico similarly are beginning to conduct commerce as if they are one country. The main drawback to this system, economists noted, is that exports from third-world countries could easily be excluded.
What is more, Mr. Bergsten said, the United States might end up paying too much for products within the zone that could be imported more cheaply from outside it. If the United States, for example, ended its textile quota, the increased imports in a free-trade world would come from East Asia, not from Mexico, whose textiles are more expensive.
Whatever the costs of this trade diversion, one view of the future seemed widely accepted at the conference: With the European trading bloc solidified, the formation of a North American alliance in the next two years could easily tilt the world away from free trade.
"This, in turn, will make it harder for Japan and others in Asia to resist pursuing defensive arrangements of their own," Mr. Bergsten said.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Immediate U.S. Recognition Of Baltic States Is Expected

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Bush Administration expects the Baltic states to be granted independence as early as Monday and is prepared to respond immediately by giving the new countries official recognition and naming envoys, American officials said today.
Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, said Washington had been told that a motion granting the Baltics independence would be introduced in the Soviet national Parliament, which convenes Monday, and other American officials said they had assurances that the proposal would be adopted. 
 Administration officials said Washington had been pressing Soviet officials to speed independence for the Baltics through what one called "quiet diplomacy."
But Mr. Bush was holding to his cautious position that American policy will not formally change until the Soviet Union itself acts. Washington does not consider Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia to be part of the Soviet Union, but has never named an ambassador or attempted to establish formal ties.
 
U.S. in Uncomfortable Position
 That left the United States in the uncomfortable position today of resisting what several European countries have already done and what even the Russian Government has been urging. And it raised the danger for Mr. Bush that after taking the forefront in the West's resistance to the Kremlin putsch, he will end up following the lead of Europe on this and other issues involving the Soviet Union's future.
As it waited for Baltic independence, which will remove one of the greatest irritants in Soviet-American relations, the United States was moving slowly, but clearly, to change its policy on the Soviet Union in at least two other areas.
In televised interviews and in discussions with reporters here with the vacationing President, senior American officials, including Mr. Scowcroft and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, put political distance between the United States and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev while embracing President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian Federation as the real power in his country.
And Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d indicated that the United States was preparing to relax its opposition to increasing economic aid to Moscow.
Mr. Bush is certain to come under pressure on this issue as he meets in Kennebunkport this week with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, who arrived today for an overnight stay, and Prime Minister John Major of Britain, who arrives on Wednesday.
 
Indirect Messages
 But those important prospective changes were largely being telegraphed in indirect ways by senior officials, both in public and in private, and Washington's official stand continued to be one of caution and hesitation in the face of the extraordinary changes in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Bush said Washington was "just biding our time" for the Soviet Union to take action toward the Baltics and was silent for a second day on the crumbling of Communist power in the Soviet Union, an event that four decades of Presidents have made the central focus of American foreign policy.
Mr. Bush has reacted to other seminal events -- like the destruction of the Berlin Wall in 1989 -- with seeming nonchalance, in part because he prefers to conduct his foreign policy in private with a few chosen world leaders.
But it also reflects his difficulty with the public nature of the Presidency. Mr. Bush, who does best in small groups and worst when speaking to the nation about complex, emotion-laden events, flashes obvious irritation at suggestions that he should strike a more eloquent public posture on events like those in Moscow or, indeed, lead world reaction.
 
Debate Over Tactics
 Aides said the Administration's public handling of events since the coup failed in the Soviet Union also resulted from a debate over tactics in which Mr. Scowcroft, who follows Mr. Bush's predilection for secrecy and low-key public statements, prevailed over Mr. Cheney, who is given to tough talk and bold gestures.
Mr. Bush and his aides argue that they can be more effective behind the scenes than with the grand gesture. But the restrained response risks putting Mr. Bush on the sidelines, as he was during Eastern Europe's upheaval, and has already left him to follow Europe's lead on economic aid and the Baltics.
Although Administration officials said the United States would not take unilateral action on the Baltics, they said they expected the Soviet Union to free the republics quickly. "We have indications that such a motion will be introduced by some of the deputies in the Supreme Soviet," Mr. Scowcroft told reporters here.
Appearing on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Mr. Cheney said, "Well, I think that's basically a question of formality at this point. I only expect it to be a relatively short period of time until there will be recognition of the independence of the Baltic republics."
Another Administration official said: "We're telling them to let the Baltics go. We're encouraging them in that direction with quiet diplomacy and as soon as the Soviet Parliament votes, we'll recognize them almost instantaneously, and that would include naming ambassadors and the like. That will stimulate the Ukrainians and others to roll ahead too."
The United States has been waiting for concrete actions from the Soviet Union on economic reform before it agrees to boost its so-far-modest financial aid and cooperation programs.
But, hours before Mr. Mulroney arrived at Walker's Point, the Bush family compound, Mr. Baker indicated that this might change. "The explosive events over the course of the past week really will present us -- the United States and the rest of the West as a matter of fact -- with an opportunity to pursue an expanded agenda," he said in an appearance on the ABC News program "This Week."
Since Mr. Gorbachev was restored to power, Mr. Bush has taken pains to make it clear that he still considers Mr. Gorbachev the legitimate head of state, and Mr. Bush can be expected to observe protocol as long as Mr. Gorbachev is in office.
But the Administration made it clear today that it was moving away from Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Cheney, the most forthright of the senior officials who commented on the question, was asked if he thought the United States is "better off" with Mr. Yeltsin than Mr. Gorbachev. He replied, "That is clearly my view."
Mr. Cheney went on, "Boris Yeltsin at this point represents a set of principles and values that are synonymous with those that we hold for the Soviet Union -- democratization, demilitarization -- and I think that's not surprising to anybody."

HEADLINE: Ending 10 Years of Rebuilding, M.T.A. Wants 5 More

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
A $16 billion, 10-year program to overhaul New York City's subways, bus lines and commuter railroads -- one of the most costly rebuilding efforts ever undertaken in the New York region -- will come to an end this year.
But officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has directed the vast project, are scrambling to convince state legislators that more rebuilding is desperately needed. And they are asking for more money -- $11.5 billion over the next five years. 
 That may be a tall order. New York State, with chronic budget shortfalls, is considered likely to approve some version of a new rebuilding plan but less likely to agree to one as ambitious as the M.T.A. is proposing. As for the Federal Government, it has been reluctant to make more financing available for local mass-transit systems.
Some state legislators have expressed their desire to help. But many note that in these tight economic times, arguments for new spending must be very compelling.
 
Concern About Wasting Money
 At issue is whether the $16 billion allocated in the last 10 years to rejuvenate the region's transit system was well spent and whether the projects proposed in the new rebuilding plan are necessary, given the region's fiscal troubles.
Some lawmakers have accused the M.T.A. of wasting billions of dollars in cost overruns and project delays in past capital spending programs. The lawmakers also say that the M.T.A. has so far done a poor job of explaining how riders would benefit from more rebuilding.
Because the transit network has been improved so much in the last decade, these lawmakers say, the need for continued rebuilding is not as crucial as it was 10 years ago, when the system was falling apart.
Supporters of the new spending plan argue that mass transit is so important to the region that further projects deserve top priority. They also argue that more rebuilding would stimulate the region's economy and create thousands of new jobs.
"Anyone who questions the need for a new capital program should think back to the days when this system went to hell," said Peter E. Stangl, the M.T.A. chairman. "If we don't finish this rebuilding effort, that's exactly where we will end up again."
Under the proposed new capital improve ment program, M.T.A. officials would continue to buy new subway cars and buses, lay new track, replace signals and other obsolete equipment and rebuild maintenance and storage yards. They also plan to refurbish subway stations and install new signs and public-address systems.
Among the improvements proposed are: electronic turnstiles designed to deter fare beaters; a subway tracking system that would better allow workers to tell where trains are and to inform passengers when trains will arrive; emergency call boxes in each subway car to allow passengers to talk to the conductor, and a connection between the 63d Street Tunnel and Queens Boulevard to reduce crowding on subway lines between Manhattan and Queens.
The work would be financed by the state, city and Federal governments.
Precisely who would benefit from a new rebuilding program is far less certain today than it was 10 years ago because fewer people are taking mass transit and service is being reduced. The M.T.A.'s subsidiary agencies -- the New York City Transit Authority, which operates the subways and buses, the Long Island Rail Road and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad -- have seen a sharp decline in ridership in the last year. Each is planning or considering fare increases and cutbacks in service to help offset swelling budget deficits.
 
A Shambles in '81
 Transit officials gained support for the last two capital rebuilding programs mainly by showing that upgrading the transit system would improve service and thus attract new riders.
In 1981, New York City's transit system was plagued by delays, derailments, track fires, mechanical breakdowns and graffiti. The situation was so bad that the State Legislature declared a "transportation emergency" and passed an $8 billion program to overhaul the system after heavy lobbying by Richard Ravitch, the M.T.A. chairman at the time.
The Transit Authority received most of the financing. Its deteriorating tracks, switches and signals were rebuilt; new subways and buses were purchased, and an aggressive anti-graffiti program was set up. The L.I.R.R. and Metro-North also bought new cars and renovated major sections of track. The work was expanded in 1986 when the Legislature passed a second $8 billion capital program.
Today, the system is vastly improved. In 1981, subway trains ran an average of only 7,000 miles between breakdowns, but now trains go an average of 30,000 miles before a failure. The graffiti that once covered trains and buses have been largely scrubbed away. More than 90 percent of the subway and bus fleet has been replaced and is air-conditioned. The commuter railroads have expanded their routes and are running closer to schedule.
 
Liking What They've Seen
 Lawmakers, mass-transit advocacy groups, regional planners and even some of the M.T.A.'s most ardent critics interviewed last week acknowledged that the rebuilding program has greatly improved the system, and all agree that a new capital program is needed.
"The misery and frustration of being booted off a train two to three times a week because of a breakdown is now a thing of the past," said Gene Russianoff, a staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a consumer advocacy group for subway and bus riders. "Was the money spent perfectly? The answer is no. But did the $16 billion result in changes that riders can see everyday? The answer is yes, yes, yes."
While lawmakers agree that some form of capital spending program will be approved, they are less confident that the M.T.A. will get the $11.5 billion it wants. Some legislators, in fact, are asking whether the transit system has improved to the point where it is now politically tolerable to postpone the rebuilding effort until the economy rebounds.
 
Demanding 'Decent Answers'
 Jerrold Nadler, chairman of the Assembly's Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committee, which would play an important role in any state financing, said he would have difficulty supporting many of the proposed projects because the M.T.A. had not indicated how the projects would improve service and ridership.
"Unless I get decent answers to these type of questions, I cannot recommend funding these projects," Mr. Nadler said. "We are seeking this information, not because we think they are hiding something from us, but because we want them to plan correctly."
But the chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee, Senator Norman J. Levy, a Republican of Melville, L.I., said that while the transit system is significantly better than it was 10 years ago, the M.T.A. has wasted billions of dollars in cost overruns and project delays through mismanagement.
The Senator said that by his calculations the M.T.A.'s capital program is about $3.5 billion over budget. He has called on State Comptroller Edward V. Regan to conduct a comprehensive audit of all capital projects. M.T.A. officials have said that such calculations are absurd and that by their best estimate the capital programs are a few hundred millions dollars over budget.
 
Planning to Lobby Hard
 M.T.A officials said that a new capital spending program is vital to preserving the improvements that have been made in the last decade and to retaining and attracting riders. The officials have made the new capital program a top priority and are planning to lobby heavily for it in Albany next month when they submit the plan to the Legislature.
The Transit Authority president, Alan F. Kiepper, said in an internal memo to another agency official last month that the authority should "avoid any service changes that would cause a distraction to legislators that might make it more difficult to gain their support."
Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Planning Association, a private research group, supports the new capital program. "It would be a hideous mistake for us to think that we have solved the problem by buying some new subway cars and buses and replacing some track."
 
More Tax Revenues and Jobs
 Mr. Anderson added that a new M.T.A. capital program would help stimulate the region's weak economy. He cited a recent study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that found that the M.T.A.'s past capital programs had stimulated $19 billion in economic activity, generated $741 million in tax revenues and created 14,000 jobs.
Still, money for the new program is uncertain. M.T.A. officials said that under the $11.5 billion capital plan they would anticipate a financing shortfall of about $5.5 billion.
Mortimer L. Downey 3d, the authority's chief financial officer, said the shortfall could be partly offset by using more revenue from taxes that were passed in June specifically for transportation needs. Raising money through bond issues was another option, Mr. Downey said. But he said the M.T.A. was less likely to do that because of the high cost of servicing the debt.

What the M.T.A. did with the $16 billion:
 Replaced or overhauled all 6,000 subway cars and 3,600 buses.
 All subway cars and buses air-conditioned and graffiti-free.
 New maintenance shops, storage yards and depots.
 All main-line subway tracks rebuilt for faster, safer rides.
 56 subway stations rehabilitated; 6 new station.
 200 new cars on Long Island Rail Road.
 Harold interlocking rebuilt on L.I.R.R., easing bottlenecks between Jamaica and Penn Station.
 More than 250 new and rebuilt rail cars on Metro-North.
 Upper Harlem line electrified on Metro-North, allowing direct service to Grand Central and reducing travel line.
 
What the M.T.A. will do with the $11.5 billion:
 Link the 63d Street subway tunnel and Queens Blvd. lines, creating another route to Manhattan for Queens commuters.
 New fans and pumps in subways to remove smoke during fire emergencies and drain the 13 million gallons of water that seep into tunnels daily.
 Automated fare collection that allows riders to pay fare using magnetic cards.
 State-of-the-art-police radio equipment that removes "blind spots" in subway tunnels.
 Electronic station signs that tell riders when the next train will arrive and what to do if there's a delay.
 Signal replacement along 150 miles of subway track, allowing trains to run faster.
 Grand Central Terminal rehabilitated.
 Third track on the Harlem line of Metro-North, allowing for more express service.
 More parking for Metro-North and LIRR customer. (Source: Metropolitan Transit Authority) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Regional trading blocs could eventually destroy the world's free-trade system, economists and central bank officials from various countries say. A few of those attending the Fed's annual summer conference, including the keynote speaker, went a step further, arguing that the 40-year-old free-trade system had outlived its usefulness and should give way to these regional blocs. [Page D1.] 
 It was business as usual, despite the tanks, for a group of American money managers who were visiting the Soviet Union last week to seek investment opportunities. Dean LeBaron, the group's leader, hopes to invest $200 million from a Batterymarch Financial fund in a group of Soviet companies this fall. [D1.]
Upheaval in the Soviet Union is forcing the West to consider greater financial aid, but Bush Administration officials and economists are uncertain which measures are most practical. [A13.]
 
Companies
Salomon named a new general counsel, Robert E. Denham, a longtime associate of Warren Buffett. He replaced Donald Feuerstein, who was asked to resign last week for failing to circumvent Salomon's managers and notify the Government directly of the firm's violations in the Treasury market. [D1.]
Designing a car from scratch is an immense financial bet, and one an auto maker must be strong enough to lose. Chrysler may not have that luxury with its latest car project, which is being hurried to completion next summer. [D1.]
 
The Economy
Orders for American-made machine tools rose 8.8 percent in July from the previous month. Still, machine tool orders this year remain well below their 1990 levels. [D2.]
An unusual form of carbon is involved in a patent dispute because it is thought to have huge commercial potential. [D1.]
Connecticut has found itself at the front of what could be a breaking wave of battles over state taxes and revenues in capitals from Austin, Tex., to Concord, N.H. [A1.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1318 words

HEADLINE: Hartford Offers Sobering Lessons As More States Face Tax Troubles

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Connecticut's bitter struggle over revamping its revenue system and imposing an income tax may be just the first in a wave of such battles in state capitols from Texas to New Hampshire, politicians and economists say.
Those experts believe that with a decrease in Federal aid and increased burdens on state governments, many state tax structures -- created primarily during two earlier periods of intense budget pressures in the 1930's and 1960's -- have become antiquated and strained. 
 "Connecticut's success in adopting an income tax, along with the other things they did in the budget, is a boost for governors and legislators who want to take on problems head on," said Steven D. Gold, the director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York at Albany.
But state government has changed markedly since the 30's or the 60's, and many politicians and economists say that a sweeping tax overhaul is probably more difficult than ever. Overall tax burdens are higher now, party controls over state politicians are weaker, legislatures are much less the kept creatures of strong governors, and the public is more cynical of politicians and their promises.
Here in Connecticut, the income-tax battle was intertwined with an unusual political drama that pitted a reluctant Legislature against a determined, independent Governor. The 4.5 percent income tax adopted on Thursday was pushed through a Democratic-controlled legislature by Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a third-party Governor who made up in fierce stubbornness what he lacked in party clout in the General Assembly.
Mr. Weicker developed a reputation as a maverick in 18 years as a liberal Republican in the United States Senate. As Governor, he vetoed three budgets and ordered a partial shutdown of the state government over the summer to drive home his insistence that "the figures" demanded dramatic change.
His actions have led many politicians and economists to ask whether changing tax systems elsewhere will take a crisis like Connecticut's or a man like Mr. Weicker -- without party ties and commitments and, perhaps, without an overweening interest in being re-elected -- or whether such a figure prolongs the turmoil.
Even states that already have an income tax, like New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts, have been thrust into political turmoil in dealing with the current intense fiscal pressures.
But the political difficulties are most acute for states that do not yet have an income or sales tax. "The political costs of originating a new tax get higher and higher the more singular the state is," said Richard F. Winters, a professor of government at Dartmouth College. "It's a lot easier to become the 26th state than to become the 47th."
Nine states have no income tax: New Hampshire, Tennessee, South Dakota, Texas, Washington, Florida, Alaska, Wyoming and Nevada. And five have no sales tax: Alaska, Delaware, Montana, New Hampshire and Oregon. State budget experts predict that perhaps half of those, led by New Hampshire, Texas and Tennessee, will try to create an entirely new tax category over the next decade, a feat achieved just twice in the last 20 years -- by New Jersey, with an income tax in 1976, and now by Connecticut.
 
New Hampshire Next?
 New Hampshire will almost certainly be the next battleground. In January, the Legislature in Concord will consider a bill to create a 6 percent flat-rate income tax, and supporters believe that they have the votes. Gov. Judd Gregg, a Republican, has vowed a veto, and the bill's main sponsor has already conceded that for the moment, an override is impossible.
"It will probably be the paramount issue in the next gubernatorial campaign" in 1992, said Representative Douglas E. Hall, a Republican and the author of New Hampshire's proposed income tax bill.
Mr. Hall, echoing the sentiments of other political observers, said Connecticut's struggles have been only marginally instructive for other states, because the tax system and public perception of it differs in each state.
And what may be instructive about Connecticut's ordeal -- with its drawn-out confrontation, threat of layoffs and likely political fallout -- is probably frightening to most politicians.
 
'Game of Chicken'
 Mr. Weicker got an income tax passed despite the lack of even a single member of his tiny party in the legislature. He proposed the income tax in February as part of a sweeping budget overhaul, then simply said no to any traditional budget alternative.
Norman Ornstein, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, said he doubted at first that Mr. Weicker would succeed here, in part because of the independence he displayed in the United States Senate.
"His greatest strength as a Senator was in standing up on the floor and saying, 'I'm going to raise terribly uncomfortable issues and make an ass of myself until you cave in,' " Mr. Ornstein said.
Alan Rosenthal, director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, said: "If you're willing to do what you believe in and fight for it, you can win -- that's what this shows. But you've got to be able to do one thing: lose an election. Weicker certainly knew what he was getting into."
 
Texas Proposal
 In the last income-tax battle, in New Jersey in 1976, Gov. Brendan T. Byrne pushed the proposal through under the weight of a court order that said the school systems were not being properly financed; a new statewide revenue source had to be found. In Connecticut, Mr. Weicker had no such mandates, but only the argument that an income tax would allow other taxes to be lowered, and so stimulate the state's depressed economy.
In Texas, Lieut. Gov. Bob Bullock proposed an income-tax plan earlier this year that was linked to a reduction in property taxes. It was rejected in the Legislature, but Brad Reynolds, a spokesman for Mr. Bullock, said the Lieutenant Governor remains committed to pressing forward. He said Mr. Bullock, who is elected independently of the governor and presides over the Senate, believes a stalemate and brinkmanship can be avoided.
Mr. Gold, of the Center for the Study of the States, said he thought that Tennessee and South Dakota would test the waters next, followed by Washington, then perhaps Florida. He said he also expected that Montana and Oregon would impose state sales taxes for the first time before the decade is out.
Declining Federal aid and soaring state costs for Medicaid and prison expansion are expected to fuel the drive. This year alone, the combined deficits in state budgets reached an estimated $50 billion, resulting in perhaps $23 billion in state tax increases, according to several surveys conducted earlier in the year. Connecticut's tax increase alone was $1.1 billion, the largest one-year jump in state history.
 
Political Risks
 But the political risks of a major tax overhaul have always been high, historians say. In the 1930's, for example, when many states imposed income or sales taxes for the first time to try to compensate for plummeting property-tax collections during the Depression, incumbent governors were kicked out of office in the next election 24 percent of the time, said Susan B. Hansen, a University of Pittsburgh professor.
Here in Connecticut, where the Democrats control both chambers of the General Assembly, and provided the majority for the income tax over the opposition of a largely united Republican minority, this summer's votes are already seen as an issue in the 1992 elections. Every member of the House and Senate will face re-election, though Mr. Weicker will not. Mr. Ornstein said the outcome would be keenly watched from Washington.
"The public debate on this question is not over," said the Connecticut Republican Party chairman, Richard Foley Jr. "Not for at least a year and a half."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Connecticut, the income-tax battle was intertwined with an unusual political drama that pitted reluctant legislators against a determined, independent Governor. One Representative, Jim O'Rourke, showed the strain last week of an all-night debate over the budget. (Steve Miller for The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Strange Contrast In Japan Economy

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
TWO recent news items here captured Japan's economic paradox in a nutshell: A survey showed that Japanese companies planned to increase capital investment in the current fiscal year by a hefty 8.4 percent, more than double the expected growth rate for the economy, which is now in the longest period of expansion since World War II; meanwhile, a tiny article noted that the Tokyo Stock Exchange, where business has been miserable, for the first time had to take out a large loan to pay its operating expenses.
The contrast between the buoyant economy, perhaps the world's most vigorous, and the sickly stock market is stark. Does the ailing market know something the economy does not? 
 There is a surprisingly wide divergence of opinions on this issue, but increasingly the experts are agreeing on one crucial point: if the stock market falls much below its current depressed level, the Japanese economy will feel the squeeze. In fact, there is growing speculation that the Bank of Japan may be forced to cut its discount rate this fall to prod the market back to life.
Many foreigners tend to favor the view that the market is expecting choppy economic waters.
Indeed, the capital investment rate, though high by the standards of any other country, is at about half the investment rate of last year. And the overall economy is expected to expand only 3.5 percent this year, down from more than 5 percent last year.
Many Japanese, on the other hand, look at the contrary directions of the market and the economy as proof of how peripheral and unimportant the stock market is to the nation's general health.
Japanese individuals play a far smaller role in the stock market here, owning only about 25 percent of the shares, compared with well over 50 percent in the United States.
By any measure, Japan has gone through an extraordinary boom in the last five years. Each year it has expanded by an amount roughly equal to the total gross national product of South Korea. A spectacular increase in capital investment has not only led the charge, but has also made Japan Inc. leaner and meaner as it roars into the 1990's.
Even so, all agree that some sort of slowdown is in store. But the varied predictions do not seem to justify the deep depression into which the market has tipped. Even before the attempted coup in the Soviet Union sent prices skidding, even before a series of financial scandals cast a pall on the financial industry, the market was floundering.
Steep interest rate rises two years ago began the slide, while Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last year delivered the coup de grace. The stock market has yet to recover.
The Nikkei index of 225 stocks has sputtered recently in a range from 21,000 to 24,000, about 40 percent below the market's peak on the last day of 1989. On Friday, the index closed at 22,065.34 after a seesaw week, and in late trading today it was down to 21,543.94. While Wall Street recovered from the shock of the Soviet coup to post a new record, Tokyo lost more than 700 points over all.
Even worse for the health of the securities industry, volume has plummeted. The average so far this year is barely 400 million shares a day, compared with a peak of more than a billion shares a day, on average, in 1988.Even those who scoffed at the problems earlier are now paying heed. If the Nikkei stock index does dip below 20,000, said Yoshihisa Kitai, chief economist at the Long-Term Credit Bank, "then the real economy would definitely be affected."
One reason is that it will become increasingly difficult for companies to finance capital investment. When the market was soaring, companies issued an unprecedented amount of securities to bolster investment programs. Much of the money was raised in the form of convertible bonds and bonds with warrants attached.
These instruments give the holders the right to buy company shares at a fixed price within a specified period. The companies, believing the market would keep rising, expected to repay the sums borrowed by issuing new shares, not with cash.
With the slump, however, most holders are expected to choose cash. According to one survey, about $73 billion worth of such bonds will come due in the next three years. One way the companies plan to make the payouts is, of course, by selling more securities. Analysts fear that the new supply could cause the market to tumble and crimp corporate Japan's ability to raise capital. So worrisome is this prospect that the Bank of Japan commented last week that it would insure that the repayments were handled smoothly, presumably by cutting interest rates.
Another way the tumbling market would affect the "real" economy is by reducing bank lending, which is already growing at its slowest pace in years. Much of the capital of Japan's banks is invested in shares. When share prices decline, their capital bases decline. And that cuts into their ability to make new loans. Once again, analysts agree that 20,000 on the Nikkei is a critical point.
"The stock market is reacting to a worst-case scenario," said Richard Koo, a senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "But I think the Bank of Japan and the Finance Ministry are scared. It's a delicate situation that is going to get much worse if the stock market falls below 20,000."

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL: SOVIETS' RUSH TOWARD DISUNION SPREADS; EUROPE EMBRACING BALTIC INDEPENDENCE;
PURGE OF MILITARY

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Following quickly on the rout of the Communist Party, the unraveling of the Soviet Union itself gained speed today, with one republic after another joining the rush to independence or laying claim to powers of the central government.
One day after the vital Ukraine declared its independence, Byelorussia unexpectedly followed suit, Moldavia announced it would vote on a similar declaration Monday, and Western governments began recognizing the secession of the three Baltic republics. 
 President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic, who has emerged in the aftermath of the failed coup by hard-liners as the predominant political figure in the country, said in a television interview that he hoped the mainstay repulics would sign a treaty next month reorganizing the country into a looser federation.
But with 8 of the 15 republics now asserting or contemplating claims of full independence, there were growing doubts that even Mr. Yeltsin could find a formula to halt the dismembering of this nuclear superpower.
 
Repercussions of Coup Attempt
 Aftershocks from the abortive coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Soviet leader's subsequent abandonment of the Communist Party rolled across the country today.
A presidential spokesman announced that Mr. Gorbachev's military adviser, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, had killed himself on Saturday night. No evidence has surfaced implicating Marshal Akhromeyev, the former chief of staff of the armed forces, in the attempted coup, but he was instrumental in promoting the military commanders who participated, and he had publicly belittled the danger of a putsch. [Obituary, page A13.]
The new Soviet Defense Minister announced plans for a wholesale purge that he said would replace "about 80 percent" of the top command structure with younger officers.
"The people must be younger than we have had, more loyal, and not capable of unconstitutional gambits," said the minister, Gen. Yevgeny Shaposhnikov, who as commander of the air force defied the conspirators and supported Mr. Yeltsin.
Shake-ups were also anticipated in the K.G.B. and Interior Ministry, following the collaboration of top national security officials in the three-day coup.
[The Speaker of the Soviet Parliament, Anatoly I. Lukyanov, who has been accused of complicity in the coup, resigned his post, according to Vitaly S. Ignatenko, a spokesman for Mr. Gorbachev who was quoted on a Cable News Network broadcast.]
Local governments across the country seized Communist Party buildings following Mr. Gorbachev's decree on Saturday effectively nationalizing the party's wealth. Citizens toppled monuments to Bolshevik heroes, prompting Mr. Yeltsin and other officials to plead for calm.
"There should be no euphoria of revenge," Mr. Yeltsin told a television interviewer tonight. "Otherwise we will lose our self-respect as democrats."
Mr. Gorbachev, who appears to have become essentially a junior partner in a coalition government with Mr. Yeltsin, was reported to be at work on a speech for an emergency session of the Soviet Parliament on Monday, which will seek to clarify the murky issue of just who is running the country.
 
Gains for Yeltsin
 Although the Soviet leader remains Commander in Chief of the armed forces, and is still formally in charge of the central Government, since his return from captivity he has ceded to the Russian president remarkable sway in dictating the shape of a future government.
On Saturday Mr. Gorbachev named Mr. Yeltsin's prime minister, Ivan S. Silayev, to head a committee charged with drastically reshaping the federal Government and decentralizing economic powers to the republics.
The four-member committee is dominated by Yeltsin loyalists, who favor slashing central ministries, privatizing state-owned industry and moving rapidly to a free market.
Mr. Yeltsin said he remains committed to a union treaty that would cede vast powers to the republics.
 
A Role for Gorbachev?
 The Yeltsin team, which once called for Mr. Gorbachev's resignation, now plans to retain Mr. Gorbachev in a scaled-back role, presiding over military and foreign policy and such centralized economic structures as the electric power grid.
"Mikhail Sergeyevich has not yet exhausted his potential," said Ruslan Khasbulatov, chairman of the Russian parliament, in an interview with the independent news agency Interfax. "I don't think that he needs to resign. We, the Russian government, will help him a great deal."
Mr. Yeltsin said today that he believed the republics should be represented in the National Security Council as a check on the Soviet president's handling of defense policy, and Mr. Khasbulatov suggested that in the new federation, the president would be chosen by the republics rather than in a general election.
 
A Different Viewpoint
 But aides involved in negotiations between the two leaders say that Mr. Gorbachev has not yet entirely resigned himself to the role of a figurehead.
In the appointment of a new chief of the security agencies, Mr. Gorbachev successfully insisted on putting his own man in charge of the K.G.B., for example. The parliamentary session gives Mr. Gorbachev a chance -- perhaps his last chance -- to describe how he sees his future role.
But the redistribution of powers is complicated by the eruption of secessionist sentiment, which is worrisome to both leaders.
In the Ukraine, the independence declaration calls for the republic to assume control of Soviet military assets on its territory and create its own army. The declaration, which requires popular ratification in a referendum in December, leaves unanswered the question of the nuclear weapons deployed there.
Mr. Yeltsin faces the additional predicament that the disintegration of the union could spread to his own domain. The Russian federation includes dozens of ethnic homelands, many of them itching for greater sovereignty.
 
Concern Over Ukraine
 A Yeltsin aide said today the Russian president would support the wishes of the Ukrainian people, but expressed concern about the loss of such a key republic. In addition to the question of the military and the Ukraine's importance as a farming and industrial stronghold, the aide said, the loss of its 52 million Slavs would tilt the ethnic balance of the remaining union toward the Muslims of Central Asia.
That concern grew today with news that the parliament in Byelorussia, the third Slavic republic, had approved an independence declaration. Byelorussia, with a population of 10 million the fifth largest republic, has long been regarded as the most conservative of the republics on the European portion of the Soviet Union, and has seemed relatively immune from the secessionist passions of its Baltic and Ukrainian neighbors.
The declaration was apparently designed by Byelorussian Communists, who still hold a majority in the parliament, as a way of insulating themselves from Mr. Gorbachev's decree ordering confiscation of party property. A smaller nationalist faction in the parliament also supported the move.
 
Byelorussian Leader Quits
 In another move to protect the party from the wave of anti-Communist sentiment, the hard-line Communist president of the republic, Nikolai Dementei, resigned under pressure.
The republic of Moldavia announced today that its parliament would vote on secession on Tuesday, a measure that is expected to pass.
"Moldavia will no longer be part of an empire which is falling to pieces," the speaker of its parliament, Alexandru Mosanu, told Reuters in Kishinev, the capital. "We shall become independent, and this is part of a chain reaction which no force in the world could stop now."
 
Recognition of Baltic Republics
 The Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, whose claim to independence has been endorsed by Mr. Yeltsin but not Mr. Gorbachev, today began to win international recognition. Denmark and Norway announced that they would establish diplomatic relations with the breakaway republics, which were forcibly annexed in 1940.
Latvia and Estonia voted their independence this week, while Lithuania declared its freedom last year.
The German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, called on the European Community today to recognize Baltic independence, and there was mounting pressure in the United States for President Bush to do the same.
Mr. Gorbachev has insisted in the past that secession be carried out according to Soviet law, which requires a referendum and a waiting period of up to five years. He now finds himself under strong pressure from Mr. Yeltsin to acquiesce.
 
Military Commander Ousted
 The Soviet Government today showed signs of relaxing its stance on the Baltics. The commander of military forces in the region, a bitter foe of pro-independence governments, was dismissed for acquiescing in the coup.
The Latvian president, Anatoly Gorbunovs, met in Moscow today with leaders of the Soviet military, K.G.B. and Interior Ministry and announced afterward that they had agreed to suspend their activies in his republic and open negotiations on "disarmament."
In the aftermath of Mr. Gorbachev's resignation on Saturday as general secretary of the Communist Party, the party leadership today followed his urging and called for an emergency meeting to disband.
The party's administrative secretariat issued an appeal to Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin to permit a special session of the governing Central Committee where "the only possible decision" would be dissolution.
In announcing his resignation on Saturday, Mr. Gorbachev noted that the party leadership had taken no position condemning the coup, that the main conspirators against him had been members of the Central Committee, and that party newspapers had supported the putsch.
Their behavior, he said, had exposed millions of rank-and-file Communists to the threat of anti-Communist hysteria.
The secretariat insisted that the coup plans were kept in secrecy and that party leaders "tried to do everything to prevent blood from being spilled."
Some republics have suspended or outlawed the party, and party buildings have been sealed pending investigation.

HEADLINE: El Gran Combo, on the Global Road, Moves Dancers to Mixed Salsa Beat

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
It's a typically frenetic couple of weeks for El Gran Combo, Puerto Rico's finest salsa orchestra, and one of the greatest dance bands working. Tonight it will play at S.O.B.'s in Manhattan. Then it goes to Jersey City for a Wednesday night engagement, returning to Manhattan to headline a salsa show at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, followed by a late set at Club Broadway on the Upper West Side. Then it heads off for Providence, R.I., Bridgeport, Conn., and Reading, Pa. before coming back for a Queens date and then flying down for a three-city tour in Colombia.
Such is the life for an orchestra that has recorded 62 albums -- its most recent, "Erupcion" (Combo), has been hovering around the top 10 of the Latin charts in Billboard for a few months -- and has been together for 29 years. The 13-or-so-member group, which is swinging through the United States on one of its annual two or three North American tours, is an institution, and spends more than 10 months a year on the road proving it. 
 Its leader, main arranger and occasional pianist, Rafael Ithier, is the last remaining original member, but its fans don't care. For several generations, whole families have gone out to hear and dance to the blissful rhythms of El Gran Combo's fully choreographed shows.
"We are very proud," said Mr. Ithier, talking on the phone from Houston, where the band had a series of shows. "We represent in many ways Puerto Rico. We play and sing like Puerto Ricans, we present a symbol of Puerto Rico. It's our culture and we're proud of it."
Though the recession has been devastating to the Latin music scene in the United States, just as it has been for mainstream music, El Gran Combo has been fairly recession-resistant. For one thing, it plays only 30 to 40 dates a year in the United States, not that many on a schedule as heavy as its. For another, Europe has developed a taste for salsa, and El Gran Combo traveled there three times this year. It has been to France, Holland, England, Spain, Germany and Switzerland. Next year, it plans two more tours, one lasting an entire month.
 
The Norman Taste for Salsa
 "Europeans are very interested in the colonies now, it seems, and we're very popular in Europe, and not just in Spain," Mr. Ithier said. "Before they didn't know what it was, but Europeans have fallen in love with salsa. We were in a small town in Normandy, which was having a jazz festival, Branford Marsalis was there, and people were jumping up and down because of the rhythms. We got an invitation for next year, right after we finished playing."
In Puerto Rico, the band usually plays free at fiestas patronales, outdoor celebrations in town plazas that last a week or more. Or it will play at playeros, beach parties sometimes sponsored by beer or soft-drink companies. These performances accentuate the feeling that the orchestra is part of the community, that music is integral to festivals and occasions.
"I like to play in Puerto Rico the most because of the food, and it's home," Mr. Ithier said. "But we're accustomed to traveling, since we do it all the time. And I love to play New York, but really it's just like Puerto Rico. I've been coming to New York for 45 years, and everybody speaks Spanish, so it's also just like home. I get to see friends."
El Gran Combo uses a series of rhythms, all now coming under the title of salsa. Though Hispanic music from the Caribbean has been influenced by Afro-Cuban music, Puerto Rico has its own set of rhythmic and social traditions, including two called the bomba and the plena, music from African plantation workers and from poor coastal towns, respectively. El Gran Combo will dip into those, reinterpreting them. Mr. Ithier was an early member of the drummer Cortijo's orchestra, one of the first groups to use bomba and plena rhythms in popular music. And he learned the power of dance music from Cortijo.
"Our music is for dancing," Mr. Ithier said. "It's dance music and as a dance band our priority is to make people dance. When we first started, television was just beginning, and we knew that we had to make a show for the people. We thought that if the band danced, with choreography, it would be more entertaining. Now, the people have gotten accustomed to this, and every time we write a new tune we make a different dance. After we did that, everybody copied us."
But it is the music that motivates audiences. Bright and shiny, it seems timeless, a mixing of big band orchestral sounds with a tough percussion section. Since they play all the time, the band members can make the transcendent grooves that make dancing effortless.
Though fads come and go in the salsa world, El Gran Combo has kept its identity, playing new music that fits the older sound of the orchestra. It has become more sophisticated, but the basic impulse, to make people enjoy themselves, has remained the same. In an era when singers take their cue from mainstream Western pop, abandoning their bands in favor of attempts at superstardom, El Gran Combo remains a band dedicated to its audience.
"When I was with Cortijo, we had one trumpet and one sax and a rhythm section," Mr. Ithier said. "It was more primitive. We didn't have arrangements, really, and Cortijo would sing things that he wanted us to play because he didn't write music, so we'd remember everything. Now you have to have arrangements because we have musicians that read music. And we try to use something a little sophisticated. We have an individual sound; our fans know us. Three years ago I used different people to do arrangements who were very good musicians, but too modern, and a lot of people didn't like it. They had studied at Berklee, the music school, and it was too much. So we went back to what the people like."
S.O.B.'s is at 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street. Club Broadway is at 2551 Broadway, between 96th and 97th Streets.

HEADLINE: SoHo Adapts to Leaner Times With a Changing Gallery Scene

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
At a time when SoHo's eulogy has been written more than once, New York City's primary contemporary art gallery area is showing new signs of life, partly as a byproduct of problems that seemed to signal its decline.
Last season, a number of SoHo galleries succumbed to the pressures of high overheads and declining art sales: among them Petersburg, Gracie Mansion, Althea Viafora, Lang & O'Hara and Massimo Audiello. Still, as the new season approaches, it seems that more galleries are opening in the area than are closing, and they are being helped by a softened rental market caused by the recession. 
 In particular, SoHo's relatively quiet southwest quadrant, which in some spots still retains the rougher, less store-studded character of the area's pre-gallery days, is becoming home to an increasing number of new or relocated galleries. Many are run by young dealers who seem determined to show new young artists and, in the process, to change the way art galleries are operated. It's probably not by chance that many of these dealers are committed to casual, process-oriented art -- be it installation work, Conceptual art or abstract painting -- that tends to go against the grain of Neo-Geo, the last art movement of the 1980's.
 
The Frenzy Is Over
 In some ways, these dealers are making the best of a drastically altered situation: the shopping frenzy of the 1980's is over and the secondary, or resale, market has shrunk; collectors are buying more selectively, taking more time to make up their minds and expecting to get more for their money. Gone are the expensive renovations that characterized so many new galleries of the 1980's, a time increasingly called "the old days."
In the meantime, a softened rental market is enabling dealers to get better spaces in better locations or to open for the first time. And in a summer that is sometimes referred to as "the transition," a new no-frills approach is emerging, one that brings to mind the early 1970's in SoHo and the early 1980's in the East Village. Rough cement floors, patched walls and partial renovations to be completed later are in vogue, as are the adjectives "modest" and "low-key" and the phrase "focusing on just a few artists."
Several dealers plan to have "programs" (another popular word) that include performance art, film screenings or poetry readings, similar to those in so-called alternative spaces. In their scaled-back approach to gallery management and their emphasis on the new and experimental, they may prove what many people have maintained all along: that the drop in art prices, while bad for the market, could be good for art.
 
'More Space for Less Money'
 "I couldn't afford not to move," said Tom Cugliani, who is moving his three-year-old Tom Cugliani Gallery from Greenwich Street, several blocks beyond SoHo's western edge, to 40 Wooster Street. He said he planned to open in early October on the second floor, one flight up from the American Fine Arts Company, a three-year fixture on Wooster Street run by Colin de Land, an art dealer. American Fine Arts is best known for showing installation pieces by artists including Cady Noland, Jessica Diamond and Jessica Stockholder, all of whom were in this year's Whitney Biennial.
"The irony of this whole situation," Mr. Cugliani said, "is that it has provided me with a kind of window, enabling me to get more space for less money in a better location."
Another new tenant at 40 Wooster Street is Brent Sikkema Fine Arts, a photography gallery relocating from 153 Spring Street, one of SoHo's fancier gallery addresses. Like Mr. Cugliani, Mr. Sikkema said that he wanted to open in early October and that he would be "paying less rent for five times as much space."
These new gallery activities are creating one of SoHo's regular shifts in concentration. Centering on or near Wooster and Greene Streets between Broome and Grand Streets, the new galleries are joining others known for their relatively low profiles and unrenovated quarters.
 
Rough and Fancy
 These include American Fine Arts, Feature, Nicole Klagsbrun and Pat Hearn, whose spiffy ground floor (very smooth cement here) is balanced by a rough-hewed upper floor for installation art, performances and film showings. Larger fancier galleries in the area include the Drawing Center at 35 Wooster Street, Brooke Alexander Gallery at 59 Wooster Street and Brooke Alexander Editions and the Josh Baer Gallery, both at 476 Broome Street.
The arrivals to this area are tipping the balance of galleries away from Prince Street and especially the big multiple-gallery buildings at Prince Street and Broadway in SoHo's northeast corner. These are buildings whose anonymity and packaging, and particularly their atmosphere of one-stop art viewing, often seemed emblematic of the late 80's art boom.
Joe Fawbush, who with his partner, Tom Jones, will reopen the Fawbush Gallery at 76 Grand Street near Wooster Street, does not speak fondly of the gallery "mall" experience. "Never again," he said of the gallery in the large building at 578 Broadway, near Prince Street, that he and Mr. Jones opened in September 1987 and closed in June 1990, partly because of poor business, partly to rethink their entire operation. "Our first priority was not to be in a multi-gallery building," Mr. Fawbush said. "We like the idea of having our own identity."
After a year of private dealing and "a decision to focus ourselves on a scale that's frankly smaller," Mr. Fawbush said, he and Mr. Jones are now the sole tenants at their new address, a small one-story building with 20-foot ceilings. While they used to represent 10 artists, they will now represent only 5, including the painters Michelle Stuart and Ed Albers, and Kiki Smith, a maker of eerie figurative sculptures and installation pieces, also seen in this spring's Biennial. Like some other dealers, they plan to leaven their exhibitions with performance art and poetry readings. "We're bored with doing one show after another of gallery artists," Mr. Fawbush said. "We want to try to shake things up a bit."
 
'My Own Identity'
 Diane Brown, who forsook a ground-floor gallery on Greene Street for the mall building at 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, echoed Mr. Fawbush's disdain for such buildings. "I'm really anxious for an autonomous space," she said. "I want my own identity."
Having closed her Broadway gallery in the spring, she will open Sept. 6 on the ground floor at 23 Watts Street, near Broome Street and West Broadway, where she says she is "getting more for my money."
"I feel optimistic," Ms. Brown said. "I think it's a time of great opportunity. Anyone who says they haven't had a decline in business is lying. But now there won't be speculators. It will make everybody be better, think harder, work harder."
Not all the new ventures are within the southwest corner of SoHo. Elizabeth Koury, formerly a partner in the Koury-Wingate Gallery at 578 Broadway, will open on the fourth floor of 89 Greene Street, upstairs from the 303 Gallery, in the fall. She said she planned to represent only three or four artists and to have two-month exhibitions, which is longer than usual. "Slowing down the process is good for me and it's in keeping with the market," Ms. Koury said.
Of the current rental market she said: "I couldn't have done this at any other time."
Another newcomer will be Arena, a gallery that Renee Ricardo, who was an independent curator, will be opening on Sept. 21. Although her location is central, the second floor of a small brick building at 128 Wooster, on the corner of Prince Street, it measures only 600 feet square, the size of many dealers' private viewing rooms.
 
Openings to Occur
 There are also some openings planned on bigger, better-known or better-financed fronts. Larry Gagosian, for example, is renovating a large garage at 136 Wooster Street, just north of Prince. His second such space in the neighborhood (he runs 65 Thompson Street with Leo Castelli), it is scheduled to open in early November with an exhibition of new sculpture by Richard Serra.
Arthur Roger, a New Orleans Gallery, will open on the ground floor of the pricey 130 Prince Street building in mid-September, a move made possible by backing from the collector Frederick R. Weisman.
And the Blum Helman Gallery, whose main headquarters are on 57th Street, will reopen its ground-floor warehouse at 80 Greene Street, intermittently used for exhibitions, as a full-time gallery. Its activities will be directed by Max Lang, of the recently closed Lang & O'Hara Gallery, who says he plans to concentrate on younger non-Blum Helman artists.
 
Renovations in the 90's
 It is the more modest developments to the south, however, that seem more intriguing. Nordanstad-Skarstedt, a gallery run by two young Swedish dealers, Thomas Nordanstad and Per Skarstedt, will open at 49 Greene Street, next door to the Klagsbrun gallery, in October. Mr. Skarstedt said the gallery would show young unknown artists from Europe and America. "We're very interested in what's happening in New York," he said, "and in what will happen once this crisis is past." Sandra Gering, formerly on West 11th Street, will open Sept. 20 in a 2,000-square-foot gallery at 476 Broome Street. Last spring, she had a group show in the space when it was raw, and she is now making minimal renovations which she characterizes as "very rough and sort of in keeping with what the 1990's are about."
Several dealers express an admiration for installation art, which had its heyday was the early 1970's, another period of market quietness. And their admiration seems to be echoed in much of the art they're seeing in artists' studios. In the words of Colin de Land, whose American Fine Arts has helped set the local unvarnished tone, "I seem to be seeing some art that has no intrinsic object value, that's virtually nontransactable."
Pat Hearn strikes a more realistic note. "The new artists are out there," she said. "As long as new dealers can get started in the area, I think things will be in good shape."

HEADLINE: U.S. OPEN '91;
Capriati Gets a Whipping That Doesn't Count

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
Jennifer Capriati was thumped with such ferocity yesterday afternoon by Gabriela Sabatini, she might have thought twice about her decision to play in the made-for-CBS exhibition one day before the start of the United States Open tennis championships.
But Capriati has more than a little Pollyanna in her, so she took her punishment, 6-3, 6-3, and insisted the 62-minute baseline fire drill at the National Tennis Center in Queens had been a great deal of fun. 
 "You know you're going out and giving the kids a show," Capriati said of her free match on the Stadium Court.
If the women's draw plays to form, Capriati and Sabatini will meet again in the quarterfinals of the Open sometime next week. Capriati will remember that she was dominated, once again, by the player who owns a 6-1 edge in their head-to-head tournament meetings. Capriati's only victory over the defending United States Open champion came three weeks ago, when Sabatini retired in the second set of their semifinal match at the Canadian Open.
"Sure, I'll know that she beat me the day before the tournament started," the 15-year-old Capriati said. "But I can't think about it. It's a new match."
The crowd was certainly different from the usual corporate cross-section. Only 6,500 fans attended, but they stayed in their seats on the changeovers and actually paid attention during lengthy rallies.
"It was great to be back here again," said Sabatini, 21, who pocketed $75,000 for her effort yesterday while Capriati donated her appearance fee. "I won my first Grand Slam here. The city, the lights, the crowd make this tournament special."
 
Roughin' It in the First Round
 The first round of the men's draw is filled with potential pitfalls for the top stars, and particularly for several of the Americans. Today, eighth-seeded Andre Agassi faces Aaron Krickstein -- a five-set ambush waiting to happen. Michael Chang, who has slipped to No. 23 in the world, meets tough Australian Mark Woodforde. Tonight, defending champion Pete Sampras will play Christo van Rensburg of South Africa. Woodforde and Van Rensburg have reached the fourth round of both Wimbledon and the United States Open.
"There's no easy ride to any Grand Slam tournament," Chang said yesterday, after a practice session. "I don't think it matters anymore if you're seeded or not. You're going to be playing somebody else who could easily be seeded.
"Ivan Lendl is playing a guy, Richard Krajicek, that most fans don't even know about, but the guy beat Stefan Edberg last week," Chang said, referring the Dutch player's upset victory in New Haven. "He could give Lendl a lot of trouble."
 
Tense Times for Soviets
 If the hard-liners' coup in the Soviet Union had succeeded, there might have been a wave of defections and substantial cold-war intrigue at this tournament. Most of the Soviet players were already in the New York area when President Mikhail Gorbachev was, in effect, held hostage. During that three-day eternity, they discussed with each other the notion of becoming permanent expatriates.
"We talked on the phone about it," said Yevgeniya Manyokova, who qualified into the main draw of the women's tournament. "I don't think we would go back to Moscow."
Under Gorbachev's reign, the Soviet players have traveled more freely and continued to fight for a greater share of their earnings. The players are now hopeful of even more liberalized rules.
"Everything is good now," Manyokova said. "I hope."
 
The Price is Out of Sight
 Back in the capitalist world: Spectators should be advised that the recession has not deflated prices at the refreshment stands around the National Tennis Center. A jumbo waffle ice cream cone will cost you $4.25; imported beer is $4.50; soda, $2.25; United States Open T-shirts, $18.49; sweatshirts, $29-$49; light jackets, $79.
The good news is that pizza, pretentiously called borboli for the last few years, is now being called pizza again. But it sells for a borboli-like $4.95 per serving.
 
Americans Aplenty
 There were 20 players from the United States in the 64-woman qualifiers draw, but none advanced to the main draw. Still, there is no shortage of American players at the Open -- 36 women and 34 men.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Coup Pre-empts Democrats' Agenda

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Like the war in the Persian Gulf, the crisis in the Soviet Union has given President Bush another chance to stride the stage as Commander in Chief and has consigned the Democrats to the wings, a hapless chorus struggling to change the subject.
In some ways it was a striking replay of the party's experience last summer: The Democrats seemed to be forcing the debate onto domestic issues, where Mr. Bush is widely perceived to be vulnerable, when world events suddenly pre-empted their script. 
 "This is the luckiest President in American history," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic poll taker, and at week's end many Democrats agreed.
But as the truism holds, a person makes his own luck, and the Democrats have been busily contributing to their own misery. The withdrawal of Senator Al Gore of Tennessee from the race for the Democratic nomination for President only underscored that the party's heavyweights, one by one, are walking away from the 1992 election. In Mr. Gore's case, the loss was particularly acute because he was widely seen as one of the few potential candidates who could hold his own on foreign policy issues.
 
A Critique of Strategy
 At the same time, the Democrats' strategy for the 1992 campaign, with its relentless emphasis on domestic issues, carries the risk of making the national party seem irrelevant when a crisis erupts in the Middle East or the Soviet Union. "World events can eliminate the premise for their campaign," said Don Sipple, a Republican consultant. "In a vacuum, their strategy sounds fine, but campaigns don't occur in a vacuum."
Presidential elections may, indeed, be driven by pocketbook issues and homefront concerns, as strategists for the Democratic National Committee say over and over again. And polls show that such issues, particularly the economy, rank at or near the top of the voters' concerns.
But last's week's events highlighted what Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn and other centrist Democrats have been warning their party about in recent months: Voters must be satisfied that a party's nominee passes the threshold test of the Presidency and seems an effective Commander in Chief.
"We are not likely to win the 1992 Presidential election on foreign policy," Mr. Solarz told Democrats in New Hampshire recently. "But we could very easily lose the Presidential election on foreign policy."
Michael McCurry, a former spokesman for the Democratic National Committee, said: "There were some Democrats deluding themselves into thinking that domestic policy alone would produce a victory. This has got to remind them that you have to have a world view."
There is another, chilling thought taking hold among some Democrats: By their actions, some of the party's leaders seem willing to take a pass on 1992 and then reassert their Presidential ambitions in 1996. But after a fourth consecutive Presidential defeat, after losing six of the last seven Presidential elections, how much long-term damage would the party incur? Already, polls show an ominous trend for the Democrats as a Presidential party, with voters age 18 to 29, who have only Jimmy Carter in their memories as a Democratic President, identifying more and more as Republicans.
"It's not good over the long term for Democrats to have overwhelming strong support for Bush among younger voters," Ms. Lake said, noting that political habits formed in youth can linger a very long time.
Martin Wattenberg, a professor of political science at the University of California at Irvine, believes that the Republican leanings of the young are exaggerated, but he sees the Democrats seriously hurt by having so much of their strength concentrated among the oldest voters.
"The people who are dying are the people who are Democrats," he said. "They grew up in the New Deal."
 
The Party Yearns
 With these kinds of trends, Democrats yearn for candidates to put their party first, enter the fray and simply fill the role of an aggressive, competitive loyal opposition in 1992.
"What is it about our times and our leadership on the 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights that causes our party to be so devoid of direction?" asked George Bruno, a member of the Democratic National Committee from New Hampshire. "It's five months before the New Hampshire primary and there's one announced candidate. The situation is deplorable."
Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, is the only official major candidate for the nomination. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, emerging as the standard-bearer for the Democratic centrists, is still testing the waters, as is Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, campaigning as the unabashed voice of traditional liberalism. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia is also pondering a race. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, Washington's elected lobbyist to the Senate, says he has not yet decided whether to run.
The difficulty for the Democrats with this field, some Republicans assert, is simply a stature gap, driven home when the Soviet crisis and other international events cast Mr. Bush in the nation's consciousness, night after night, as a world leader.
"Keep in mind what the job is -- the job is being President," said Bob Teeter, Mr. Bush's political adviser. "The fact is the Democrats have a problem this year, in that they don't have anybody on the candidate list or the potential candidate list who has any experience in the conduct of foreign policy."
 
Replay of 1988?
 The Republicans were exceedingly skillful in the 1988 campaign in casting Michael S. Dukakis, who was the Governor of Massachusetts, as too untested, too risky and too weak to put at the helm of foreign policy. They seem intent on a devastating replay in 1992: The Soviet crisis "points out to the American public that foreign policy crises do not happen once a decade; they can happen with increasing frequency," said Clayton K. Yeutter, chairman of the Republican National Committee. "And it's important to have someone in charge who can handle them skillfully."
Some Democrats comforted themselves with the notion that the Soviet crisis came early in the Presidential campaign cycle and ended with a victory for the forces of change. Paul Tully, political director for the Democratic National Committee, argued that it told voters something they already knew about Mr. Bush, about his interest and ability in foreign affairs, but would not change their sense of what was important in the 1992 campaign.
"There are substantial challenges the country faces," Mr. Tully said. "There are substantial concerns on people's minds. There are things to have an election about and people to contest it vigorously.'
But after Mr. Gore's withdrawal, and with Mr. Bush looming ever larger, some Democrats inevitably harbored hopes that some of their heavyweights, like Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, might reconsider.
"I'd like to see some of our major figures just gut up and do it," said John White, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "Of course, we've got a different kind of politician now. The driven guys with fire in the belly, like Hubert Humphrey and Lyndon, are gone."
