HEADLINE: San Francisco Mayor in Tough Bid for Re-Election

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Swept into office in a landslide in 1987 and hailed as a hero after the earthquake two years later, Mayor Art Agnos now finds himself in a bruising campaign for re-election, blamed by a cranky electorate and four challengers for urban problems that will not go away.
Panhandlers seem to be multiplying on downtown street corners. There is litter by the curbs and graffiti on the buses. Polls show that residents of San Francisco are running out of patience with the homeless and that suburbanites consider this a dirty, dangerous city and are staying away. 
 In this environment, adversaries and friends have declared open season on Mr. Agnos, a former social worker and State Assemblyman who won with 70 percent of the vote in a runoff election four years ago. For weeks now, candidate forums have drawn standing-room-only crowds and the Mayor has been booed and taunted.
 
Relative Conservatives
 Two longtime opponents of the Mayor were the first to declare. They are Frank Jordan, a former police chief, and Tom Hsieh, (pronounced shay) a member of the Board of Supervisors and the first Chinese-American to run for mayor in a major city. The two men are relative conservatives in a place where the political spectrum runs from the center to the left.
But Mr. Agnos is also being challenged by people who supported him the last time around: Angela Alioto, a rookie supervisor and the daughter of an esteemed former Mayor, and Richard Hongisto, the city assessor and a perennial officeholder.
The only independent poll so far was done before Ms. Alioto entered the race so its results are inconclusive, except as a harbinger for Mr. Agnos. That poll, by The San Francisco Examiner and KRON-TV, showed the Mayor with 27 percent of the vote, Mr. Jordan with 22.9, Mr. Hongisto with 13.7, Mr. Hsieh with 10.8 and the rest undecided. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.
The election will be held Nov. 5, with a runoff of the top two finishers on Dec. 10, unless one candidate gets more than 50 percent of the vote, which is considered unlikely.
 
Magnet for Frustration
 Mr. Agnos said he expected to be a magnet for frustration in the early stages of the race. But the Mayor said he believed that voters would come to realize that nobody could govern any better in these times of recession, Federal and state cutbacks and so many intractable urban problems.
"The social worker in me understands their frustration," said Mr. Agnos. "They need to ventilate about their anxieties and uncertainties."
Mr. Agnos's opponents hope to convert that frustration into votes, tapping the nostalgia of residents who widely believe that San Francisco used to be a paradise but is not anymore.
Ms. Alioto has used this tack most effectively. A member of one of the city's dynastic families, she declared her candidacy with her father, Joseph C. Alioto, by her side within sight of the historic North Beach church where she was baptized.
"The greatness of this city is its joie de vivre," said Ms. Alioto. "People have never been down and out like they are today. You can feel the lack of morale in the streets."
Ms. Alioto's entry into the race earlier this month scrambled the early betting line. Conventional wisdom had it that Mr. Agnos would struggle in the general election, face Mr. Jordan in a runoff and breeze to a second term, because San Franciscans are at heart a progressive lot and the former police chief is pitching tough policy on the homeless.
 
The More Serious Threat
 Now, Ms. Alioto is seen as the more serious threat, particularly in a runoff of likeminded liberals. A private poll, which prodded her entry into the race, shows her finishing a close second to Mr. Agnos in a general election.
The recurring subject on the campaign trail has been homelessness. At debates, where everyone has two minutes to speak, Mr. Agnos insists that his multiservice centers are an effective solution and that the homeless problem is not as bad as critics claim.
Jerry Roberts, the political editor for The San Francisco Chronicle, summarized the downfall of this approach. "By trumpeting his performance on the homeless issue as a model for the nation, Agnos is effectively asking voters to disbelieve what their own senses tell them is true," Mr. Roberts said.
In more leisurely formats, like neighborhood coffee klatches, Mr. Agnos does a better job of explaining his long-term goals. "This problem was 10 years in the making," the Mayor tells voters. "You can't fix it in 10 days."
The main criticism of the Mayor is that he has been too kind to the homeless, not forcing them from parks as other cities have done and urging restraint on the Police Department.
Mr. Hsieh and Mr. Jordan have accused Mr. Agnos of making San Francisco a magnet for the homeless with his hospitality. Even Mr. Hongisto, who stresses compassion, said that Mr. Agnos has demoralized the Police Department by insisting on a "hands-off policy even when the homeless are acting out."
 
Putting the Homeless to Work
 Mr. Jordan has been the most specific. He has proposed requiring that the homeless help out on public works projects, such as cleaning graffiti. He also urges that transients be screened for criminal records before they are admitted to shelters and that people sleeping on the street be jailed.
Ms. Alioto, so far, has chosen gentler rhetoric. The homeless are "somebody's children," she said. Ms. Alioto's quarrel with Mr. Agnos is that he has concentrated on new, large shelters and not pumped enough money into small, neighborhood programs that she says do a better job.
Another charge against Mr. Agnos, leveled most often by Mr. Hongisto, is that the Mayor has sold out to the Chamber of Commerce and other business interests, betraying the neighborhood groups that elected him, by supporting large-scale development. Mr. Hongisto harps on the Mayor's support of a ballot measure, which went down to defeat, that would have replaced Candlestick Park with a downtown baseball stadium.
 
Counter-Culture Bastion
 Mr. Hsieh and Mr. Jordan take the opposite tack, accusing the Mayor of discouraging investment in San Francisco by fostering the city's image as a counter-culture bastion, a place that makes life difficult for real estate developers. An article in the latest issue of Forbes magazine describes the "wacky economics that echo around San Francisco's City Hall," and both Mr. Hsieh and Mr. Jordan were quick to include the criticism in their campaign oratory.
Mr. Hsieh, an architect and an effective fund-raiser for both his own campaign and the national Democratic Party, blames Mr. Agnos for "chasing jobs out of town" by "opening the door to military deserters and vagrants." And Mr. Jordan calls the Mayor's countenance of huge anti-war demonstrations during the Persian Gulf war, when the rest of the nation was waving yellow ribbons, as an embarrassment.
Mr. Jordan is responsible for the campaign's most memorable handouts so far, a set of postcards that the candidate says tell a truer story than the ones in the tourist racks at Fisherman's Wharf.
Those are pretty, colored pictures of the Golden Gate Bridge enshrouded in fog, the cable cars cresting steep hillsides, the world's crookedest street banked in summer flowers. These are black-and-white shots of homeless people pushing shopping carts, shuttered libraries and vandalized cars.
"The Mayor won't be happy about these, I'm sure," Mr. Jordan said. "But he can't refute them. These are actual photos. This is San Francisco as the residents see it."

HEADLINE: Accord in Detroit Would Let Girls Attend All-Boy Schools

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 25

 BODY:
A tentative agreement has been reached to allow girls to attend three all-male public academies scheduled to open in the city this fall, according to a published report.
The academies will open for boys only this week but will accept applications from girls over the next two weeks under the agreement between the Detroit school board and civil rights groups that challenged the board's original males-only plan, The Detroit News reported today. 
 The American Civil Liberties Union and the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund challenged the proposed all-male academies, suing on behalf of two Detroit mothers with children in the public school system.
The separate academies are being created to combat the social and economic problems that disproportionately affect black males. Ninety percent of the school system's pupils are black.
Judge George E. Woods of Federal District Court ruled Aug. 15 that the male-only academies were unconstitutional and ordered the board and civil rights groups to reach a compromise to allow girls to attend the schools.
A tentative agreement was reached late last week and is to be considered by the board on Tuesday, The News said.
"We plan to comply with the court decision," the schools Superintendent, Deborah McGriff, told The News, "and it's going to work out to everybody's satfisfaction."
About 1,200 males applied for 560 slots in the three academies. It was unclear how many girls would be admitted, but none of the boys were to lose their places.
If the tentative agreement is approved, applications for girls will be available beginning Wednesday, with a Sept. 4 deadline. Girls would start classes on Sept. 9.
Howard Simon, executive director of the Michigan chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, told The News that the compromise was "good for the community."
"It's good for the school board and, most importantly, it's good for the male and female students," he said.

HEADLINE: The Missing Reform in Mexico

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari fumbled his own potential triumph in last week's Mexican mid-term elections.
President Salinas has enjoyed three years of spectacular success in building a modern Mexico. His policies have helped check inflation, reduce foreign debt and open much of the economy to wider competition. Negotiations are now under way for a free-trade agreement with the U.S. 
 Thanks to these achievements, Mr. Salinas and his Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, are considerably more popular than they were during the disputed Presidential elections three years ago.
Yet Mr. Salinas failed to turn the elections into the triumph they could easily have been. He seems less impassioned about democracy than he is about economic reform. That's a serious failing, endangering Mexico's international reputation and the permanence of its economic gains.
As long as anyone can remember, Mexican elections have been massively fraudulent. Thanks in part to Mr. Salinas's modest efforts, this one was probably less so. But the accusations of fresh electoral fraud are credible enough to give the regime an unnecessary black eye.
Problems began with a last-minute distribution of new voter credentials that may have short-changed opposition constituencies. Election day brought familiar charges of stuffed and stolen ballot boxes, barred poll-watchers, bullied voters and selective closing of polling places. Then came a suspicious delay in releasing computerized results. Now, any formal appeals will be reviewed by official bodies dominated by PRI allies and loyalists.
It is as traditional for Mexican opposition parties to cry fraud as it is for PRI operatives to perpetrate it. Understandably, opposition politicians are reluctant to explain their dramatic loss of support in more self-critical ways. And even if every fraud charge were true, that could change only a handful of results.
But given recent history and the built-in biases of the present electoral system, the burden of reform falls on the Salinas Government. Honest democratic competition is now the rule from the Arctic to Tierra del Fuego. Mexico, Cuba, Suriname and Guyana are the only exceptions. Mexico won't be able to remove itself from this shameful list until Mr. Salinas shows himself to be as serious about democracy as he is about economic reform.

HEADLINE: The Parties, After the Party

 BODY:
It will take months, even years, for the world to grasp fully the implications of the Soviet Union's most incredible week since the Bolsheviks seized power in 1917. But in all the turmoil, few events matched the drama of Mikhail Gorbachev's renunciation on Saturday of the Communist Party. And few events hold out as much promise for a true turn toward multi-party democracy.
By resigning as the party's chief and calling for the dissolution of its Central Committee, Mr. Gorbachev ratified the rebellious popular judgment on decades of Communist tyranny. Only the day before, he had loyally pleaded the party's cause; hooted down by the Russian Parliament, he abandoned overnight a lifetime's allegiance. His turnabout may enable him to stay on as symbolic head of state in a radically altered union. 
 As George Bush is already learning, it is far from clear who speaks for this new Soviet Union -- Mr. Gorbachev, or Boris Yeltsin, who has emerged as the dominant political figure. What is clear is that the Soviet Union is no longer a multi-ethnic empire dominated by the Communists and controlled from Moscow. And as the party collapses, so too do the impediments to political pluralism and regional autonomy. Already the Ukraine and the Baltic states want out and the list is growing.
This unraveling is happening so fast that there are only proximate answers to new questions. Who will manage the economy? And who will control the defense establishment? These are questions for Soviet citizens, freed now from the party's yoke, to decide. For this has been their revolution. The collapse of Communism was not brought about by Western military might, though years of patient NATO resolve played a big part. Nor was this revolt spawned at C.I.A. headquarters in McLean, Va.
What undid the Communist Party and Lenin's revolution was massive questioning of inherited ideas and the growing ascendancy of new and predominantly Western values. This, together with the market economy's promise of a more prosperous life, was what emboldened Soviet demonstrators to face tanks in Moscow.
Some hopes of the new revolutionaries may prove as impossible to realize as the dreams of universal justice that invigorated the original Communists. And it's true that the Soviet rebels and their leaders have tasted freedom only briefly, and that in good part thanks to Mr. Gorbachev.
Genuine democrats everywhere have learned that the essential corollary of majority rule is respect for minority rights, and that a multiplicity of factions is the best safeguard against single-party despotism. This is a lesson that enthusiastic Soviet recruits to the fledgling democratic order need, in their moment of euphoria, to weigh.

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Off 8.8% in July

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Spurred by a sharp rise in demand from domestic automobile makers, orders for American-made machine tools rose 8.8 percent in July from the previous month's level, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.
Still, machine tool orders this year remain well below their 1990 levels. 
 The Association for Manufacturing Technology said July's increase, the second consecutive month-to-month rise, was a result of increased domestic orders for machine tools. In the last few months, high levels of orders from foreign customers are what had sustained the industry.
 
Lower Seven-Month Total
 The association's report for July showed that orders rose to $188 million in the month, from $172.9 million in June. But orders for the first seven months of the year remain 18 percent below the level of a year earlier, the association said. And the July figures were down 19.7 percent from those of July 1990.
Machine tools are used to cut or shape metal parts used in durable products like appliances, automobiles, aircraft and building components. The levels of orders and shipments of machine tools are considered an important indicator of the health of American industry.
"The modest rise in machine tool orders for the second month in a row, with improved domestic orders leading the way, is encouraging," said Albert W. Moore, president of the tool maker's association, which is based in McLean, Va.
 
Strength in Aerospace
 Machine tool companies said that the July upturn in domestic orders may be a sign that American car makers were retooling their assembly lines and preparing for new engine designs that require new machine tools. They also said they saw continued strength from aerospace companies, which have been ordering machine tools to assist in building the next generation of aircraft.
"Automotive and aerospace orders are still going strong," said William J. Fife, chairman of Giddings & Lewis Inc., a large machine tool company in Fond du Lac, Wis. "We're seeing more activity in orders for the third quarter than we did in the first quarter and second quarter."
But some analysts were unwilling to attribute the increase in July to a prolonged period of buying by automobile makers and appliance makers.
"Things are mixed, with some machine tool companies doing well and some machine tool companies suffering," said James Paper, an analyst with Kirkpatrick, Pettis, Smith, Polian, an investment banking firm in Omaha.
He contended that the American machine tool industry continues to be weakened by foreign competition, which now accounts for as much as 40 percent of domestic orders in some product categories.
"The imports continue to take market share," Mr. Paper said, "and the auto industry, while doing more ordering, has still not been ordering new machine tools in the quantities we would like to see. So I'm still very cautious."
The figures for July showed that domestic orders climbed 36.3 percent in the month from June's level. Meanwhile, orders from foreign customers -- which have been strong throughout the year -- dropped 42.9 percent in the month. Compared with July of last year, domestic orders fell 28.2 percent, while orders from foreign customers rose 69.2 percent.
 
Slight Rise in Shipments
 Machine tool shipments for July were up slightly, to $214.3 million, from June's $212.15 million. For the first seven months of the year, shipments were 19.6 percent below the level of the same period last year, and down 8.2 percent from July 1990.
Machine tool orders have been hurt during the recession because of troubles with car makers, who typically account for more than a third of the industry's new orders. Some analysts have suggested that increased orders from auto makers would help stimulate the machine tool industry for the rest of the year.
But the level of machine tool orders remains highly volatile, varying from one month to the next. Analysts have said that the overall pattern for the first half of the year has been weak, but most expect some strength during the fourth quarter and the early part of 1992.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 28, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A headline in Business Day on Monday about orders for American-made machine tools misstated the change from the previous month. Orders rose 8.8 percent in July.

HEADLINE: A Peril Reborn: Mercury in the Environment -- A special report.;
Ancient Hazards of Mercury Re-Emerge

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DULUTH, Minn.

 BODY:
Two decades after the Government thought the problem had been put to rest, mercury is accumulating in fish in thousands of lakes across the United States and Canada, poisoning wildlife and threatening human health.
Twenty states, including New York and Connecticut, have warned people to limit or eliminate from their diets fish they catch in certain lakes because of dangerous levels of mercury. Canadian scientists have found elevated levels of mercury in fish caught in 95 percent of the lakes tested in Ontario. 
 Scientists say the principal source of contamination is rain containing traces of mercury from coal-burning power plants, municipal incinerators and smelters. Other contamination comes from lake and ocean sediments previously polluted by mercury.
States and the Federal Government have taken almost no action to reduce releases of mercury, in part because recognition of the problem is recent -- and because Federal energy and state environmental policies are actually part of the problem.
 
Harm Comes to Animals
 There have been few studies of the extent to which Americans might have been harmed by mercury poisoning, and state health officials say there is no evidence yet of damage to human health in this country.
But mercury has been confirmed as the cause of deaths of panthers and loons in Florida and is suspected in the reproductive failures seen in eagles, minks, otters and other animals in the Great Lakes region. Contamination is generally not an issue for store-bought fish, which do not come from the lakes most affected, the authorities say.
"It's a very messy pollutant," said John Bachmann, an engineer in the Environmental Protection Agency's Office of Air Quality. "It's a liquid metal that becomes a gas even at mild temperatures. That makes it difficult to control. We need to know more."
But state environmental officials and a top Government mercury researcher disagree, saying that enough is known to begin halting mercury's spread. Delays, they say, are a result not of inadequate information but of conflicts.
Federal energy policy encourages power plants that burn coal, which contains small amounts of mercury. Meanwhile, the states, faced with dwindling landfill space, are encouraging construction of incinerators. Since mercury is used to make batteries, paints, electrical switches and hundreds of other products, incineration of these discarded items releases mercury.
"Solving this problem means changing our ways and spending money to control emissions -- a lot of money," said Dr. Gary Glass, a chemist at the E.P.A. Environmental Research Laboratory here who is a leading Government researcher and has been studying mercury since 1987 with state support. "It's going to take a very focused effort to cut back on consumer products that contain mercury."
The Edison Electric Institute, a trade group for utilities, estimated that power plants with equipment to remove mercury from emissions could cost $5 billion nationally. Incinerator builders say curbing mercury emissions could cost $10 million to $30 million per plant.
Some steps, much less costly, are being taken. Disposal methods that keep discarded batteries and paint from incinerators help reduce mercury in the atmosphere. Battery manufacturers, concerned about possible new regulations, have cut the use of mercury to 250 tons in 1989, from almost 1,200 tons in 1984, the E.P.A. says. Last year, the agency outlawed mercury in interior latex paints.
But there are still hundreds of millions of batteries, and many old paint cans. And wood that has been covered with latex paint containing mercury still emits mercury when burned.
 
From the Earth
Ancient Gift,
Ancient Peril
 Mercury has been a valuable raw material from the earth's crust for 3,500 years and a recognized hazard for nearly as long. Romans used the bright red sulfide ore of mercury for pigments, and at least one Roman naturalist, Pliny, described how mercury miners died in large numbers.
In the 19th century, fur that was used in the manufacture of felt hats was dipped in mercuric nitrate solution. Many felt workers absorbed so much mercury through their skin that they became known for slurred speech and uncontrollable shaking.
In the 20th century, mercury's disinfecting ability make it indispensable to the paper and paint industry in controlling slimes and molds. Chemical companies incorporate mercury in some reactions as a catalyst. Historically, industrial plants poured their mercury waste into rivers or lakes, where it collected in sediments and passed up the food chain, from plankton to minnows to large fish to birds of prey and large mammals -- and human beings.
 
Tragedy in Japan
 In the 1950's and early 1960's, more than 100 people developed tremors, fell into comas and died in Minamata, Japan. Fish caught in Minamata Bay had mercury levels that measured an average of 11 one-thousandths of a gram for every kilogram (2.2 pounds), comparable to a speck of pepper on a 36-ounce steak. The F.D.A. considers eating a single meal of fish containing one-thousandth of a gram of mercury per kilogram to be dangerous, and bars commercial sales of fish that have more.
The events in Minamata spurred a global investigation that yielded evidence in the 1960's of rising mercury levels in game fish caught in American waters. In 1972, Congress passed the Clean Water Act, requiring paper companies, smelters, paint factories and other plants to install equipment and prevent mercury from being released into water.
Before the law, Minnesota sampled its rivers and found adult fish containing a mean mercury level of about one-thousandth of a gram per kilogram in their flesh -- the amount judged by the F.D.A. to be too dangerous. By the late 1970's the mean mercury levels in fish taken in Minnesota rivers dropped to 0.38 thousandths of a gram per kilogram, a level then considered safe.
But prompted by reports from Sweden of persistent and widespread mercury contamination in fish caught in remote lakes in that country, the Minnesota Department of Health in the 1970's began sampling the state's lakes, particularly those along the wild border with Canada. In 1978, the agency identified mercury at levels of more than one-thousandth of a gram per kilogram in large walleye and northern pike caught in Crane Lake, 130 miles north of here and miles from any industry. The discovery prompted sampling by scientists in Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan and in Ontario, which turned up similarly high levels and spurred renewed efforts to identify the sources.
 
From the Skies
Not So Gentle
Falls the Rain
 Scientists now believe they know the culprits. They say mercury is being swept into the upper atmosphere from cement and phosphate plants as well as power plants and incinerators. Mercury also is evaporating from contaminated lake and ocean sediments and falling back to earth as toxic rain.
"There is a lot of very nasty, unpleasant stuff in rain coming at us from everywhere," said Dr. Terry A. Haines, a fishery research biologist for the United States Fish And Wildlife Service in Maine who has documented evidence of fish contaminated with mercury in the wilds of that state.
Eliminating mercury and the other compounds from rain is an enormous technical and political problem. For one thing, like the air pollutants that cause acid rain, mercury is released into the atmosphere hundreds of miles from where it is doing the most damage. How far mercury can travel is not known, but in its gaseous form it can linger in the atmosphere up to two years before it falls back to earth.
Swedish scientists estimate that 930 tons of mercury is circulating in the world's atmosphere at any time, enough to taint rain at levels that average 10 to 50 parts per trillion. That amount, while minuscule, is enough to cause problems.
In each of the last two years, the Minnesota Legislature rejected legislation that would have made it the first state to enact strict controls on mercury emissions. Industry argued that it would increase the cost of doing business without lowering mercury levels in fish, since most of the mercury falling on Minnesota was coming from outside the state.
"In a sense, they're right," said Willard Munger, the chairman of the state House Environment and Natural Resources Committee, who proposed the measure. "It's going to take national legislation to solve this problem. But we have to start somewhere."
 
How Safe?
Tainted Fish
In the Wilds
 Crane Lake in northern Minnesota is a stepping-off point to one of the largest wilderness regions left in the continental United States. Packs of timber wolves roam the pine forests, otters sun themselves on the rocky shoreline, bears forage for berries and eagles soar across blue skies.
Yet studies by Dr. Glass, and his colleague, Dr. George R. Rapp Jr., a researcher at the University of Minnesota in Duluth, have found that mercury levels in large adult walleye and northern pike from Crane Lake range from 0.9 to 1.1 thousandths of a gram per kilogram, and that they are rising 3 percent to 5 percent a year. Younger, smaller fish have less mercury.
The Minnesota Department of Health has set a limit for mercury in fish, 0.16 thousandths of a gram per kilogram, that is thought to be the nation's strictest. New York's limit is one-thousandth of a gram per kilogram, the same as the F.D.A.'s.
In almost every case, walleye and pike, even young fish 5 inches to 15 inches long, that are caught in Crane Lake and in neighboring Sand Point Lake exceed the state limit. The Minnesota Department of Health has warned Crane Lake anglers not to eat more than one eight-ounce serving of pike or walleye a week. Pregnant women, nursing mothers, women thinking of becoming pregnant, and children under the age of 6 are advised against eating any fish.
 
Harmless to Visitors
 Businessmen and lodge owners from Crane Lake say the limits are so stringent that they may ruin summertime lodging and fishing. Large fish are recognized as having the most mercury and they are rarely eaten, say homeowners and fishing guides. But smaller fish are staples of the meals that guides prepare, and the guides say they are harmless, especially to visitors who spend only a few days in the region.
"I've been eating fish here my whole life, and I'm fine," said Arthur (Butch) Eggen, a 38-year-old fishing guide. "The small fish aren't going to hurt you."
But businessmen recognize that rising levels of mercury in fish in Northern Minnesota lakes represents an economic problem, especially if people conclude that families seeking refuge from citys pollution face a greater risk of exposure to a dangerous toxic compound while on their vacations.
"We just have to tell people who come here what we know," said David K. Dill, the economic development director in Orr, 28 miles southwest of Crane Lake. "Yes, mercury is here. Yes, it's in the fish. But nobody in Minnesota has ever been diagnosed with mercury poisoning. And as far as the local people are concerned, it's a pressing issue only because if people get scared and go someplace else, it's pressing our pocketbooks."
 
What to Do?
Why Solutions
Are Elusive
 Perhaps most distressing about mercury pollution, say scientists, is that even if every industrial source of mercury was shut down today, the problem could get worse in some areas before it gets better.
First, more than 100 years of reliance on mercury has helped to produce some 45 million tons in the soil, the oceans, the sediment of lakes and rivers and the atmosphere. Second, scientists have found that other pollutants affect how mercury behaves.
Mercury is most dangerous when it is converted in the environment from its elemental form to methyl mercury, the organic form readily absorbed by fish. One of the disturbing recent findings is that acid in lakes and in clouds, and ozone pollution from cars and power plants, more quickly converts elemental mercury to methyl mercury. Environmental agencies in Minnesota, Wisconsin and New York have noted that the highest levels of mercury were found in fish taken from the most acidified lakes.
Thomas C. Jorling, the Commissioner of the New York Department of Environmental Conservation, said mercury contamination "can't be solved by one state acting alone, which makes it an appropriate place for the Federal Government to act."
The Edison Electric Institute estimates that the amount of mercury released from burning coal in the United States each year is 100 tons, a small fraction of the 3,000 to 5,000 tons of mercury that pours into the atmosphere from burning coal around the world. The group argues that, like the destruction of the earth's ozone shield, the mercury problem will be solved only by an international treaty.
"Maybe we'll decide to go to new ways of generating power," said Dr. Donald B. Porcella, an ecologist at the Electric Power Research Institute, the utility industry's research arm. "Maybe we'll put more controls on incinerators. Maybe we'll cut back on using, or even eliminating mercury in industry. But its a very complicated problem, and we better understand it before we start making decisions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It's going to take a very focused effort to cut back on consumer products that contain mercury and to require controls," said Dr. Gary Glass, an inorganic chemist with the Envrionmental Protection Agency. "If we don't, the alternative is higher levels in fish and more environmental contamination."; In 1978, the Minnesota Department of Health identified rising levels of mercury in large walleye and northern pike caught in Crane Lake. Fillets of a fish caught there were examined by an angler. (Photographs by Jack Rendulich for The New York Times) (pg. B5)
 
Diagram: "Mercury in the Environment"
 
Mercury is a stable, naturally occurring element that is highly toxic and forms a variety of compounds. Here is how mercury circulates through the environment, and estimates of how much is present or produced.
 
Natural Sources: Emissions estimates range from 3,000 to 20,000 tons a year. Volcanoes are one major source; mineral ores that give off mercury are common in the earth's crust.
 
Industrial sources: Emit up to 21,000 tons a year. Mining is the biggest source; others include burning of oil and coal; metal smelting; steel and cement making; incineration of batteries, paint and other products made with mercury.
 
Atmosphere: Contains up to 930 tons at any one time. Once they reach the upper atmosphere, mercury compounds remain suspended for up to two years.
 
Toxic rain: Rain and snow carry mercury back to earth. Acid rain promotes formation of methyl mercury, the form most readily absorbed by fish and wildlife.
 
Soil: No estimate. Mercury reaches soil from dumping of solid and liquid waste, and from tainted rain and snow.
 
Water: Lakes and rivers contain up to 2,200 tons; the oceans contain more than 45 million tons. Methyl mercury is formed and is readily absorbed by fish.
 
Sediments: No estimate. Mercury compounds collect in lake, river and ocean sediments and, when disturbed by dredging, release mercury back into the water. (Source: Environmental Protection Agency) (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: Using Credit Cards, Students Learn a Hard Lesson

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
As a freshman at the University of Houston, Alicia Perez signed up for classes and, in the cafeteria, for credit cards. She had no job and no credit history, but she soon had three Visa cards, a Sears card, a Discover card, two gasoline company cards and a local department store card.
Today, Ms. Perez, a junior, has no cards but $6,800 worth of credit card debt. 
 "For some reason, I just got out of control," said Ms. Perez, 21 years old. "I used the cards to pay for meals, buy compact discs, or if I saw something in the mall."
More than half of the nation's 5.6 million full-time four-year college students will be taking credit cards to school this fall along with their books and bedding, says Credit Card News, a bimonthly trade newsletter published in Chicago.
And for those students who do not yet have any, companies that offer cards will do everything in their power to see that the students acquire them. Among the measures some will take are setting up solicitation tables on campuses, providing incentive gifts, like the dictionary that Ms. Perez got when she signed up for a package of six cards, and waiving some of the usual requirements, like credit histories, income requirements or parental signatures.
The credit card companies are aiming at college students because they are a growing new market, with 3.68 million spenders having brought the major card issuers at least $3.5 billion in 1990, according to an estimate by Credit Card News. While this is only about 1 percent of the $341.8 billion that was charged in 1990 in the United States, it represents the future. The rest of the market is saturated, with the average non-student cardholder owning seven cards.
 
'Somewhat More Responsible'
 Susan Weeks, a spokeswoman for Citicorp, the nation's largest issuer of credit cards, said college students are good customers. "We've found that they are somewhat more responsible than our other customers," she said. "And student delinquency rates are less than those of the general population."
Asked if that was because parents were paying the bills for their children, Ms. Weeks said, "We don't have a co-signer on the card, so it's the person who takes out the card who has legal responsibility for it."
Among those who see some advantage in extending credit to students are the students themselves. Some campus organizations that help sign up cardholders say it can be valuable for students to establish credit.
But many outside the credit card industry are far less enthusiastic about the expanding market among students. Financial counselors at colleges and universities across the country say they are finding that more and more students are using cards to cover rent, groceries and other necessities, especially as the recession squeezes family incomes, and that the students are establishing bad credit records.
And increasing numbers of parents, credit counselors, financial aid officers and students worry that the practice is creating a new generation of debt addicts.
"Students are saying that they should get credit cards now because it is easier than when they graduate," said Flora Williams, an associate professor in family economics and financial counseling at Purdue University. "And it is, because the credit card companies know that the parents are going to pay the bills or bail the kid out if he gets in trouble."
Those whose parents can not or will not bail them out are turning to counseling agencies, like the not-for-profit Consumer Credit Counseling Services. The 621 such agencies across the country help consumers work out payment schedules with creditors. Ms. Perez took this route, as did Ralph (Tip) Fishburn, a senior at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va.
 
Straightening Out Priorities
 "I just had all my priorities screwed up," said Mr. Fishburn, 28. "I went into college straight out of high school, flunked out, worked for a while as a bicycle courier and then in 1987 went back to school. I had a virgin Mastercard with a $1,500 credit limit. I promptly put $1,200 worth of tuition on it."
No longer working as a courier, but in the school's cafeteria, Mr. Fishburn said, his income shrank precipitously. But not his credit habit.
"I didn't have any parents backing me up," he said. "I'd taken out a couple of school loans as well, and the slide just started."
Anne Swift, an associate professor at the Financial Counseling Clinic at Iowa State University, said students who are referred to her clinic often use credit cards to pay for gasoline or for cash advances to pay rent or buy groceries.
 
'He's Maxed Out'
 "I've got one junior who works part time and goes to school full time and he's $8,000 in debt," Ms. Swift said. "He's got a loan and a Pell Grant and he's maxed out his credit cards. You can't automatically say drop out, get a job, pay everything off and then come back to school, because six months out of school the student has to start paying back his school loan."
Paying off credit card bills is an expensive proposition. Last year the average cost of financing purchases on a standard fixed-rate Visa card or Mastercard was 18.86 percent.
Fred Waddell, a family resource management specialist at Auburn University, said increasing numbers of students were coming for counseling about their troubles with credit cards. "It's reached a serious proportion in terms of the students here who not only use credit cards indiscriminately but who write checks on credit cards which then bounce," he said.
Mr. Waddell said: " There's hardly a university student today who isn't receiving many solicitations. I have some real reservations about that." "
Some universities or national student organizations participate in "affinity" programs in which banks make credit cards available in bulk to special interest groups and then pay royalties to the groups for every dollar charged by the new cardholders they sign up.
"We find that it's very important for students to have credit," said Pierre Barolette of the United States Student Association, which has an affinity card program with MBNA, a bank in Delaware. "It's important that students begin a credit history."
But some worry about the implications of such trends for the attitudes of the young people.
Dr. Williams at Purdue said that credit card companies are no longer using the rigorous standards they once set in issuing cards and that the young people are not learning how to handle them responsibly.
"Students are getting credit when they don't meet the requirements for credit: capital, character and collateral," Dr. Williams said. "They look at credit as a resource, not as what it is, a debt."
Oliver Love, a 19-year-old freshman at Illinois State University, is one who has so far resisted the temptation to acquire a credit card. Mr. Love said he marched right by a solicitation table that was set up outside the school's bookstore in his first week on campus. "I've just seen them abused, and I don't need to feel like an adult yet."
Kurt T. Peters, editor of Credit Card News, said the card companies' turning to college students had increased "dramatically over the last five years."
"The rationale for card issuers is very obvious," he said. "They're hoping to establish students as customers, when the students are at a stage of forming brand loyalties. And cards are so profitable that they're willing to take certain risks."
 
Cardholders of the Future
 And there is increasing interest in the younger teen-age population in owning credit cards. Peter Zollo, president of Teen-age Research Unlimited in Northbrook, Ill., recently completed a survey of 2,000 students 15 to 19 years old to determine how many wanted credit cards in their own names. Of the 15-year-olds surveyed, 52 percent said they wanted cards in their own names; 45 percent of the 16-to-17-year-olds said so; and 37 percent of the 18- and 19-year-olds said so.
"The more sophisticated they are, the more they realize there is a bill to pay," Mr. Zollo said. "They know there is some danger as far as credit."
It is a danger that Ms. Perez and Mr. Fishburn know well. Ms. Perez says she believes credit cards should be more difficult for students to obtain. Mr. Fishburn says credit card companies should do more to educate college-age consumers about how to use cards.
And neither is going to be charging anything soon. The first thing they agreed to do in their counseling sessions was to turn in their credit cards.
"Even cards I hadn't run amuck on, I turned in," said Mr. Fishburn, who has $3,500 still to pay. "Maybe someday down the road I'll get another one, but one with a very small credit limit."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alicia Perez, a college student who used credit cards to pile up $6,800 in debt. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times) (pg. A17)
 
Chart: "Credit Card Abuse: Some Symptoms"
A financial counselor, Beverly Richardson, of Fort Bend County, Tex., said parents and students can look for these signs of credit card abuse:
 
 Students have more than one credit card and one charge card that must be paid in full each month.
Card payments prevent regular payment of rent, utilities or car loans.
Cash advances or checks written on one credit card are used to make payments on another.
Balances are at the credit limit, making them unavailable for emergencies.
Credit is used to pay for meals with friends who reimburse in cash, which is then regarded as "found" money. (pg. A17)

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL: SOVIETS' RUSH TOWARD DISUNION SPREADS; EUROPE EMBRACING BALTIC INDEPENDENCE;
3 NORDIC LANDS ACT

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TALLINN, Estonia, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Three Nordic countries became the first today to recognize the secession of the Baltic republics from the Soviet Union, paving the way for the rest of Europe to embrace Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania as sovereign equals.
Denmark, Norway and Finland informed the three Baltic governments that they had extended recognition and stood ready to establish diplomatic relations immediately, and Argentina followed with a similar announcement. Iceland said it would do so on Monday, and Japan said it would recognize the sovereignty of the republics when Moscow does.
 
Bonn Wants Speedy Action
 At the same time, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany invited the Baltic foreign ministers to Bonn this week and said in a radio interview, "I will propose that we decide to establish diplomatic relations." 
 The Bush Administration expects the Soviet Union to free the Baltic republics as early as Monday and is prepared to respond immediately by giving them official recognition. American officials said. By waiting for the Soviet move, President Bush raised the danger that he would end up following the lead of European governments. [Page A13.]
Here in Tallinn, such political considerations did little to mar a sense of exhilaration. "It's a fantastic day," said Toivo Klaar, an Estonian foreign affairs official, spreading before a visitor the faxed messages his office received from governments ready to recognize the secession of the Baltic republics or who are considering such action.
 
European Community Session
 The flurry of diplomatic welcomes followed by a day the issuance of two decrees by Boris N. Yeltsin, declaring that his Russian federated republic recognized the independence of Estonia and Latvia. Russia had earlier endorsed Lithuania's claim.
The European Community announced today that its 12 foreign ministers would meet in the next few days and that a common policy on granting recognition would be discussed at this special session. Denmark, which had urged such action, decided not to await the decision of the other community members.
A letter by the Danish Foreign Minister, Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, received here today, greeted Estonia's declaration of independence with "a profound sense of joy and relief."
Lithuania, moving to add substance to its own declaration of independence, which it first asserted in the winter of 1989-90, announced that it would take full control of its borders on Monday. It will also take over the issuing of visas, which are now given by the Soviet authorities. There has been no Soviet comment on these statements.
From Riga, it was reported that Latvia planned to take similar action soon. The Estonian cabinet met today and decided to send Premier Edgar Savisaar and Interior Minister Olev Laanjarv to Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the issue with officials of the Soviet Interior Ministry.
In another action, the cabinet decided to urge Parliament on Monday to dissolve the municipal councils of three cities near its northeastern border with the Russian federation because they supported the Moscow coup. The bulk of Estonia's Russian population, the result of Stalin's policy of Russifying the Baltic lands, lives in the northeastern industrial region.
 
Ethnic Russians in Estonia
 The area is under the control of hard-line Communists, who have opposed not only the independence of Estonia but also Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies of democratization throughout the Soviet Union. About 30 percent of Estonia's population of 1.6 million consists of ethnic Russians.
The foreign ministers of the three Baltic states arrived in Reykjavik today, where Icelandic officials said they were prepared to sign an agreement on Monday establishing diplomatic ties.
From there, the officials will go on to Oslo to sign similar accords, Mr. Klaar said. Still later in the day, they will proceed to Bonn on the invitation of Mr. Genscher to discuss diplomatic relations with Germany.
The three Baltic lands were annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, after conclusion of a secret protocol to the 1939 nonaggression treaty between Stalin and Hitler. They were occupied by Germany in 1941, in the first stages of the Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union. In the closing months of World War II, the Red Army ousted the German forces.
 
Great Postwar Suffering
 The process of Sovietization that followed in the next few years took an appalling toll of Baltic victims, as Stalin reasserted Moscow's authority. Tens of thousands joined those who had already disappeared into Soviet prison camps before the German conquest. Many never returned.
Although most Western nations, including the United States, never extended recognition to the Soviet annexation, their reluctance until now to do more than give verbal and moral support have disappointed Estonians, Lithuanians and Latvians. This has been particularly true in Lithuania, which was the first of the three to formally declare independence.
Latvia and Estonia took that same legalistic step only last week, once the Communist hard-liners' coup failed.
Even then, Baltic hopes of virtually immediate Western recognition were thwarted as Western foreign ministries tried to find out exactly how power was shifting in Moscow and throughout the Soviet Union.
Mr. Meri noted that just over a week ago, he had been told by Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain, in a phone conversation, that Estonia did not meet the criterion of being in control of its territory and borders.
 
British Think Again
 The acceleration of events in Moscow appeared to have caused a rethinking that led to the actions of the Nordic nations today. It also caused London to announce that a Foreign Office Minister, Douglas Hogg, would soon visit the three Baltic lands to study the possibility of establishing diplomatic relations.
In Copenhagen, it was reported that Denmark might dispatch a senior diplomat to Latvia as early as Monday to serve as ambassador to the three republics.


GRAPHIC: ARMENIA -- President Levon Ter-Petrosian has indicated he might sign a new union treaty that had the support of 8 of the 15 Soviet republics before the coup last week. But Armenia has a strong independence movement that opposes the treaty, which would establish a looser federation and transfer considerable powers from the Kremlin to republican leaders.

HEADLINE: School Boards Reach Out To Elderly for Support

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Each year in the Riverside school district in New Jersey, the elderly converge on the schools for Senior Citizens Day. They sample food from the cafeterias, watch students sing and dance and learn about the academic programs being financed with their tax dollars.
In Westchester County in New York, the Pelham schools have begun issuing gold cards that give the elderly there free entry to all sports events, while in nearby North Tarrytown members of the Board of Education visit groups of older people during the budget season to assure them that the fat is being trimmed from the budget. 
 Across the New York metropolitan region, school officials, some of whom faced heated school budget votes earlier this year, have begun soft-sell campaigns aimed at older residents, a growing voting bloc that has at times been ignored because its members have no children of school age.
And in doing so, the educators have taken to offering not only school dances, special days and free admission to school events, but also -- as in one district -- to lobbying state officials for property-tax relief for the elderly.
 
Budget Support Waning
 "We're going to have more and more people living in local communities without children in school," said Dr. Richard Lerer, Superintendent of the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, a statewide net work created by the Legislature to serve local school districts. "It becomes critical therefore for school districts to understand this phenomenon and to inform and involve these people."
This past spring in New Jersey, only 55 percent of the school budgets in some 600 districts were approved, while in New York State the approval rate slipped to 72 percent, one of the lowest in 11 years, the New York State School Boards Association reported. In 1984, the board noted, nearly 90 percent of the New York budgets were approved.
In Connecticut, residents do not vote on school budgets.
Educators attribute the poor approval rate primarily to general frustration over high taxes and the hard times wrought by the recession. But in some communities with large elderly populations, the vote of older people was also cited as a factor.
"They are a powerful voting bloc," said Betsey Hardeman, deputy superintendent of the Tarrytowns district. "The senior citizens are not necessarily negative about the schools, but really believe that they cannot afford to pay higher taxes -- whether state, county, local or school taxes. The only place they can show dissatisfaction is in the school budget vote."
 
Elderly Population Growing
 Educators say that with the elderly population growing -- Westchester's has grown 36 percent in the last 20 years, for example -- schools can no longer afford to ignore them. The educators say that while many of the programs are not necessarily planned to convince the elderly to vote for school budgets, they could have that affect nonetheless.
Julie Peacox, the board president in the Tarrytowns school district, is lobbying legislators in Albany for property-tax relief for 500 residents who are more than 65 years old. "If they can get tax relief, which they deserve, they will be more willing to say yes on a school budget, since the budget comes out of property taxes," she said.
The Hopewell Valley Regional School District in New Jersey, which suffered budget defeats in the last two years, holds monthly luncheons for older people, as well as a Valentine's Day dance.
Linda Maiden, a district spokeswoman, said the district did not use the programs as a "sales pitch or forum," although, she noted, "I did say at the luncheon before the last election that I hoped everybody would vote."
"They are important taxpayers, and we want to thank them for being part of our school community," she said.
Only a handful of states hold annual school-budget elections, according to the Education Commission of the States, a research organization in Denver. Most school boards have the power to determine their budgets themselves, but within a formula set by the state that keeps a lid on increases.
As a result, the only time school boards in most states run into voter resistance is when there are special bond issues for new school buildings or major renovations; these must go to voters for approval. And in states with large retirement communities, like Arizona, the obstacles from older voters can be enormous.
 
Bloc Voting Hurts
 In Chandler, Ariz., 18 miles southeast of Phoenix, the residents of Sun Lake, a large retirement complex, have battled the Chandler Unified School District. The district, looking for ways to get its message across, has been denied access to the retirement community's newspaper and television station.
"At first, it didn't really affect the district, because their voting bloc wasn't that large," said Dr. Howard K. Conley, the Schools Superintendent. "But now they can generate 3,000 to 5,000 votes for any issue that comes up, and these votes come in at least 90 percent no. So you have a rather difficult mountain to climb."
The American Assocation of Retired Persons, a lobby and service organization in Washington, says that, on the whole, its 33 million members do support public education. "Our experience is that the opponents are a vocal minority and that most older people do support the education of their children and their children's children," said Ted Bobrow, a spokesman.
Nonetheless some school districts have found themselves at odds with a growing group that lives on fixed incomes and is deeply concerned about rising taxes.
 
Ties to Pupils Encouraged
 Educators have used all sorts of programs to get the elderly involved in the school districts. In the East Islip school district on Long Island, a foster-grandparenting program for young children who are considered to be at risk is entering its fourth year.
About two dozen residents of the district, ranging in age from 60 to 86, "adopt" students with family troubles in elementary school and give the children emotional support and positive feedback. The program is operated by Foster Grandparents Inc. of Suffolk County, an agency of United Way.
Though the program's main purpose is to help the youngsters, school officials say that any gain in support for the schools by the elderly is a "serendipitous" outcome.
In the Connetquot Central School District, which draws 7,800 students from Oakdale, Bohemia and Ronkonkoma on Long Island, there is a pen-pal program between English students in the junior high school and elderly citizens. Begun three years ago, the correspondence culminates in the spring with a breakfast at which the writers meet one another.
In addition, students in all plays and musicals give one free performance just for the elderly, and every year the board names a "senior citizen of the year."
"I feel strongly that we're all going to be senior citizens one day, but it's also good public relations," said Schools Superintendent John S. Maloney. "If they know what's going on in our schools, they will vote for the budget and hopefully vote positively."
 
Retirement Communities Wooed
 In Lakewood, N.J., which has a few retirement communities, school officials work closely with retired people. Leisure Village, the largest of the communities, has appointed a liaison to the Board of Education and has held candidates' nights before board elections. School district officials, in turn, have sent representatives to discuss the budget process with the elderly.
"We spent a lot of time going to the senior-citizen community this year," said Evelyn Feigin, president of the Lakewood board. "We presented our budget and explained things. We're trying to gain their trust and show that we are making an effort to keep spending down."
In all but one of the last 10 years, however, the budget has failed to win approval. "The elderly consistently defeat the budget," Mrs. Feigin said. And yet school officials direct their resentment not at the elderly, but at the parents with children in school who do not vote.
"We have 5,000 children in Lakewood schools, and if the parents would come out to vote, they have more than enough votes to offset the elderly vote," Mrs. Feigin said.
Whether the efforts to woo older people will pay off remains to be seen. Rose DeMilia, president of Tarrytown Seniors in Westchester County, said that her members were angry that the school budget was approved this year and that they were not interested in further contact with the schools.
"The school tax is too much, and the kids don't get much benefit," she said.
But Lidjia Tremper, a trustee at Leisure Village in Lakewood, said residents of her retirement community appreciated the school district's outreach.
"The board is very cooperative with us," Mrs. Tremper said. "We have asked them to keep the budget increases down to 5 percent. They're trying."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 31, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about programs to involve the elderly in school districts misstated the method of adopting school budgets in Connecticut. In most communities, they are included in municipal budgets and are not subject to a separate popular vote. But in regional school districts, the vote is separate.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Demand Up In Medical Technology

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
HOSPITAL industry executives say there are thousands of job openings across the country for technologists in medical imaging and radiation therapy. "We are desperately in need of people," said Howard W. Schwartz, senior administrative director of radiology at the University of Minnesota Hospital and Clinic in Minneapolis.
The supply of trained people has not kept up with the explosion in the use of medical technology, notably images generated by computerized X-ray scanners, magnetic resonance imaging and ultrasound devices, as well as radiation treatment for cancer patients. 
 The Labor Department forecasts continued strong demand: At least 70,000 more jobs for radiolologic technologists and technicians will be created by the end of the 1990's.
Despite the recession and cutbacks in New York health-care budgets, there are an estimated 1,000 unfilled jobs for radiologic technicians in the state, said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, operator of the New York Health Careers Center, which provides information about wages, job opportunities, educational requirements and scholarships in imaging, as well as other hospital job openings.
Mr. Raske said that in New York City radiologic technologists earn $26,000 to $28,000 a year. Diagnostic medical sonographers, who work with ultrasound, make $31,500, and radiation-therapy technologists, who work mainly with cancer patients, $36,000.
He said most hospitals were raising wages in these specialties by 10 percent annually to compete with higher offers from a rapidly growing number of independent imaging centers. James N. Heuerman, a partner at Korn/Ferry International, a health- care management recruiter, said technologists at some imaging centers earned $50,000 to $60,000 a year.
Nationally, the average pay scales are several thousand dollars lower than in New York, where living costs are high. Mr. Schwartz said that a Minneapolis ultrasound technician, for example, might earn $24,000 to $25,000, plus benefits. The American Medical Association publishes wage and school information in an annual Allied Health Education Directory.
Applicants for imaging jobs must have certificates or associate degrees from a one- or two-year training program. Some earn four-year college degrees. To be admitted to the training, students must have a high school diploma, or its equivalent, with classes in mathematics and science.
"It is a tremendous opportunity," said Barbara Bloom Kreml, director of the human resources department at the American Hospital Association. "They have the potential of studying for two years and coming out and making a good salary."
There were 672 radiography training programs in community colleges and hospitals last year, and most could have admitted more students. "Student spaces are going begging," Ms. Kreml said.
Mr. Schwartz said hospitals and radiologists became alarmed when the Labor Department predicted that the number of imaging jobs would increase by 66 percent between 1988 and 2000. "We had to do something," he added, because the supply of candidates was growing much more slowly. Indeed, the number of high school graduates was shrinking, and under budget constraints many schools curtailed career-counseling programs.
Physicians' professional groups, administrators and licensing boards in radiology, nuclear medicine, ultrasound and radiation therapy organized a consortium, the Summit on Manpower, to drum up interest in the school programs and job opportunities. The group sponsored public service radio and television announcements and is working on videotapes and high school science workbooks to describe the field.
The consortium also hopes to improve the status of imaging technicians in hospitals, which provide 90 percent of the jobs. "We used to call these jobs X-ray technicians," Ms. Kreml said. "Now they want to call them radiologic scientists." Mr. Schwartz said that another problem was to answer concerns about exposure to AIDS and other diseases in hospital work.
Some hospitals are broadening the possibilities for advancement, for example, by raising the pay of employees who learn to operate both X-ray and magnetic resonance imaging scanners. But Mr. Heuerman, the management recruiter, said the technicians, unless they also studied business administration, only rarely moved up into supervisory jobs.
Students and job counselors can call hospital personnel departments or contact the New York Health Careers Center, 555 West 57th Street, 15th floor, New York, N.Y. 10019, telephone (800) 365-1633, and the Summit on Manpower, 1825 K Street NW, Suite 210, Washington, D.C. 20006, telephone (800) 432-3247. The Allied Health Education Directory may be ordered from the American Medical Association, P.O. Box 2964, Milwaukee, Wis, 53201-2964.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Agencies Speed Up Plans To Expand in Soviet Market

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE collapse of Communism in the Soviet Union will bring a significant increase in the presence of United States advertising agencies there, industry executives said yesterday. Agencies already operating in the Soviet Union are looking to expand, while others are now considering opening offices.
Many of the largest United States shops have had Soviet operations since the late 1980's, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev touched off experimentation with capitalism. But last week's stunning, rapid-fire sequence of events, which culminated with the rout of the Communist Party, could inspire companies to accelerate their plans. And where companies go, their agencies follow. 
 "The Soviet Union will now become a very interesting and exciting market," Wolfgang Slupetzky, regional director for Eastern Europe at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, said in a telephone interview from his office in Vienna. "I see the first signs that a market economy will move in, and we are fully prepared to support this."
Ogilvy's office in Moscow, with a staff of 18 Soviet citizens, was opened "to give international clients services whenever they came into the Soviet Union," Mr. Slupetzky said. The idea was that "if more international business comes in, we would move more people into Moscow," he added, "and I see this coming now."
At Young & Rubicam/Sovero, Moscow, a joint venture of Young & Rubicam and the Soviet Union's largest agency, "we'd planned to add people as fast as we'd have a genuine need for them," said Bill Munsell, chief operating officer, who is in the United States on business.
As a result of growth earlier this year, he added, the agency had already hired three or four additional employees. That brings to 16 the total staff working on projects for clients like Colgate-Palmolive, Eastman Kodak and Johnson & Johnson.
Another reason to expand Soviet operations, Mr. Munsell said, would be to handle assignments from Soviet clients as state-owned companies are transformed into private enterprises. For one such concern in Moscow, the First Watch Company, Y.&R./Sovero is now gathering market and consumer research data, he added.
Market information is also on the mind of Roy Bostock, chairman and chief executive of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, which employs eight Soviet citizens in its Moscow office. He said the managing director there, Sergei Koptev, had been meeting with "one of the key people from our London agency, to lay out the specifications for research into specific consumer segments."
"I am sure the number of focus groups conducted in the Soviet Union is going to triple in a matter of a couple of months," he added, referring to the consumer research interviews that are common in creating advertising in the United States.
In addition to stepped-up activity in DMB&B's Moscow office, the agency will call even more on its staff members at offices in Western Europe, Mr. Bostock said, asking them to lend expertise to Soviet projects.
The fast-moving Soviet changes are "an opportunity for our clients and for us," said Hank Feeley, chairman and chief executive of Leo Burnett International in Chicago, which has had no presence in the Soviet Union. Depending on client needs, he added, the agency might open an office there or offer services through existing Burnett offices.
Since the Berlin wall fell in 1989, Burnett has begun operations in three former East Bloc nations: Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland. The Soviet Union "has been on the agenda," Mr. Feeley said, adding, "It has just been a matter of when it is right."

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The Case Against Lower Inflation

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
FOR the first time since the late 1980's, inflation is clearly in decline. The most popular inflation measure, the Consumer Price Index, has fallen by more than a percentage point, to an annual rate of less than 3 percent, in the first seven months of 1991. Various other measures also show inflation to be edging down. And that raises the question, should the Government use its powers to push the inflation rate even lower? The consensus, for the moment, is no.
Economists offer three main reasons. First, trying to reduce inflation from its already relatively low level would come at a high cost in more unemployment and recession. Second, inflation is not a problem as long as prices rise each year by the same predictable percentage. When the inflation rate jumps around, the uncertainty about what prices will do next is disruptive. Or, as William Niskanen, chairman of the Cato Institute, put it: "A stable 4 percent inflation rate is better than an unstable zero rate that might soon rise." 
 Finally, pushing down the average inflation rate would be much harder on manufacturers than on service companies. Medical care fees, for example, are still rising at an 8.6 percent annual rate, but the General Electric Company could not make a recent price increase stick for its appliances and backtracked as sales fell. If the Government were to succeed in reducing the average inflation rate in this situation, doctors would probably still raise their fees, although not by as much as before, but manufacturers would have to cut prices. For them, the Government's strategy would be deflationary.
"You kill off profits when you do this, and with profits, new investment also goes, and that reduces potential economic growth," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant. "You never get the economy out of the woods."
The inflation-fighting process explains why manufacturers bear the brunt. The Government's main agent in fighting inflation is the Federal Reserve, which tries to keep interest rates high enough so that people will be discouraged from financing new refrigerators, cars or homes. The recession that began last July, with its weak demand and falling production, was a byproduct of this anti-inflation effort. But the impact is always uneven.
The demand for refrigerators, cars or houses, and therefore their prices, is much more affected by interest rates on loans than are medical fees or the prices of other services. Whatever the cost of borrowing, medical fees tend to get paid, although they rise. Health insurance, Medicaid and Medicare sustain the demand.
Some inflation, then, "greases the wheels of the economy" for manufacturers, and also for wage earners, said Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist. Rising prices for gasoline or haircuts means that a $400-a-week wage can lose purchasing power without having to be cut from $400. With zero inflation, the same loss in purchasing power requires a wage cut and "people scream about cuts in their nominal wages," Professor Blinder noted.
Still, the case for pushing down the inflation rate to zero, or nearly zero, attracts many followers. They acknowledge, for example, that a 4 percent inflation rate would be no more damaging to the economy than a 1 percent annual rise -- if the 4 percent rate remained steady and predictable. But 4 percent inflation is, by definition, hard to maintain, they say, and is therefore unpredictable. For that reason, the anti-inflationists prefer to aim for zero inflation, which they say is easier to maintain than 4 percent. "Price-level stability, popularly called zero inflation, is superior to inflation-rate stability," W. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, wrote recently.
Those who invest in Treasury securities and corporate bonds also tend to favor zero inflation, because inflation reduces the purchasing power of the money they have tied up in these securities. And then there is the argument that downward pressure on inflation forces companies to be more efficient and productive. If General Electric cannot raise refrigerator prices, it tries to preserve profit margins in the face of rising labor costs through automation, layoffs and new procedures.
Manufacturers generally respond more quickly than service companies to the anti-inflation prod, but lately the service sector, too, seems to be pushing for efficiencies, mostly through layoffs, as obtaining price increases becomes more difficult.
It is this behavior that demonstrates the problem in pushing inflation down too hard: Falling employment levels can prolong a recession or make a recovery very weak. "To achieve zero inflation," Paul R. Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said in a recent article, "the Fed would probably have to engineer a recession that would keep the average rate of unemployment at 7.5 percent for the next five years."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Sluggish Trading in Dollar; Gold Prices Up Moderately

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mixed in listless trading yesterday as investors evaluated events in the Soviet Union.
Gold prices rose modestly. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold closed at $355.20 an ounce, up $1.80 from late Friday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $355.25 an ounce, up $1.75. 
 Traders said there was little economic news to affect the dollar, and trading was also slow because the currency and precious metals markets in Britain and Hong Kong were closed because of holidays.
"People are just kind of taking a wait-and-see attitude on how the Russian situation settles down," said George Eckhardt, manager of foreign exchange at Paine Webber International.
The dollar initially surged last week on news of the Soviet coup, but it fell when the coup failed. The dollar is historically seen as a safe investment during international instability.
The dollar rose sharply on Friday after the Government's report on orders to factories for durable goods suggested an economic upturn.
In Tokyo yesterday, the dollar rose 0.32 yen, closing at 137.02. In European markets, it was quoted at 136.95 yen. In New York, it closed at 136.90 yen, unchanged from Friday.
In Europe, the British pound rose to $1.6775, from $1.6738 on Friday. In New York, a pound cost $1.6800, more expensive than $1.6775 late on Friday.
The dollar rose minimally against the German mark in New York, closing at 1.7480 marks, compared with 1.7475 on Friday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.5240 Swiss francs, down from 1.5275; 5.9365 French francs, up from 5.9345; 1,304.50 Italian lire, down from 1,304.75, and 1.1440 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14415.
In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $354.25 an ounce, up from $353.50 late on Friday.
Silver fell to $3.930 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, from $3.936 late on Friday.

HEADLINE: Donald C. Platten, Ex-Chairman Of Chemical Bank, Is Dead at 72

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Donald C. Platten, chairman and chief executive of Chemical Bank from 1973 to 1984, died on Sunday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.
He died of lung cancer, his family said. 
 Chemical Bank was the only place Mr. Platten ever worked. He had nonpaying summer jobs there for two years while he was in college, and joined Chemical's credit department soon after he graduated from Princeton in 1940. His salary that first year was $1,300, nearly as much as he made in a single day 35 years later, when he was Chemical's top executive.
Mr. Platten specialized in philosophy at Princeton -- not economics "or an accounting course that gave me fits," he once said -- even though "I sort of knew I was going into business."
 
Moved Bank's Headquarters
 He was appointed an assistant secretary of the bank in 1950, assistant vice president in 1953 and vice president in 1957. Promoted to senior vice president in 1964, he was put in charge of Chemical's 145 branches in the metropolitan area at the time.
He was named executive vice president in 1967, with responsibility for the international division. Mr. Platten turned it into a $3 billion unit before he was named first vice president in September 1970, the steppingstone to the chairman's office.
Chemical nearly tripled its total assets and grew as a diversified financial services organization while he was chairman. It assembled the state's second-largest branch network, after Citibank, when it paid $40 million for the Security National Bank on Long Island in 1975. Security had 96 branches and deposits of $1.4 billion.
In 1979, Mr. Platten moved his office -- and Chemical's headquarters -- from lower Manhattan, where the bank had been based for more than 150 years, to 277 Park Avenue.
 
Building Named for Him
 In the aftermath of New York City's fiscal crisis of the 1970's, Mayor Edward I. Koch named Mr. Platten chairman of the New York City Mayor's Management Advisory Committee. That nine-member panel met monthly to review issues of management and operations.
He was a lifetime director of the Collegiate School, which he had attended, and was the first person to have a Collegiate building named for him.
He is survived by his wife, Margaret; a son, Peter W., of Cranbury, N.J.; two daughters, Katherine P. Tyson of Sudbury, Mass., and Alison P. Vanderbilt of Norwalk, Conn.; two brothers, John H., of Princeton and Peter, of Devon, Pa.; seven grandchildren, and a great-grandson.
