HEADLINE: A Silent Budget Victim: New York's Dying Trees

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER

 BODY:
There's a pit on 42d Street, right by the north entrance to the New York Public Library, that looks like the giant footprint of a prehistoric animal. In it is the cracked cork-like remains of a tree that once cooled the passers-by and helped purify the air they breathed. Now it looks like a fossil from another time.
Indeed, only one tree still lives on this stretch of sidewalk between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. It's a bedraggled London plane, with a huge scar running up its trunk, the mark of repeated batterings by trucks and cars.
08-27-91 
 Dog feces and Juicy Fruit gum wrappers lie on its tiny square of soil, as compacted as concrete. Not too long from now, this lone tree will go the way of the others that once shaded the street. Now they are just empty pits. Some are discreetly covered over with concrete like unmarked graves.
 
Environmental Threat
 New York City's trees are in trouble.
In many ways as much a part of the city's infrastructure as its bridges, subways and sewers, the city's trees, which cool and purify the air, turning bare, hot streets into neighborly gathering places, are suffering from a lack of maintenance.
"Eight trees are dying or being taken down for every one that's planted," said Nina Bassuk, director of Cornell University's Urban Horticulture Institute.
Scientists say that trees can cut air-conditioning needs by one third, saving cities and businesses millions of dollars. A recent survey by Cornell University's Urban Horticulture Institute showed that a sun-baked section of Columbus Avenue on a hot August day pushed the mercury to 108 degrees. In Central Park at the same time, it was 86 degrees.
 
Pollution Fighter
 Healthy trees can also cut pollutants by about one third, according to the American Forestry Association. And an abundance of trees can also help raise real estate values by adding natural beauty to an otherwise harsh urban landscape.
Yet these natural energy savers and beautifiers are disappearing from the city's streets at an alarming rate. They lack water and pruning care and they suffer the combined abuses of impacted soil, rammings by cars and salt from the streets. It all adds up.
The American Forestry Association found that in 1989, more than a third of the available planting spaces in New York were either empty or had dead or dying trees. The existing trees were, on the whole, small, or less than 12 inches in diameter.
Though the city plants thousands of trees annually, neglect dooms many. It's also important to plant a tree that can take urban abuse. Ginkgo and locust trees, for example, can take a beating. Pin oaks and red maples cannot. And planting too many of one kind -- the London plane, for example -- invites devastation from disease.
Since 1980, the Parks Department has planted more than 87,885 street trees, at an estimated cost of $44 million. Yet an estimated 15,000 are dying every year.
There are 2.7 million trees in the five boroughs -- 700,000 of which grow along the street. But recent budget cuts almost guarantee further neglect.
On July 1, last year's $5.2 million forestry budget was reduced to $660,000. And the chief city forester, William Lough, was laid off -- along with more than 100 climbers and pruners. That leaves 20 trimmers -- for 2.7 million trees.
"We haven't been able to properly maintain our trees since I came here late in 1986," said Mr. Lough. "These trees should be pruned every five to seven years."
That would take about 400 pruners, according to Paul Berizzi, the city's chief of environmental services. "Even before the cuts, we were on a 28-year-cycle."
 
Need for Care
 "The administrators of this parks department don't seem to bear in mind that trees need to be maintained," said Barbara Eber-Schmid, director of the New York City Street Tree Consortium, a 2,100-member volunteer group formed in the late 1970's to care for trees, especially newly planted ones, that were suffering neglect.
"You don't just stick a tree in the ground and figure God will take care of it," she said. "They need to be watered in time of drought, the soil needs to be loosened, they need to be pruned."
Now, said Ms. Eber-Schmid, "It looks like we'll be on a 100-year pruning cycle."
Regular pruning removes dead or diseased limbs and shapes the tree to withstand storm damage. And regular inspections insure that dead trees or hazardous branches are taken down before they fall.
"Obviously, we're not going to be able to care for the trees," said Betsy Gotbaum, the city Parks Commissioner. "It's very foolhardy. If we have a storm or catastrophe -- another Gloria -- we'll be in trouble."
But city officials say that the needs of the trees are competing with more immediate human needs.
"It's a very unpleasant business, but it's a case of weighing trees against infant mortality and vital human services," said the city Budget Director, Philip Michael. "The Mayor has also indicated that public security is his number one priority after fiscal integrity, so trees are going to lose out when measured against a cop."
Experts here and around the country are shaking their heads over the fate of New York's tree program.
 
'Worst Possible Time'
 "This is the worst possible time for the city to do away with forestry," said Wayne Cahilly, manager of arboretum and grounds for the New York Botanical Garden. "A major portion of the tree population was planted in the 30's during the Robert Moses era, and many of these trees, given the stresses of the urban environment, are reaching maturity."
Trees like the overplanted London plane may present real problems.
"They have very degraded roots systems, and a huge amount of biomass leaning over the streets," he said. "All we need is a couple of big blows and those things are going to come down."
Which begs a question: What will they fall down on?
"Trees never fall up, they fall down, and down means falling on something," said Robert Skiera, who just retired after 17 years as forestry director of Milwaukee.
Milwaukee, legendary for its tree care, allots $10 million for its 320,000 street trees and green spaces. Over 80 trimmers keep trees on a five- to six-year pruning cycle. And its street trees live an average of 60 years compared to the national average of seven.
 
A Squeeze on Trees
 But many cities, crushed by the recession, have put the squeeze on trees.
"We've virtually eliminated care to street trees," said Barry Bessler, the assistant director of the Fairmount Park Commission, which manages 250,000 street trees and 8,700 acres of parks in Philadelphia. "No pruning, no spraying. All we do is answer citizen calls. If a tree is dead or hanging at a 45-degree angle over a group of kids, we'll take it down."
Los Angeles lost $6.5 million of a $19.5 million budget for tree care. It lost 66 employees from its forestry program -- but it still has more than 200 to care for a million trees.
"We were trimming our trees every four to five years," said Robert Kennedy, the city's street tree superintendent. "With these cuts and vacancies, it'll go back to a 14- or 15-year cycle."
 
'City Doesn't Seem to Care'
 "A lot of cities have financial problems, but unlike New York, they haven't fired their urban forester," said Donald C. Willeke, chairman of the National Urban Forest Council. "It's one of the shortest-sighted things I've seen since 1970, when I left. I was a lawyer on Wall Street, but I got out. I found life there unpalatable, and one of the reasons was city trees."
Mr. Willeke, who practices law in Minneapolis now, recently toured the country, assessing the state of city trees.
"I don't think any place is in as bad shape as New York," he said. "The city doesn't seem to care about its environment. It can spend all kinds of money on concrete, but it doesn't realize that trees are part of the infrastructure too." Scientists have begun to evaluate trees -- and they do a lot more than act pretty.
"If everybody planted trees on the south and west side of their houses, they'd save 30 percent on their air-conditioning bill," said Arthur Rosenfeld, a physicist and director of the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory at the University of California.
Urban trees suffer enormous stresses. They evolved to live in a forest, with other trees, with plenty of room for their roots. But in the city, they are placed in tiny boxes of soil so compacted that little air or water can permeate. Reflected heat dries them out, trucks bang into them, people pile garbage bags on them, dogs urinate on them. Their roots are sheared off when sidewalks are repaired or streets widened. They are deluged with salt in winter.
Given these constant assaults, it's no wonder they only live an average of seven years. If nothing gives, that elephant-like footprint on 42d Street may be one of those telling artifacts archeologists come upon: dusty proof of a city that once loved trees.

GRAPHIC: Photos: New York City has 2.7 million trees, but loses 15,000 of them annually, many due to lack of care. On 42d Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, the stump of what used to be a tree, left, sits decaying outside the north entrance to the Public Library, while a London plane tree, at right, the sole tree standing on the block, gets hit by cars and trucks and is often littered with dog feces and gum wrappers. (Photographs by William E. Sauro/The New York Times) (pg. B5)
 
Photos/Drawings: Elm -- The American elm has been devastated by Dutch Elm disease. It taught urban foresters a lesson: planting a mix of trees, rather than blocks of one kind, guards against disease and insect infestations.
 
Ginkgo -- The ginkgo is an excellent urban tree, because it can tolerate high heat, drought and alkaline soils, and is relatively disease-free.
 
Locust -- The locust tree is another hardy city dweller. It can withstand smog, dust and pollution, heat and drought and alkaline soils.
 
Pin Oak -- The pin oak loves rich, moist acid soil. It languishes under alkaline conditions, caused by limestone in concrete, so it is not a good survivor on the street.
 
Red Maple -- The red maple, which thrives in moist, rich soil, has weak wood and is easily damaged by ice. It's not a good candidate for the city. (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Debate in Parliament: Gorbachev Takes 'an Enormous Share' of the Blame; Legislators Speak Out: 'We Have the Spirit of Reaction in this Assembly'

 BODY:
Following are key sections of the session of the Supreme Soviet yesterday, including a speech by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and speeches by other Supreme Soviet members. The speech by Nursultan A. Nazarbayev was transcribed and translated by The New York Times and the BBC monitoring service; all others were translated by CNN and transcribed by Reuters.
 
GORBACHEV'S SPEECH
 Distinguished members of the Supreme Soviet: first of all, I would like to support the decision adopted by the Supreme Soviet to convene an emergency session of the Congress of People's Deputies, because the problem itself and everything we have gone through over the last days and the decisions that are necessary are all the prerogatives of the Congress. And this is the first thing I wanted to say. 
 And then I would like to suggest the following thing: that is to invite members of the Russian Parliament and members of other parliaments to attend the session of the Congress.
In the period remaining, I would request that the people's deputies working in commissions and committees in different chambers and groups of deputies to discuss and analyze everything that has happened and the reason for that and to draw appropriate conclusions. What is needed is not just philosophizing but specific and concrete decisions and actions, which must be based on accurate and uncompromising analysis of everything we have gone through.
Naturally enough, in the buildup to the Congress, we will not remain idle. In fact, we have begun our work and we have raised the matter of nonconfidence in respect of the Cabinet of Ministers. The Cabinet of Ministers did not live up to the challenge and actually participated in the coup. The decree on the departicization of troops and the K.G.B. has been adopted.
People have been removed from the key positions in the army -- I mean those who sided with the plotters. New people have been put in key positions. The office of the Procurator General of the U.S.S.R. and the Russian Federation is currently conducting a criminal investigation into the coup.
You are familiar with the declaration I made earlier. I resigned from the post of the General Secretary of the Communist Party and I suggested that the Central Committee of the Communist Party should disband itself. Similar measures and these specific measures are necessary to defuse tensions in the country and we will unswervingly pursue this policy in the future.
 
Signs of Impending Coup
 In this statement that I am making -- this is not a report, this is just a statement because a report would need much more preparation and we need to consult with each other before I make a report. But for the time being, I would like to dwell on the most important issues.
Distinguished deputies, the coup was not entirely unexpected. It was not a bolt from the blue. It was prepared by the provocative statements of certain generals and people in key positions and certain statements made in the Supreme Soviet, and there were attempts to undermine the decisions. And the coup was impending and appropriate steps were necessary to protect the constitutional order in the country. However, that had not been done, although we did draw appropriate conclusions and we rebuffed those attempts in the Supreme Soviet, in the press and elsewhere.
However, instead of decisive actions, there was lack of determination, and I am also responsible for that lack of determination. But this is one conclusion that must be drawn from that situation. There is another cause for the attempt to push the country toward totalitarianism and that is lack of decision in the implementation of democratic reforms, particularly in those structures that spearheaded the coup. And this is not only my responsibility but the responsibility of the Supreme Soviet, the party and the Government.
Our good intentions and plans were not implemented because the old mechanism and the old structure of power had not been changed. And I mean primarily the state apparatus, which was totally in agreement with the policy of the party and there were people in key positions who remained loyal to the Stalinist doctrine. We vacillated for a long time and even at this moment, we have not embarked on the road of decisive transformation.
This has affected the sociopolitical situation in the country. In fact, the plotters wanted to take advantage of the difficulties in the country and it is true that the people of the country are facing a very difficult situation. There's a slump in living standards. The criminality is on the rise. And the overall situation is deteriorating.
There's another reason for the coup and that is there was lack of coordination between the forces of perestroika, between different groups of democratic forces. We were divided. And both in the session of the Congress and at plenary meetings, I used to say again and again that if we are committed to democracy and democratic movement, it would be a major mistake if we get involved in a political struggle.
However, there was a lack of political vision and a lack of responsibility for our common cause. I mean the democrats first and foremost. Without appropriate constitutional supervision, the army was in a very difficult situation. However, the plotters failed to plunge the army into the struggle against its own people, and those were the major miscalculations on the part of the plotters.
 
Troops Refuse to Attack
 They believed, and I apologize for the languages I'm using, but they believed that they could manipulate the people. However, the country had changed, and that was a major mistake on their part. The country had changed. The people had changed and the army had changed, because the army is a part of the people. And even those forces in the army that had been trained for emergency situations and contingency situations, for anti-terrorist activities, refused to take actions against the people.
Although they were threatened with court-martial, they refused to participate in the coup. Airborne troops refused to participate. And you know the actual capability of airborne troops. Just three planeloads would have been enough to remove the Government from power.
And those people who took the troops into the streets of Moscow refused to participate in the coup, and this is another major cause for the failure of the coup. However, troops were out in large numbers in the streets of Moscow. There were tanks in the streets. And those actions were taken without an appropriate approval on the part of the legislature. That means that the mechanism of power is not functioning properly.
The K.G.B. had not been reorganized. It is true that the K.G.B. protects the interests of the state, using its intelligence agencies, but the K.G.B. remained an instrument of political struggle, despite the changes that have been made.
The Supreme Soviet failed to move and members of the Cabinet of Ministers panicked and failed to take action [change of interpreter] face of the committee. All of this helped. But I, as President, bear an enormous share of the responsibility for this. I say this because during these days, a lot has become clear to me. I have drawn a lot of different conclusions from what has happened to us.
They seem to say that I've come to a different country. I could even add another country in the sense -- the way that I look at various problems, such as human rights, and I look at the future also with other eyes.
In any case, no oscillations and no delays will be accepted in carrying out these reforms as long as I am President. No more compromises with those who -- your applause I accept to mean that you are not willing to accept any compromises. Although my main desire was that everything we do should lead to democracy, and this supported my position -- and this is perhaps what helped me avoid doing anything that would have led our country to a catastrophe.
One other reason that made the process of reform so painful and -- the party bureaucratic structures have -- I recall how in the Central Committee meeting there was some struggle against those who were trying to block the democratic transformations. The old system was already undermined, disorganized, but it continued to hang on and it tried to prevent the transformations from being carried out.
 
Soviet Society's Changes
 Its -- we -- indeed, initially I thought it was possible to separate the millions of party members from the leadership. Indeed, the belief of many members of the party inspired me with hope that we would be able to have a genuine transformation and reorganize the party along contemporary lines. But this coup d'etat made it no longer possible for me to think this way. And I thought it was my duty as Secretary General and urged the Central Committee to dissolve itself for that reason.
Even so, despite all of these reasons that made the plot possible, it was nonetheless condemned from the very beginning to failure. The last six years have shown that we did not live them in vain. We can no longer recognize how the country has changed. New democratic forces have emerged. These coup leaders didn't understand this, and maybe we also don't understand each other all the time, but nonetheless we have become able to deal them a crushing blow.
This conclusion is directly linked to why the plotters hastened so rapidly to carry out their plans. I can state with full conviction that they understood that any delay was fatally dangerous to them because such processes were emerging, such as the nine-plus-one process we're engaged in. And not only in the party Central Committee, but even in the Supreme Soviet, we will understand that -- we have fully understood that process. And these days, we have to say everything sincerely and openly, because we are all here together and the country is behind us.
That's -- in signing the union treaty and undertaking the transition to a market, the meeting of the E.E.C. is going to make it possible to be integrated into the world economy unless this coup failed and it was crushed. I would like once again to express my unlimited gratitude to the hundreds of thousands of Muscovites who came out into the streets, fearlessly confronting machine guns and tanks to defend legality.
An enormous role here was played by Boris Nikolayevich Yeltsin and the Russian Parliament, the inhabitants of Leningrad and their leaders, and also the peoples of the other republics.
The country did not accept -- however they tried to package their appeal to the people, the country would not accept what they had to say. And in these very difficult circumstances, people took -- were willing to accept decisive measures but not any kind of measure. At the same time, the very fact that the coup was possible is evidence that we are still only halfway there, and we have to take other urgent measures to create guarantees of constitutional legality.
What shall we do next now? First of all, I feel it very important to immediately renew the process of signing the union treaty. The plotters were able to undermine this process. This was one of the main aims, unfortunately.
 
The Union Treaty
 A number of the decrees of this so-called Emergency Committee included decrees by the President of the Supreme Soviet Lukyanov, as we found out later immediately handed over to the information media, in which he tried to show that the union treaty should not be signed.
The draft treaty is a balance of the interests of all participants. Of course, it could be improved here and there, but the main thing is, and here I agree with those proposals that have been made these recent days and the statement by the leadership of the Russian Federation and certain meetings, certain proposals made in Leningrad and other republics that we have to sign the treaty and not delay its signing any longer.
The fact that it can be improved, this can be done by addenda and by protocols and thereby we will be acting on the basis of the people's will as expressed in a referendum.
In meetings with the leaders of the nine republics on Aug. 23, after my return, I understood that the union treaty has got to be signed as quickly as possible. In the meantime, certain steps have been taken, but we are not talking only about the final step in the transformation of our society but only the first step.
Second point: we have to take the attitude with respect to those republics who don't want to sign the treaty. They have to be given the right to make their own choice. After signing the treaty we have to start business discussions with those who want to leave the union.
The preparatory work can be done here and now. The agreement with them has got to contain all guarantees of the observation of human rights, regardless of their ethnicity. We have to solve the question of compensating those citizens who don't want to remain outside the union but want to join it, the question of the military infrastructure, where it has to be retained for a certain period of time on the territory of those republics which have separated from the union.
At the same time, considering the vital interests of all 15 republics in maintaining economic ties, we have to start to work on concluding economic agreements, and this has to be done here and now, immediately.
In the third place, we have immediately to solve certain questions of how the country is going to be governed until the new constitution is accepted. This has to be done right now. We have to have elections to solve some major questions such as the election of the new U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, a new vice president. We must consult with each other very assiduously on this.
At the meeting with the leaders of the republics on the 23d of August, a proposal was made to have an authoritative body that can adopt coordinated decisions on all major questions relating to the whole Soviet Union. I'm talking about administration or government now.
 
New Soviet Laws
 It was proposed that we use the constitutional body known as the Security Council, which doesn't yet exist. And we have to enhance the significance of this body in its makeup and its competence. This can be done if the leaders of the republics enter it, those republics that have decided to sign the union treaty -- Comrades Bakatin, Primakov, Popov, Revenko, [GRIGORY I., a member of the presidential council] and others.
We have to form on the basis of agreement with the other republics a cabinet of minsters of the U.S.S.R., although a decision has already been taken to form such a group with Comrade Silayev.
In the fourth place, the plotters would not have been able to carry out their plans if on their path there had been a firm Supreme Soviet with its president. Therefore, we have to convoke the Supreme Soviet immediately. This was done immediately in Russia. This played an enormous role in blocking the coup d'etat. But at this moment the republics in the Supreme Soviet were not able to carry out their rights and responsibilities.
Now why this did not happen, why they did not come to the capital immediately, this is something we have to think about. We can draw all sorts of lessons from this, not only moral and political ones but we have got to be able to insure that this will not occur again.
What kind of formulation do we need in the Constitution or in the law? We'll have to think this one over also. I propose that those delegates here give some thought -- who is going to be the president of the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R.
I'm ready for consultations on this, am always, but in particular today. None of us should leave anything unresolved. We've got to act together and with the leaders of the republics so that there'll be total confidence and total understanding and total awareness that the job will be done as it must be done. In the fifth place, necessary to evaluate the situation and establish social control over the activity of the armed forces.
Here major transformations are necessary. First of all, we have to do everything to make sure that today, during the work on the constitution there'll be military reform as well. And then this will become a major part of the new law on military reform.
We've got to increase the professional makeup of the army. We have to reorganize the Committee of State Security. My decree of naming Comrade Bakatin as president of the committee has a second paragraph urging him to reorganize the whole system of state security.
We have to erect a barrier against any possibility of abuse of the security organs against the constitution.
I will sign a decree on the troops out of the Ministry of Defense. It's also necessary to suspend the activity of the law on the K.G.B., to work out a new conception of state security, and reform it accordingly. And [inaudible] economic measures. In view of the cardinal changes in the country, we have to revise existing laws. At the forthcoming session of the Supreme Soviet, let us discuss this and work out measures on our future economic policy, considering everything that we -- considering the fact that we are now in new circumstances after these events.
 
Economics and Republics
 We have to do everything possible, and on my part, I will -- we should not be too hasty, but we have to proceed deliberately. At the same time I take on myself the responsibility of saying something about this. First of all, measures must include elimination of all blocks created by the old structures and the old people on the path to a market economy. We have to eliminate all obstacles to this. And we have to accelerate the creation of the necessary market institutions.
We have to move the center of gravity of the economic decisions to the republican level, maintaining the, on the union government insuring a unified economic area. [Inaudible] cardinal change in our financial and creditary policy is necessary. Measures have to be taken to combat the budgetary deficit and to assure the money supply. All obstacles have got to be eliminated that prevent land from being granted to those who want to cultivate it.
We have plenty of land. We have several million such farmers, but that is not the end of it. We have to insure that there be a genuine land reform, so that this land reform shall get the necessary oxygen, and for this it needs our support.
Of course we have to collect the harvest, but there's -- there will be plenty to think about afterward, in the autumn. We have to organize a whole foreign trade, our trade with hard-currency countries. We're going to need to increase the economic assistance we get from Western countries. I've had negotiations with the main Western countries, and they have confirmed that due to the fact that the last events of recent days have convinced them that the Soviet Union has now set about reforms which are irreversible, and they understand the necessity of cooperating, and increasing this cooperation.
Social policy should go, be conducted with less demagogy in carrying out our program. We've got to get away from economic fatalism. We've got to concentrate attention on the major questions of social defense of the workers, supporting their living standard, and in particular of the, those who are less well-provided for. And an acute issue, in particular, is the food and fuel question.
Proposals to remedy this have been prepared in the republics, and we have to think about that, too. We cannot permit a breakdown in the supply of food and fuel to the population.
Even from this rostrum, I want to take this opportunity to appeal to our peasants and to all inhabitants of our countryside, all of our miners, all of those working in the power industry, to stick to their jobs until we have succeeded in solving all of these main issues.
The Committee on the Economy has been set up by me, and it has to concentrate its efforts primarily on these problems, because all these problems are interlinked.
In the seventh place, after signing the union treaty we have to start an electoral campaign for elections to the Supreme Soviet, including the President. These are measures that in my view we have -- this is what we have learned from the events of the last days, and this campaign has to be worked up very closely. Committees of the Supreme Soviet have to deal with this in a business-like way and furthermore, they have to give thought to control mechanisms to insure that the election is carried out legally, and they have got to have all of our support.
This is all I felt it necessary to tell you in this statement of mine, which I have prepared in the wake of these recent events.
Everybody is expecting decisions and business from us, and I think that the Supreme Soviet, and all of us have to do everything possible to insure that legality and order should continue. That means that all of those who are participating in -- participated in the coup d'etat have got to be dealt with as the law provides. But on the other hand, at this moment, we and the democratic forces of the country, and the whole people are opposed to any arbitrary actions that would simply compromise and endanger everything we are doing now.
 
LEVON TER-PETROSYAN
Armenian President
 Distinguished deputies, dear guests, I came up to this rostrum to make a short statement. It seems to me that I regret that we are being led away from the most crucial problem of this moment. And the most crucial problem of the current moment is not the assessment of what has happened and not the consequences, but the most crucial problem at the moment is what will happen to the center, what will happen to the union parties in power.
It seems to me that the central authorities after this coup have been outdated. The center is dead. The center has committed suicide. And to reanimate this cadaver now would mean to get back to the danger of the catastrophe that we had.
As I have been listening to the debate at the Supreme Soviet, it seems to me that the Supreme Soviet is not yet ready to seriously discuss this problem. That is why I think it's too early for me to speak. I'll speak before you at the Congress. . . .
 
YURI N. SHCHERBAK
Ukrainian Journalist
 Dear Comrades: please, I'd like to draw your attention to the draft resolution. We don't have the editorial group yet, but we'll elect it. There are several questions here and we put those in the work now.
Five years after the atomic catastrophe, we have to live through a political Chernobyl. The resolutions and decrees of the Emergency Committee smelled of threats. And these decrees showed like an X-ray machine who is who, and we now know what could have happened if the plotters could have gotten access to the nuclear trigger.
So in the Chernobyl catastrophe it was Block No. 4 that fell down, was ruined, and in 1991, it was not Chernobyl, but the Stalinist empire that collapsed. . . .
The Ukrainian Parliament has ruled that the Ukraine will be an independent because on Aug. 19, 1991, it was threatened by the state coup of losing its independence. As the state now has the right to self-determination and this has been written down in U.N. and other international documents.
So the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet or Parliament has declared the emergence of an independent state, the Ukraine. The Ukraine will have only its own laws and its own constitution and on December the 1st there will be a general referendum in the Ukraine, and we'll see what the people will decide.
I'd like to tell you that 15 deputies, a group from the Ukrainian Parliament, and I hope that others will join in, as the citizens of the Ukraine have spoken in favor of an independent Ukraine. Then we are planning to set up our own National Guard and we envisage some other measures for political and economic sovereignty.
We have been assessing the coup and the consequences it may have for Russia and the Ukraine. The people's deputies from the Ukraine have stated that the events of Aug. 19-21 have shown that the central Government is inconsistent, and Gorbachev included, and the present government bodies have no power to protect the security of peoples, and there are such uncontrollable structures as the C.P.S.U., the Communist Party, and the Ukrainian branch.
By the way today they told me that in one of the headquarters of the Ukrainian head party they had found a note, an official document in favor, in support of this coup. I'm talking about the Ministry of Defense. . . . And there were a number of Soviet officials who backed the coup. For example, the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union heard more than one threat to carry out a coup.
In May 1991, I wrote an article, a requiem for the Parliament, and I said that Gorbachev and Lukyanov are like Mozart and Salieri. But today I would compare them to Christ and Judas. . . . And I think we should remember that there were deputies here threatening the President all the time and let's get back to the protocols and read them. . . . Remember, Colonel [inaudible], Petroshenka and many others. . . .
And now it is becoming clear that we should take another stand in respect to the union treaty. There can be three kinds of ties between the sovereign republics. First, they can be bound in one state. Second, the sovereign republics sign a union treaty with the state. And third, they just sign economic, military, ecological and other agreements between each other, being sovereign.
From this point of view there can be no one state but the point is now to avoid bloodshed and to avoid the changing of borders and take into consideration the [unintelligible] and his experience instead of using the centrist structures here. I think that we should create a Eurasian community or something like the NATO and so on. Only these kinds of unions will give us peace, stability and security [unintelligible] the world. Thank you.
 
KONSTANTIN M. OBOROK
Moldavia Council Chairman
 People have been arguing that the tricolor of Russia should be retained as the national flag of the country. We have a particular problem in that we are committing an immoral act. The K.G.B. was instrumental in implementing the coup. However, I'm not going to speak about Lukyanov, but I called one of the deputies on Monday and I asked what was going on, and I was told that everything was under control, that the constitutional bodies were in place, everything was quiet. . . .
In conclusion, let me say that we have the spirit of reaction in this assembly, and many members of this Parliament are reluctant to implement the reforms.
I would like to say a prayer for Boris Yeltsin and Russian Parliament.
 
VLADIMIR P. SHCHERBAKOV
Chairman, Moscow Trade Union Council
 We indulged in wishful thinking when we thought that our Constitution could protect the constitutional order and democracy. The Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. is called on to give answers to the following questions.
What were the deep-rooted causes of the coup and what needs to be done now?
One of the causes was the political, social, and economic crisis.
Our people are suffering, there's a lack of power at every level, both executive, legislative, and judicial.
Mikhail Sergeyevich, let me tell you that the replacement of Ryzhkov, and your special powers, did not help to change the situation in the country.
Another root cause of the crisis is lack of democracy and lack of political culture in the country. As a result of that, a small group of apparatchiks believed that they could stage a coup, they thought that they were saving this country. This is easy to condemn, the plotters, and say to the people that the old system would be dismantled.
On the 23d of August, the presidium analyzed the situation and therefore, today, we speak from the position formulated by the presidium.
First of all, it is necessary to deal with the question of power in this country. This session should deal with the following issues: The formation of a new union government that would take this country through the period of transition. We believe Boris Yeltsin has suggested a very good idea of setting out a government of national reconciliation.
Next, it is necessary to identify the deadlines for the election of the parliament and the president of the country. . . .
In order to defend our democracy and to hold a genuinely democratic general election, we need to set up a united democratic front.
As a first step, we need to organize a round table, and the Supreme Soviet must initiate the formation of such a round-table discussion.
Mikhail Gorbachev promised to discuss the urgent measures such as food, energy, et cetera, and this is our top priority.
People have got to know how he's going to be fed and how he's going to be heated.
Finally, during the last three days there has been a greater change in people's consciousness than over the previous six years. The people have changed. We should not -- should we not make a use of this change in order to implement our economic reforms? The new consciousness needs a new economy. The people should become the bosses of their own factories and of their own country.
Thank you.
 
ANATOLY A. SOBCHAK
Mayor of Leningrad
 Dear colleagues, I would like when I ask for the floor to speak from this rostrum about all the mistakes that we made and the reasons that with our connivance led to a coup d'etat, but today I have decided to talk about something else.
I want to tell our distinguished colleague that all of the discussion here today leaves a very burdensome impression on me. We're talking about who is trying to distort his real position and make himself look better than he was. But let me talk about something else.
Today we have before us perhaps the most favorable situation, the most favorable conditions for rapidly progressing forward in our political and economic reforms.
For six years we have, our whole reform has been hindered by the Communist structures. For six years, every attempt that we had to move away from that center was blocked by the fact that the whole system of the Communist Party of the U.S.S.R. as a part of the state structure delayed and put the brakes on any reforms we tried to attempt.
Today finally we have an opportunity to remove those shackles and we have the opportunity now to move forward, and what do we hear? I'm most concerned, more than anything else, at the tendency I hear to try to deprive the country of its governing bodies. People are saying we don't need any kind of unified all-union authority. We're hearing that everything has to be liquidated, that all independents exist at the republican level, et cetera, et cetera.
There are two sources of danger here. First of all, Nursultan Nazarbayev, a man whom I greatly love and respect, a man who I worked with in Tbilisi in the old days -- and even then I had great respect for him and for his position of principle and honor -- but today when I heard his statement I thought that somehow it had been dictated by some kind of emotional factors connected with a lot of other equally emotional statements by some Russian deputies and some members of the Russian leadership.
Now, I'm not talking about Yeltsin. But there were some statements to the effect that we have to convey all union functions to the Russian Parliament or the Russian leadership, all union prerogatives to the President of Russia. I understand that this evokes a kind of a negative reaction. I understand it perfectly well. But I cannot understand something else.
Today there's a serious danger, a much greater danger they will take hasty decisions. Today we are deciding the future of the country and to some degree the future of humanity. Therefore it's very important that we not do things hastily, superficially, carried along by this wave of emotion in talking about national independence and the rest.
Let me just give you one example. I was very concerned by the fact that the statements of the representatives of our republics, who talked about the necessity of full state independence, never said a word about how they were liquidating the Communist structures and what they're going to do with the party property. There's a very severe danger. All this talk of independence is designed to cover the desire to retain these party structures but in a new form, retain these party bureaucrats but simply call them national bureaucrats or national leaders.
Until we have liberated our country from all the remnants of the Communist structures, we have to be quite straightforward to everybody. First of all, let us liquidate those elements or that system that has been suffocating us all these years.
Let us first of all create the necessary legal basis, and then everybody has the right or every people, every state formation has the right to independence, to solving its own national problems. But in the beginning, it is necessary to guarantee the rights of every citizen so that we not condemn our citizens in various of these republics to a new totalitarian existence. And I think this is one of the most important problems before us.
 
Mistake: Party Reforms
 Furthermore, I would like us to take a look at our ability to criticize ourselves. I think that the statement of our President was the most self-critical, although it could have even been more self-critical. We're talking about the mistakes of the union leadership and personally about Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev.
His main mistake was that all the economic and political changes in the country were presented as the desire to reform a Communist society. So all reforms were acceptable or not acceptable to the degree they were acceptable to the Communist Party.
And so these six years of attempts to reform the unreformable was our main mistake, and this is something we should have recognized a long time ago. We should have recognized that this system could not be reformed, was not capable of being reformed, and it should have been dissolved from the beginning. This is something we just waited to do today. It took a coup d'etat to do it. And let us look at ourselves critically, more critically than we have done in the past and all of this.
Let us recall how we sat by and witnessed the continuing manipulations in this very hall, in particular, the last six months, when we agreed that we wouldn't come, didn't have to come here every single day. I was never here one time to deal with an item on the agenda decided upon ahead of time, that that particular item was in fact examined on that day.
Every day Anatoly Lukyanov, was manipulating the agenda, manipulating the apparat, manipulating our votes in order to get the decisions he wanted. We should ask ourselves why we went along with this. Why did we deputies and members of the Supreme Soviet responsible for the work of this body, did we accept the dicta of this one individual who always got what he wanted?
When he saw that the hall was against him, he postponed the decision and two or three days later, when there was a different atmosphere in the hall, when some of the deputies were not here, then he submitted an item for a vote. That is something which we should take note of.
O.K., the judiciary will deal with Lukyanov and we'll find out what he really did and what role he played in this plot. But let us take a look at the position of our own legislative bodies. It's said that Lukyanov did not [unintelligible], but how about the committees, how about the factions? We have dozens of groups of deputies. Why did not one of those factions convoke on Aug. 19 and announce its own attitude? You are people's deputies after all. The decisions depend on you. This is called the Supreme Soviet. Nobody is higher than us.
Why did not one single committee come and save the honor of the Supreme Soviet and condemn the activities of the emergency committee? Why did we permit ourselves to be led by the nose and did not speak with our own voice? We showed the decisions of the President to the generals. Where were our committees, where was our committee on security, which today, on the 24th, is publishing its conclusions? Where were the other committees?
 
Return of Conspiracy
 Any committee could have met. How many people there were here, and could have taken its own decisions. Why did not any of them do this? Everyone of us here should look at his own conscience and ask why this was not done -- but they didn't do it. So let us think of the kind of system we want to have in the future so that this does not happen again.
I am very concerned that today's discussions will be a very favorable soil for conspirators to come back in the future. Imagine if we had spoken this way on the eve of the coup. Think what kind of encouragement this would have given to the emergency committee. This is something, comrades, that you have all got without trying to conceal or gloss over your own role -- have got to take into consideration.
But we cannot dissolve any governing bodies -- this is something we absolutely cannot do. We cannot remove the President, we cannot dissolve the Supreme Soviet. Who is going to run the country if we do that?
We do not have a government. Therefore we need right now to insure that there is some authority, there is somebody to hand the authority over to. This session has got to solve a number of major issues.
And on the last day of our previous session, when we decide some issues, I think that is the time to talk about dissolving ourselves in order to make way for a new election. We can have different types of elections. It will be a function of the new union of sovereign republics.
But what shall we do today or tomorrow? We have time. This is in our control. We've got to abolish our own law giving the President supplementary laws, this very emergency rule of which was at the basis for many of the decrees of the emergency committee, but which the President did not use.
What is the danger of such legislation, that if one person does not make use of this sort of law, then somebody else will? In this case Gorbachev never used any of those supplementary powers that were given to him, but the conspirators did make use of them in order to carry out a coup d'etat.
Therefore I hereby propose at this session that that particular law be abolished.
There is appeal from some delegates from the northwest and from the three Baltic republics, and I think it will be given to you -- and here we give our positions on a number of questions, in particular the question of the necessity of abolishing a number of laws relating to decrees of the Supreme Soviet with respect to the information media in particular.
We at the Supreme Soviet have to examine the legality of some other decisions taken, such as the one to close up some of the newspapers and informational media. And bear in mind that we have a law on how these measures can be carried out, and the Supreme Soviet should examine that decree as well so as not to, on a wave of euphoria, make the kind of mistakes that will be a source of shame to us in the future. We've got to manifest self-restraint and create so that in the future we will not say that we missed the opportunity to bring our country out on the path of freedom and democracy.
 
NURSULTAN A. NAZARBAYEV
President of Kazakhstan
 Esteemed peoples' deputies: Last week was not just a period of time. It was an epoch that divided us from all our past. It was a time of victory for the reactionary forces. But the people of Moscow stood face to face with tanks that were trying to restore authoritarianism. . . .
Concern for the future of our country demands that we cope with the problems facing us. As we can see, these problems are far from being resolved.
All of us today have a different awareness, and this obliges us to take a new view of the country's future and of the union treaty.
It is clear to me that a renewed union cannot be a federation. We have spent too long chasing after the past. The Ukraine's declaration of independence, and a similar decision by Byelorussia, witness a new historical reality that we cannot escape or ignore.
The situation has changed radically. You know that I was in favor of signing the union treaty, but recent events have shown how explosive the old plan was. We heard Andrei Sakharov call for the union's transformation into a community, a federation, a commonwealth, but his call fell on deaf ears.
In a future union what we have in mind is more economic relations with the center. . . . Each republic should have its own army. This decision has already been made in many republics. Each republican army will send detachments under orders of the Defense Ministry, and if there is a common threat the Defense Ministry will mobilize all of the forces. . . .
This is true also for inter-republican ties. The problem of disarmament should also be dealt with in a coordinated way. Each republic should set up its own Foreign Ministry for conducting external, economic activities and for concluding treaties with other countries. Each republic should have its own consulates to protect or defend its citizens wherever they may be located in the world.
We are used to the term U.S.S.R. We propose leaving it, and expanding it into the Free Union of Sovereign republics. By this I mean all republics including the autonomous republics that have declared or intend to declare their independence.
 
Human and Language Rights
 We should give representatives of every nationality the right to speak in their own language at republic and union meetings, and each republic should have the right to hear their deputy in their mother tongue. Thus, we are in favor of a confederative treaty, and we are convinced that only in that way will we achieve equal rights among republics. Only in this way will we achieve a genuine federation.
I would also like to mention that the existing union treaty is practically a confederative one. Let us recognize this and dot our 'i's. Only if we conclude an economic agreement also can we have a stable situation in which every republic will have full respect for its rights.
We must grant human rights to every individual regardless of culture, race, religion or background. For this, Kazakhstan is ready to invite an international commission to work and be in a multinational republic. We urge that all violations of human rights cease immediately. We are also ready to invite a commission of experts to inspect hospitals in our republic. We also propose that all we also feel this to be a guarantee of the rule of law in our republic. I urge that all question of granting sovereignty to the Baltics, Georgia, and Moldavia to be given at once.
It's true that this may cost some money but human lives are more valuable.
In the new union there should be no union cabinet of ministers or union parliament, except groups or delegations from different republics.
This is a moment of truth. I cannot see any other basis on which Kazakhstan will be willing to join the union. This is our strategy, and in the near future we have to form not a cabinet of ministers but a transitional goverment in which all of the republics will participate as part of an economic commonwealth. This interim economic council can include all of those including those who have decided to leave the union but are determined to continue their economic cooperation later.
I don't want anybody to have the illusion that Kazakhstan will be anybody's younger brother. We will join a union only with equal rights and opportunities.

HEADLINE: PERIPHERALS;
Bargains for Business

BYLINE: By L. R. SHANNON

 BODY:
A SMALL business doesn't have to spend a small fortune on software. Here are two helpful programs that cost less than $100, one of them far less.
MyBusinessCheckbook is a versatile expense-tracking, check-writing and printing program aimed at the small business or home office with an MS-DOS system, although anyone who writes a lot of checks can benefit from it. It can handle multiple accounts and businesses and give up to 15 different reports on things like cash flow trends and expenses in various categories. It works from the keyboard or with a mouse and can use Lotus 1-2-3 worksheets. 
 The publisher, MySoftware Company, says the essentials of the program can be learned in less than five minutes. That may be a bit optimistic, but it really is easy to learn, and help is a press of a function key away. In fact, there is no printed manual, just a card telling how to install the program on either a hard or floppy disk and how to get started. You can read the instructions on the screen as you go along or, if you are still wedded to paper, print them out.
Despite its relative ease of use and low price, there are advanced features. You can see the history of a payee while you are working, so you don't pay the same bill twice. As many as eight different invoices can be totaled up and paid on one check. And a simple word processor or calculator can be invoked, so you don't have to leave the program to write a reminder or add up a column of figures.
MyBusinessCheckbook is a product of the MySoftware Company of Menlo Park, Calif. Its suggested list price is $39.95 and it should be available at many software shops. People who pay the bills for giant corporations will, of course, look elsewhere.
In a kind of give-away-the-razors-to-sell-the-blades ploy, MySoftware also markets blank checks for both dot-matrix and laser printers in a variety of styles and related products like personal and signature stamps. Information and an order form are in the package.
 
Updated Calculator
 SolveIt, the financial calculator mentioned here about a year and a half ago, is out in a new version, 4.1. It still does many of the things number-crunchers need to do and a few more besides, and it is still surprisingly fast, but it looks much better.
Unlike some other similar programs, SolveIt does not put the image of a financial calculator on the screen. You fill in the blanks of a form and it does the calculations on the fly. To use one form as an example, the Future Value routine -- what money invested for a certain period of time will have grown to at the end of the period -- asks you to fill in the following blanks: present value; starting date; payment period; deposit amount; total periods; payment method; compounding period, and annual rate. With that information, the program then fills in the following blanks by itself: future value; gain; ending date; total invested; total years, and ending day.
There are 25 routines in the program. To list a few more or less at random: net present value, loan calculator, balloon payment, second mortgage, net worth. An extensive on-screen help system probably makes the manual unnecessary for people who already know about such matters; the rest of us will read the manual to find out what EOQ is and what it can do for us. ("EOQ is Economic Ordering Quantity. If you are a large volume buyer, this routine will calculate the best quantity of an item to buy considering the costs to purchase and the value of money.") The definition is followed by step-by-step instructions for filling in the blanks, and an example of the kind of problem the routine is designed to deal with. ("If you have to buy bolts, and you buy 30,000 a year . . .") So, in a way, SolveIt can be seen as an educational program as well.
Pine Grove Software, the publisher of SolveIt, also markets four other programs that are specialized pieces of the main program. MoneyCalc consists of finance routines; AmortizeIt the loan menu; Budget Plus the budget and net worth menu, and finally, RentIt offers the real estate menu. For corporate buyers, Pine Grove will modify SolveIt to reflect company needs. Contact the company for details.
SolveIt works on computers with 512 kilobytes of internal memory running DOS 2.1 or later. It can be used on a floppies-only machine, but a hard disk is recommended. It is $90, plus $5 shipping and handling and any applicable sales tax from Pine Grove Software, 67-38 108th Street, Suite D-1, Forest Hills, N.Y. 11375; telephone orders can be placed by calling (800) 242-9192 or (718) 575-9192. The smaller, specialized programs are $50 each, plus $5. Specify 5.25-inch or 3.5-inch disks.

SECTION: Section D; Page 8; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Stocks Decline Slightly in Light Trading

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Stock prices held their own yesterday after the strong rise on Friday, with some indexes inching ahead and others off a bit.
Analysts said investors were beginning to focus on domestic issues, particularly on how swift the economic recovery would be and how quickly interest rates might recede. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average finished the day just shy of Friday's record high, dropping 0.89 point, to 3,039.36. Declining issues slightly outnumbered advancing stocks on the New York Stock Exchange, 809 to 751.
Volume was light, at 130.5 million shares, compared with 189 million on Friday.
"It's clear that the recession has run its course, but the rebound has not been as swift as people would have liked," said Anothony Ludovici, senior investment strategist with Tucker Anthony Inc. "Investors see an economy that is recovering slowly, and there are concerns about interest rates."
Mr. Ludovici said there is "the consensus belief that long-term rates will decline, but in light of what's going on now, the drop in interest rates might be postponed somewhat."
"In short," he continued, "the long rates may not decline as quickly as had been expected." He added that the stock market "simply reflected what the bond market was doing, and the bond market was soft."
 
Other Markets Mixed
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 0.32 point yesterday, to 521.38. The Standard & Poor's 500 closed at 393.85, a drop of 0.32 point. The American Stock Exchange's composite index gained 0.37, closing at 369.72. And the New York Stock Exchange's index dropped 0.14 point, to 215.61.
In the first hour of trading yesterday, the Dow lost 9 points, then rushed ahead 17. But that rally lost steam quickly, and by 11 A.M. the Dow had begun a slide that would last until it recovered a bit in the last hour of trading.
Losers in the Dow average included Sears, which was down 5/8, to 42, and Chevron, off 5/8, to 71 1/4.
The most-active Big Board stock yesterday was the First Union Corporation, a commercial banking concern, which was down 1/8, to 27, with 4.2 million shares changing hands. The company's debt was downgraded by Moody's and Standard & Poor's in recent weeks.
Salomon Brothers, the second-most-active stock, gained 2 1/4, to 26, on volume of 3.3 million shares. The stock has been rebounding since Warren E. Buffett took over as head of the troubled investment banking firm, analysts said. But the stock was also affected by rumors that Laurence A. Tisch, president and chief executive of CBS Inc., had bought a large amount of stock last week.
Another big gainer yesterday was Molecular Biosystems, an organic and biochemical research and development concern, which advanced 2 3/8, to 28 3/4. Analysts said they had no explanation for the move.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
I.B.M. Lifts Some Prices

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
I.B.M. announced its annual price increases yesterday, but analysts noted that nearly all of the computer giant's big-selling items were absent from the list -- a sign of its worries about the health of the market.
Earnings at the International Business Machines Corporation, along with those of many competitors, have been ravaged by the recession, a factor that may have limited the price rises, analysts said. 
 "It says that I.B.M. is a little gun-shy," said Robert Djurdjevic, the president of Annex Research.
I.B.M. said it would raise prices 5 percent on many hardware and software products sold in the United States, effective Jan. 1, and would cut its prices by 6 to 37 percent on selected products, effective immediately.
The company excluded its newest mainframes and said the 3090 mainframe, which runs on its older technology, faced an increase. I.B.M. also left out minicomputers, work stations and personal computers.
I.B.M. declined to comment on whether economic conditions had precluded a more comprehensive increase. "Our normal business review shows that these price changes are warranted at this time," a spokesman said.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Fell in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes fell a sharp 6.7 percent in July, ending five consecutive months of increases, a real estate trade group said today.
Regionally, the seasonally adjusted annual sales rate declined 14.8 percent, to 1.27 million units, in the South; dropped 3.3 percent, to 890,000 units, in the Midwest, and fell 1.6 percent, to 610,000 units, in the West. But in the Northeast, sales rose for a fourth consecutive month, up 1.8 percent, to a rate of 580,000 units, a 19-month high. 
 Nationally, single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.35 million, down from 3.59 million in June, the National Association of Realtors said. That drop followed rises of 1.4 percent in June and 6.9 percent in May. Nonetheless, the July sales level was nine-tenths of 1 percent higher than a year ago.
Falling mortgage rates this month should help revive sales. Last week, 30-year rates were down to 9.17 percent, a four-year low. Rates on one-year adjustable mortgages were 7.03 percent, the lowest since 1984, when they were first tracked.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
BUSH HOLDING OFF ON TIES TO BALTICS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 26

 BODY:
Despite mounting pressure to take the lead in the West's response to the Soviet upheaval, President Bush held to his caution today and said that he was still not ready to grant full recognition to the Baltic republics.
Brushing aside suggestions that he move faster, the President said the United States has "special responsibilities" not to make hasty decisions that could contribute to instability in the Soviet Union, although he acknowledged that it was unlikely that American actions could have that effect.
 
'I've Expressed Myself'
 Mr. Bush was asked at a news conference today if he agreed with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who said Sunday that the United States might be better off with Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian republic's President, in charge of the Soviet Union. He replied: "Well, we'll deal with who's there. I've expressed myself on Boris Yeltsin. I've expressed myself on Gorbachev. It's not a choosing either-or here." [Excerpts, page A11.] 
 Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, who stood at Mr. Bush's side during the news conference, announced that his Government had already begun the process of establishing diplomatic relations with Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, the three Baltic lands annexed by Stalin.
The President's approach was part of his Administration's apparent determination to try to steady the position of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Bush and his aides still look to Mr. Gorbachev as the original architect of the reform movement in the Soviet Union, despite their increasingly close ties to Mr. Yeltsin and despite the view of some top officials that Mr. Yeltsin will emerge stronger than Mr. Gorbachev.
The President called the changes in the Soviet Union "exciting." But he said he had "seen nothing to change my mind" about giving more financial aid to Moscow and made it clear that Washington was not prepared, at a meeting of officials of seven industrial democracies this week in London, to agree to more aid.
"We'll stand ready to assist when we can," Mr. Bush continued."But speaking for the United States, there will be nothing out of this sherpa meeting that will commit us to the writing of checks." The term "sherpa" is applied to senior officials who conduct negotiations on behalf of their bosses.
 
A Defiant Quality
 The President seemed almost defiant at times as he defended his decision to proceed with slow, deliberate changes in American policy toward a rapidly changing Soviet Union.
Insisting that caution and prudence were in order, he seemed to be suggesting that while he was optimistic that political and economic reform were truly under way in Moscow, he was not fully convinced.
"I'd just like to see a little bit more, a few more cards on the table before we take another step," he said of his decision not to grant immediate recognition to the Baltic republics, even though an increasing number of countries have done so.
Mr. Mulroney said in his opening statement that he was instructing a Cabinet minister to meet with Baltic officials and begin "the process of establishing full diplomatic relations."
 
U.S. Isn't Canada, Bush Implies
 This prompted a question about the political implications in Canada of such a move at a time when there is strong separatist sentiment in Quebec.
He replied that the "Canadian experience and the Canadian history is the antithesis of the Soviet Union," which he said was born in a "totalitarian and illegal integration of states."
Asked about Canada's actions, Mr. Bush bristled. "I think we have special responsibilities," he said, suggesting that American actions carry more weight than those of other countries.
He expressed annoyance at television experts on Soviet affairs who urge faster action, and at a reporter who asked if he was reassessing his policy of restraint in China relations in light of his decision last week to confront the Kremlin coup masters head on.
In explaining his decisions, Mr. Bush touched on what many of those close to him say is an important factor in his decision-making process -- the fear of doing the wrong thing.
"I don't want to be a part of making a mistake that might contribute to some kind of anarchy inside the Soviet Union," the President said. He added: "I don't -- I'm not -- I don't see that we could do that. But I want to be darn sure we don't. And these developments are happening very, very fast."
On Sunday, Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, said the United States expected the Supreme Soviet, which is meeting this week, to grant the Baltics independence. Officials said that once that happened, Washington would immediately recognize them and establish diplomatic relations. But the Parliament did not take such action today and Mr. Bush made it clear that he would not recognize the Baltics on his own.
 
'Let's Know What We're Doing'
 He said the diplomatic mechanics of independence had yet to be worked out, adding: "You also want to know a little more about controlling one's own territory and what you're recognizing. I mean, there are some difficulties there. Lithuania today, for example, is different than the Lithuania that had its freedom."
Mr. Bush noted that the Ukraine had initially agreed to sign a new treaty that would keep it in the Soviet Union, but has since declared independence.
"But does that mean that they don't want a union treaty at all?" he asked. "I don't know the answer to that. And to have answers to all these complex questions at the end of a week that's moved this fast is expecting too much. And I, for one, am going to say, 'Hey, we've got a few days here. Let's know what we're doing. Let's be sure we understand what's happening.' "
The President used a similar argument in explaining why it was not yet time to move ahead more rapidly with economic aid, arguing that until the relationship between the central Government and the republics is worked out, there are too many uncertainties.
"If they're going to get aid from the West they're going to have to have some agreement, a treaty, some understanding, so people know who they're dealing with," he said.
"One of the things that they need is a deal on energy," the President added. "Canadian interests, United States interests stand ready to help, but you can't have it if you have 25 different guys going off in different directions when it comes to making a contract. There would be a benefit to them to hammer out these details in a treaty, so an entrepreneur from Canada or from the United States could go in and say, 'O.K, now we know who to deal with.' "
 
Loan Guarantees Provided
 Mr. Bush also announced today that he would be releasing early $315 million represents the next installment of a $1.5 billion package of such guarantees that the President announced on June 11, $600 million of which was given to Moscow at the time. An additional $500 million was scheduled for October and the rest for early 1992.
 An Agriculture Department official said that the $315 million was in response to a specific Soviet request.
 Moscow had to pay an unusually high interest rate for a United States Government-guaranteed loan when it went to banks to borrow the money last month, a reflection of the commercial banks' concern about Soviet credit-worthiness. A senior Administration official said today that the Soviets had encountered problems in financing the first installment and that these problems might persist for the remaining installments.

HEADLINE: Long Hot Summer of Political Sleaze Leaves Rhode Islanders Boiling Mad

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 21

 BODY:
In the annals of sleaze, this has been a memorable summer for Rhode Island.
In the last few months scandals have been breaking out here with the regularity of bills arriving in the mail. Theyhave ranged from garden-variety corruption, like that involving a mayor who was indicted for extortion, to more far-reaching affairs, like the state's banking crisis. 
 As the summer wears on, it has been difficult for Rhode Islanders to avoid the conclusion that, on a per capita basis, this tiny state has some of the most corrupt politics in the country. By now, residents no longer seem shocked by the scandals. Instead, they simply ask, "What's next?"
"I've never seen people this disgusted," said Steve Kass, a talk show host for radio station WHJJ in Providence. "You wake up and think, 'What's the outrage of the day?' Every time you pick up a rock, it's something else."
 
An Omen on New Year's Day
 Perhaps it should have been clear last New Year's Day that this was not going to be a good year for Rhode Island politicians when, in his first official act as Governor, Bruce G. Sundlun, a Democrat, ordered the immediate closing of all 45 state-chartered banks and credit unions until they had arranged Federal insurance for their deposits.
About 300,000 Rhode Islanders -- nearly one out of every three of the state's citizens -- had money invested with the institutions when they were shut down. Most of the 10 banks and 35 credit unions that were ordered closed have since reopened, and eventually all depositors are expected to get most of their savings back. But several credit unions, with combined deposits of more than $1 billion, still remain closed, their assets frozen and their customers out of luck.
The banking crisis was precipitated by the disappearance of Joseph Mollicone Jr., president of one of the credit unions, the Heritage Loan and Investment Company, who apparently embezzled more than $13 million in deposits before he disappeared. To cover these losses, the institutions' insurance fund used up virtually all of its reserves, and the house of cards that was Rhode Island's banking system collapsed.
In the months since then, no trace of Mr. Mollicone has been found. But investigations have disclosed that his alleged misdeeds were only the latest in a series of transgressions by banking executives and public officials. So far, only Mr. Mollicone has been indicted in the banking scandals.
 
Lawmakers Ignored Warning
 Unlike most banking institutions, which carry Federal insurance, Rhode Island's credit unions were insured by a private company, the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation. A recent report disclosed that lawmakers were warned as early as five years ago that the company was in trouble. But legislation that would have forced the state-chartered banks and credit unions to obtain public insurance died in the General Assembly after lobbying efforts that included dinners sponsored by the indemnity group.
Philip West, executive director of Common Cause of Rhode Island, said many Rhode Islanders believe they have been tricked by a government that was supposed to protect them. "There is a huge sense of betrayal," he said.
Since the collapse of the indemnity group, state legislators have said they had no warning of the impending crisis. But in televised hearings earlier this summer it was disclosed that several public officials had withdrawn their own money from the banks and credit unions just days before they were shut down.
State Senator John Correia, an East Providence Democrat who was a vice president of the East Providence Credit Union, withdrew more than $200,000 from that institution just three days before the bank emergency was declared. At the hearings in July, he insisted that the withdrawal had not been prompted by any inside information. And it was not really a withdrawal at all, he said; it was a "transaction."
"The intention was not to withdraw the money," he said in a recent interview. "All I did was make out a check to another bank."
 
A Soap Opera Atmosphere
 The televised hearings, now in recess, have kept the banking scandal boiling along in soap opera style. And whenever the testimony threatened to grow wearisome, a new scandal emerged to reawaken the public's sense of outrage.
In early July the Mayor of Pawtucket, Brian J. Sarault, was indicted on charges of extorting $3,000 from a city contractor. Later in the month a retired judge, Antonio S. Almeida, was charged with soliciting kickbacks from a lawyer he had appointed to lucrative receiverships.
Finally, four lawyers were suspended on charges of having lent money to a former Family Court judge before whom they had argued cases. The judge, John E. Fuyat, was indicted in June on charges of bank fraud in connection with the loans.
"Every day it's been another fiasco," said Joe Gormley, one of the founders of Operation Clean Sweep, a citizens' group organized this summer on a platform of unseating incumbent politicians.
Unseemly politics is nothing new in Rhode Island, which had its beginning as a refuge for religious dissenters and applied this tradition of tolerance to state and local government. In recent years Mr. Sundlun's predecessor, Edward D. DiPrete, a Republican, was often accused of using his office to help his son's real estate business get a profitable zoning variance. And last year voters here in Providence, the state's capital, returned to office a former Mayor, Vincent A. Cianci Jr., who is a convicted felon.
 
The Importance of Size
 Political analysts contend that some of Rhode Island's problems stem from its small size. In a state whose population barely exceeds one million and where everyone lives within an hour's drive of everyone else, political decisions are easily influenced by friendships and family relations.
"There's an enormous problem with such a small state," said Russ Cheit, a professor of political science at Brown University here. "People just don't scrutinize each other the same way. There's an acceptance that things are done this way that isn't there in other states."
Rhode Island's public officials have tried to put the best face on this summer's disclosures, portraying them as the beginning of a healing process that will result in a stronger state government.
But many of them may not remain in office long enough to lead such a process. Polls show the approval rating for many politicians has reached record lows. And several citizens' groups, like Operation Clean Sweep, have been formed with the aim of defeating incumbents in next year's elections.
Jack Kayrouz, the founder of one of these groups, Citizens for Depositors' Rights, urges that new state elections be held immediately. "What we need is a revolution," he said. "Nobody can salvage our situation unless we throw them all out."

(The Providence Journal-Bulletin); "There is a huge sense of betrayal," said Philip West, executive director of Common Cause of Rhode Island. (Bill Powers for The New York Times)
