HEADLINE: Youth Indicted in Fatal Stabbing In Crown Heights Racial Rampage

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

 BODY:
A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday indicted a black youth in the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic Jew in Crown Heights on Aug. 19. At the same time another grand jury wrestled with the explosive issue of whether to charge the Hasidic driver of a car that killed a black boy earlier that night, touching off four nights of racial violence.
At the funeral yesterday morning for the boy, 7-year-old Gavin Cato, demands for the arrest of the Jewish driver, Yosef Lifsh, were a refrain of the crowd. 
 Over and over, among the hundreds of people packed into St. Anthony's Baptist Church, people repeated the words they had been saying for days: that the driver should have been arrested and that if he had been black, he would have been.
"Whose kid? Our kid!" came cries from the crowd as women wept, men muttered angrily and people surged forward to touch the motorcade on its way along Eastern Parkway to Cypress Hills Cemetery. [Page B3.]
From the courthouse where the grand juries were sitting to the church where the funeral was held, the events of the day captured one of the central strains of the Crown Heights crisis: Blacks demanded what they described as equal justice, while Jews expressed outrage that the two deaths -- one a killing motivated by racial hate and the other a traffic accident -- were being equated in any way.
Managing this volatile brew of legal and political issues was the District Attorney of Brooklyn, Charles J. Hynes, who late last week returned from a visit to Israel.
The turmoil in Crown Heights has pitted two communities against each other over issues based on emotional, deeply held perceptions and years of long-festering friction.
To the black community -- a mixture of middle-class people living in well-kept homes sprinkled among the Hasidim and bitter, unemployed young people from nearby housing projects -- the accident touched off resentments that the Hasidim had used political influence to gain special treatment.
To the insular Lubavitcher Hasidic community, where life revolves around the practice of an emotional form of Judaism, the rock-and-bottle-throwing attacks on Jews and their buildings were reminiscent of the anti-Semitic pograms of Eastern Europe and the Nazi Holocaust.
So tense are the feelings that Mr. Hynes took the unusual step of appearing on the popular black radio call-in program "The Breakfast Club" on WLIB for a full hour yesterday morning to respond to what he called the "tremendous amount of misinformation and misperceptions" of the case in the black community.
Answering questions about the handling of the accident, he said on the radio show, "It's significant that within two hours an alcohol test was administered to the driver, and it's finding was zero-zero-zero."
What the grand jury has to examine, he said, is whether other factors -- speed or "a distraction, caused by the driver" -- contributed to criminal negligence.
Asked later whether Jews get preferential treatment in Crown Heights, Mr. Hynes said: "I have more than enough problems on my own trying to bring some sanity out of these two horrible tragedies without figuring out who gets preferential treatment. But you know, ultimately that's going to be something that has to be solved by those two communities."
With calm prevailing in Crown Heights yesterday, the focus largely shifted from the streets to Mr. Hynes's office, which said that the grand jury had reported "affirmative action" against Lemerick Nelson Jr., 16. That meant an indictment had been returned and sent to the State Supreme Court.
Because the indictment is still sealed, the charges were not announced. But the youth had initially been arraigned on an accusation of second-degree murder, and Brooklyn authorities said the indictment would track the initial charges.
The police say Mr. Nelson fatally stabbed Yankel Rosenbaum, a visiting Hasidic scholar from Australia, as groups of black youths went on a rampage after a car in the entourage of the Lubavitcher Rebbe, Menachem M. Schneerson, struck two black children, killing one, on Aug. 19.
The District Attorney's spokesman, Patrick Clark, said the grand jury began considering the accident case on Thursday and had further sessions Friday and yesterday.
 
Touchy Political Issues
 The lawyer for the Cato family, Colin Moore, expressed doubts yesterday about the grand jury investigation, saying, "They are setting this up for a non-indictment; the black community is not dumb."
The highly charged political nature of the situation was hardly helped by the fact that several Lubavitcher officials are prominent on a Jewish citizens committee organized by Mr. Hynes to consult with the District Attorney. It is one of nine such ethnic or special-interest advisory councils.
Mr. Hynes has asked two of the Crown Heights Lubavitcher members to step aside temporarily because of a possible conflict of interest. One is Rabbi Joseph Spielman, whose two sons were riding in the car involved in the accident; the other is Edgar Gluck, a board member and spokesman for the private Hasidic ambulance service accused by blacks of not taking care of the injured black children.
Mayor Dinkins, returning wearily to City Hall from the funeral of Gavin Cato, conceded that if the driver was not indicted, "it will certainly not be well received by the African-American community in that neighborhood."
But he quickly added: "Whatever the grievances, the manner in which we redress these grievances is not through violence. This is not the answer."
The lawyer retained by the Hasidic community, Barry Slotnik, meanwhile, said that he had met with United States Attorney Andrew J. Maloney to demand a Federal investigation of what he called civil rights violations against the Jewish community.
"It's time we put a stop to this," Mr. Slotnik said, adding that the unrest was "the invention of some very ugly characters."
Asked whom he was speaking about, Mr. Slotnik replied: "I think its self-evident who the racist hustlers are. Its the same people who raise their head every time there's an incident where they can become provocative."
As the day progressed, there were two incidents that seemed likely to upset the Hasidic community further.
One of the most senior Lubavitcher leaders, Rabbi Shea Hecht, was driving through Bedford-Stuyvesant with several other rabbis when he heard a discussion on Bob Grant's WABC talk show about Crown Heights on his car radio.
He pulled over to call in, but as he and several other rabbis clustered around a pay phone, they were robbed by a half dozen black youths while Rabbi Hecht was on the air.
In the second incident, Brokha Estrin, a Holocaust survivor from Russia in her 60's, jumped to her death from her third-floor apartment at 1650 President Street in the racially troubled area.
Though her son, Alexander, said, "I have no idea why she did this," Lubavitcher leaders immediately said it was a suicide brought on by the violence. They said she feared that blacks were coming to get her.
"It was a direct result of fear placed on her by strangers outside of the community using Nazi tactics," said said Rabbi Shmuel Butman, a Lubavitcher leader.

HEADLINE: Buffett Sets Salomon Rules; Stock Up on Tisch's Buying

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Warren E. Buffett, the interim chairman of Salomon Brothers, laid out a set of guidelines yesterday for behavior at the troubled firm. His message: Losses will be tolerated; anything that damages the reputation of the firm will not.
At the same time, Salomon's stock rallied more than $2 on reports that Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of the Loews Corporation and CBS Inc., had bought a big block of the firm's stock last week. Traders involved in the purchase confirmed the reports yesterday. But it could not be determined how many shares Mr. Tisch bought. 
 "If you lose money for the firm by bad decisions, I will be very understanding," Mr. Buffett said at a regular Monday meeting of employees. "If you lose reputation for the firm I will be ruthless."
Mr. Buffett addressed the staff in the 39th-floor auditorium, where eight days before he had announced the firm's acceptance of the resignations of its top officers. The resignations followed Salomon's acknowledgement that employees had violated bidding rules in the Treasury securities markets and that top officals had known of one violation for months before reporting it to the Government.
According to excerpts provided by the investment bank, Mr. Buffett also said: "Everyone must be his own compliance officer. That means everything you do can be put on the front page of the newspaper, and there will be nothing that cannot stand up to scrutiny."
But the firm continued to be troubled by the reaction to its violations, including the loss of important customers, numerous lawsuits and the effects of continuing criminal investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department.
Salomon could not put a specific figure yesterday on the total loss of customers. But a spokesman said the firm had lost 5 percent of its public fund business, which is just part of the firm's overall business. The public funds area includes public institutional clients like the World Bank and the California Public Employees Retirement System.
Duff & Phelps, the credit agency, put Salomon's debt on its rating watch with an unfavorable bias, which means the rating could be lowered. Other leading ratings agencies had already taken similar steps.
The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, called on the Federal Reserve to suspend Salomon as a primary dealer in the Treasury securities market. But the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which is in the midst of an investigation of Salomon, has already said it would not make a decision on the firm's status until the inquiry was complete.
The rally in Salomon's stock pushed the shares up $2.25 each, to $26, and it was the second-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with 3.3 million shares traded. Some analysts said the buying by Mr. Tisch might have given other buyers renewed confidence in the outlook for Salomon.
The stock, which fell 38 percent after the initial revelations, has gained 15 percent in two trading days. A Salomon spokesman would not confirm the Tisch buying, but he said: "At the price, it wouldn't surprise me. He is a very savvy investor."
 
Volatility Could Continue
 Guy Moszcowski, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, warned, however, that the stock could continue to be volatile, because Federal investigations have not been completed.
A Salomon spokesman said yesterday that the firm's level of customer business last week -- the first week since the resignations and the installation of new leadership -- was down only a few percent compared with the average for the year in the fixed-income areas. He said that compared with the week a year earlier, customer business in the fixed-income segment was up 10 percent.
One customer the firm has not lost is the City of New York. "We have talked with our money managers, and they have assured us that the city has not suffered any losses because of Salomon Brothers," said Charles Moses, a spokesman for Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.

HEADLINE: Officials Drop Plan to Cut Medicare by $6.9 Billion

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Federal health officials said today that they would revise a proposed schedule of Medicare fees to restore $6.9 billion that was to have been cut from payments to doctors.
The changes come in response to political pressure from Congress and a torrent of complaints about the cuts from doctors around the country. The cuts were proposed three months ago by the Bush Administration as part the the fee schedule, which represents a major overhaul of Medicare's reimbursement policy. 
 With the latest changes, Medicare would spend $191 billion for doctors' services over the next five years, rather than $184 billion under the original proposal. Medicare finances health care for 34 million elderly and disabled people.
Health-care economists had said elderly people would have had more trouble getting medical care under the original fee proposal because it would have made doctors less willing to take Medicare patients. Doctors had charged that the Administration was breaking faith with the nation's physicians by using the fee schedule to save money for the Government.
 
Intent Was Fairness
 The fee schedule was mandated by Congress, but not with the aim of cutting Medicare spending. Rather, it was intended to spread money more fairly, to reflect the work, time and effort that go into each service provided by doctors. The fee schedule, set to take effect in January 1992, is supposed to increase Medicare payments for family physicians and general practitioners, while reducing payments for some specialists, including surgeons.
The apparent success of the doctors' lobbying effort, led by the American Medical Association, illustrates why it is politically difficult to impose comprehensive controls on health-care costs. "It shows what kind of resistance there is in this country to the Government really controlling costs," said Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of Public Citizen's Health Research Group, a consumer organization.
Gail R. Wilensky, head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare, has described the cuts as an "unintended consequence" of the 1989 law that established the Medicare fee schedule.
A senior official who supervises Medicare, and who refused to be identified, said today, "We found a small bit of flexibility that allows us to get around the problem," by using a new interpretation of the law.
The cuts were disclosed Sunday by The Washington Post.
In a recent letter to Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Senate leaders from both parties said they "clearly anticipated that the fee schedule would neither increase nor decrease Medicare spending for physicians' services."
The medical association and other medical groups reacted warily today, saying they had not analyzed details of the Administration's new proposal.
James H. Stacey, a spokesman for the medical association, said his group was studying a detailed written proposal prepared by the Department of Health and Human Services. "We are not prepared to comment on the details until it is thoroughly reviewed," he said.
Dr. Robert Graham, executive vice president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, said, "It is an extremely positive sign that the Government appears to be taking account of our criticism."
 
Assumption of More Services
 The nationwide fee schedule has been described as one of the most sweeping and significant changes in Medicare since the program was created in 1965. Medicare currently pays doctors according to the lowest of their actual or customary charge for a service or the prevailing charge in the area.
Medicare officials said the new fee schedule retained a feature of the original proposal detested by doctors: It assumes that they will increase the volume of their services to recover some of the income they would lose as a result of reductions in fees.
Under the 1989 law, the fee schedule is to be put into effect over five years. In its original proposal, the Administration said the cuts in Medicare payments for "overvalued services" had to be three times as deep as expected because the fee schedule governs only one-third of the physician payments to be made in 1992.
 
Insurers May Follow
 Doctors and members of Congress rejected that interpretation of the law. Administration officials said they had now concluded that the cuts could be spread across a larger number of physician services over a longer period, so it would not be necessary to make such deep cuts next year.
Many private insurers have said they might adopt a version of the Medicare fee schedule to pay doctors. The core of the fee schedule is a computation system under which the Government assigns numerical values to various services performed by doctors. These values, ranging from 1 for a typical office visit to 119 for a liver transplant, take account of the complexity of the work, the amount of time required for the service, malpractice insurance costs and the doctor's office expenses.
To arrive at the price for a given service by a doctor, the Government will multiply its numerical value by a monetary conversion factor. The Administration said in May that the conversion factor would be $26.87. Presumably, that number will be higher under the new proposal, but Administration officials declined to say what it would be.

HEADLINE: Insurers Set Storm's Damage at $780 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The hurricane that struck the East Coast last week caused $780 million in damage to insured property, making it the second-most-expensive hurricane in American history, according to insurance industry figures released today.
An industry official said that even though the storm did not cause widespread destruction of buildings the cost of the damage was high because the hurricane struck a densely populated area and because inflation had raised repair and replacement costs.
The hurricane hit New England last Monday, damaging buildings, boats and farmland, and knocking out electrical power to more than 2 million customers. 
 According to estimates by the American Insurance Services Group, a trade group, the largest loss occurred in Massachusetts, with $525 million in insured damage. That was followed by Rhode Island, with $115 million in damage; New York, $75 million; Connecticut, $40 million; Maine, $21 million, and North Carolina, $4 million.
Massachusetts, Maine and Rhode Island have applied to the Federal Government for disaster relief. Although the hurricane also affected parts of New Hampshire, that state was not included in the total because the damage was not considered catastrophic.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

116 Pages of Calvin Klein
In a sign that the recession may be lifting on Seventh Avenue, Calvin Klein has taken 116 pages of advertising space in a single issue of Vanity Fair magazine.
The whopping advertising package, to appear in a separately bound supplement in October, is the largest industry executives could remember. In the 1970's Revlon bought 100 pages of advertising in Harper's Bazaar, to celebrate that magazine's 100th anniversary. 
 "It's certainly a record for me," said Mr. Klein, who was one of the first fashion designers to place multiple-page ads in magazines. "I felt I really had something to say, and the only way I could say it was in book form." Ronald Galotti, the publisher of Vanity Fair, must be on cloud nine.
The Klein supplement will be printed by Conde Nast Magazines, which owns Vanity Fair, using the same cover stock and paper that are used for Vanity Fair. All the ads will be for Calvin Klein Jeans, which in recent years have received far less promotion than Mr. Klein's fragrances.
Nothing much will come between Tina Brown and her Calvins: the advertising package will be poly-bagged -- encased in a plastic wrapper -- along with Vanity Fair. All the photographs were shot by Bruce Weber. The model is Carre Otis.
The cover will say Calvin Klein Jeans. Otherwise, no text accompanies the photographs.
"The photographs say it all," Mr. Klein said. "The theme is a fantasy rock concert, shot in San Francisco, and it revolves around sex, motorcyles and rock 'n' roll. Carre lives on motorcyles and hangs around with bikers. She lives the life style I was trying to portray. It's about the audience, it's about kids screaming for their modern heroes. It's on stage and back stage. It's like a movie."
Mr. Klein would not disclose how much he paid for the 116 pages, but he said he did not receive any substantial discount over Vanity Fair's regular rates. Industry sources have put the cost of the pages at more than $1 million.
"They're very suggestive and provocative," Mr. Klein said. "If I say that, trust me."
 
Hard Sell in Paris
 Defying decades of conventional wisdom, a group of American men's-wear manufacturers will be trying to sell traditional American tailoring in Paris at the world's largest trade show for men's wear.
It is safe to say that while Italian, German and British tailored clothing has flooded this country over the years, American manufacturers have had little success in exporting their products. It's a little like trying to sell oil back to Texans.
Among those who will be attending the Sept. 7-10 show, known as SEHM (for Salon International de l'Habillemente Masculine), will be executives from the Greif Companies, which manufacture the Perry Ellis line; Pincus Brothers-Maxwell, which makes Bill Blass; Botany 500; Racquet Club, and Adolfo. The five manufacturers will share the costs of exhibiting at the show in hopes of cracking the European market.
"We feel that as a group we have lot more strength on the world market," said Nathan Pincus, a vice president of merchandising at Pincus Brothers Maxwell. He added that the group had planned to attend the January show but was prevented from doing so by the Persian Gulf crisis.
"This is the first true test," Mr. Pincus said. "With things tough in the States, we're all looking for new market share. It's the global approach to fashion. The way retail is, we've been banging our heads."
Michael Sandler, the vice president of merchandising for the Greif Companies, said he thought that although Europeans have traditionally looked down upon American-made products, young people overseas were great fans of American style.
"For the first time we're starting to see some interest in tailored clothing with a Made in U.S.A. label," Mr. Sandler said. "It could be the political situation, an outgrowth of our success in the Persian Gulf war. We've been competitive, pricewise, for some time, with the falls in the dollar.
"We have a trend of our own: American traditional clothing, which is becoming part of the European mood. Armani showed a natural shoulder, the slouch suit, a move toward American traditional."
"We're trying to start a new world business," Mr. Sandler continued "We're looking to do what the Italians did to us. In order to grow in business today, you have to look at new markets."
 
Shows at the Macklowe
 For a while, it looked as if the Macklowe, on West 44th Street, just east of Broadway, were turning into the Emperor's New Hotel. Although the Council of Fashion Designers of America had promoted it as a central location for fashion shows and many designers said they found it attractive, no one was committing to it.
But last week, Michael Kors announced that he would show his spring collection in the Macklowe. Mr. Kors, whose showroom ceiling caved in last season, narrowly missing models and splattering several editors, was the logical one to take the plunge first. Expect other designers to follow.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carre Otis, model for Calvin Klein Jeans. "The photographs say it all," Mr. Klein says. (Bruce Weber)

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 607 words

HEADLINE: Un-Soviet Unions?

 BODY:
Americans, devoted to political self-determination, can only cheer the disintegration of the Soviet Union, a whole maintained by force and terror over the parts. Yet they must also feel alarmed by the destructive forces unleashed by disintegration. Disunion: which is it, good or bad?
It's merely an abstract question; there's no point bemoaning a trend that is unstoppable anyway. But disunion need not mean chaos. Once the proud, impatient republics assert themselves, the parts still have compelling reasons for recombining in one or more new wholes. These new, un-Soviet unions could serve the republics' interests rather than that of a totalitarian empire. 
 That's a process the United States and the outside world can promote, by encouraging economic links between the former Soviet republics and discouraging any slide toward Yugoslavia-style fratricide.
Last week's foiled hard-line coup, aimed at blocking a union treaty, ended up accelerating the independence trend. Seven of the fifteen Soviet republics have now declared their independence. The remaining eight favor a new union treaty that even more radically shifts power away from the Kremlin.
The rush toward autonomy is wholly understandable out of reasonable fears; the freer the republics are, the less vulnerable they become to some new hard-line assault.
It is also understandable for historical reasons. The Baltic States are only the most recent "captive nations." Byelorussia and the western Ukraine were initially annexed after the partition of Poland in 1793, partly disgorged after World War I and only absorbed into the Soviet Union after World War II. Central Asia, Moldavia and the Caucasus were first annexed by 19th-century czars.
Different republics have different ideas about what disunion means. The Baltic republics demand full independence. The Muslim republics of Central Asia want autonomy and equality, but within an overall union. Many in the republics of Soviet Europe now yearn to face west instead of east. Yet the Baltic States have established friendly ties with Boris Yeltsin's Russia, and the eastern Ukraine and Byelorussia have strong links to Russia as well.
Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia got a foretaste of the hard-liners' methods when Soviet forces attacked civilians in Yerevan, Baku and Tbilisi. Independence pressure has been building since. But none of these republics can relish a future as a Christian or Muslim mini-state in a hostile region.
There are also political and military reasons for continuing association between most of the present republics. These include the difficulty of apportioning union-wide possessions, control of strategic weapons and the future of the country's permanent U.N. Security Council seat. And in all republics uneasy minorities worry about their fate under new, nationalist regimes.
Perhaps the most compelling reason for re-union is economic. No one now knows how taxes and spending will be shared; it will be hard enough to control one currency, let alone 15. At least for an interim period, some confederal or community framework seems the only alternative to economic collapse -- and the most practical vehicle for Western assistance.
Western Europe has a clear interest in the stability and prosperity of the East. Nightmare scenarios include famine, tidal waves of refugees and civil war. The U.S. closely shares Western Europe's interest in a healthy transition.
For Washington, that suggests neither encouraging nor discouraging the present disunion -- but standing ready to contribute to post-Soviet reconstruction and, plausibly, un-Soviet reunion.

HEADLINE: SHOULD WE AID THE SOVIET UNION?;
Yes, It Helps Us, Too

BYLINE: By Robert Eisner; Robert Eisner is professor of economics at Northwestern University.

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Whatever the merits or demerits of "aid" to the Soviet Union or its various splintering republics, the argument that we cannot afford it is nonsense. Can our Iowa farmers not afford to sell grain? Can Detroit not afford to supply trucks to ease transportation bottlenecks? Can the Baby Bells or A.T.& T. not afford to get telecommunications functioning in what was the Soviet empire so that businesses there and here, as well as ordinary citizens, can communicate with one another?
Is our computer industry so overwhelmed with orders at home that it cannot help usher Russia and the other republics into the computer age? Is our pharmaceutical industry so lacking in capacity that it cannot provide vital medicines? Would our food conglomerates or families suffer if some baby foods fill empty shelves in Leningrad, Minsk or Kiev? 
 Will our banks or Federal Reserve crumble if we join an effort to make the ruble convertible so that Russians can buy our goods and Americans can better invest in what is or has been the Soviet Union? Will the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank suffer if the U.S. drops its opposition to full Soviet participation in those important instruments of international economic cooperation?
Too many seem to think of aid to the Soviet Union -- or to other countries -- in terms of cash taken from their own bank accounts, presumably through taxes, and then given away to foreigners and hence forever lost to the American people. It is viewed as an international welfare system that may merely save or inhibit foreigners from working for themselves. A dollar given to foreigners is then a dollar less to meet our needs at home.
This conception betrays as much a failure to understand how our own economy works as a failure to see the portent of the collapsing Soviet economy. We are obviously not in a position to provide for 290 million people in the Soviet republics. Any program even partly aimed at that would run the risk of causing them to provide less for themselves. But that is not the issue. It is rather to jump-start their productive machinery in a developing market without the human disaster that might make it impossible.
There is, of course, the apt analogy to the Marshall Plan after World War II, when we helped put Western Europe on its feet, to its huge benefit and our own. Now we are speaking of a vast international effort, with Germany already making major contributions, the rest of Western Europe ready to move and a Japan that may well join in a common endeavor. The U.S. would hardly be the dominant force and would be picking up only a small portion of what tab there is.
But that "tab" is not what it seems. It is not properly measured in new taxes, which are unnecessary, or a bigger, mismeasured "budget deficit." It is rather to be counted in savings of billions of dollars in our wasteful farm supports and subsidies, in new jobs for American workers, in new investment for American business.
In an economy with 6 percent still unemployed and few forecasts of vigorous growth, a world effort to develop the vast potential Soviet market would move us forward as that market expanded. Instead of worrying about the Japanese selling too much here, we and they could be selling there.
On those occasions when events have demanded it, Americans have learned to realize the full potential of their economy, and not suffered for it. By the end of World War II, we had more than doubled the production with which we had emerged from the Depression. In a supreme irony, we were thus able to devote half our output to fighting a war and still, for the most part, live better than ever before.
Our industry thrives on demand for its products. A well-focused program to get the economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe moving again will help us as much as if not more than it helps them. And that is without counting the enormous gains from a truly peaceful new world order.
It would indeed prove as good to give as to receive.

HEADLINE: New York Taxpayers Would Be Crazy to Buy $250 Bonds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Little Bonds for the Big City" (editorial, Aug. 10) shows the same arrogance and lack of respect New York City administrations show for money collected through taxes. 
 Taxes collected by governing bodies represent no less an investment in the commonweal than money invested for profit. One could argue that taxes are the citizen's investment in city, state and country, and are the "profit" the government reaps for maintaining, creating and protecting the rights and freedoms of a democracy. When governments fail in this responsibility, people and businesses leave, and tax revenues decline.
The leadership has failed. To replace lost revenues, the city wants to sell bonds. To imply that money invested for profit will "create a new cadre of committed New Yorkers" is bogus. Only a fool would buy a city bond and then pay taxes to pay the interest on his own investment.
One would be hard pressed to find any New Yorker who invests less than $250 in taxes to the city. I am a disgruntled taxpayer precisely because the city government does not and has not treated tax revenues as money to invest wisely.
Recent and current city administrations have failed to create and maintain an environment for business and living. They want more money. I want more smarts and leadership. That tax dollars -- which should be keeping parks, libraries, school programs, bridges, the arts, social programs and city services flourishing -- will be siphoned off to pay interest to bond investors, whose only commitment to the city is a tax-free high interest rate, is unconscionable.
A civic, cultural and clean environment for raising a family and earning a living will make "committed New Yorkers." And that takes leadership, integrity and commitment -- qualities scarcer than money in our fair city's government.
 
DANIEL HARRIS
Brooklyn, Aug. 11, 1991

HEADLINE: Arts Budget Cuts: Invisibility Isn't Painless

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Here are some cultural events you're sure to miss:
*"The Black Rider," the Robert Wilson, Tom Waits and William S. Burroughs vaudeville version of Carl Maria von Weber's opera "Der Frei schutz," which was twice scheduled and twice canceled by the Brooklyn Academy of Music this year. 
 *"Secrets, Dialogues, Revelations: The Art of Betye and Alison Saar," a mother-daughter show of multi-media sculpture organized by the Wight Art Gallery at the University of California at Los Angeles, which was to have been exhibited at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
*A show of Spanish colonial art at the Brooklyn Museum timed to coincide with the Columbus quincentenary celebration in the fall of 1992.
*The Royal Shakespeare Company's production of Euripides' "Electra," planned for the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
In addition, the Brooklyn Museum will be closed this week and one week in February, and it will rotate closing each gallery for a few hours. The Bronx Museum of the Arts has been closed since Aug. 4 and will remain shut until Oct. 22, when it will reopen, but for only two hours a day from Monday to Thursday.
These are samples of the effects of New York City's recession-driven $28.7 billion budget, which was adopted in July after months of pulling and tugging by the affected institutions and their supporters. In the spring, Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed cutting the city's Department of Cultural Affairs budget by 47 percent. The final budget approved by the City Council, however, reduced the allocation for the arts by 28 percent, or $24 million, of the department's original $87.1 million, which does not include mandated expenses.
 
The Invisible Consequences
 Apart from canceled events and reduced hours, arts administrators say, many of the cutbacks are invisible to the public. The Brooklyn Academy of Music laid off 22 people from its staff of 120. The City Center Theater lost 11 from a staff of 35. Wave Hill, the 28-acre public estate in Riverdale, the Bronx, lost 20 of 54 staff positions this year and last.
The New York City Ballet has dispensed with educational, marketing and development programs. "That's terribly damaging," said Marie Nugent-Head, the company's development director. "Those are the programs addressed to our future audiences."
Gregory Long, the president of the New York Botanical Garden and chairman of the Cultural Institutions Group, whose members occupy city-owned buildings, said: "We're experiencing a brain drain. Having to lay off 25 or 30 percent of your staff is bad enough, but when you're also forced to furlough people and can't give raises, curators and people in middle management look for jobs in other cities, and then they're gone. I know of four such cases, and we fear many more."
Mr. Long said he planned to lead a delegation to the Mayor this week to seek the restoration of some of the cut money.
While generally bemoaning the cuts, Harvey Lichtenstein, the president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, also expressed a sense of relief about them. "We lost about $650,000," he said, "but at least now we're clear as to how much the cut is. Last spring, when they were talking about a 47 percent cut, we were terrified."
 
Who's Hurting the Most
 Cultural spokesmen differ over whether institutions in the other boroughs are harder hit than those in Manhattan. Robert Buck, the director of the Brooklyn Museum, maintains that organizations like his are more dependent on the city for their income because they have less access to wealth than their counterparts in Manhattan.
But Anthony Micocci, the executive director of the City Center Theater, said that for the last decade Manhattan-based cultural institutions had been "systematically undersupported both because there are so many of them and because it was thought we had greater access to private money."
There is no disagreement, however, among cultural administrators that the major institutions fared better than smaller ones. For example, even though the Metropolitan Museum of Art lost $3.475 million in the city cut, that is only 4.4 percent of its total budget of $79 million. In contrast, the city contribution to many smaller institutions makes up nearly half of the budget.
"A 28 percent cut meant a loss of $200,000 for us," said Kinshasha Holman Conwill, the director of the Studio Museum in Harlem. "We've had to lay off 13 people out of 45, and not replace 5 who retired. We're also raising the price of admission from $2 to $3, and we're increasing fees for special events. It's ironic that we're in a community that's particularly challenged economically by the recession, and yet we're forced to try to charge this community."
In addition to closing for nearly three months, the Bronx Museum of the Arts has announced that all staff members will be furloughed an additional one to six weeks. "All of our satellite galleries in hospitals and nursing homes will be shut down," said Lisa Payne, the public affairs director of the museum.
 
Prices Are Rising
 The New York City Ballet has raised ticket prices for its most popular attractions, said Ms. Nugent-Head. Orchestra and first ring seats for "The Nutcracker" have increased to $58 from $55; orchestra seats for "The Sleeping Beauty" have gone up to $50 from $42, and first ring to $58 from $50. "We hated to do that," Ms. Nugent-Head said, "because that closes a point of entrance to the ballet to many people."
The Brooklyn Children's Museum has cut school services by 40 percent, said Mindy Duitz, the director of the institution. "That means that 10,000 fewer kids will visit the museum this year," she said.
Cuts and layoffs have been common throughout city agencies since the adoption of the new budget, but cultural administrators say that the impact on their institutions has been proportionally greater. "Reducing the city's work force by 7,000 jobs sounds pretty drastic, except when you recall that that work force grew by 50,000 jobs over the past decade," said one. "The staffs of most cultural organizations shrank during that same period, and so further cuts today are especially difficult."
The lost revenue, cultural spokesmen say, is not being replaced by private sources. "It's pretty tough to ask people to become members of your museum when its closed," said Mr. Long of the New York Botanical Garden.
 
One Survivor
 Kate French, the executive director of Wave Hill, said her institution would lose the third installment of a $50,000 grant made two years ago by a private foundation. "It's a three-year grant contingent on the city's maintaining its level of support," she said.
At least one institution has survived with its programs substantially unaffected. The Queens Museum has not closed any exhibition space or reduced the number of hours it is open to the public, although it laid off four staff members in June and is reducing the frequency of its newsletter.
"We foresaw this back in January 1990," said Steven Klindt, the museum's executive director. "We realized that our $13.5 million rebuilding of the museum would temporarily cut our exhibition space in half, and also that the recession would have an impact, so we made some changes back then. Last February, we laid off an assistant director, and the entire staff began to take off one day a month without pay. That has meant that we haven't been as drastically affected as some of our sister museums."
Mr. Lichtenstein said the layoffs had been heartbreaking and left him with a feeling of sadness. "After 25 years of work," he said, "we're back to where we were 10 or 15 years ago. Still, people are pulling together and somehow we'll get through these next few years. We're doing some things we're proud of."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 28, 1991, Wednesday

HEADLINE: Verbal Scores Hit New Low In Scholastic Aptitude Tests

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The verbal scores of 1991 college-bound high school seniors on the Scholastic Aptitude Test declined to an all-time low and mathematics scores fell for the first time since 1980.
The College Board, which released the S.A.T. results today, cited what it called a "disturbing pattern of educational disparity" between top-performing students who were accepted by selective colleges and the general student population.
Some educators said they worried that the decline in the general S.A.T results might indicate that a fall was continuing in the quality of primary and secondary education that first caused alarm more than a decade ago. Although some educators disagreed, the officials said they viewed the scores as a sign that 10 years after warnings were sounded in the benchmark study, "A Nation at Risk," the country's schools are experiencing continued problems resulting from a general decline in academic quality and study habits at the secondary level.
 
Call for 'Drastic Measures'
 "The declines in the averages for all students this year are a further sign that we must take drastic measures if we are to meet the educational goals set by President Bush and the nation's governors," said Donald T. Stewart, president of the College Board.
Even though college attendance is at a high, Mr. Stewart said, the decline in scores for the college-bound, particularly those for the verbal portion of the test, is "disturbing."
Despite the heightened concern expressed by College Board officials about what the decline might mean, some educators said they saw in the decline, of four points in the combined average scores and two points in the score for each component, an indication that the universe of S.A.T. takers had become more democratic, with a wider variety of students taking the test.
"If one year you have the top 10 percent of performers taking the S.A.T. and you have one score, and the next year you have the top 20 percent and the scores fall only a few points, then you're looking at a great victory because you have a whole lot more kids taking the test and hardly a change in score," said Marc Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, a non-profit policy and analysis organization based in Rochester.
Other educators added that the change in this year's scores are not statistically worrisome.
"That two-point drop is not a drop in my eyes," said Marvin Sontag, associate professor of psychology and education at Columbia Teacher's College. "It's such an infinitessimal amount as to not be worth commenting on."
The S.A.T, a two-and-a-half-hour, multiple-choice test, is taken by high school students, most of whom plan to attend college, and measures verbal and mathematical reasoning ability.
The highest possible combined score on the S.A.T.'s verbal and mathematics components is 1,600 and the combined minimum is 400. The national average score this year was 896, compared with 900 in 1990. On average, students scored 422 on the test's verbal section, down two points from 1990, and they scored 474 on the math section, down from 476 last year.
 
Breakdown in Scores
 Average scores among women dropped one point in the verbal portion and two points in the math section. For men, the average verbal score fell three points and the average math score dropped two points.
This year, 100,209 black students took the SAT -- more than ever. The average score for black students in 1991 was 351 on the verbal section and 385 on the mathematics section. Test scores for blacks were in the same neighborhood as last year's.
The performance of ethnic minority students, whose scores have shown substantial gains since they were first reported in 1976, showed mixed results in 1991. Only Puerto Rican and Asian American students' scores showed increases in both verbal and math sections in 1991.
Among the possible explanations offered by some educators for the decline is a change in the demographic makeup of the group taking the test. The group now includes more minorities, women and non-English speakers.
Others point out that in recessions, young people stay in school longer, meaning a larger pool of students are taking the tests, including those who would not ordinarily be attending college.
Still others, including several College Board officials, attributed the decline to less rigorous academic standards, less time spent reading at home and in school, too much television and too many videos.
Mr. Stewart agreed, saying demographic changes alone could not explain the drop in test scores, because there is an effect also of what people are being taught, he said.
Generally, the students competing for the colleges with the toughest entrance standards take the S.A.T. and special subject-specific Achievement Tests, as compared with many students who take only the S.A.T.
 
Specter of a Division
 He noted that students who took the board's subject-specific achievement tests, required by the nation's most selective colleges, scored an average of nearly 100 points higher on each part of the S.A.T. test than did the others taking the same portions. These students, who represent about 20 percent of all those who take the S.A.T. nationally, have average S.A.T. scores of 515 on the verbal portion and 584 on the mathematics portion. This group has continued to score substantially higher, on average, than the national mean since the agency began calculating the mean in 1976.
"If this kind of dichotomy continues, we could evolve into a nation divided between a small class of educational elite and an underclass of students academically ill-prepared for the demands of college or the workplace," said Mr. Stewart.
He noted that among S.A.T takers, 65 percent had four or more years of math, 55 percent had enrolled in a trigonometry course and 44 percent had taken physics -- with lower percentages for nearly all ethnic minority students.
Mr. Tucker conceded that if the best students take the achievement tests, it is not surprising that they also outscore students who only take the S.A.T. Top-scoring students, particularly those who take the subject-specific Achievement Tests, tend to be the most advantaged, he said.
"Disproportionately, they tend to go to the best high schools and the best high schools are disproportionately where the real estate prices are highest," he said. "That essentially means that the people who are able to go to those school districts have the highest incomes."
Instead, the drop may reflect the greater proportion of high school students taking the test, said Mr. Tucker. This year 1,032,685 students took the test, an increase of 7,162 over 1990.
With more students taking the test, he said, the decline "is not necessarily a downward trend."
He also emphasized that the S.A.T. test does not measure intelligence or the ability to learn.
"If the S.A.T. is measuring intelligence, then we should be extremely alarmed by falling scores because that would mean that American kids are being born less intelligent," he said. "The real issue is whether our kids know what they need to know and are they able to do what they need to do to do college level work. The S.A.T. doesn't tell you that."
Ramsey Selden, director of the state education assessment center for the Chief State School Officers, said another problem with extrapolating overall educational trends from the S.A.T. tests was that they do not test representative samples of students.
For example, while Iowa reported the highest average scores, with a verbal score of 515 and a score of 578 in mathematics, only 5 percent of its graduates took the test. South Carolina reported the lowest averages, with verbal scores of 395 and scores of 437 in mathematics, but 58 percent of its high school seniors took the test.

HEADLINE: Our Towns

BYLINE: By George Judson

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
Thelma Williams stood at a microphone, staring down homeowners who had come to the Housing Authority to oppose a plan to scatter public housing across New Haven. The agency hopes to do this by buying individual houses and condominiums and renting them.
Mrs. Williams, who lives in the authority's Brookside Avenue apartments, was sure of one thing: "A certain stigma has been laid upon public-housing tenants as a whole." 
 Like Newark, New Haven has torn down a blighted housing project. Now it must replace half of the 366 apartments. Like Yonkers, it plans to put new public housing in areas that don't have a lot. Unlike Yonkers, it decided this without the help of a Federal judge.
That doesn't make the city's homeowners any happier. The areas without a lot of public housing are their neighborhoods.
Public housing here is not pretty. This city pursued urban renewal in the 1950's and social welfare in the 60's as aggressively as any, but now even the cinderblock and concrete look worn. There is vandalism and graffiti and drug dealing. Many apartments are simply boarded up.
So now the Housing Authority wants to buy houses and rent them. The homeowners, who learned the addresses of 10 targeted houses the day before the hearing at which Mrs. Williams faced them, distrust the authority. It can't maintain its own projects, so who will care for these houses? Certainly not the tenants, the homeowners say.
"Renters, regardless of income, view their living quarters as a stopping-off place along the way," two Alderwomen, Elaine Braffman and Elizabeth McCormack, said in a statement.
Some speakers were blunter. "I don't feel these people in the housing projects have proved themselves," said Lisa Lancia, a young homeowner in the Fair Haven section, where many of the purchases are planned.
There is a scent of race to all this, an odor of class, a sharp edge of fear. People who own their own homes in Fair Haven or Edgewood generally don't visit apartments in Brookside or any other project. They don't see inside, where working families make their homes; they see the outside, what those families endure. They don't want that for their families.
What angered Mrs. Williams, who is president of the authority's tenants association and helps screen residents at Brookside, was the assumption that public-housing tenants don't share these concerns. She readily admits to prejudice in choosing her neighbors. "I'm prejudiced against anybody who makes my life living hell," she said.
The authority has voted to buy 28 homes and has selected sites for 28 more, leaving 127 to go. Its executive director, David L. Echols, assured residents that a management company (to be named) would care for the properties and that tenants would be "tightly screened" (in a process to be determined).
The issue of trust, however, is already dead for Jill and Daniel Lenhart.
In 1989 the Lenharts paid $124,000 for a town house in Fair Haven, a few minutes from downtown. They were committed to the city and its social services. He is personnel manager at the Hill Health Center, which serves the poor Hill neighborhood; she works on the children's psychiatric ward at the Hospital of St. Raphael.
By 1990 only two other homes in Chamberlain Court, their 44-unit complex, had been sold. The builder applied to a state affordable-housing program, set up to buy 500 condominiums at bargain prices. The program largely failed; only four deals were completed, only 73 homes bought. But 34 were at Chamberlain Court, sold to a nonprofit housing group for an average price of $91,000.
This summer the builder sold the last seven units to the Housing Authority for its scattered-site program.
The Lenharts understand the need for affordable housing; they chose New Haven, in part, because they qualified for a state-subsidized mortgage here. But they also know their home is now worth far less than that mortgage. They want out, and they don't see why they should have to walk away.
"I understand affordable housing has to go somewhere, but that doesn't mean you have to put me into bankruptcy," Daniel Lenhart said.
The state's affordable-housing plan didn't foresee people like the Lenharts. It counted on creating a mix of incomes by buying small numbers of condominiums in complexes that were largely sold out. But owner associations in healthy complexes blocked the sales, while Chamberlain Court, without an association, unloaded as many units as possible.
When Chamberlain Court forms its association, there will be only five owners: the nonprofit group's co-operative, with 34 votes, the Housing Authority, with seven votes, and the Lenharts and their two neighbors, with one vote each.
"I want people to live here," Jill Lenhart said.
"But we want them to do it the right way," her husband added.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
America West Airlines Names Chief Executive

BYLINE: The Associated Press

 BODY:
America West Airlines Inc. said yesterday that Michael J. Conway, the company's president, would replace Edward R. Beauvais as chief executive. Mr. Beauvais, the airline's top executive since it was founded in 1981, will remain chairman of the financially troubled carrier.
Mr. Beauvais said he recommended the change because the airline needed Mr. Conway's financial expertise as it worked its way through a bankruptcy reorganization. 
 America West's move represented the second time in a week that an airline in bankruptcy court promoted a financial expert to the highest levels of management. The head of Continental Airlines stepped down last Thursday to be replaced by the carrier's executive vice president for finance and marketing.
Mr. Conway, who is 46, has been the company's chief operating officer since its inception. He became president in 1984.
Mr. Beauvais, who is 54, said it was appropriate to promote a financial expert now that the company has arranged for $55 million in loans from Northwest Airlines and an aircraft-leasing company. Those loans are subject to the bankruptcy court's approval.
America West, which has its headquarters in Tempe, Ariz., and hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas, Nev., has implemented a $100 million cost-cutting program that includes trimming its route system, returning some planes to leasing companies and imposing an across-the-board pay cut of 10 percent. The airline has also laid off or placed on unpaid leave hundreds of employees.
America West said the appointment would be effective Sept. 15. Dik Shimizu, a spokesman, said the company's board took the action during an unscheduled meeting over the weekend.
America West filed for protection from its creditors in United States Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix on June 27. The company lost $80.8 million in the first half of 1991.
America West attributes its financial troubles to high fuel prices and lower demand brought on by the Gulf War and the recession.
Efforts will continue to reduce costs, with every aspect of the company under scrutiny, Mr. Conway said in a statement released by the company.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Turning Waste Plastics Into Fuels

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich.

 BODY:
As complex plastics increasingly replace metals in cars and appliances, recycling these products becomes a larger problem. Attention is now turning to a high-temperature process called pyrolysis that breaks down plastics into burnable oil and gas.
Auto makers and plastic suppliers hope to demonstrate within a few years that this technique has great commercial potential. Environmental advocates question whether pyrolysis is truly recycling, but backers of the technique say it is far better than throwing the plastic away. 
Pyrolysis breaks materials down by heating them at high temperatures in the absence of air. Because no oxygen is present, plastics and rubber left over from cars do not burn, as they would in an incinerator. Instead, the heat, about 1,300 degrees Fahrenheit, breaks the complex hydrocarbons down into simpler molecules, producing a liquid resembling heating oil and a combustible gas, along with some ash.
 
Potential for Pollution
 Because nothing except the fuel for the pyrolysis reactor is burned, the technique may cause less air pollution than incinerators. But if the gas produced by pyrolysis is used to heat the reactor once it reaches operating temperature, as most plans envision, pollution will result from plastic and rubber that contain chlorine or sulfur, said Raymond Machacek, of A. D. Little, a consulting firm.
Vinyl plastics contain chlorine, and sulfur is used in the vulcanization of rubber. The chlorine and sulfur atoms tend to form hydrochloric and sulfuric acids, which are toxic pollutants, Mr. Machacek said.
The growing amount of plastic in automobiles causes grumbling among metal recyclers, because it results in more worthless material that must be disposed of in landfills, at additional cost. Unlike plastic soda bottles, which can easily be reprocessed, most of the plastics left after cars are shredded and the metals extracted are composites of materials that have been further contaminated by paint and adhesives.
"Very often you will have incompatible plastics glued together," said Richard L. Klimisch, an environmental specialist at the General Motors Corporation's Technical Center here. In addition, many of the plastics are a type known as thermosets, which cannot be melted down and used again, like the material in soda bottles.
A car on exhibit at the technical center, cut away to display new sound-deadening insulation materials, also inadvertently illustrates how difficult these new materials might be to recycle. Several of the insulating materials are simply labeled, "Complex blend of various stuff."
Researchers at the G.M. Technical Center are running perhaps the largest pyrolysis trials, but an association that includes several major plastic and rubber makers, including Goodyear Tire and Rubber, Dow Chemical, Eagle-Picher, Allied-Signal and Owens-Corning Fiberglas, is also experimenting with the technique.
Industry trends make it clear that metal recyclers are going to have to find ways to cope with more plastic. "Cost is driving the industry to greater use of plastic," said Irvin E. Poston, a plastics specialist at G.M.
He notes that plastic body parts are lighter than steel, requiring less costly tooling to shape and improving fuel economy. The entire outer body of G.M.'s new line of mini-vans, like the Chevrolet Lumina APV, is made of composite plastic. Pyrolysis recovers the energy content of plastic after its useful life is finished, he said.
Plastics suppliers say they may be able to use the ash produced in pyrolysis as well, particularly if the feedstock is uncontaminated scrap from the production process. Since some of the composites used in auto body panels consist of 50 percent inert filler, clean ash might be substituted for the limestone used now. But it is less likely that ash from shredder residue contaminated with other substances could be used.
Industry officials have been quick to label pyrolysis a form of recycling, but some environmentalists say it is similar to incineration, because the material is destroyed and some energy is used. "We do not consider incineration as recycling on this side of the environmental fence, and a lot of people put pyrolysis in the same category," said Lisa Collaton, a solid-waste specialist at the Environmental Action Foundation in Washington.
Added John Ruston of the Environmental Defense Fund in New York, "Pyrolysis is not recycling; it is pyrolysis."
Mr. Poston said G.M. and some plastic suppliers had run pyrolysis tests on shredder residue at two operations for processing old tires. He said that once the material reached operating temperature, it gave off enough gas to be self-sustaining without external fuel. The recovered oil is available for sale.
He said the company and its suppliers planned larger-scale tests to see if the approach was technically and economically feasible in commercial quantities. "We have done 5,000 pounds; now we are going to do a run of 50,000 pounds so we can see the true economics," Mr. Poston said.
 
More Plastic in Cars
 A group of plastic parts suppliers predicts that the amount of thermoset materials going into cars will almost double by 1995, to 423 million pounds, from 242 million pounds in 1990. That is in addition to thermoplastic materials, which can be melted and used again.
Officials involved in recycling say pyrolysis may have a place in materials disposal, after more valuable plastic parts of old cars and appliances have been pulled out for recycling. "Pyrolysis can be part of the waste-management approach, but we should not give up on recovering various plastic streams for re-use," said Michael Fisher, a technical director at the Council for Solid Waste Solutions, a plastics industry group.
Noting that it took metal recyclers several decades to refine techniques for separating different metals and alloys, he said that the plastics industry was just beginning the process. "There are 20 different types of plastic on an automobile," he said. "Some will be recycled, and some will go for pyrolysis."
Herschel Cutler, executive director of the Institute for Scrap Recycling Industries, said the institute was interested in pyrolysis, despite economic, technical and pollution problems with some other experiments. "There have been some plants in the past that were dismal failures," he said.
Nevertheless, he said, with the amount of plastic in cars rising, "we are still looking at it." He added, "We may see a new generation of pyrolytic activity that really can convert materials to oil, gas and carbon black."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kedar Agarwal, an engineer at G.M.'s Technical Center, demonstrates the presence of flammable gas resulting from the pyrolysis of plastics. The plastics are being heated electrically, in the absence of oxygen, in the cylindrical furnace at right. The hydrocarbons produced in the process are piped out of the furnace into a condenser, at left, where a liquid fuel gathers in a flask and the remaining gases are flared at the top. HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why Black Men Have Lost Ground

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT is no great puzzle why young male workers have had to run so hard over the last 15 years simply to stay in place. They are the first generation to compete with women workers on a nearly equal basis. More important, they are the first postwar generation to enter the labor market when labor productivity was barely growing.
The mystery is why, in spite of the triumphs of the civil rights movement, young black men have lost ground to their white counterparts during the period. 
 Economists like simple explanations -- especially ones that point toward simple policy fixes. But in this case, argue John Bound of the University of Michigan and Richard Freeman of Harvard, simplicity is the enemy of truth.
No single cause stands out in their analysis of stagnating employment opportunities for black men, published last month in a National Bureau of Economic Research working paper. Anything that could go wrong, it seems, has gone wrong, damaging the job prospects of black college graduates as well as high school dropouts.
There is no disputing that the drive for racial equality in the workplace ran out of steam in the mid-1970's. Adjusted for education levels, the gap in weekly earnings for black men and white men with less than 10 years of work experience fell from 35 percent in 1963 to just 11 percent in 1975. But since then, it has crept back up to 18 percent.
Young black men face parallel problems in getting jobs. In 1973 the black-white gap in employment rates was 9 percentage points; by 1989 it had widened to 15.
What happened? Many small things rather than one big thing.
The researchers divided black men by region (Northeast, Midwest, South) and by education (college graduates, high school graduates, dropouts). All of these sub-groups lost ground on wages and (with one modest exception) on employment rates as well. But the differences in the rate of loss are striking.
College graduates did especially badly on wages. The white-black differences for college graduates widened three times faster than the gap for high school graduates and six times faster than the gap for dropouts. Midwestern blacks were also particularly big losers, losing far more ground than their Southern counterparts.
The pattern is somewhat different on rates of employment. Dropouts' prospects deteriorated far more rapidly than the prospects for all young male blacks. And in contrast to Southerners and Midwesterners, young male blacks in the Northeast actually gained a little on whites.
Using statistical regression techniques to dig deeper, the economists found that blacks had the misfortune of being in the wrong places and the wrong occupations at the wrong time. For example, relatively more depend on minimum-wage jobs for a living. The erosion of the minimum wage as a fraction of average wages is all that is needed to explain 17 percent of the ground lost by young male blacks. Similarly, a disproportionate number were union members. Thus as union wages fell relative to wages in general, blacks lost more than whites -- a phenomenon that explains 5 percent of the change in the earnings gap.
Then there are the twin problems of occupation and industry. More blacks wore blue collars and more worked in manufacturing. Both groups suffered heavily in the early 1980's, when foreign competition savaged the Rust Belt. This one-two punch accounts for 29 percent of the relative decline in the wages of young blacks.
Slippage in employment rates is largely a problem at the unskilled end of the job spectrum. And here, Mr. Bound and Mr. Freeman look to crime and punishment for the explanation: Between 1980 and 1989 the proportion of black high school dropouts in jail or on probation has grown by one-fifth. This explains fully 71 percent of the downward trend in black dropouts at work.
These results should depress people who look to government to promote equality of result as well as equality of opportunity. The great forces of history that have exposed the American economy to global competition and have led to a restructuring of industry probably cannot be stopped. Even if they could, few policy makers would be inclined to reverse course solely to keep black workers out of harm's way.
By the same token, Americans already have very good reasons to end the plague of urban street crime. The fact that crime leaves so many young black men effectively unemployable is not, in itself, likely to move public policy.
About the best that can be said here is that the worst is probably over. The regional economic shifts that worked to the disadvantage of blacks have apparently ended. So, too, have the shifts in labor demand that made blue-collar workers such a drug on the market during the 1980's. With a little luck, future trends will prove colorblind -- or even work to the advantage of racial minorities.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Looking at Sears As a Good Buy

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

 BODY:
WHEN a new Sears store opened recently in Nashville, Edward A. Brennan, the company's chairman, rolled up his sleeves and sold a refrigerator.
Mr. Brennan's sales efforts have met with success in a larger arena as well. A small but growing group of investors are finally buying Mr. Brennan's claim that he can restore Sears's lumbering $32 billion merchandise group to a respectable degree of profitability. 
 The stock of Sears, Roebuck & Company has nearly doubled from its 52-week low of $22 in October, closing yesterday at $41.625. It was off 37.5 cents for the day on a report that consumer confidence fell in August.
Despite the growing uncertainty over the direction of the economy, retail stocks have done well this year, buoyed by the prospect of a pickup in consumer spending. As of last week, stocks in Standard & Poor's retail group were up 49.6 percent since Jan. 1, compared with a 65.5 percent increase for Sears in the period. The S.& P. 500 was up 19.3 percent since the beginning of the year.
Because of its strength in selling durable goods like washing machines, Sears, which accounts for more than 35 percent of all washers and dryers sold in the country, is expected to benefit strongly from any increase in consumer spending. But if the economy does not rebound, Sears and other retailers will be hurt.
There has been a persistent notion that Sears is worth more in pieces than whole and that that has driven the stock up, but Mr. Brennan rejects that, saying flatly, "We do not intend to break up the company."
Some analysts say the stock has further to rise. "Sears should have a very strong earnings rebound over the next few years," said Daniel Barry of Kidder, Peabody, who has been recommending the stock since the spring. Mr. Barry says he expects Sears stock to hit $58 next year.
No one is prepared to declare that Sears's retailing problems have been fixed. The company is still burdened by high costs and less-than-appealing offerings in important lines like women's apparel. The company continues to face stiff competition in its most important areas from stores that concentrate on one type of product, like The Gap in clothing and Circuit City in electronics and appliances.
But the impact of Sears's cost-cutting program is beginning to show up in the company's financial results. At the end of July, the retail division showed the first inkling of improving profits in several years. Despite a drop in sales during the quarter because of the recession, income increased because of reduced expenses. By laying off tens of thousands of employees, the company expects to eliminate $600 million in expenses this year.
While the improved results were greeted enthusiastically by investors, retailing is chiefly a market-share game; cutting overhead does not build a business. "I would still like to see some sustainable sales growth," said Richard Nelson, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago.
To that end, Sears needs to stock the right merchandise and design the type of stores that will attract new customers. "Sears is still trying to find a niche in the marketplace," said Mr. Nelson.
Still, it is not clear whether the women of America will ever be comfortable buying their clothes around the corner from a display of lawn mowers and drill bits.
Mr. Brennan maintains that Sears's merchandise assortment and the look of its stores is improving. In the last few months, Sears, which has 864 full-line department stores, has opened about half a dozen stores around the country with a new clean, crisp design not customarily associated with Sears. Mr. Brennan calls them "the first example of stores that we are happy with."
Wall Street has prodded Sears to spend more on upgrading the look of its stores. Analysts say that Sears plans to spend $450 million on store-related capital expenditures in 1991, compared with $2.4 billion by Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and $1.2 billion by the K Mart Corporation.
While Sears has become more focused on retailing in recent years, there are still questions about some of its strategic moves. With the furniture business in the doldrums, Sears is expanding its free-standing furniture stores, called Homelife. An earlier venture into speciality retailing, the McKids children's clothing stores, failed and was discontinued earlier this year.
Mr. Brennan took direct control of the merchandise group last year, an unusual move for the chairman of a $56 billion corporation and one that has raised questions over whether Mr. Brennan's time is best used selling refrigerators.
"They need some more help at the top level," Mr. Barry said. "No one can be stretched that thin and be effective."
Retailing, of course, is only part of Sears's operations. The company has the Allstate Insurance Companies, the Dean Witter Financial Services Group and the Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group.
Mr. Barry argues that if Sears can just stabilize the retail group, its financial-services operations make the company a decent long-term investment. "If they can just stop the hemorrhaging in retailing," he said, "you really have a decent moderate-growth company."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Gold Closes Lower in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly higher in foreign exchange trading yesterday in an uneventful session.
Gold prices rose overseas but slipped in domestic trading. At the New York Commodity Exchange, gold closed at $354.40 an ounce, down 80 cents from late Monday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $354.35 an ounce, off 90 cents. 
 The dollar opened higher in New York from Monday's close here. But it fell slightly after the Conference Board reported that its consumer confidence index declined in August from the month before.
The survey by the business-supported research group showed that consumer expectations for future economic improvement dimmed this month, offsetting a slight rise in optimism about current conditions.
The dollar later recovered, however, and Paul Yarden, a currency trader at Credit Suisse in New York, said there were few other matters to influence trading.
"People are not overly scared with the situation in the Soviet Union," he said. He said the Soviet power shift has already been factored in to exchange rates, barring significant developments.
Trading was light, with many traders apparently taking the week off because of holidays in Britain and Hong Kong on Monday and the Labor Day holiday next Monday in the United States, Mr. Yarden said.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 137.05 Japanese yen from 137.02 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 137.00 yen, and in New York it closed at 137.00 yen, up from 136.90 yen late Monday.
The British pound rose to $1.6795 in London from $1.6775 late Monday. In New York, one pound cost $1.6800, unchanged.
The dollar closed at 1.7490 German marks in European trading, down from 1.7535 late Monday. In New York, the dollar traded at 1.7505 marks, up from 1.7480 late Monday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5235 Swiss francs, down from 1.5240; 5.9435 French francs, up from 5.9365; 1,306.00 Italian lire, up from 1,304.50; and 1.1415 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1440.

HEADLINE: C.D. Yields Decline Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, but the steepness of the previous week's decline had eased.
According to the Bank Rate Monitor, a North Palm Beach-based interest rate publication, the rapid drop in C.D. yields has just about caught up with the last reduction in interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board. 
 Dennis R. Kosovak, a senior vice president at Chemical Bank, said bank rates are now in synch with the market.
"There are signals of an economic pickup, and interest rates have begun to stablize," he said. Some customers are taking short maturities, he said, especially in the 13- and 30-month certificates of deposit.
The yield spread between both products has narrowed considerably in the past few weeks, from 80 basis points three weeks ago to about 25 basis points last week.
At the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction held on Monday, average discount rates, down for four consecutive weeks, rose sharply this week, rebounding from the sharp decline last week when developments in the Soviet Union sent short-term rates to very low levels. The three-month bill rose 23 basis points, to 5.40 percent, while the six-month bill rose 24 basis points, to 5.47 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The largest yield changes in New York area banks this week were at Banco Popular De Puerto Rico, which dropped its money market account 21 basis points, to 5.13 percent, and at Chase Manhattan. At Chase, the yield on a three-month certificate was cut 27 basis points, to 5.34 percent, and the yield on a six-month certificate was lowered 26 basis points, to 5.39 percent.
Among the commercial banks, the only decline was in the average yield on a money market account, which fell 5 basis points, to 4.90 percent. Three-month certificates rose a basis point, to 5.16 percent, and six-month certificates rose 2 basis points, to 5.34 percent.
For depositors at savings institutions, there was no respite as the average yields on a money market account and three-month certificate fell 3 basis points, to 5.43 percent and 5.61 percent, respectively. The six-month certificate fell 4 basis points, to 5.86.
By comparison, 20 large banks around the country that are outside the New York market reduced the average money market yield 2 basis points, to 5.13 percent.
