HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Calvin Klein Redefines The Big Buy

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
IF Calvin Klein sets trends in advertising the way he does in fashion, magazine executives said yesterday, the appearance of a 116-page ad supplement for Calvin Klein Jeans with the October issue of Vanity Fair might be a harbinger of better times for their recession-racked field.
The issue of the monthly, which is published by Conde Nast Publications, will be accompanied by what is being called the largest ad supplement for a consumer magazine in the United States. 
 Filled entirely with black-and-white photographs shot by Bruce Weber, it will be wrapped in a plastic bag and delivered with the issue. It is the first time such a supplement -- or, in the industry's colorful terminology, a polybagged outsert -- has accompanied a magazine from Conde Nast, whose other titles include Glamour and Vogue.
Bagged supplements first appeared in the mid 1980's, as marketers sought to stand out amid the clutter of magazine ads. But they have become scarcer since the industry slipped into recession in 1989. One reason is the cost, which can exceed $1 million. Another is that as many advertisers fled magazines, those remaining found they could stand out by buying conventional ad pages.
Yet conventional is not a word used to describe Mr. Klein.
"I've never done it," Mr. Klein said yesterday, referring to the supplement's size. "No one has ever done it."
Mr. Weber, who frequently photographs ads for Mr. Klein, presents young men and women, in various stages of undress, involved in sensual and sensuous activities before, during and after a rock concert.
"This gives me the opportunity to say just what I feel to people," Mr. Klein said. "If I can say it with two pages, I'd be happy to say it with two. Sometimes, I need a lot more."
After deciding on the supplement, which was created in-house, Mr. Klein said he realized: "I could only do it in one place. I wish I could afford to do it in more." He chose Vanity Fair, he added, because it is "where I thought it would work. Vanity Fair is the hot book." In 1987, Mr. Klein and his wife, Kelly, were the subjects of an adulatory cover story in the magazine, but they have also received favorable coverage elsewhere.
Mr. Klein's words were welcome to Ronald Galotti, Vanity Fair's publisher since December.
"At a time when business is soft for most," Mr. Galotti said, "to have something unique like this appear is really exciting."
At Vanity Fair's rate of $29,180 for a black-and-white ad page, the supplement would cost almost $3.4 million, excluding production costs, which were borne by Conde Nast. Mr. Galotti would not disclose what Mr. Klein was charged, but noted that he qualified for several discounts. Industry executives estimate the cost exceeded $1 million.
More important, Mr. Galotti said, is a statement he hopes the supplement makes about Conde Nast. "We're considered a little bit stodgy in our willingness to participate in creative ideas," he said. "That's not the case if they're well thought out and profitable."
But whether such a supplement "is making money is not the object," said a publisher of a rival magazine who asked not to be identified. "Making a splash is. You can rationalize the splash rather than the cash."
Vanity Fair has been faring better than most magazines lately. Through July, its ad pages fell 7 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau, compared with an industry decline of 10.4 percent. Mr. Galottiestimates the magazine will finish the year at around 1,425 pages, compared with 1,459 in 1990.
The supplement is the equivalent of 29 ad pages, Mr. Galotti said, because it will accompany the 250,000 or so copies delivered to newsstands and subscribers in California and New York, rather than Vanity Fair's entire circulation of approximately 850,000. Such limited distribution is common with print ad extravaganzas; for instance, special ads created by TBWA Advertising in New York for Carillon Importers' Absolut vodka often appear in selected portions of magazine print runs.
William Tragos, TBWA's chairman, said unusual ads become the usual if a client "wants to be seen" and "wants to break out from the crowd with panache."
Not all executives, though, see the supplement as an indicator of improving business.
"I'm not sure I would translate this into a signal for the marketplace," said William T. Kerr, the president of The New York Times Company Magazine Group, "though I'd like to." He added that while "there are some stirrings, I don't think it's a trend yet."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Japanese Planning U.S. Sake Plant

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GOLDEN, Colo., aug. 27

 BODY:
The Tatsuuma-Honke Brewing Company of Japan is building a sake plant on land it bought from Adolph Coors Company in 1989. The $7 million plant is scheduled to open in the spring, said Bill Shores, project superintendent for the Ohbayashi America Corporation, a partner in the venture. 
 When it opens, economic development officials say, the plant will be one of five breweries in the United States to produce the alcholic drink that is made from fermented rice and usually warmed before serving. The mostly automated plant will employ about 30 people, officials say, and produce sake under the brand name Hakushika for export mostly to the Far East and Europe.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Traces of the Old Guard Linger in a New Latvia

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: RIGA, Latvia, Aug. 27

 BODY:
"We have stopped doing absolutely everything we did before," said Maj. Gen. Janis Trubins, deputy commander of the K.G.B. in this breakaway Soviet republic.
General Trubins, an amiable and voluble man of 46 -- one of the youngest generals in the K.G.B., he noted proudly -- appeared to be resigned to unemployment and expressed no resentment about the turn of events. 
 "I can feel neither joy nor sorrow," he said in an interview in the nearly abandoned K.G.B. building in the center of the Latvian capital, as he considered the events that followed the abortive Soviet coup last week that have brought ruin to Moscow's organs of power here in the Baltic republics.
One of his deputies said: "When Latvia declared its independence, we became part of an organization of another country. What is happening is not much different from what happened in Eastern Europe."
 
First Envoy Presents Credentials
 Today Riga also acquired the first visible token of recognition of its 51 years of striving to regain international standing as the capital of an independent country. Otto Borch presented his credentials as Denmark's Ambassador to President Anatolijs Gorbunovs. Mr. Borch, former Ambassador to the United States, said the Soviet Union had raised no objections.
Mr. Borch is going to Lithuania and Estonia to be accredited there as well.
The streets of this Hanseatic city dominated by many Gothic steeples also showed other, more informal signs of the profound changes, whose pace was so markedly speeded by the failure of the coup.
A five-day festival of Jewish culture in the Baltic countries is under way, and bearded men wearing yarmulkes strolled on the streets for what was perhaps the first time since the invading Germans and Latvian fascists decimated the once-thriving Jewish population in 1941.
A banner stretched across Freedom Avenue, newly renamed after having long been dedicated to Lenin, announced that Hare Krishnas would arrive on Saturday.
At the end of the avenue, a city work crew was removing the remainder of the base of the monument of Lenin. Onlookers applauded every thud of the wrecker's heavy metal ball.
At the edge f Riga, near the fishing port on the Baltic Sea and amidst industrial plants, stands the redoubt of the last holdouts of the old regime. Ringed by mines and barbed wire, guarded by armored personnel carriers whose machine guns are pointed toward the narrow entrance as an evident deterrent, a detachment of "black berets," the feared troops of the Soviet Interior Ministry, stands in readiness.
In an interview, their deputy commander, a major who declined to give his name, said that the orders weren't coming and that he was no longer sure what the detachment's mission is. "You know the situation in the Soviet Union now," he said. "We are waiting."
He refused to say how strong his detachment is. "Enough to control the city," he said. Riga's population is 916,000, and Latvian officials estimated the number of "black berets" at 80 to 100. Their camp bristles with automatic arms, hand grenades and ammunition. "There is more here than what you see," the major said.
The major said his troops would fire on the population only if fired upon. "We never fire first," he said. Throughout the Baltic republics, the "black berets" are viewed with terror because of their roles in the crackdowns here and in Vilnius, Lithuania, last January.
The K.G.B. man, General Trubins, discussed the recent changes as he sat under a portrait of Feliks Dzerzhinsky, the founder of the first Communist secret police, next to eight telephones, including one he said was a direct line to K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow.
Since Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985, he said, his job has been mainly the exercise of police functions -- fighting the drug trade and organized crime, guarding against terrorists and protecting civil and constitutional rights.
General Trubins conceded implicitly, however, that in earlier days the K.G.B. exercised surveillance over all Soviet citizens and persecuted political opponents. Describing work that took place in Yuri V. Andropov's long reign as K.G.B. chief, he said, "That was done when there was not a democratic society."
His deputy, a 37-year-old former history teacher who was more ready to bare his soul than to allow his name to be published, admitted to a less tranquil conscience. He said he was proud of his part in reducing the illegal arms network, which he said moves many military weapons stolen here into southern republics like Georgia. But he conceded he had done things he was not proud of.
When asked to specify, he tapped his fingers rapidly on the desk and said quietly: "I leave this inside myself."
 
Ideas Change, Monuments Fall
 Both men denounced the removal of the statues of Lenin and Dzerzhinsky from public places and offered similar cynical forecasts.
"Ideas change, ideologies even more," the deputy said. "In the 1950's, Latvian monuments were destroyed here. Others will be put up now, and in time, they, too, will be destroyed."
The two secret policemen agreed also on another issue. Although they face unemployment, they said, they would not accept new K.G.B. assignments that would remove them from Latvia. "I'm a Latvian," General Trubins said. "We'll stay here. I'll never again be involved in politics. It's a dirty business."
Asked whether he favored independence for Latvia, the deputy replied: "Of course. Who would not?"

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Mirror Sets Buyouts

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company said today that it planned to offer some employees of its largest newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, early retirement to cut costs.
The Times said the program would be offered to employees 55 years old or older who have at least 10 consecutive years of service. The Times, which has 6,000 full-time employees, said a maximum of 300 people would be allowed to retire under the program. 
 Laura Morgan, a Times spokeswoman, said the number of workers in each department allowed to accept the offer was confidential, but she said every department, including news, was included.
The Times said it had had a virtual hiring freeze all year. The Times's advertising revenue, like that of other newspapers, has fallen during the recession. The newspaper has said volume for the first seven months of the year is down 18.3 percent from last year.
Times Mirror said the retirement program would require the company to take an unspecified charge against earnings later in the year.
Other newspapers, including some in the Times Mirror chain and The New York Times, have offered similar programs to reduce staff and save money.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
The Day's Highlights

 BODY:

Gorbachev Battles the Tide
A Threat to Resign: Trying to stave off total disintegration, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was said to have reached agreement with the leaders of three republics -- including Russia and Kazakhstan, the two largest in area -- on retaining some form of union. But Moldavia became the latest republic to announce its independence. Mr. Gorbachev threatened to quit if a new union treaty were not renegotiated. Page A1. 
 Purging Tyranny's Apparatus: President Gorbachev said the governing board of the K.G.B. had been virtually disbanded and its military units reassigned to the army. A Soviet newspaper announced the arrest of the leaders of the K.G.B. unit charged with security for top officials, including the men who confronted Mr. Gorbachev at the coup's outset. Page A1.
Not Without A Fight: Mr. Gorbachev is offering the Soviet Union a desperately needed lesson in resilience. "We should not destroy!" he pleaded in Parliament in one of his best domestic speeches. Page A6.
 
Breaking Away in the Baltics
A Boost from Europe: The European Community recognized Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania as independent nations. But community officials said independence declarations by other Soviet republics would be treated differently. Page A1.
Why Others Hesitate: President Bush's caution on recognizing the Baltics stands in sharp contrast to other nations' responses. For the republics' immediate neighbors, the choice has been clearest, driven by their proximity and years of close cooperation. But for Washington and other countries, the equation is considerably more complex. Page A11.
Profound Changes: In Riga, the Latvian capital, a K.G.B. commander says "we have stopped doing absolutely everything we did before," and appears resigned to unemployment. In Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, the Soviet authorities have abandoned airport entry points. Page A7.
Olympic Recognition: The president of the International Olympic Committee said in Tokyo that the three Baltic republics might participate as independent teams in the Barcelona Olympics next summer. Juan Antonio Samaranch, the Olympic Committee's president, added that the organization may grant the three republics provisional membership at a meeting in Berlin next month. He suggested that the world track and field championships in Tokyo this week might be the last time the Soviet Union fields a single team in its current form.
 
 Of Alibis, Conspiracy and Betrayal
Rampant Rumors: One thing that hasn't changed in Moscow is the strong sense of conspiracy, well-founded or not, among its inhabitants. The search for an ultimate culprit in the coup has fanned out to encompass radical democrats, President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic and, of course, President Gorbachev himself. Page A10.
The Coup Flu, or Just Following Orders: It turns out now that just about everyone was against the putsch, or sick, or just doing his job. The most ironclad aibi was probably that of two Soviet astronauts who continued circling the earth through all the excitement. Page A10.

HEADLINE: For Chinese Artists, Shattered Dreams Despite Freedom

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
A shocked and solemn crowd consisting mostly of young artists from China had gathered in the narrow, dingy apartment on West 145th Street. Upstairs, in a friend's home, a young woman was weeping inconsolably. Between sobs, Duan Haimeng, the widow of a Chinese artist slain near Times Square, managed to say, "I never dreamed that something like this could happen."
On Aug. 18, Ms. Duan's 34-year-old husband, Lin Lin, was shot dead while drawing a portrait in the wee hours of Sunday morning. The police said a young man provoked an argument with Mr. Lin and then shot him through the chest when the artist answered back. They later arrested James Skinner, 21, of Brooklyn, and charged him with second-degree murder in the killing.
 
Survival or Freedom?
 The incident stunned the subculture of Chinese artists to which Lin Lin belonged. Many of his artist and painter friends came to the city in recent years to escape the political atmosphere in China, which they believed threatened their artistic development. And yet several artists said what happened to Lin Lin would be inconceivable in China, where violent street crime is almost nonexistent. 
 Since Mr. Lin's death, many young Chinese artists here have been asking themselves a fundamental question: Are the difficulties and dangers of life in New York City worth the artistic freedom for which they came?
"Lin Lin once gave an interview after the students were killed on Tiananmen square in Beijing," one friend, Zhang Hungtu, recalled. "He said that the students in China deserved our admiration because they lived in real danger while we live in safety, like in a strongbox, because we are in America."
Mr. Zhang, who came to this country nine years ago to pursue a career as a painter, pointed to a particular paradox: Lin Lin was so enchanted by life in New York, and particularly the neighborhood in which he lived, that he gave himself the pen name Billy Harlem.
"He loved this country," Mr. Zhang said. "He felt safe. But he is dead. It's a great shock."
 
A Talented Subculture
 Lin Lin, a graduate of the prestigious Zhejiang Art Academy in Hangzhou, China, who came here three years ago from Shanghai, belonged to a loosely knit group of Chinese painters who have come to New York in such numbers that they have made the city a major new center of Chinese art, certainly the largest in the world outside of China itself. Some of the artists say that New York is the most important place in the world these days for new Chinese art, having become for them what Paris was for many artists in the 1920's and 1930's -- a place where people could gather freely and experiment with new forms.
Some of the Chinese painters have found financial success and been taken on by major New York galleries. Most, however, have not. They talk about difficult lives, beset by economic and artistic challenges so that much of the initial glitter of New York has considerably faded. Yet returning to China, especially after the violent crackdown on the democracy movement there two years ago, is impossible for most of them.
 
'Broken Dreams'
 "After 10 years living here, I don't think there's so much opportunity," said Ai Weiwei, a painter and sculptor who was one of the first young Chinese artists to come to this country. "But people come here because they are always hoping to improve things for themselves even if they have to live in terrible circumstances. For example, Lin Lin's living conditions were worse than just about anything you would find in China."
Mr. Ai and other artists compare New York unfavorably with other centers of the Chinese artistic Diaspora like Paris and Zurich, where government subsidies and artists' housing are often available. But Chinese artists keep coming here, they say, and they stay because New York is still the place where dreams of success in the arts are made.
"Lin Lin's death shocked a lot of people because it could have been any of them," Mr. Ai said. "But a lot of people already had broken dreams."
Nobody seems to know exactly how many Chinese artists live here. Mr. Ai says there may be about 100; others say the figure is twice that, maybe more.
"Every artist wants to make it in New York," said Yan Li, a Chinese painter and poet who came here in 1985. "In China they can't express themselves. They have no way of exhibiting their work."
 
'They Feel Cut Off'
 Mr. Yan, who is also a poet and edits a poetry magazine called "First Line," which publishes the work of poets who have no outlet in China, says that Chinese artists confront not only practical problems, like surviving financially, but artistic problems stemming from their lack of the roots that are the very sources of their original inspiration.
"They feel cut off," he said, "and they need to change the styles that they have developed or were taught in China. But it's very difficult to change. It takes 10 years to develop a new style."
Many of the artists live in Flushing, where a large and varied community of recently arrived Chinese has sprouted in the past few years. Others live on the Lower East Side. A few, like Lin Lin, settled in narrow dilapidated flats in Harlem.
Financial difficulties led many of them to paint portraits on the street. That custom started about 10 years ago, when some artists used to set up easels on West Fourth Street and Sixth Avenue, until they were chased away by the police in Greenwich Village.
The technical training of these painters is generally quite rigorous; the schools they attended in China empasized such basic skills as sketching in charcoal. Because of their common backgrounds, some of the Chinese artists quickly developed a subculture within a subculture, learning the ways of life on the streets as they sought to earn spending money.
"Sometimes it was fun," Shen Chen, a painter from Beijing who came to this country in 1988, said of his days working on New York streets. "You practice your art making portraits. You learn English. You meet people from all over the world."
 
Getting Streetwise
 The artists learned where to go and when to go there. A typical day might include several hours in the afternoon drawing portraits in Central Park, Mr. Ai said. Then, a portrait artist might travel down to 34th Street to work for a few hours in the early evening outside Macy's. Later at night, he might venture over to Times Square, where, despite the dangers of the neighborhood, there are often many prospective customers late into the night. Several artists said that there were fewer police in Times Square after 11 P.M., so there was less risk of harassment by the officers there very late at night.
"Last year, I was arrested, handcuffed, fingerprinted, photographed and put in a cell with common criminals for an hour," said Hao Bing, a painter from Beijing who was doing portraits next to Lin Lin on the night of the shooting. "Sometimes the police are nice. They tell you to go away for 10 minutes because a supervisor is coming, and then to come back." But Mr. Hao also told of ethnic slurs hurled his way by police officers. "The police sometimes chase us down the street in their cars until we are out of breath," he said.
Another painter, Sunny Tu, who was also with Lin Lin the night of his death, said that he has tried to go to the Bureau of Consumer Affairs to get a peddler's license, but he has been refused.
"They only give peddler's licenses to veterans and the widows of veterans," said Mr. Tu, who originally came here from Hong Kong. "Painting portraits is a cash business, so they want us to pay taxes, and we are willing to pay taxes. But what can we do if we can't get licenses?"
"In every city, in Paris, Zurich, Toronto, it's a custom to support artists by letting them paint street portraits," Mr. Tu said. "Why can't they do the same thing in New York?"
But Lin Lin felt more kindly toward the city. "He liked New York a lot," Mr. Zhang said. "He thought it was a good place to be an artist.
"He felt safe in this country," Mr. Zhang said. "But he is dead. It's a great shock."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Now Chairman At Chemical Waste

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Jerry E. Dempsey has been promoted to chairman of Chemical Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest hazardous-waste management company.
Mr. Dempsey, 58 years old, had been president and chief executive of the company, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill. He succeeds Dean L. Buntrock, who will remain the chairman and chief executive of Chemical Waste's parent, Waste Management Inc. 
 D. P. (Pat) Payne, a Waste Management senior vice president, replaces Mr. Dempsey as president and chief executive. Mr. Payne joined Waste Managment in August 1990 from I.B.M., where he was vice president and general manager for the Midwest region.
One analyst described the changes as a logical transfer of management duties at Waste Management, which plans to go public next year in Europe. Mr. Buntrock "has his hands full and is moving some of the responsibility," said Kay Hahn, director of research at the Chicago Corporation, an investment bank.
Waste Management owns 76 percent of Chemical Waste, which went public in 1986 and saw revenues nearly triple through 1990, when sales were $1.14 billion. During that period, net income more than tripled to $175 million in 1990.
Mrs. Hahn said Chemical Waste, the leader in its market "by a country mile," has grown with the industry as more and more substances have come under regulation requiring sophisticated handling and disposal methods. She added, however, that the industry's growth was stalled by the recession.
Mr. Dempsey said that one new direction the company is pursuing is the cleanup of contaminated Defense Department sites. Two years ago it established a subsidiary called Chem-Nuclear Environmental Services to develop its nuclear-waste management business.
"We see big opportunities in those Federal faciliites," he said.
Mr. Dempsey joined Waste Management in April 1984 as a director and vice chairman of the board, and was responsible for the company's strategic planning and long-range business development. He has been president and chief executive of Chemical Waste since July 1985 and has been a senior vice president of Waste Management since May 1988. Previously, Mr. Dempsey was president and chief operating officer of the Borg-Warner Corporation in Chicago, where he had worked since 1956.
Mr. Dempsey holds an M.B.A. from Georgia State University and a B.S. in mechanical engineering from Clemson University. He and his wife, Harriet, have three daughters.
During Mr. Payne's 11 years at I.B.M., he held a series of marketing and management positions, including administrative assistant to the chairman, and director of strategy evaluation in corporate finance and planning.
While Mr. Payne was senior vice president of Waste Management, his responsibilities included strategic planning, sales and marketing, information systems, human resources, quality programs and state government affairs.
Mr. Payne has a business administration degree from Texas A.& M. University. He and his wife, Patty, have two sons and a daughter.

HEADLINE: New York's McIntoshes Get the Jump on Autumn

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: CLAVERACK, N.Y., Aug. 27

 BODY:
Apples in August? Yes.
Ten days to two weeks ahead of schedule, before cold evenings have had a chance to bring a full red blush to the cheeks of McIntosh apples, the harvest has started in upstate New York. 
 An early spring and warm summer have speeded the maturing of apples and many other crops, despite a drought in July.
"In my 30 years as an apple grower, I have never picked a Mac in August before," said Russell Holze, a farmer on Schoolhouse Road here in Columbia County. "This year I'll have most of my Macs picked before the end of the month."
 
Cold Nights Needed
 Because of the early maturing, the McIntoshes, the most popular of all the apples grown in New York State, may be a little smaller than usual, as well as not as red.
"A touch of cold is very much needed," said Craig Telgheder, a fruit specialist of the Cooperative Extension Service in Columbia County. "The ideal weather during the harvest season is dry, sunny days with cold nights, which we are not going to get."
In the orchards on Mr. Holze's 150-acre fruit farm, the apples appeared to be about half red, not the three-quarters required for grading as extra fancy, the kind demanded by supermarket buyers. He has 12 workers picking this week, hoping to get the apples off the trees before they fall.
Standing under an apple tree in one of his orchards, Mr. Holze explained the economic problem of waiting for the fruit to reach the desired redness.
 
For Eating or Cider
 "If they color well and are picked, I can get $8 to $9 a bushel for them," he said. "If they drop and are sold for cider, I get $2 a bushel."
Despite the potential for loss, the general outlook is good for McIntoshes and about a dozen other varieties of apples grown in New York, according to the Agricultural Statistics Service in Albany.
It forecast that the 1991 crop in the state would be 1.01 billion pounds, up 2 percent from 990 millions pounds last year. Apple growers sold last year's crop for $80.6 million, the service said.
New York is the second leading apple state in the nation, behind Washington, which produces most of the nation's Red Delicious apples. This year's crop there was forecast at 4.6 billion pounds.
New Jersey and Connecticut produce so few apples commercially that they are not included in the state figures collected by the United States Department of Agriculture.
 
3 Major Apple Areas
 New York has three major apple-growing areas -- the Hudson Valley, the western shore of Lake Champlain and several counties on the south side of Lake Ontario.
Throughout the state the McIntosh is the leading apple grown, followed by later-maturing varieties like Rhode Island Greenings, Romes, Red Delicious, Idareds, Cortlands, Empires, Golden Delicious and Twenty Ounce.
But the McIntosh is in a decline, mainly because it falls when ripe, making an orderly harvest difficult. Up to two years ago, farmers used the chemical Alar to keep the fruit on trees longer.
With Alar now banned by the Federal Government, the impact on the harvesting of McIntoshes has been intensified by the warm weather this year, making the season earlier and shorter and requiring the hiring of more pickers.
Farmers are responding by replacing McIntosh trees with other varieties, like Jonamacs, an early apple, and later apples, like Empire and Cortland, according to Warren Smith, a fruit specialist for the Cooperative Extension Service in the Hudson Valley.
"They're easier to manage and not apt to drop their fruit when ripe," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "In my 30 years as an apple grower, I have never picked a Mac in August before," said Russell Holze on his 150-acre fruit farm in Columbia County, N.Y. He checked bins of McIntosh apples, which are ripening sooner than usual because of an early spring and a warm summer. (Dave Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Registered a Decline in August

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Consumer confidence edged down in August with expectations for the economy over the next six months becoming less optimistic, the Conference Board reported today.
The decline in the New York business group's confidence index, to 76.3 from 77.7 in July, was the fourth in five months, following a postwar surge in March of more than 20 points. 
 "It's rather disappointing," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Board's Consumer Research Center. "While many of the economic indicators suggest that a recovery is in progress, the evidence will not be convincing until there is a substantial improvement in consumers' spirits."
The expectations component of the index, a predictive indicator for the economy, slipped to 96.3 at the August reading from 100.3 in July, with employment a particular concern. For the second straight month, there was a decline in the number of respondents who said they expected jobs to rise in the months ahead.
On the other hand, there was an improvement in the way the 5,000 households surveyed assessed current economic conditions. This component rose to 46.3 from 43.7 and 43.8 in June and July, respectively.
 
Results Taken in Stride
 Over all, economists and securities markets appeared to take the results in stride, with some analysts noting that confidence was lackluster for a year following the 1970 recession without signaling economic relapse.
"I don't think it's anything to worry about," said David S. Klein, an economist at Paine Webber Inc. "We're still well above the trough" of 55.1 percent confidence level reached in January.
In assessing general business conditions, 25.2 percent said they would be better six months from now, while 10.1 percent said they would be worse, and the rest said they would be about the same. Last month. 24.4 percent predicted improvement, and 9.5 percent predicted worsening conditions.
The percentage expecting greater job availability, however, shrank to 18.6 from 19.9, while a tighter job market was predicted by 18.5 percent, up from 18.1 percent.
"We're still getting a lot of worry about the job situation," said Mr. Linden.
For incomes, the Conference Board survey found 20 percent expecting increases, down from 23 percent, and 9.9 percent expecting decreases, up from 9 percent.
The other major compiler of data on consumer attitudes toward the economy, the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center, does not yet have full results of its August polling, which are to be sent to subscribers on Thursday.
But Professor Richard T. Curtin said today that it would "not be surprising" if they should parallel those of the Confernce Board. He added that the current "hiatus" in the improvement of consumer psychology was not unusual for this stage of the business cycle though it does suggest the recovery will be less vigorous than usual.
The Michigan expectations index is one of the 11 components of the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Indicators, which is intended to call turning points in the economy.
As for the consumer's view of present conditions, the Conference Board found 12.6 percent considered them good and 37.2 percent considered them bad; the comparable July figures were 12 percent and 37.3 percent.
For jobs, 8.8 percent believed them currently plentiful compared with 7.8 percent in July, while at the same time 38.6 percent believed them hard to get, up from 37.6 percent.
Edward Yardeni of C.J. Lawrence said that the rise in jobs-hard-to-get suggested that the nation's unemployment rate for August when reported on Sept. 6 could show a rise of one-tenth of a point from July's 6.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
An index of construction spending rose in July after a decline the month before, indicating that this important sector of the economy resumed a recovery begun earlier this year.
The F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that its index of construction contract value rose 7 percent in July compared with June. 
 The gain lifted the rate of newly started construction slightly above its average for the second quarter, which was when the industry's recovery started, Dodge said. It said improvements were noted in both housing and nonresidential construction. Nonresidential building had sagged in June.
The value of newly started residential building rose 6 percent in July, extending an upward climb that began in February, Dodge said. By July, residential construction contracting was 25 percent above its January low, with virtually all of the gain in single-family homes.
Contracting for nonresidential buildings rose 2 percent, while the non-building category, which includes public works and utilities, jumped 19 percent. This category was helped by a $400 million contract for a utility plant in New Jersey, Dodge said.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Group of Seven Is Seen Backing Some Soviet Aid

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
When senior officials from industrialized nations meet this week to discuss aid to the Soviet Union, they are likely to disagree on whether to provide large-scale financial assistance but strongly endorse technical assistance and humanitarian aid.
Advice and training for Soviet officials seeking to rescue their country's foundering economy is vital to help officials there understand the country's troubles, said a senior Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Technical assistance also provides a way to identify the problems and possible solutions while waiting for either the central Government or the republics to emerge as responsible recipients for aid, he added. 
 Humanitarian aid, including food, is likely to come sooner, the official said.
 
Food Aid 'Essential'
 Richard T. McCormack, who until recently was the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said food aid "is essential, and to do that you've got to start moving reasonably early because of transportation lags."
The personal representatives of the leaders of seven richest industrialized nations are scheduled to meet Thursday in London. Deputies to the nations' finance ministers plan to meet a day later in Paris.
Mr. McCormack's successor at the State Department, Robert Zoellick, will represent the United States in London; David C. Mulford, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, will go to Paris. Besides France, Britain and the United States, the group of seven includes Canada, Germany, Italy and Japan.
Technical assistance includes drafting plans and training Soviet officials in Western techniques for monetary policy, banking, taxation, agriculture and transportation. Until recently, for example, ministries in Moscow controlled virtually all Soviet trade and few duties were assessed on their imports.
With many Soviet citizens and enterprises now engaged in international trade, the Soviet Union has been expanding customs offices at its borders, drafting a more detailed list of import tariffs and seeking the International Monetary Fund's help in organization.
Latvia, which declared its independence from the Soviet Union last week, will seek Peace Corps volunteers to teach English and basic business skills there. And the World Bank today announced a trust fund to pay for training programs.
But experts warn that if the Soviet authorities are unable to control Government spending, allow markets to determine prices and provide a stable currency, technical assistance may have little effect. "It's like riding bicycles in the wrong direction on a superhighway filled with trucks," Mr. McCormack said. "The trucks just crush the bicycles."
 
Political Complications
 But providing technical assistance has been complicated by the political upheaval in the Soviet Union. The I.M.F., for example, had been expected to oversee much of the effort, but is not sure whom to deal with in the Soviet Union.
After extensive negotiations, the international lending agency was expecting the heads of the Soviet Finance Ministry and central bank to arrive next week with a detailed list of needs. But Finance Minister Vladimir Y. Orlov and Viktor V. Gerashchenko, chairman of the Soviet central bank, were both implicated in last week's coup.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2320 words

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
GORBACHEV THREATENS TO QUIT UNLESS REPUBLICS FIND A WAY TO PRESERVE A MODIFIED UNION;
NEW PACT IS SOUGHT

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Fighting to stem the flight of republics from a disintegrating nation, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he had won agreement today from two major republics to keep some kind of Soviet Union and threatened to resign if efforts at unity failed.
Mr. Gorbachev said the leaders of the Russian federated republic and Kazakhstan, the largest of the republics in area, had agreed with him and the President of Kirghizia on the need for an early signing of a revised treaty between the Kremlin and those republics willing to stay in the union. Such a revised agreement would determine what kind of political and economic structure would emerge from the current crisis -- a federation, or a commonwealth, for instance.
 
Break by Another Republic
 But even as he announced this agreement, another republic said it wanted its independence. Moldavia, situated on the border with Romania, with which it was long associated in the past, announced its independence from the union, the third republic to do so since the failed coup in Moscow last week. 
 With some of his old combative zest, Mr. Gorbachev today urged the Soviet Parliament today to help mount a rescue effort, and negotiate a new union treaty to define relationships between the republics and the central government and thus save the Soviet Union from total collapse, or face his departure.
"If something else comes about, I will simply raise the question of my resignation," he said, addressing the Supreme Soviet. [Transcript, pages A8 and A9.]
Mr. Gorbachev, his voice raised in urgency, warned that without a new treaty to replace the one that was to have been signed last week, the Soviet Union was on the verge of disintegration, with frightening consequences for itself and its neighbors.
 
Error Would Be Too Costly
 "This collapse threatens the lives and property of millions of people, and of the defense potential of our country, which is a superpower," he said. "We do not have the right to make a mistake of this proportion."
At today's meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic, President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev of the Kazakh republic and President Askar Akayev of the Kirghiz republic said they would continue negotiations, Mr. Gorbachev said.
Mr. Gorbachev said that "our common point is that the U.S.S.R. should be maintained as a union of sovereign states. Everyone is in favor of a unified defense, a unified armed forces."
A statement issued by Tass later said the four "expressed hope that the earliest signing of the union treaty with the necessary amendments, dictated by a new situation in the country, will help promote political stabilization and open wide vistas for the unimpeded carrying out of reforms, the creation of a single market, conclusion of an economic agreement between all 15 sovereign republics."
"Serious doubts were expressed during the conversation over the expediency of creating separate national armies, except for the possible formation of small national guard units," the statement said. "This approach is dictated by the fact that the Soviet Union is a nuclear power."
 
Status of Baltic Republics
 What seemed to be emerging was an agreement to seek some kind of political arrangement for those republics willing to remain under Kremlin leadership, with an acknowledgment that the three Baltic republics, which have now won European recognition, are probably gone from the union. But Mr. Gorbachev was clearly hoping to include the Baltic republics in any economic community that might be forged.
It was uncertain that the optimism Mr. Gorbachev conveyed to the Parliament about negotiating a new treaty would be borne out. As he left the meeting, Mr. Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan said he had "no special optimism" that a solution was in sight on a new treaty that would keep the republics bound in a political union.
Nevertheless, there seemed to be some backlash in the country against the hasty actions taken in the wake of the failed coup, and this movement appeared to help out Mr. Gorbachev.
In the Soviet Parliament today, a number of liberal politicians expressed alarm at the political unraveling taking place across the country. Mayor Anatoly A. Sobchak of Leningrad called it a "suicidal process."
 
Warnings of Disintegration
 From the podium, deputies warned of the "Balkanization" of the country, particularly after the warning by the Russian republic yesterday that it would seek a review of existing borders if neighboring republics with large Russian populations break away from the union.
As the drive for independence spread to republics where the Communists are still in control -- such as Byrelorussia and the Central Asian republics, some interpreted their actions as a political dodge to avoid the radical reforms now expected to come from the Gorbachev-Yeltsin coalition in the Kremlin.
"These announcements of the splitting up of the Soviet Union without any preliminary agreement, through unilateral proclamations of independence, this is a continuation of the putsch, already in different forms," Mr. Sobchak said.
 
Quest for Political Gains
 By pushing for greater sovereignty, republic leaders, in many cases recent Communists, were seen to be using the opportunity created by the mounting political chaos to gain political capital with a radical nationalist stance.
By moving rapidly to claim dominance over the Soviet Government in the aftermath of the coup, the Russian republic, led by Mr. Yeltsin, has cast a shadow over the fate of new union, giving rise to old fears of Russian chauvinism.
Mr. Nazarbayev, who only 10 days ago was negotiating with Mr. Yeltsin for closer economic ties between their two republics, today told reporters that he could not support a Russian Government claim to be "first among equals."
"The President and Prime Minister are Russian and now we hear that they might agree for the vice president to be from Central Asia," he said. "Well, thanks a lot," he added wrily.
 
Division of Authority
 Before the coup, the Russian republic, Kazakhstan and others were poised to sign a treaty that has been under negotiation for four months outlining the division of responsibilities between Moscow and the republics, giving the regions more control over their own policies and economies. But after the week's tumultuous events, all parties -- including Mr. Gorbachev -- have agreed that the old treaty is now inadequate, and must be redrafted to reflect the republics' demands for greater independence.
Only 9 of the Soviet Union's 15 republics had participated in the previous round of talks on a new union treaty; the other 6 -- the Baltic states, Georgia, Moldavia and Armenia -- had already declared their intention to leave the union, although each had a different timetable.
Mr. Gorbachev said again today he would not move to keep republics in the union against their will, but he argued that secession should take place under the aegis of a new treaty and the new Soviet Constitution that would include the provisions of the treaty.
But with more and more foreign states recognizing the independence of the Baltic republics, the process has already begun to take its own course, leaving Mr. Gorbachev to deal with an unwelcome reality. Today in an interview with reporters, Mr. Gorbachev chided the Baltic republics and the countries that have recognized them for making "hasty decisions."
In the last few days, the Parliaments of the Ukraine, then Byelorussia and now Moldavia moved to declare independence. Kazakhstan has declared itself in favor of a commonwealth arrangement, while in Uzbekistan, the chairman of the parliament has called for preparation of an independence declaration that would be submitted to a vote.
Today, in Moldavia, a republic of 4.5 million people, of whom two-thirds are ethnic Romanians, crowds gathered in the main square of the capital, Kishinev, to cheer the official declaration of "full, immediate" independence voted by the parliament.
In interviews this week, Mircea Snegur, the president of Moldavia, said independence was only a step towards Moldavia's ultimate goal, which he said is reunification with Romania. Like the Baltic republics, Moldavia was absorbed by the Soviet Union in 1940 under the terms of the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact. Today, in Bucharest, the Romanian Government recognized Moldavian independence within moments of its announcement.
For advocates of the union treaty, the most troublesome moves towards independence this week came from the Ukraine, a republic second only to the Russian federation in population, located in a strategic position on the Soviet Union's southern and western borders and well-stocked with weapons from the Soviet military's formidable arsenal. Without the Ukraine and Byelorussia, the two other Slavic republics, Russia could find itself in a union in which the largely Muslim republics of Central Asia would play a dominant role.
A spokesman for Mr. Yeltsin said on Monday Russia would call for a review of its borders, if neighboring republics with large Russian populations leave the union. That would affect the Ukraine, which includes the Crimea, largely populated by Russians. The Yeltsin statement on borders also alarmed Kazakh leaders, since their republic also has a large Russian population.
 
Specter of Yugoslavia
 That statement added new alarm to the crisis, raising the specter of a repeat of the Yugoslav crisis. That country's republics are now warring over disputed territory.
Speaking to Parliament today, Mr. Gorbachev warned against any discussions of internal border changes. "I want this discussion to be ended," he said. "The draft treaty says that borders cannot be changed."
He also defended Mr. Yeltsin and the Russian government against charges of chauvinism and power-grabbing. "The Russians are concerned about consolidating the defeat they dealt the putsch," said Mr. Gorbachev. "Today, we hear that they are trying to implement the Russian empire. But the Russians have no such intention."
He also praised the army for resisting the coup, saying this was a testament to the reforms that have taken place in the military over the last few years. "The army did not go along with the plotters," he said. "Let us pay them their due. Perestroika gave birth to a new army."
 
Credit for Defeat of Coup
 Democratic reforms in society were also instrumental in paving the way for the popular resistance to the coup, Mr. Gorbachev said. "If we had not gone down the path of democratization, the putschists would have dealt very easily with perestroika," he said.
While warning against anti-Communist hysteria, Mr. Gorbachev today called on Communists to form a new party to support the democratic transition -- yet another death blow to the party that until last week was still the dominant political force in the country.
The Soviet press agency Tass today announced that the chief coup plotters are being charged with "betrayal of the motherland," a capital crime under Soviet law.
Meanwhile, reformers continued to stake out new positions in the wake of the defeat of the coup last week. Today, the former editor of Moscow News, Yegor Yakovlev, was named to head the Government broadcasting company, which controls central television and radio channels.
 
A Bastion of Free Speech
 Mr. Yakovlev's newspaper, a weekly published in Russian and several foreign languages, was one of the first to test the limits of Mr. Gorbachev's policy of openness and free speech, publishing articles about Soviet politics and history that were a sensation five years ago. He replaces Leonid Kravchenko, named to the post last winter when Mr. Gorbachev began shifting towards the conservative camp.
Under Mr. Kravchenko, central television dropped popular programs that carried free-wheeling political debates, and returned to the format of an earlier era, alternating between lengthy lectures by public officials and light popular music. Its news program, "Vremya," became a vehicle for the new conservative slant on events, prompting millions of viewers to switch their allegiance to the Russian channel, and its news program "Vesti."
In Parliament today, deputies readied for the opening next week of the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies, which has been charged with a major overhaul of government in the wake of last week's coup.
 
Gorbachev Dominates Session
 But the main feature of the day's lengthy debates was again Mr. Gorbachev, who after addressing the Parliament yesterday, returned today for a question-and-answer session.
Although still visibly chastened by his diminished political role, Mr. Gorbachev -- who last weekend resigned as General Secretary of the Communist Party -- came to the podium, fired with alarm over the state of the union.
"There is a real threat of the collapse of the Soviet state," he said, "and I say this with enormous anxiety and urgency."
He showed his old impatience at the meandering debates that have filled the Parliament for the last two days. "While we are sitting here, everything is getting weaker, collapsing," he said.
For Mr. Gorbachev, as for the union itself, the stakes are enormous, as he tries to rein in the forces let loose in the aftermath of the coup. "He is President," said Mr. Sobchak. "If he can not solve this issue, then he should leave."
But some deputies were gloomy about the prospect of halting the Union's slide. "Right now this is an uncontrollable process," said Konstantin Lyubenchikov, a liberal deputy. "Gorbachev does not have enough authority to stop it, and the Supreme Soviet is embroiled in a struggle."
"Honestly speaking, I don't believe that any effort on Gorbachev's part to hold the center can be successful," he said."I am afraid this powerful struggle could continue, and cause serious damage."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
New to Yanks, New to City, Old Hand in Cutting a Deal

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
After a hastily planned flight from North Carolina, baseball's newest millionaire, Brien Taylor, was finally able to rest with his family at a Manhattan hotel yesterday afternoon. They needed it.
In the previous 24 hours, a long-awaited deal with the New York Yankees had transformed Taylor from a 19-year-old would-be junior college pitcher to the highest paid player in the history of baseball's amateur draft.
 
Studied the Rules
 His plans had been altered, literally, overnight. The direction of his career had changed. Everything had changed, that is, except his family's sensibilities. Bettie Taylor, the mother of the left-handed pitcher who will soon be $1.55 million richer, stared at the movable table of empty room-service plates. 
 "Fifty dollars," her son said quietly, in wonder.
"Can you believe that?" Mrs. Taylor said, her tone rising with each word.
Mrs. Taylor's indignation over an expensive, though suddenly affordable, meal is entirely consistent with the character of the woman who as much as anyone was responsible for the record-setting deal her son will sign in New York today.
In a matter of months, Mrs. Taylor, a crab processor from Beaufort, N.C., made a quick study of the baseball industry and led her family through complex, intense and sometimes acrimonious negotiations with the most famous organization in professional sports.
The force of her will when confronting Yankee vice president and General Manager Gene Michael led to a stunning spiral in the Yankees' long-standing offer from $650,000 to the final agreement in a matter of days.
"Bettie Taylor, when she met with Gene Michael, was ready," said Scott Boras, the California-based agent who has advised the family since the Yankees drafted Taylor in June. "She was confident. She was fully apprised of the idiosyncrasies of major league baseball rules, the major league marketplace for draft picks, the value of Brien Taylor to teams other than the Yankees, and the varied options available to him if he attended college."
Taylor's contract firmly established a million-dollar value for a teen-age prospect whose triumphs have been limited to high school games, the latest distressing development for baseball executives seeking to limit the size of contracts.
As a result,their work could have a profound affect on athletes at a level that once held the least negotiating leverage -- high school athletes faced with choice of a college or a major league organization. While highly publicized lucrative contracts in the late 1950's and early 60's led to the establishment of the amateur draft in 1965, the entry-level contracts have often been dwarfed by free-agent agreements secured by veteran players.
But these days outstanding pitching is at an ever-increasing premium, which can only rise again when the National League adds two expansion clubs for the 1993 season.
The high school market first jumped beyond a million dollars last year when a Texas high school pitcher named Todd Van Poppel, also represented by Boras, signed a deal with the Oakland Athletics for $1.2 million. Although the Taylor family insisted that Brien deserved the same kind of money, the Yankees resisted, and baseball executives across the country held out hope that the Yankees could hold the line against escalating salaries.
 
Met With Michael
 Mrs. Taylor's relationship with the Yankees could have reached the breaking point in late July, after she wondered publicly whether the long impasse in contract negotiations may have been the result of an effort by the Yankees to take advantage of a poor, black family.
She maintained today that her thought had been misinterpreted as a suggestion that Michael was acting in a racist manner. "I'm a poor black woman," she said. "Why would that thought occur to me? It was just a thought, and I expressed it."
Mrs. Taylor said that her questions were erased upon meeting Michael a week ago, during a one-on-one meeting in a home economics room at East Carteret High School in Beaufort.
"He seemed like a nice guy," she remembered, "and he seemed not really all that different from where we were coming from. He gave me the impression. Maybe there was a time in his life when things were not great, either."
The suddenly open lines of communication gave the two sides an opportunity to solve an issue that became more complicated than money. In addition to the money (which Taylor will receive in two installments, one this year and one next), the Taylors wanted a major league contract, which would have guaranteed that Taylor could rise to the major league level in three years. The Yankees had insisted that such a demand would have required the organization to unnecessarily protect Taylor before his arrival in the major leagues, and could have led to the loss of more experienced players, particularly in the expansion draft next year.
Last Saturday, during a discussion between Boras and Michael, the obstacle began to be removed when the agent said the biggest consideration was the money, not the type of contract.
"At that point," Boras remembered, "Gene, I believe, said, 'You mean you're not demanding a major-league contract?' "
Boras and the family eventually arrived at a higher money figure to compensate for their concession. The Yankees agreed to a separate letter that claimed the organization would not take advantage of a clause in the standard minor league contract that allows an agreement to be voided within a 90-day period in the event of an injury. Taylor is scheduled to undergo a physical today to demonstrate that such a clause is uncecessary.
By the 10 hours of negotiations on Monday, fax transmissions were flying in all directions, to and from points extending coast-to-coast: the Yankee offices in the Bronx, the commissioner's office in Manhattan, Boras's hotel in Atlanta and his office in Southern California.
There would be a deal. Boras glanced at his watch at 5:55 Monday afternoon, and suddenly remembered a potential deal-breaker that would have been as comical as it was expensive.
 
Awaiting Instructions
 Mrs. Taylor had wanted to know by 6 P.M. if she should attempt to reach her son at Louisburg with instructions for Tuesday morning: Either attend the tennis class, and thereby reduce the Yankee opportunity to sign him, according to baseball regulations, to a small period next spring. Or he should prepare to come home.
Boras remembered telling Yankee vice president Leonard Kleinman: "You know, I almost forgot. You better call Bettie Taylor and advise her we have a deal in principle. Otherwise we might not be able to get a hold of Brien, and he'll go to class."
The connection was made. Bettie Taylor told her son he was coming home only to turn around and head for New York.
The airplane departed from North Carolina yesterday morning. Suddenly Taylor and his parents possessed first-class tickets to a new world. As if by magic, there would suddenly appear grown men waiting to carry his luggage, hotel food delivered to his door for the asking, and the promise of a long-awaited trip to Yankee Stadium scheduled to take place this afternoon. There will be introductions, and a tour, and his signature on a $1.55 million contract, the richest an amateur player has signed in the history of the game.
First, however, as the plane eased lower and lower in its final approach to La Guardia, there was a small problem with Taylor's first visit to New York City. Where was it? "I saw the water," Taylor said softly, with more wonder than fear. "I kept looking for the landing strip. I said, 'I don't see a landing strip."'
And then, like everything else in the previous 18 hours, it was there. After twelve weeks of strategic diversions, verbal storms and unscheduled delays in an economic relationship with the Yankees, Taylor finally made his smooth landing.

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:

'Metallica'
Metallica's first album in three years has squashed all opposition on the charts. In its first week, "Metallica" sold 2.2 million copies, easily moving into the top slot on Billboard's charts and bumping another Elektra act, Natalie Cole, into the No. 2 position. "Metallica" outsold Ms. Cole's "Unforgettable" 3 to 1. The Wiz had its biggest single-day sale in 10 years with the album, and other major chains also reported record-breaking sales. 
 "In my 20-year career, I have never seen a record go this quickly," said Kenny Hamlin, the senior vice president for sales at Elektra Records. "Based on the history of the band and our projections for it, we were prepared, but we did have to place an additional production order. We had ordered 1.4 million copies originally, but on top of that initial shipment, we received a reorder for 800,000 copies in the next 4 days."
That the top two records in America are a hard-rock album and an album of standards makes nothing clear culturally but does underscore a reversal of fortunes for Elektra Records, which had a dry period before Ms. Cole's success. In the short history of the new tabulating system for Billboard's charts, huge early sales -- as for N.W.A.'s "Efil4zaggin" -- have often been followed by a precipitate fall from first place after hard-core fans leave the record stores. "Metallica," a more mainstream album than usual for the band, seems calculated to go further, and the band's managers, Cliff Burnstein and Peter Mensch, are generally thought of as being among the shrewdest in the hard-rock business.
 
Cajun Music
 When Luderin Darbone, the violinist, started his band, the Hackberry Ramblers, in 1933 in southwest Louisiana, the term Cajun was derogatory. Things have changed for Mr. Darbone, who is 79 years old. "My dad and mother talked French when I was growing up," Mr. Darbone said in a telephone interview from his home in Sulphur, La. "When it was time to start school, my mother said, 'There won't be any more French, just English.' People looked down on Cajun people. Now the name is an honor in this part of the country."
The band, which is playing its first show outside Louisiana in nearly 30 years this weekend at Tramps, presents a strange hybrid of Western swing, jazz, Cajun and country music that reflects some of the cultural and economic pressures to assimilate that French-speaking people felt in the 1930's. Mr. Darbone, who moved to Texas with his parents (his father worked in the oil industry), began learning country tunes at dances. When the family moved back to Louisiana they settled in Hackberry, close to the Duhone family. Edward Duhone, the guitarist and accordionist, who will also be at Tramps, and Mr. Darbone became friends and musical compatriots. Mr. Duhone, who is 81, brought Cajun music to the duo. Though they were one of the most popular bands in French-speaking Louisiana, they kept their day jobs and never traveled much out of the area.
"I figure Tramps is hiring us to play Cajun music, so 90 percent of what we play will be Cajun, plus some instrumentals and a country number or two," Mr. Darbone said. "I liked country better, but now Cajun music is going nationwide and we have lots of demand for it, and I really enjoy it. We get regular festival jobs in Louisiana, but mostly we now donate our time playing for the elderly or at nursing homes. It's like therapy to them. Most of those people used to come to our dances and now they're in wheelchairs. It makes us feel good to see them tapping their feet or getting out of the chairs to make a few dance steps."
 
The Illustrated Dead
 The Grateful Dead are as iconic as any band around, and their songs are filled with visions of loners, criminals and drifters. The Dead's album covers and concert posters have always had a relationship to the comic culture of the group's home town, San Francisco, so it's no surprise to find that Kitchen Sink Comix (No. 2 Swamp Road, Princeton, Wis. 54968) has commissioned a new line called Grateful Dead Comix. Issue No. 1 features four songs -- "Dire Wolf," "Terrapin Station," "One More Saturday Night" and "Casey Jones" -- set to illustrations. It has sold 50,000 copies.
"Several members in the band are comics fans," said Denis Kitchen, the publisher. "Jerry Garcia is avid, and when the band first made a bit of money, he bought a complete set of EC Comics. He's followed underground comics, and he'd wanted to do it for 20 years."
The first edition, printed on recycled paper and using soybean ink ("a very tasty product if stir-fried with a little tarragon and basil," reads a small note in the beginning of the comic), was pleasing enough to the band for Kitchen Sink to plan an indefinite series. And where the first issue reproduces the songs visually, other issues will illustrate anecdotes, or review concerts; the possibilities will be endless. The first four issues will be collected and released by Disney Books.
"Of all the bands out there playing, we could most naturally tap into the Dead," Mr. Kitchen said. "The cartoonists are in the same age group as the band. We all started in the late 1960's. Just like the band are fans of underground comics, the cartoonists were fans of the band. And I just read in Newsweek the band has grossed the most of any touring band this year. So the audience is there. We know that."

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Calypso, Past and Present, As Two Veterans See It

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
Kavery Dutta's "One Hand Don't Clap," opening today at the Village East Cinema, is a sweet, lilting documentary on the history and present state of calypso and its more recent spinoff, soca, defined as calypso with soul.
Ms. Dutta concentrates on two key figures: Lord Kitchener, born 70-some years ago in Trinidad as Aldwyn Roberts, who introduced calypso to London in 1948, becoming an internationally known performing artist and composer, and Calypso Rose, born in Tobago in 1940 as McCartha Sandy, who is said to be the first woman to become calypso star. 
 They are a most engaging pair, whether seen on screen separately or together. Lord Kitchener, a big man with a wide, toothy smile, talks easily about the Afro-Caribbean origins of calypso, what he thinks of soca and Harry Belafonte's influence on making calypso popular in the 1950's.
Calypso Rose, who looks a little like a Caribbean version of Roseanne Barr, has something of Ms. Barr's humor and, when interviewed, her self-conscious gravity.
Both performers, though, only really come to life when they are performing. The film carries snatches of the two singers on the soundtrack throughout the film, and some complete numbers done for the camera.
Sitting at a Trinidad racetrack, Lord Kitchener and an old pal, Lord Pretender, talk about their early days. Both express reservations about today's calypso style. Lord Pretender has no time for lyrics that don't rhyme and what he sees as the laziness of the singers, "A man sing a line, the music play five minutes."
Calypso Rose, who now lives in New York, feels strongly about the social importance of her songs, which, as she says, carry on the calypso tradition of "domestical, spiritual, economical and political" commentary. Her show-stopping moment onstage is strictly domestical. Wearing a gold lame pants suit, she sings and shakes her way through "Solomon," a bawdy number about a man who is thoroughly no good.
Lord Kitchener's great moment arrives near the end of the film when he appears on the stage of the Calypso Revue, his club in Port of Spain, to sing and dance "Pillow Fight," which uproariously recalls another battle between the sexes.
"One Hand Don't Clap" uses the carnival in Trinidad as its climactic sequence, crosscutting among the various calypso events, featuring new performers, and the great Mardi Gras parade in Port of Spain.
There is one major problem for anyone whose ear is not attuned to the Caribbean accent: many of the calypso lyrics and a lot of the words in the interviews are virtually unintelligible. Reviewers were furnished with a dialogue script.
The film's title is taken from a remark made by Calypso Rose when she acknowledges that without the help and advice of Lord Kitchener, she would never have reached the top. As she tells her mentor, "One hand don't clap."
 
One Hand Don't Clap
 
Directed and edited by Kavery Dutta; director of photography, Don Lenzer and Alicia Weber; music by various composers; produced by Ms. Dutta and Bhupender Kaul; a Rhapsody Films Presentation of a Riverfilms Production. At the Village East Cinema, Second Avenue and 12th Street. Running time: 92 minutes. This film has no rating.
 
WITH: Lord Kitchener, Calypso Rose, Black Stalin, David Rudder, Mighty Duke, Natasha Wilson, Lord Pretender and Growling Tiger

SECTION: Section B; Page 19; Column 3; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 1636 words

HEADLINE: As Life Changes, So Does Freshman Orientation

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
A college education used to begin with a quick and casual freshman orientation: There usually was a barbecue, followed by a big dance and finally a rambling campus tour led by a bored sophomore.
Now orientation has evolved into an intense social and intellectual initiation that combines aspects of academic boot camp and cultural finishing school. 
 These programs, which are being instituted at hundreds of colleges and universities for the first time this year, are comprehensive, well-structured courses that can last up to a year, not small-scale experiments like AIDS seminars or study skills classes that many institutions have been trying.
They mark the growing realization among administrators that real-world problems, like race relations, are intruding on campus life more and more. They also realize that the entire freshman-year experience is crucial to a student's chances for success and a college's ability to sustain enrollment, particularly at a time when one of three freshmen does not return to the same school for sophomore year.
 
Outside the Curriculum
 While still including basic introductions like class registration and a library run-through, freshmen orientations on many campuses this week are exposing new students at once to delicate subjects like date rape, drug abuse, race relations and how freshmen, some from small towns and tiny high schools, are supposed to deal with them.
"It has been a surprise," one freshman, J. Dale Cannedy from Midland, Tex., said of his first few days at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., where orientation lasts three weeks. "They treat you much more like an adult. They're not afraid to broach the subjects of sexuality, substance abuse and harassment."
While colleges and universities are concerned with preparing first-year students for campus life, they have another motive for paying special attention to freshmen. Colleges, now scrambling to fill their classes, hate to lose students they might have retained.
"The economics of higher education helped produce this, and anyone who doesn't admit it is not telling the truth," said Richard K. Matthews, a professor of government at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., who directs the study program for first-year students. "This is a much more competitive market."
 
Freshmen Get 'Our Best'
 Lehigh pampers freshmen throughout the year by overturning some fairly common traditions. While freshman survey classes at Lehigh were once taught in large lecture halls by junior faculty, the college of arts and sciences this year has set aside 34 seminars in which enrollment is limited to 16 freshmen and only full-time faculty will be allowed to teach.
"We want them to have our best," Professor Matthews said.
Freshmen have not always been treated with such care. John N. Gardner, vice chancellor of the University of South Carolina at Columbia, has studied the freshman-year experience at colleges around the country for more than 15 years. In previous generations, he said, first-year students, feeling lost and overwhelmed, lived in the oldest dorms, ate the worst food, sat in the largest lecture halls and generally were left to sink or swim.
Professor Gardner said such a policy might have worked when most freshmen were more or less alike: privileged white men whose parents were college-educated. But that changed as colleges admitted more and more women, and again when minority students and those from lower-income families, with varying degrees of academic preparedness, arrived on campus.
 
Basic Training of Sorts
 Suddenly, orientation had to be taken seriously as a kind of basic training for students. The strategy appears to have been succeessful. Professor Gardner said studies by many institutions, including South Carolina, have shown that students who participate in orientation have a significantly higher survival rate and are more likely to graduate than those who founder through the first critical weeks on campus alone.
Professor Gardner conceded that since participation at orientation often is voluntary, students who joined organizations and did well in high school -- and thus who could be expected to survive well at college in the first place -- might be more likely to take part in orientation. But he said that research at the University of South Carolina had shown that high school students who took part in many activities were neither more nor less likely to take part in freshman orientation.
At the University of South Carolina, freshmen receive one of the most thorough orientations, a semester-long course called University 101, which has become a model for many other institutions. It is a three-credit elective, graded on a pass-fail basis, in which students are taught scholastic basics like how to use the library, and modern college survival skills like dealing with acquaintance rape. Students are graded on the papers they write and exams they take.
 
Tackling Moral Issues
 If University 101 represents the hard-line approach to orientation, the University of Pennsylvania's Bacchae project is the soft sell, focusing on academic preparation but also subtly counseling students on modern moral issues.
The principle underlying the project is the need to introduce students to an intellectual life in which ideas are lived, not just learned. Penn freshmen read the classic Greek drama "The Bacchae" about the ancient cult of Dionysus and discuss it in their dorms and in seminar groups. Some elective courses will cover the play, which will be performed next spring.
"Many of these students may never have sat around a table and talked about a book," said Norman T. Adler, associate dean for the School of Arts and Sciences. "My job is to show these kids the passion of the mind."
Selecting such a canonical work of Western civilization as "The Bacchae" by Euripides nearly killed the project, but many faculty members first objected to the ancient drama because it seemed antithetical to current concerns over multiculturalism. Later, these faculty members agreed that the play's treatment of cults, religions and beliefs touched on many cultures and made it contemporary.
 
Provocative Drama at Cornell
 While Penn's project ends with the production of a play, a similar project at Cornell begins with a provocative drama. During orientation, incoming students watched a live performance of "Miss Evers' Boys," a play, based on an actual incident, about a group of black men who became unwitting medical guinea pigs for a Federal study of syphilis. The freshmen then break into small groups, continuing the discussion in their dorms.
Cornell officials say they hope that by talking about the ethical issues raised in the play, which was written by David Feldshuh, a Cornell professor, new students will come to understand people who are different from themselves.
Officials at the University of Louisville have found that it sometimes is easier to reach students by promising fun rather than facts. Dr. Madelyn J. Jacobs, the university's director of student health services, said that for years she delivered serious dorm talks about contraceptives. Men showed up in droves but women generally stayed away.
Three years ago, Dr. Jacobs started a new session for the women that she advertised as a pajama party. Sitting on the floor, she chats with them about college life while gently steering the conversation to the serious topics of contraception, sexuality and AIDS.
"It takes a little longer to get the conversation to where we were headed, but when we get there it really means something to them," Dr. Jacobs said.
Dr. Jacobs said the encounter sessions have helped raise the awareness of date rape at Louisville and the willingness of women not to be silent victims of it. In 1989, there were 11 reported incidents. Last year, after orientation covered rape for the first time, the number of reports increased to 60, suggesting to college officials that women were more likely to report a rape, not that more rapes had occurred.
 
Over the Mountains
 Freshmen at the University of Puget Sound in Tacoma, Wash., learn something about themselves by hiking along a mountain ridge for three days. Robert H. Stremba, director of counseling and co-ordinator of the backpacking program, remembered one student's surprise at having hiked over a mountain with a heavy backpack for the first time. "He told me, 'Now that I know I can do that, I know I can do other things, like taking a couple of midterms in one week,' " Mr. Stremba said.
The academic portion of Puget Sound's orientation is based on a successful and widely copied program at Bard College. Bard freshmen spend the last three weeks of summer on campus reading critically, writing intensively and discussing controversial topics like censorship and bilingualism.
The program appears to have been instrumental in helping Bard keep its students. Before it began in 1981, about 70 percent of the freshman class came back the second year, a rate slightly better than the national average. After the program's start, the retention rate rose to 85 percent.
The benefits of these sophisticated new orientation programs may not be immediately evident to the freshmen themselves. Margaret G. O'Connell, a sophomore from Wilmington, Vt., said she felt she had not gained much from her three-week intellectual summer camp during her tumultuous first year at Bard. But returning this summer to tutor new students in the program made her think otherwise. It was much easier for her to organize her thoughts, form opinions and deal with new people than it was for this year's freshmen, she said.
"In retrospect," Miss O'Connell said, "I see how much all that helped. At the time I just didn't want to do it."
