HEADLINE: Polite Robber, Kind Till End, Goes to Police

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
An unemployed oil company worker surrendered to the police today in a widely publicized conclusion to a case that involved a string of nearly 100 robberies of hotel guests in Texas and Louisiana, all said to have been commited by a criminal dubbed the "gentleman bandit" by law-enforcement officers.
The authorities said the robberies were carried out by a man distinguished by his dapper attire and courteous manner, who was said to have apologized profusely to his victims, sometimes calling them at home to be sure they had recovered from the ordeal and once calling an ambulance for a man who had a heart attack during a robbery. 
 A statement circulated Friday by lawyers for the man who surrendered to the police, Lon B. Perry, 49 years old, said his action was motivated by pangs of conscience after he learned in June that another man fitting his description had been arrested for the robberies, which occurred over two years.
The surrender was attended by a throng of reporters and jostling photographers, many of them in town for the beginning of the trial of Wanda Webb Hollaway, who allegedly tried to win a spot on a high school cheerleading squad for her daughter by arranging the murder of a rival's mother.
 
Tabloids and Public Radio
 Representatives of everything from British tabloids to the syndicated television show "A Current Affair" to National Public Radio gathered outside police headquarters to await the arrival of the man who reportedly took the names and addresses of all the people he robbed, promising to pay them back someday.
In a statement made public by his lawyer, Allen C. Isbell, Mr. Perry asserted that he had fallen into a deep depression after being laid off as a computer programmer at the Texas Eastern Corporation, an oil and gas pipeline company, in December 1988.
In the statement, Mr. Perry contended that he turned to robbery when he found himself nearing age 50, with a son in college, a mortgage and back taxes to pay, and without the necessary background needed to switch to a job in computers with another company.
Mr. Isbell had announced Friday that Mr. Perry would turn himself in today after spending the weekend saying goodbye to his family.
"He wanted to turn himself in right away, but we advised him to negotiate a plea before he did so," he said. "He will plead guilty to several of the robberies, and will help police clear the rest of them with his confession, in exchange for a 35-year sentence."
Mr. Perry was charged with two counts of aggravated robbery and was being held in city jail on $200,000 bond, said Sgt. Richard Retz.
Speaking about the intense news media fascination with the case, Rick Hartley, a spokesman for the Houston police, said, "They say they're here for the cheerleader trial, but they all seem to love this case."
As one television cameraman explained it: "He lost a job in the oil business. He was friendly and nice when he robbed people. How Texan can you get?"

HEADLINE: Bush Approves Storm-Relief Aid in 2 States

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 27

 BODY:
President Bush today authorized Federal disaster aid for Rhode Island and Massachusetts as a result of damage to public property by last week's hurricane.
He designated both states as major disaster areas. 
 In Rhode Island, the action makes Federal assistance available to help restore public services in all of the state's affected counties. In Massachusetts, the aid will be used in four eastern counties -- Barnstable, Bristol, Essex and Middlesex.
In both states, Federal funds will be made available in affected areas for disaster unemployment compensation for workers who lose their jobs as a result of the hurricane.
The American Insurance Services Group Inc., a trade group, estimated on Monday that the hurricane caused $780 million damage to insured property when it swept up the East Coast on Aug. 18 and 19.
Over all, the largest losses occurred in Massachusetts, with $525 million in insured damage; followed by Rhode Island, $115 million; New York State, $75 million; Connecticut, $40 million; Maine, $21 million, and North Carolina, $4 million.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Whitehurst's Collapse Gives Mets One More To Forget About

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
For Wally Whitehurst, the chance he waited a lifetime for has become the fiasco he can't end.
Whitehurst, after a long and dutiful apprenticeship, was anointed a regular starter for the Mets last month. The right-hander, though, has been a regular flop ever since. 
 In his latest pratfall, Whitehurst tonight was singed for five runs over the first three innings in an 8-3 loss to the Astros, a defeat that is certain to endanger his status as a starter of the future.
"I couldn't care what happens, and you can print that," Whitehurst told reporters after the game.
The dismantling of Whitehurst, marking the sixth straight start in which he has failed to last more than five innings, left his record at 0-6 since July 15, the date on which the Mets traded Ron Darling and thereby issued what at the moment was their complete endorsement of Whitehurst as a critical component of their team.
"He has not done what we expected him to," Manager Bud Harrelson had said of Whitehurst before the game. "I expected more quality starts."
The only quality Whitehurst has demonstrated has been the unfortunate one of consistency. He's been inadequate almost every time out. Tonight, the first man he faced singled, as did the second, and the most recent rampage against Whitehurst's fastball was on.
The Astros scored two runs in the first, another two in the second when they sent seven men to the plate against Whitehurst, and a single run in the third. Pete Schourek came on to start the fifth in place of Whitehurst and was cuffed for three runs in one inning.
"I thought he deserved better," Harrelson said. Asked if he was then satisfied with Whitehurst's work, Harrelson bluntly said, "No."
Whitehurst, who started tonight for the injured Dwight Gooden because he had lasted only two innings in his last start, thus had five full innings to digest the latest lamentable tabulation of his numbers. Since the All-Star break, Whitehurst, 5-10 on the season, has worked 312/3 innings and given up 44 hits and 25 runs for an earned run average of 7.11.
"I've got a plan for next time -- I'm going to pitch left-handed," said Whitehurst with a smirk.
Harrelson, asked if Whitehurst's performance could be earning him a return trip to the bullpen, said cryptically before the game that it would be another option considered at the end of the season. Asked directly after the game if Whitehurst would make his next scheduled start this season, Harrelson said, "We'll see." He conceded that his options included a flip-flop of Whitehurst with Schourek or the promotion and regular use of of a minor-leaguer like Anthony Young when the rosters expand in September.
"I'm not going to do anything crazy -- at least not until the numbers say I can," said Harrelson.
Whatever the fallout amounts to, the last six weeks have been a terrible personal deflation for Whitehurst. The 27-year-old, after a patient apprenticeship during which he never complained about his status or the switched services he was constantly asked to provide, thought he had at last entered the stage as a major player with Darling's trade.
"I got named the fifth starter, and the bottom fell out," said Whitehurst. "I don't know what to say. At least I don't know what to say that's printable."
Harrelson's quiet threat about his future as a starter being in trouble could be more bluff than anything else. There is every chance the Mets will not re-sign Frank Viola after this season, a development that will only deplete further an organization no longer all that deep in starting talent.
"A lot will be rethought after the season," said Harrelson.
Tonight, Harrelson tried as best he could not to think about what he'd just seen -- the Mets lose to Darryl Kile, stranding 11 men in the process, the Mets commit two more errors.
"They're all starting to look alike," the manager said of the losses.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 KEVIN McREYNOLDS, surprised at the lack of swelling in his sprained left ankle, said he hoped he'd wind up missing no more than a couple of games. X-Rays of the left-fielder's left ankle late this afternoon were negative., and McReynolds was walking with no great limp in the clubhouse before the game. "It's nowhere near as sore as I thought it would be," he said. . . . DWIGHT GOODEN said he experienced fatigue in his right shoulder while throwing in the outfield Monday, although he said he didn't know how it might affect his scheduled start on Sunday. . . . Manager Bud Harrelson said he could envision Mackey Sasser becoming a bona fide part-time right fielder for the Mets next season. "I'm amazed at how well he's played out there," Harrelson said of Sasser.

HEADLINE: Testing Waters, Wilder Says America's Needs Come First

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 27

 BODY:
Testing the waters for a campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia came to New Hampshire today with an appeal to "put America first," asserting that the nation could not neglect its own fiscal and economic problems while facing the crises in the Soviet Union and elsewhere in the world.
In a speech to a state treasurers' convention, the text of which was later made available by the Wilder campaign, Mr. Wilder declared, "We cannot focus all our energies on the international arena at the expense of America's finances and economic health." He added, "This neglect can no longer be tolerated." 
 Mr. Wilder, who has sought to portray himself as a voice of fiscal responsibility in his party, outlined a "Put America First" initiative that would cut $50 billion from the annual Federal budget and provide $35 billion in tax breaks for the middle class and $15 billion to state and local governments for new approaches to social problems like drug abuse. He did not provide details on where the $50 billion in cuts would be found.
 
'Put Your Household First'
 The Governor dismissed the notion that his new campaign slogan, which has strong echoes of past isolationist movements in the United States, was an appeal to isolationist sentiments. It simply means, he told a group in Nashua this afternoon, that "you put your household first." He said that as he campaigned on Nashua's streets, "We heard from people today who asked us, 'Why not Americans First?' "
He added: "It's so important to remember that if jobs are going to be found, why not jobs for Americans? If schools are going to be built, why not schools for Americans?"
Mr. Wilder's themes on the first of a two-day swing through New Hampshire reflected the Democrats' attempts to turn the focus to domestic issues, where President Bush is considered vulnerable, even in the midst of the crisis in the Soviet Union. The Governor showed no inclination to tangle with Mr. Bush over foreign policy today.
"I would concede that I have no criticism at all of the President relative to what foreign policy initiatives to undertake," Mr. Wilder told reporters. But the Governor, who is expected to announce next month whether he will seek the Democratic nomination, said he believed that domestic issues were of paramount importance to the American people.

	--------------------	 	
 
Nebraska Senator Is Considering
 WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska "has put himself on a timetable to make a decision in the next several weeks" on whether to seek the 1992 Democratic Presidential nomination, his spokesman said today.
The spokesman, Steven Jarding, said Mr. Kerrey was actively considering a run for the nomination because of recent decisions against running by Senators Al Gore of Tennessee and John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia. In Nebraska last weekend, Mr. Kerrey himself said, "I'm beginning to concentrate on the slimness of the field."
The only declared candidate for the Democratic nomination is former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, although Governor Wilder and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas have both formed exploratory committees.

HEADLINE: After Blackout at A-Plant, a New Wariness

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCRIBA, N.Y.

 BODY:
The control room went dark on a Tuesday morning while the dawn sprang gray on Lake Ontario. The nuclear plant sent off a whooping siren that seemed to fall from the sky. It was said to have spooked the cows, but it settled on the house trailers and the front porches and the ballfields like a soft net. The town barely stirred.
By late morning, however, men and women in Scriba, were sharing the news: This had been no routine warning to ignore in your sleep. There had been real chaos up the road at Nine Mile Point in the depths of the Unit 2 reactor, where a group of operators, sitting in a windowless chamber, had been at the mercy of a master panel that suddenly turned blank. 
 In the age of Shoreham and other plants that have been waylaid by community protest, people here have largely clung to a trust in the officials who manage Nine Mile Point. Now, for one of the few times since the 455-foot cooling tower rose on their shore Kong-like 17 years ago, people are angry and openly afraid.
"We used to ignore the alarms," said Carl Carpenter, standing in the driveway of his house three-quarters of a mile from the plant.
"Everyone's got a brother or a sister or a son or a daughter working there, and we were always told there was nothing to worry about. But the room went dark. What's the whole story?"
Officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Agency have since swept in to declare the incident on Aug. 13 -- a loss of power caused by a surge in an electrical transformer -- one of the most serious at an American nuclear plant. Yesterday the agency said that dead batteries in backup power sources were the underlying problem. But even the plant engineers, while issuing assurances that no radioactivity escaped into the atmosphere, have acknowledged that there were several moments when they were not sure how close the plant was to real danger.
Still, Mr. Carpenter and others said they would not be chased from their homes. Theirs is a curious kind of rationalizing in the face of unknown risk.
"I also look at it this way," Mr. Carpenter said. "If something happens, we live to the south. And, thankfully, the winds blow east."
Many people in Scriba, as well as in Oswego, six miles to the west. now say they have grown wary of the explanations offered by the Niagara Mohawk Corporation, which operates the three reactors at Nine Mile Point. Unit 2, in particular, has prompted the most concern. It has one of the poorest records of any reactor in the country -- in operation only 39.4 percent of the time.
Residents said that during other emergencies the company had played down the urgency, only to come forth later to say that the risk was greater than first believed. Still, many of these people said that the plant provided too many economic benefits to the region to warrant being closed. Operations at the plant have been suspended while the company decides when to restart.
 
'You Have to Be Afraid'
 "When the power goes out like that, you have to be afraid," said Ellen O'Brien, a retired office worker. "But where are you going to go in this world without risk? To New York City? There's too much crime. To another rural area? Chances are there's also a nuclear reactor or some such thing."
The response of the community, nuclear experts said, is typical.
"There are four factors at work: financial desperation, fatalism, geographical bonds and ignorance, " said Karl Grossman, a journalism professor at the State University of New York's College at Old Westbury L.I., who has written two books about the nuclear industry.
Here and in Oswego, the debate typically centers on how to make use of the tax dividends provided by Nine Mile Point. The schools have modern auditoriums, the parks are pristine and functional, and the whole town, once rugged and a bit antiquated, now has an efficient, utopian feel. Until two weeks ago, said Donald Vanouse, an English professor at Oswego State University, hardly anyone got riled up over the reactor, which he called "our monstrous neighbor."
Mr. Carpenter stood with his wife, Pauline, in front of the house they bought 23 years ago on Lycoming Road. Back then, they said, maybe three cars would pass each day. Now there is constant traffic as workers make their way to and from the plant.
 
A New Unease Apparent
 Mr. Carpenter, 71 years old, said that before retiring, he worked three jobs to support 10 children. His only passions have been his family and the 1938 Buick Special he has restored in the garage. He worked decades at a clip without a day off, decades that seemed to have lasted as long as that day's lunch, he said.
"Until now," he said, "I accepted what the plant people said, because I never had time."
Clearly a kind of fog seems to have settled over his house since the problem at the plant.
"When that thing goes," his wife said, "We're going to be fried right here on the porch."
Their daughter, Shirley, 39, said she had long been imagining a catastrophe, but she said, it had never been fashionable to talk about it.
"It will be just like I saw it in a movie on TV," she said. "The sky will turn yellow, and everything else in the town will turn dark. There will be men in white suits, and they'll be looking for bodies and deciding who's living and who's dead."
She did not speak about her vision until after the events of Aug. 13. It was something that had often run through her like a quiet shudder.
"Now I can't get rid of the feeling," she said. "It's with me all the time."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 30, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about problems with a nuclear reactor in Scriba, N.Y., referred incorrectly to the operation of three nuclear plants there. The New York Power Authority, a state agency, operates the James A. FitzPatrick Nuclear Power Plant. The Niagara Mohawk Corporation operates two reactors at the Nine Mile Point plant.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
A Mosaic of Motives: The West's Response to Baltic Quest for Independence

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 27

 BODY:
The variety of Western responses to the prospect of Baltic independence reflects a mosaic of self-interest, geopolitical currents and domestic political pressures.
 For the second day in a row, President Bush's cautious moves on the issue stood in sharp contrast to other nations' responses, like Scandinavia's rush last week to establish diplomatic relations with the Baltic republics to the European Community's concerted action today to formally recognize Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia as independent countries. 
There were signs that Washington was feeling pressure on the Baltics as Robert S. Strauss, the new Ambassador to Moscow, briefed Mr. Bush here on his trip to the Soviet Union. Both men both hinted that American action on the Baltics could come on Friday, and Administration officials later said they expected the Soviet Parliament to take some action by then.
 
Clearer for Near Neighbors
 Throughout the last eight days, Mr. Bush's native prudence and his conviction that American actions carry more weight than those of other countries in a volatile situation have dominated Washington's decision-making.
 For the Baltic republics' immediate neighbors, the choice has been clearest, driven by their proximity, by a sense of ideological debt and by years of increasingly close cooperation between the Baltics and themselves.
 But for some of the economic powers of Europe -- Britain, France and Germany -- the equation has been considerably more complex.
 The splintering of the Soviet empire added a potentially troublesome element to a question with which the Continent has been grappling for two years: how to integrate the former members of the Communist bloc into its political and economic structure.
Keenly aware of the financial implications of the sudden appearance of three struggling new nations on the northern flank and eager to maintain unity in their foreign policies, the powers chose to act in concert through the European Community, rather than have any one nation shoulder a disproportionate burden by acting alone.
 Moreover, for some Governments, like Italy's, recognizing the Baltics was a gesture that soothed domestic irritation with their failure to take a stronger stand against the plotters, European officials said.
 In the United States, the prospect of Baltic independence forced Mr. Bush to confront, however reluctantly, basic questions about America's new role as the only remaining nuclear superpower, about Washington's relationship with its old ideological adversary and about the President's personal ties to Soviet leaders.
 Although he risks ceding, even temporarily, the leadership role he has sought over the last year, Mr. Bush has so far chosen the safe approach, allowing Moscow to sort out its own relations with its republics.
 The President and his aides have said they fear that acting "precipitously" might upset the delicate balance that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is trying to strike with the republics and with President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic.
 Despite the increasing powers of Mr. Yeltsin, the Bush Administration is still driven by a fundamental desire to shore up Mr. Gorbachev. American officials said today that the President did not want to force Mr. Gorbachev's hand.
 "There is an element that says, 'Let's not put anything more on Gorbachev's plate while he is somehow trying to pull out of this nosedive,' " an official said.
 Beyond that, officials said, are practical considerations. If the United States establishes diplomatic relations with the Baltics before the Soviet Union granted their independence, Mr. Bush fears that other republics would seek the same thing, they said.
 "If we recognize the Baltics, the Ukrainians, the Moldavians and the Georgians will say, 'Do the same for us,' " an official said. "But if the Soviet Parliament votes, then we can say there was a constitutional process and we're simply recognizing that."
 Another official said: "The interesting thing here is that we don't only run the risk of getting out ahead of Gorbachev, but also of getting out ahead of Yeltsin. He's recognized Baltic independence, but hasn't worked out what to do about the Ukraine and the other republics, not to mention the minorities within Russia itself."
 These considerations were at the core of Mr. Bush's talk this week of America's "special responsibilities" as he explained why he was staying his hand at recognizing the Baltics.
 American officials took heart in an interview given by President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania today to NBC News, in which he seemed unconcerned about Mr. Bush's pace. "We can wait a little more," Mr. Landsbergis said.
 But American officials acknowledge that their maneuvering room is shrinking, as pressure builds from Europe and at home to recognize the Baltics.
 As a result, officials said, the United States was waiting for the Soviet Parliament to grant independence. But the body that can do that, the Congress of People's Deputies, will not meet until next week. The officials stopped short of saying Mr. Bush would act on his own if Soviet lawmakers did not solve his problem for him by Friday as expected.
 There has been some division of opinion in the Administration about how to proceed with the Baltics, officials said, with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney urging swifter recognition, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, counseling the more reserved approach.
 "A lot of people find it somewhat difficult to understand why there should be such hesitation, now that there isn't nearly the same question of offending Gorbachev or the central Government," an official said.
 European diplomats said that there was sympathy in their capitals for Washington's position, but that most European governments felt they could not wait to move.
 For instance, Germany, which has been pressing hard for the West to establish relations with the three subjugated republics, has fresh memories of its own struggle for unification.
 But the Germans, who are the biggest donors of foreign aid to the Soviet Union as they work to ease the removal of Soviet troops from the eastern part of their country, did not want to act on their own, the diplomats said.
 "There is a strong sense these days that the European Community must have a distinct foreign policy if it is truly to be the unifying force on the Continent, and so everything now is done at the community level," a diplomat said.

HEADLINE: In Flushing Council Contest, a Slice of Asian Politics

SERIES: Neighborhood Politics: Choosing the Council -- An occasional look at the
races for New York's new City Council.

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
Vito Dottone, a retired mailman, has spent more than 50 of his 71 years in Flushing. When he thinks about downtown these days, it pains him.
 "It looks like hell," he says. "It's really a disaster." There is too much traffic, filth and chaos. More and more, he says, his neighborhood is turning into an unwieldly Hong Kong. 
Fred Lin Sye would not have it any other way. As he meanders between tables at his Happy Dumpling restaurant just off Main Street, he vehemently defends the vital business district that he and his fellow immigrants have helped create.
 "What's wrong with Hong Kong?" the 62-year-old Mr. Sye says in a voice full of exasperation. "Asian people have put a lot of money in here. Business is good. Now, all of a sudden, people are saying there are too many Asians."
 Between Mr. Dottone and Mr. Sye -- between the old Flushing and the new -- stretch a welter of conflicts that quietly punctuate life in this fast-changing, wildly polyglot community. And as New York prepares to elect an expanded and perhaps more ethnically representative City Council, this interplay of new and old has become the rhythm of the District 20 campaign in Flushing.
 Among the candidates and on the streets, much of the talk is of change and development. Many of the old-time residents -- including Julia Harrison, the two-term Flushing Councilwoman -- say that development simply cannot continue at the same haphazard pace. Many of the newcomers -- including the Chinese candidate for the City Council -- counter that the huge immigrant arrivals have revitalized a dying neighborhood and should proceed unchallenged. In this season of openly ethnic politics, though, there is other talk as well -- about the dangers of polarization, and the hope of electing an Asian to represent Flushing at City Hall.
 But even though the Chinese and Korean immigrants have left such a prominent stamp on the economy -- and the consciousness -- of Flushing, they are still struggling to make an impact on the politics. District 20 was drawn to include a sizable number of Asians, but the Asians of Flushing are finding that they share a common problem with other minority groups in other parts of the city: Demographics alone cannot win an election. Although large in numbers, the Chinese and Koreans remain far less potent in the voting arena.
 Of the new district's 140,000 residents, 44 percent are white and about 31 percent are Asian. Yet whites make up three-quarters of the registered voters and Asians only 6.7 percent -- less than 500 of these registered voters are Chinese. The rest are Koreans and Indians. Both black and Hispanic registered voters constitute less than 10 percent each of the total.
 Although both Asian candidates have concentrated on heavy voter-registration drives, they also admit that the greatest goal of redistricting -- a greater number of minority voters -- may only be achieved a decade from now. Many of the Chinese and Koreans are either not yet citizens or they are wary of authority and politics. A few work in downtown Flushing but live elsewhere. And others are illegal aliens.
 "This is long-range planning," explained Augustine Chen, a community leader and a professor of physics at Saint John's University who helped draw District 20. "In redistricting we first achieve a numerical advantage."
 District 20 was created by cutting out the northern part of the old District 19 -- which was composed mostly of Jewish European immigrants and Irish Americans -- and tacking on to the south the largely Chinese and Korean contiguous populations that live around Kissena Park and the Long Island Expressway.
 
Waves of Immigrants
 Flushing was originally settled by whites of Irish and German descent that built small single-family homes. The black community first centered in what today is downtown Flushing -- their oldest church was founded in the 1830's -- and then filtered out gradually to other areas including three public-housing projects.
 The next large wave of immigrants came after World War II, with the arrival of European Jews. But it was in the 1970's that the area began to change dramatically as a huge influx of Chinese, Koreans, South Americans and Indians moved in. The most recent arrivals are Russian immigrants.
 Since 1980, while black and Hispanic populations have remained relatively stable, about 20 percent of the whites have moved out of the area and many more are talking about moving out because they claim that the quality of life has seriously deteriorated. In the residential areas outside of the din of downtown, many of the older white couples that have lived all their lives here say they refuse to shop in the downtown area because of the traffic and noise and now commute to Long Island instead.
 
Building Political Awareness
 Like other voters, they also worry about issues that are trumpeted by all the candidates. Property owners want lower taxes. There are traffic and sanitation problems, burglaries, robberies, larcenies and even prostitution. Chinese gangs have moved in from Chinatown and extort and steal from restaurants.
 On the surface, the District 20 race is calm. The favorite is Ms. Harrison, whose consituency among her white voter base stands virtually unaffected. She says she has raised about $30,000 mostly in donations of less than $3,000 a piece. In both of her previous council races she has won with at least 70 percent of the vote.
 But one of her Democratic opponents, Pauline Chu, 46 years old, seems to be accomplishing small miracles at least as far as building a political awareness among the Chinese immigrants in Flushing. Vice president of Community School Board 25, she says she has raised about $62,000 so far and by pounding the streets has registered more than 3,000 voters.
 She is deeply involved in community activities and is also backed by the Majority Coalition for a New New York. Her greatest emphasis is on improving the quality of education in public schools. She also says that she will act as a link between the Asian community -- which she defined as insular and shy of authority by nature -- and the rest of the district.
 Robert Gordon, the third Democrat, is the mystery man. He has no known campaign office, his phone number is unlisted and he did not submit any personal information for the Campaign Finance Board's voting guide. But in an interview with The Bayside Times, Mr. Gordon, 58, said he was a retired Housing Authority manager who now worked as an independent business and education consultant. He told the paper that his concerns were education and racial harmony.
 The winner of the Sept. 12 Democratic primary will face the lone Republican, Chun Soo Pyun, 54, a former president of the Korean Businessmen's Association and owner and principal of a vocational school. He considers himself the sacrificial lamb in the race. He is running unchallenged on the Republican ticket because he says he does not want to split the Asian vote in the primary. He believes Ms. Harrison will win the primary and then he hopes to inherit all of Ms. Chu's constituency in the election.
 Outwardly everyone says they want racial harmony but residents say they worry about the Asian candidates representing only their own communities. The race has brought to the surface nagging complaints and community friction.
 One repeated complaint is over the scores of churches, mosques and temples, and other community buildings that have taken over private homes and that residents say have destroyed the character of the neighborhood by bringing crowds of cars and people onto once quiet streets. Many black and Hispanic residents assert that they are automatically considered criminals in certain Chinese and Korean stores -- either barred from entering or followed closely when they go shopping.
 "As long as nobody is going to lean towards -- let's call it 'their people' -- then I don't care whether they are white, black, pink or purple," said Bonnie Burkhardt, who grew up in Flushing, is the owner of Callaghan's Pub and worries that prejudice might govern the elections.
 But Mr. Sye, a registered Republican, says he is voting Democratic this year because he wants to vote Chinese.
"In this area, I'd like a Chinese elected because Chinese know what minorities need," he said. "We should have a Chinese leader. Everyone here is so excited."

HEADLINE: Hard Road for Software Merger

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
Almost every month brings news of a new computer industry match-up: A.T.& T. and NCR, Computer Associates and On-Line Software, Borland International and Ashton-Tate. As profit margins shrivel and the costs of developing new products multiply, merger momentum is bound to continue.
But the record of other high-technology deals, like the one that formed Dun & Bradstreet Software Holdings Inc. in 1989, might give these proud new partners pause. 
 The merger of Management Science America Inc. and McCormack & Dodge was hardly made in heaven. The two companies had been such bitter rivals in the mainframe software business that their animosity was legend. The McCormack & Dodge chairman, Frank H. Dodge, had a goofy red-cheeked mask of his M.S.A. counterpart, John P. Imlay Jr., which he wore at sales meetings while the sales representatives screamed "kill, kill, kill."
 
Cutthroat Tactics
 Several times, M.S.A. sales representatives tracked down prospective customers on their way to meetings with M.& D. sales representatives, took them out for meals and then drove them around for hours professing to be lost.
"We simply hated each other's guts," said Dean F. Redfern, a former M.& D. executive.
But on Nov. 20, 1989, the unthinkable happened: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, M.& D.'s parent, acquired M.S.A. for $390 million and merged the two software makers into a single entity. When Mr. Imlay went before his employees at the company's Atlanta headquarters to tell them, a voice called from the audience, "Who do we hate now?"
Now, as Dun & Bradstreet Software, the merged companies have to aim at different rivals while enduring internal upheavals. Some employees have been laid off while others received lucrative payments, one of the principals angrily departed, and many customers are wondering how well the new company will maintain and update their installed software.
The stakes are high. Dun & Bradstreet is now the fifth-largest software maker in the world, pursuing a chunk of what the International Date Corporation of Framingham, Mass., expects to be a $250 billion industry by 1994.
To Robert E. Weissman, president and chief operating officer of the Dun & Bradstreet parent company, the merger is already a success. "This one has not been seamless, but it's better than 99.7 percent of all the deals we've made," he said. Dun & Bradstreet Software is now a $500 million giant, profitable in its first year, according to the company.
 
Few Past Successes
 But history offers Dun & Bradstreet Software scant encouragement. In the early 1970's, the Xerox Corporation bought a hot computer company called Scientific Data Systems for more than $1 billion and effectively killed it. More recent match-ups, like the one between Sperry and Burroughs to form Unisys, or the International Business Machines Corporation's acquisition of Rolm, a leading telecommunications company, have produced dismal results.
Computer Associates International, of Garden City, L.I., a Dun & Bradstreet Software competitor, has gobbled up several software companies, leaving it with such an assortment of successes and failures that earnings are flat and the company's reputation on Wall Street has soured.
"The old adage is that if you take two companies, each playing with half a deck, and put them together, you don't get a full deck, you get a quarter deck," said Harvey L. Poppel, a partner in Broadview Associates, a merger consulting firm in Fort Lee, N.J.
The difficulty of high-technology mergers stems from the rapid changes in technology itself. Merging companies tend to be competitors who often have to spend more time combining their proprietary product lines than planning further innovations.
Software companies, especially, have strong, distinctive cultures, with dominant leaders who have unique styles, said George Colony, president of Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "People within the company tend to grab onto that style, and when you try to slam that together with the culture of another software maker, it generally flops," he said.
Analysts say it did make sense for M.S.A. and M.& D. to merge. Their combined size could make it easier to develop new products for networks of desktop computers as their traditional market, before mainframe computer software stagnates. "The merger was absolutely a smart move," said Stephen McClellan, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.
But few who study the industry are ready to declare the merger a long-term success. "The process is long and tedious," said Clare Gillan, an analyst with International Data. "It's still too soon to call it a success."
The company now has to support two full product lines for its combined 13,000 customers, while trying to create an entirely new and complex software line, and customers are anxious. "It's like waking up in the morning and finding someone else in bed with you," said Scott Davey, an accounts payable manager at Van Waters & Rogers Inc., a chemicals distributor in Bellevue, Wash., that is a longtime M.& D. customer.
The new corporate partners have often found that their styles clashed. M.S.A. was known as an aggressive marketing and sales organization, while M.& D. had a reputation for better technology and a family-like atmosphere for employees.
Resentment lingers among the 3,500 employees in the Atlanta headquarters of the combined company and in Framingham, Mass., where the former M.& D. contingent remains. "It feels like the Civil War, the North against the South," said one Framingham employee.
Lawrence Catchpole, an M.S.A. veteran and the new company's director of research, said many Atlanta employees were having trouble adjusting to new ownership.
"The M.& D. side knew what it was like to be owned, but we had never been owned before," he said. "It feels a little like Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid. Just as those characters were pursued by lawmen they didn't know, the M.S.A. people are prone to ask about the strangers in their midst, "Who are these D.& B. guys anyway?"
Or, as Mr. Redfern, the 12-year M.& D. veteran who became executive vice president and general manager in the Framingham office after the merger, put it, "In a merger like this, there are winners and losers."
 
Survivors and the Vanquished
 Among the winners is the 54-year-old Mr. Imlay, the heavy-jowled Southerner whose homespun humor accompanies a sharp business sense and the motivational skills of Elmer Gantry. Mr. Imlay took over M.S.A. in 1970 and built it into a $265 million business. On the day he sold to Dun & Bradstreet for $18.50 a share, Mr. Imlay pocketed $53 million and became chairman of the new company.
His first task was to stroll through the executive offices on the 13th floor in Atlanta handing out million-dollar-plus checks to 15 members of his management team.
Among the losers is Mr. Dodge, the co-founder of M.& D., who had sold his company to D.& B. in 1983 but remained in charge. Mr. Weissman, president of the Dun & Bradstreet parent company, asked Mr. Dodge to stay on as vice chairman of the software company, but Mr. Dodge did not want to be second in command. Three months after the deal was concluded, he left.
He contends that he was locked out of his own building and dismissed. He filed a suit seeking to be released from his contractual pledge against competing with his former employer. D.& B. fired back, saying Mr. Dodge quit "gracelessly." Mr. Dodge's suit was thrown out of court.
Strangely enough, it was Mr. Dodge who had proposed a merger to Mr. Imlay during a round of golf in 1988, but Mr. Imlay refused. Now, Mr. Dodge has announced plans for a new software company.
 
Taking It Personally
 Mr. Dodge's abrupt departure shocked M.& D. employees who regarded him as a father. So much for the family-like atmosphere at M.& D., they told each other. Mr. Redfern, who was close to Mr. Dodge, understood the apprehensions. Employees feel like "a personal crime has been committed and never adjudicated," Mr. Redfern said.
Mr. Imlay moved quickly to consolidate the two companies. His first priority was to send a united sales force into the field. "The secret to a successful merger is realizing that the revenue is created from the sales force," Mr. Redfern said. "You've got to get the sales force moving quickly."
At the first combined sales meeting, Mr. Imlay compared the merger to the fall of the Berlin wall. He built to a rousing conclusion, dancing to rock music and yelling, "How would you like to compete with us?"
 
Higher Compensation
 What really motivated the sales force was a more generous compensation package, giving everyone the high commissions usually reserved for those who had already reached their quotas. So despite 200 layoffs in the first 120 days, the sales force stormed out and by November had fulfilled Dun & Bradstreet Software's targets for the fiscal year ending that month: nearly $500 million in revenues with profits in excess of $50 million.
But the layoffs continued, with the company blaming a poor economy, not the merger, for the most recent round in March. Executives find themselves having to deny rumors of further cuts. In all, 600 people have lost their jobs.
Employees hoping for a return to the good old days are waiting in vain, said Mr. Redfern, who has since left the company. "There are some employees who got on the bus and some who never got on and never will," he said. "It's just not the company it once was."
 
Good Morale From Success
 Some of the executives still with the company deride such nostalgia. John Landry, the merged company's chief technologist and the software wizard who created M.& D.'s most profitable products in the 1970's, left the company in 1985 but was persuaded to return by Mr. Imlay last winter. He said that neither M.& D. nor M.S.A. turned out a "significant new product in five years," adding, "Good morale is based upon success."
Many in the industry say that success will depend on the company's ability to keep the ambitious promises it has made to customers.
"If D.B.S. can truly deliver the products and technology they are talking about, the merger will be a success," said Mr. Davey, the long-time customer. "If not, it's a big waste of time."

Before leaving the company, Mr. Dodge gave Mr. Imlay the mask of Mr. Imlay's face that Mr. Dodge had used to motivate his staff at sales meetings. (Jim Middleton for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: History Repeats, Europe Forgets

BYLINE: By Josef Joffe; Josef Joffe is foreign editor and columnist of Suddeutsche Zeitung.

DATELINE: MUNICH

 BODY:
Where was Europe?
A few hours into the Moscow putsch, as Europe's chanceries were preparing to cave in to the amateur plotters, George Bush took the lead by hoisting the "coups fail" banner. Last August it was the United States that drew a line in the sand, dragging a bunch of reluctant allies all the way to victory against Saddam Hussein. 
 How about closer to the European home -- say Yugoslavia, where the Serbs are no longer skirmishing but conducting a real war against the Croats, complete with tanks and aircraft? Well, the Europeans are still pondering the issue. Germany is threatening to recognize Slovenia or Croatia, but so much fecklessness does not play in France or Britain, which fear a Teutonic power play in the Balkans.
Just a year ago, Europe was merrily surfing along yet another wave of the future. Soviet power was retracting, U.S. power was turning obsolete. Indeed, the might of nations was becoming thoroughly "civilianized," with economic clout muscling aside tanks and thermonuclear weapons. Poised for a more perfect common market as of 1993, the European Community was eyeing imminent superpower status. And just two months ago, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher was presiding over an inaugural meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that would act as a latter-day "Concert of Europe" and bring peace to the restless natives on the periphery.
Alas, Clio -- the goddess of history -- is a nasty lady. Amid celebrations of transcendence she has reminded us that history, seemingly banished, has a habit of sneaking in through the back door. Just look at Europe, where three forgotten dramas are being enacted again.
In the East, an empire is exploding once more, and though the republican revolution is entirely wholesome, it is already overshadowed by the classic codas of such breakups: nationality and border strife. Consult the encyclopedia on such friendly tribes as the Gagauz and Moldavians, the Armenians and the Azerbaijanis. Also familiarize yourself with the traditional resource flows of the Soviet Union and ponder what the southern republics will do when Russia, already eyeing pieces of Kazakhstan and the Ukraine, cuts off their water supplies.
In the Southeast, recall Sarajevo 1914. Serbian imperialism gave us World War I, and the '91 model is already well positioned to carve out a Greater Serbia from the remains of Yugoslavia. Neo-Communism plus expansionism does not equal peace. But Europe has nothing more to offer than yet another team of mediators, complete with battalion of "observers" armed to the teeth with notepads and binoculars.
In the rest of Europe, the ghosts of yesteryear are reappearing all over again -- albeit not clad in jackboots. Call it power politics on cats' feet. Norwegians and Danes rushed their diplomats into the Baltic republics to make sure that the Germans did not get there first. The French and the British, already wary of a "Greater Central European Co-Prosperity Sphere" centered on Berlin, cannot bring themselves to make common cause with Germany in the Balkans because they suspect the making of a "Teutonic bloc."
But, most important, what about post-putsch Russia? The Germans have shelled out $34 billion since 1989 to keep Mikhail Gorbachev afloat. Much of it was strictly protection money, disbursed to speed the withdrawal of some 400,000 Soviet troops from eastern Germany. That makes for a powerful separate interest toward Russia-U.S.S.R. that France, Britain and Italy naturally do not share with the same urgency.
The moral of this tale is the opposite of common foreign policy, let alone of a European superpower in the making. While the demise of the cold war has liberated ancient blood feuds in the East, it has -- predictably -- loosened the political bonds forged in the West. Western Europe '91 resembles a bunch of teen-agers suddenly forced to fend for themselves.
In the old days, they could collectively rub up against the powerful father figure that was the United States, confident of Washington's forbearance and protection. And there was always the Soviet Union of Leonid Brezhnev and successors, offering the opportunity for cautious side deals that delivered leverage against the United States.
But today? There is power without real purpose, aspiration without real leadership. Nor will Europe rise to the challenge. In the crunch, the French will always fall back to their favorite policy of "splendid aggravation." The British will never quite leave their favorite place on the fence. The Germans will try to please everybody while quietly cultivating their Central European garden. And all of them will be quick to check one another's ambitions rather than coalesce in a common policy. Which leaves the United States in the not-so-enviable position of No. 1 in the world.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Is Big Business Getting Too Cozy With the Mob?

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The hottest underground videotape in Japan right now is a grainy two-hour montage of a secret accession ceremony of a major organized-crime gang. Many major businesses are said to be nervously checking the tape for familiar faces.
The reason for their concern is that in the last five years, organized crime, fattened by huge profits in Japan's fast-growing economy, has managed to infiltrate legitimate business to a degree never before imagined in a society that likes to think of itself as basically law-abiding. 
 Willingly or not, some of Japan's most prestigious companies have become involved in questionable deals with even more questionable individuals and groups, and disclosures about these contacts have been at the core of a series of financial scandals rocking Japan for months.
In a recent speech, Ryochi Suzuki, director general of the National Police Agency, called on police chiefs to get tough. Mobsters, he said, "are having a major impact on the country's economic system" by moving into mainstream businesses.
 
$10 Billion For Gangsters
 The police say the income of organized crime was nearly $10 billion last year, as much as a major industrial company, but they acknowledge that this is only an estimate and that the total could be two or three times higher. About a fifth of the gangs' total revenue these days is said to come from legitimate business.
According to the police, there are 88,600 members of organized crime in Japan, belonging to 3,300 groups dominated by three large syndicates. Their primary sources of income are said to be gambling, drugs, prostitution, labor rackets and extortion, known in police parlance as "intervention in civil affairs."
But skyrocketing real estate and stock market prices in the last five years have attracted the gangsters, known as yakuza. Indeed, real estate has long been known to be infiltrated by mobsters who assemble large pieces of land by employing thugs to remove tenants or force property owners to sell.
 
Biggest Brokers Implicated
 "To be honest, we never realized until recently how much money these groups have at hand," said Hiroshi Ishizuki, director of the financial crimes unit at the Police Agency. "I also don't think we are getting full cooperation from companies or individuals with our investigations."
Among the recent embarrassments have been allegations that Nomura Securities, the biggest brokerage firm in the world, helped a reputed organized crime leader, Susumi Ishii, manipulate share prices of the Tokyu Corporation, a railroad and real estate conglomerate. An official investigation is under way.
At least two other major companies have admitted making loans to Mr. Ishii, who has declined to comment on all charges. The net has even gone to the United States, where it appears that mobsters have been no less eager than mainstream businesses to find good investments and hire influential lobbyists.
In another case, an old-line textile company was alarmed that its shares were being accumulated by a mob-related investment group, and it eventually repurchased the shares, apparently at a loss. This suggested that mobsters are engaging in a form of blackmail known as "greenmail."
In addition, some purchasers of paintings at auctions in the United States and Europe are known to be organized crime figures. It thus appears that trafficking in paintings, often portrayed in the overseas press as an amusing eccentricity of the Japanese, is actually sometimes carried out by professional criminals to launder money, make illicit payments or evade taxes.
 
'Difficult to Say No'
 Legitimate businesses maintain that criminal infiltration is not their fault. "The stock market is accessible to anybody," said Yasuhiro Mizuuchi, an executive vice president of Nomura. "It's extremely difficult to say no to clients who have not violated the law just because of their backgrounds."
Organized crime may be pervasive around the world, but in Japan it has one unique feature: its openness. Criminal syndicates operate storefront offices with their own signs, especially in poor areas of big cities where gambling, drugs and prostitution flourish. Their spokesmen sometimes speak freely of their engaging in illegal activities.
In a recent interview, for instance, Yukio Yamanouchi, a lawyer for the syndicate known as Yamaguchi-gumi, maintained that police estimates of mob income were not entirely accurate. "The estimate of income from drugs is a little exaggerated," he said.
Mr. Yamanouchi, a boyish looking man with metal-frame glasses, portrayed organized crime as providing a service that society demands -- like sex, drugs or gambling -- and said the police generally "let them behave freely to a certain extent" unless there is violence.
 
'Modest and Timid Men'
 "You cannot deny that there is a strong demand for these activities," he said. "Many yakuza members are actually modest and timid men whose girlfriends earn most of the money from prostitution. The murder rate among members of organized crime is quite low."
Another factor in the strength of the yakuza is that the number of lawyers is strictly limited in Japan, to maintain a ratio with the number of judges and prosecutors. Thus many people with grievances, like victims of traffic accidents, hire yakuza to obtain damage payments, and they get a percentage of the payment.
Mr. Yamanouchi said he agreed with the sardonic observation that the mob in Japan thus fills a function played by lawyers in other societies. In any case, as a lawyer, Mr. Yamanouchi said, he does not usually see himself as a defender of innocent people. He explained that his own main tactic in court when a client is arrested is to advise him to plead guilty.
 
'Few Innocent Defendants'
 "There are very few cases of innocent defendants in Japan," he said.
Like other experts, Mr. Yamanouchi agreed that mobsters were moving into legitimate businesses, and he was doubtful that the police could make any headway. The Government has enacted laws, for instance, to confiscate assets and define activities so as to make it easier to arrest members of the groups.
But Mr. Yamanouchi said the new laws would only serve to drive the mob underground.
"We have to remember that the Japanese yakuza are very open about their activities," he said, suggesting that open organized crime helps to insure a low crime rate generally. "Japanese public security is very high. The crimes to be tolerated are a basic choice of the Japanese people."

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Seeks to Expand Africa Aid and to Cancel Deb

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Five years after the United Nations carried out a wide-ranging plan to improve African economies, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar says Africa is worse off than ever and has proposed extending and expanding the program.
Citing the United States' cancellation of $7 billion of Egypt's debt and forgiveness of much of the Polish debt, Mr. Perez de Cuellar has proposed that donor nations also forgive or help pay off virtually all of Africa's combined $270 billion in debt. 
 "Clearly, additional and more energetic efforts are necessary to revitalize growth and development in Africa," the Secretary General said in a report released today.
He attributed the failure of the United Nations Program of Action for African Economic Recovery and Development to low commodity prices, the reluctance by some African governments to adhere to the plan and donor fatigue.
"Economic and social conditions actually worsened over the five years of the period," Mr. Perez de Cuellar continued. "This occurred despite the many far-reaching actions and reforms undertaken by African countries, including notable progress toward democratization."
Although results varied among countries, Africa on the whole during the last five years saw its per-capita gross domestic product fall an average of seven-tenths of 1 percent, the report said.
"Social conditions worsened considerably, with deterioration in the areas of education, health, nutrition, employment and incomes, with especially serious effects on children, youth and women," Mr. Perez de Cuellar said.
The General Assembly adopted the original aid plan in June 1986. African nations estimated that it would cost $128 billion and pledged to provide $82.5 billion of it.
But weak prices on world commodity markets hampered the program from the outset. And promised increases in international aid, measaured against inflation, never materialized.
Also, many African governments were reluctant to accept Western-imposed austerity provisions, like paring subsidies and increasing taxes on already poor people.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar, in trying to persuade African governments and aid providers to make commitments, warned that a failure to do so would wipe out meager gains and could cause political and social turmoil that would destroy recent democratization gains.
"These successes have been achieved at a high social and political cost," he said, "and African countries will not be able to sustain them unless additional resources are made available to insure that significant gains soon become apparent to the African people. "
The Secretary General said the new economic blueprint must be explicit, with specific sets of action to be carried out by Africans. To meet one objective -- doubling per-capita income to about $700 by the year 2015 -- Mr. Perez de Cuellar said, Africans must strive for 6 percent annual growth.
He proposed that donors cancel all debts owed to them by African countries and that the wealthier nations help pay off some African private and commercial debt.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Stages Broad Retreat On Report of Lower G.N.P.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined on world currency markets yesterday after the Government reported that the United States economy had unexpectedly contracted in the second quarter.
Gold prices eased in domestic markets after settling mixed overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $353.90 an ounce, off 50 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank of New York said gold slipped 10 cents an ounce, to a late bid of $354.25. 
 The Commerce Department reported yesterday morning that the economy had contracted at an annual rate of a tenth of a percent in the April-June quarter, a sharp contrast to an initial estimate of a rise of four-tenths of a percent in the period.
 
Concerns About Lower Rates
 The report on the gross national product raised questions of whether the nation had emerged from the recession and heightened the prospect that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates to stimulate growth. Lower American interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors.
"The G.N.P. report was below expectations," said Randolph Donney, the research director at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. That created a technical selloff that will probably extend into the next session, he said.
Mr. Donney said that in order to stem the selling, fresh economic statistics were needed to back up last week's favorable report on orders for durable goods.
Trading volume on the foreign exchange markets was relatively light. "That's partly because people are reluctant to extend positions at the end of the month and ahead of a holiday weekend, and because a lot of people got burned after last week's violent swings" in response to the failed Soviet coup, said Marc Chandler, an analyst at the advisory firm IDEA.
 
Japanese Yen Rises
 In Tokyo, before the G.N.P. report was released, the dollar finished at 137.13 yen, up 0.08 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, it was quoted at 136.60 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 136.55 yen, down from 137.00 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the pound rose to $1.6900, from $1.6795 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.6900 to buy a pound, up from $1.6800 on Tuesday.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell in New York to 1.7395 marks, from 1.7505 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.5171 Swiss francs, down from 1.5235; 5.9025 French francs, down from 5.9435; 1,297.50 Italian lire, down from 1,306.00, and 1.1408 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1415.

LENGTH: 1223 words

HEADLINE: The Bitter Victims of B.C.C.I.'s Fall

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRADFORD, England

 BODY:
The people accused of engineering the huge fraud that brought down the Bank of Credit and Commerce International reside in various states of luxury, ranging from a villa in Karachi, Pakistan, to a hotel suite in Abu Dhabi to a yacht in the south of France.
But the victims are in places like Bradford, an old industrial city in northern England where Mohammed Aslam Choudary sadly surveys his idle workshop. It used to employ as many as 60 people stitching up bed sheets, pillowcases and quilts, more than 10,000 sets a week. Now the shop floor is deserted except for a few barren tables, unattended sewing machines and a dejected Mr. Choudary, one of B.C.C.I.'s former customers. 
 "The innocent people -- depositors and small businesses -- did not have anything to do with the fraud, yet we are the ones getting hurt," said Mr. Choudary, a 40-year-old Pakistani immigrant. "It does not seem fair."
His company, Greatmade Ltd., got its trade financing from B.C.C.I. to pay for the cloth it imported from Pakistan. It also had about $14,000 deposited at the local branch. The bedding producer cannot obtain trade financing at another bank until British regulators sort through B.C.C.I.'s customer accounts, a laborious process likely to take months and threaten the survival of Greatmade, which is losing orders and an estimated $20,000 a month.
The stories of B.C.C.I.'s former customers differ in certain details, but the theme is remarkably similar: Unlike in the United States, where a generous deposit-insurance program has socialized the financial burden, in most other countries, bank failures mean personal hardship.
Britain's deposit insurance, for example, covers only 75 percent of the losses on an account, up to a maximum of just 15,000, or $25,500. In the United States, accounts up to $100,000 are insured, and sometimes even larger amounts are covered.
B.C.C.I. had more than 40,000 depositors in this country, and it is the Asian business community, whose members were among the bank's biggest depositors, that has felt most of the pain. C. B. Patel, the editor of Asian Business magazine, estimates that 20,000 Asian businesses may be in danger because of the seizure of B.C.C.I in July.
Having come to Britain in the postwar years, Asians now run thousands of newsstands, restaurants, small shops, and fabric and garment factories throughout the country. Many of these entrepreneurs, mainly Indian and Pakistani immigrants, have been hurt directly because they had accounts at the bank. Yet even those businesses that did not bank at B.C.C.I. are often suffering because so many of their customers did.
Founded by a Pakistani entrepreneur, B.C.C.I. was the bank of choice for members of the Asian community, who were outsiders, often shunned by traditional British banks. But at B.C.C.I. they found a welcome, people who looked like they did, spoke their language and understood their problems. To walk into a B.C.C.I. branch was to enter a comfortable world of shared cultural assumptions and business norms.
For lending when others would not, B.C.C.I. charged higher interest rates on commercial loans than did other banks. And in keeping with its aggressive approach to growth, B.C.C.I. offered higher interest rates on deposits. "But for most Asians, the real reason for going to B.C.C.I. was the social links," Mr. Patel said.
 
Higher Number of Asians
 Nowhere would that be more true than in Bradford, a city of roughly 460,000 people where the economy is in transition from the textile industry to services, tourism and high technology. Bradford has one of the highest concentrations of Asians of any city in Britain, with 45,000 Muslims, 9,000 Hindus and 9,000 Sikhs. The Bradford telephone book, for instance, has 104 listings under the name Patel, 227 Singhs and 221 Alis. And those figures understate the presence of Asians, since many, seeking privacy and fearing racial taunts, have unlisted numbers.
Many of the Asian immigrants arrived in the late 1950's and early 1960's to work the night shifts in the textile mills on the new machinery that had been installed in a belated and eventually futile effort to respond to foreign competition. But the immigrants stayed after the mills closed, setting up small businesses while their children attended universities and went into the professions.
In Bradford, the victims of the B.C.C.I. scandal are often bitter about the way Western government officials shut down the bank, leaving depositors, borrowers and former B.C.C.I. employees in the lurch. And it is a bitterness echoed among B.C.C.I.'s customers worldwide, who tend to be in developing countries or immigrants from the third world.
"The feelings in the Asian community are very strong that the Government should have kept the bank alive and their savings intact," said Aurangzeb Iqbal, a Bradford lawyer representing some 600 depositors with $26 million in B.C.C.I. "In other financial scandals in Britain, like the Guinness affair, the criminals were brought to book but the company was not shut down."
A garment maker, Wetherby Fashions Ltd., in the neighboring city of Leeds, had its $2.6 million pension fund for its 27 employees deposited at B.C.C.I. A friend of the owning family was an official at B.C.C.I. and, at the start of the year, he convinced Wetherby to move its pension fund account from National Westminster to B.C.C.I., where the interest rate was half a percentage point higher.
Before they put the money in B.C.C.I., explained Ajmair Bhullar, Wetherby's managing director, his family was concerned about the money-laundering conviction against B.C.C.I. in Florida. "But when the American branches closed down, it didn't seem to have any effect here," he said.
But today, the company's $2.6 million pension fund, accummulated over 20 years, looks to be in grave danger because of the 15,000 limit on deposit insurance. Unless the bank's principal shareholder, Sheik Zaid bin Sultan al-Nahayan of Abu Dhabi, can be persuaded to finance a multibillion-dollar bailout, large deposits like Wetherby's pension fund will be lost.
Mr. Bhullar believes that the British banking authorities and B.C.C.I.'s auditors performed poorly. "They should have warned people," he said. "The Bank of England and auditors knew, and we didn't."
 
Bleak Outlook for Employees
 For the bank's 1,200 employees in Britain, the outlook is bleak. And their job prospects have not been helped by the comments of the British authorities. Robin Leigh-Pemberton, the governor of the Bank of England, told Parliament in July while testifying on why B.C.C.I. had to be seized that "the culture of the bank is criminal." Still, he also said that he thought the British operations of B.C.C.I. were solvent, despite the huge losses the bank suffered worldwide. And only in the United States has anyone been formally charged with fraud.
Yet the bank's employees feel they have all been tainted by the bank governor's statement that B.C.C.I. was a "criminal" bank.
"I'll have a very difficult time getting a job in banking in this country," said Ijaz Choudary, the former B.C.C.I. branch manager in Bradford. "And I don't think this whole affair would have been handled this way if B.C.C.I. were a white, Western bank instead of a Muslim bank from the third world."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Up on Tax-Exempt Money Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with yields of tax-exempt funds rising as many usual buyers moved to longer maturities with higher yields.
The seven-day compounded average yield for tax-exempt funds rose 2 basis points, to 4.12 percent, with the simple yield up 1 basis point, to 4.03 percent. During the same period the 30-day compounded yield rose 3 basis points, to 4.10 percent, as the simple yield was up similarly, to 4.02 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios fell one day, to 57.
Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, said there is at least an even chance that the Federal Reserve will ease short-term interest rates again, as the economic numbers continue to indicate that the recovery is struggling.
"Last week's durable-goods figures put a temporary halt to speculation of another easing by the Fed," he said. "And right now the market is focusing on the employment number which is due out Sept 6 for a clue to Fed intentions."
Analysts said total assets of tax-exempt funds for the week were down by $253 million, to $87.7 billion.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded yield is 5.72 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket is 5.97 percent.
Of the funds monitored by IBC/ Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, which buys some securities that for some investors is subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax, continued as the best performer. The fund, which is distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. of Milwukee, had a return of 5.02 percent, down 7 basis points from the previous week.
Assets of taxable funds fell by $3.7 billion, to $456.5 billion. The drop was the reverse of last week's flight to safety from the stock market and international markets.
"The average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios is up to historical highs, with fund managers reaching higher along the steep yield curve for better returns," Mr. Frank said.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 5 basis points, to 5.45 percent, while the simple yield fell 4 basis points, to 5.31 percent. The 30-day compounded yield was down 5 basis points, to 5.57 percent and the simple yield was down 4 basis points, to 5.38 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return was Riverside Capital Money Market fund, distributed by the Winsbury Company of Columbus, Ohio. The return was 6.39 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with money market funds, were down 2 basis points to 5.14 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index. The yield spead between bank money market accounts and money market funds narrowed to 31 basis points this week, compared with 34 basis point only a week ago.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
U.S. Swords Into Plowshares for Soviets?

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Congress began grappling with the murky consequences of Soviet upheaval today as Representative Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, urged taking $1 billion from the military budget to send food and medicine to the Soviet Union this winter.
He contended that providing stability in the Soviet Union was "defense by different means, but defense nevertheless." But he was quickly challenged both on the wisdom of large-scale aid and the best source of it. 
 The emerging debate, conducted today not in committee meetings or the floor of the House or Senate but in news conferences, press releases and telephone interviews, is sure to grow and may gain focus when Congress returns to Washington the week after next.
But then it is likely to be mixed with the message the Democrats made insistently last month, that more money needs to be spent on domestic needs. Senator Patrick V. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee on foreign aid, said today, "People are more interested in what domestic aid we get than in what foreign aid we give."
 
Skepticism on Aid
 He said that short of actual famine, large-scale aid to the Soviet Union would be a mistake without substantial reforms. Last year, he said, the Soviet Union let "22 million metric tons rot in the fields." The differences of opinion were not limited to Democrats. Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, said the uncertainties after the failed coup in Moscow showed "for the time being, it is imperative that we keep our eyes wide open and our guard up."
But Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said the United States should now pledge that "people will not go hungry this winter in the Soviet Union." He said the Pentagon budget was the logical source of funds because "the destruction of Communist control in the Soviet Union obviously reduces the long-term military requirements of the United States."
 
$1 Billion in 'Seed Money'
 With little or no guidance from the Administration, there is little sense in a Congress scattered around the country, and the globe, of how much the Soviet Union or its republics may actually need this winter. But there is a widespread fear of food shortages.
The version of the foreign aid authorization bill passed last month by the Senate, for example, included $20 million in humanitarian aid for the Baltics. No aid was provided for Moscow.
Mr. Aspin said today that his $1 billion number was merely "illustrative," and the proper sum might be $500 million or $1.5 billion. The Wisconsin Democrat also called that $1 billion "seed money" that should lead other Western democracies to join in an emergency aid package.
Overlaying the substance of what range of money might wisely be spent is the looming presence of last year's budget agreement, which sets a ceiling of about $15 billion on all foreign aid and erects so-called "fire walls" to prevent the shifting of money among the categories of defense, domestic spending and foreign aid.
Mr. Aspin's proposal offered a legal way around that firewall, by creating a category of Soviet humanitarian aid within the defense budget. But Leon V. Panetta, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, reacted coolly and said he thought it was a bad idea to evade the laboriously negotiated limits.
Mr. Panetta said he did not "question the need to provide some kind of assistance package." But he said it was "ultimately going to have to be worked out with the White House."
Senator James Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, said that he thought the Aspin proposal was "slightly premature," but added that it would be "difficult to quarrel" with taking $1 billion from a military budget of nearly $300 billion for food and medicine.
Representative William L. Dickinson of Alabama, the senior Republican on Mr. Aspin's committee, said that while he supported "some form of limited humanitarian assistance," it would be a mistake to tap the Pentagon's budget and undo the "fragile" budget agreement. Any program of long-term help, he said, needed bipartisan agreement within Congress and with the Executive Branch and Western nations.
Mr. Aspin made it clear he was not talking about any long-term aid program, which he said should await internal economic reforms. But foreseeing severe problems this winter, he argued that food and medicine would reduce the risk of "chaos in a nation with 30,000 nuclear weapons."
 
Enhancing U.S. Security
 After the arguments made on the Cable News Network and to The Washington Post by the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, Mr. Aspin picked the $291 billion military authorization bill as the sensible source of money. He said taking $1 billion from it to try to avert disorder would reward democratic reform in the Soviet Union and enhance United States security.
Mr. Danforth said that forecasts of shortage and hunger called on "a long tradition in our country to offer food aid," and added, "We better be prepared to do what has to be done." Providing food to seek stability in a power like the Soviet Union, he said, meant that there was now a "double reason" for the United States to help.
He insisted that the budget agreement and its defense spending numbers were now obsolete. "Why should we be locked into a defense strategy that has been overtaken by events?" Mr. Danforth asked. Mr. Leahy said that while he would see that some funds for the Soviet Union were included in the foreign aid appropriation bill, they would be "symbolic" rather than substantial. The United States is already supplying substantial food aid through guarantees of loans to the Soviet Union, he said, even though "their credit worthiness is about on a par with a Texas savings and loan."
