HEADLINE: Bubble and Trouble in New York's Venerable Melting Pot

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
Few people speak unabashedly anymore about the ideal of the melting pot. Years of ethnic and racial battling, varying degrees of progress by various groups toward America's mainstream and the yawning rift between whites and blacks -- all have made the concept an object of derision, amendment or outright dismissal.
Yet frayed as the image may be, a summer of tension in New York indicates that it still holds some mythic sway in a city that used to accept it as a municipal credo. How else to explain why during a period of severe budget cuts, recession and violent crime, an outbreak of racial and ethnic incidents overrode all else and seemed to hold the city in its thrall?
 
A Collective Anxiety
 From a month of racial firebombings and attacks in slowly integrating Canarsie, to the ethnically inflammatory statements of Prof. Leonard Jeffries, to last week's conflagration in Crown Heights, the city seemed to react with particular anxiety to events that seemed to threaten the live-and-let-live milieu that many New Yorkers take pride in and view as crucial. 
 For behind live-and-let-live in this ultimate polyglot city is the absolute necessity of coexisting with one's often very different neighbors. And there is also the hope of something grander. If few still endorse the image of the big pot from which the world's wretched refuse emerge as middle-class, non-hyphenated Americans, there is still Mayor David N. Dinkins's "gorgeous mosaic," in which pieces of different sizes and colors help to form a larger whole more attractive than its components.
Yet behind a summer of friction, violence and murder, are other sobering truths that have emerged with regularity in the past half decade after the attack on three black men by a crowd of white teen-agers in Howard Beach, Queens, the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins by white teen-agers in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, the Tawana Brawley case, the Central Park jogger attack and trial, and the black boycott of the Korean grocery stores in Flatbush, Brooklyn.
 
Resistance to Change
 Many New Yorkers, mostly entrenched whites, are resistant to trading their insular neighborhoods for a rapidly changing, ever more diverse world. Many New Yorkers, mostly black, are moving further into poverty and away from the fruits of the city's unparalleled urban experience, and at best don't connect with ideals that have yielded them nothing. Many New Yorkers, of every race and ethnic grouping, are far from immune to racism, anti-Semitism and other forms of bigotry. And many New Yorkers, particularly blacks, at moments of crisis overtly reject the integrationist goals implicit in the melting pot and similar ideals and find their voices at least in part in the persons of the Rev. Al Sharpton, Alton H. Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason.
 
'Conflict Is Normal'
 In the face of this, say many human-relations experts, the city never committed the resources to dealing with tense neighborhood relations when they erupt.
"Conflict is normal -- we still have not accepted that fact; the question is how are we going to handle it," said Joseph Giordano, a family therapist who operates a consulting firm called Ethnicity and Mental Health Associates, which helps school districts and neighborhood groups cope with ethnic tensions. "The melting-pot idea is analogous to the concept of the family -- it's like what the American family is supposed to be -- and it's filled with the same unreality. You have to work at relationships, whether they're family or community."
For Jim Sleeper, whose book "The Closest of Strangers" was strongly critical of a liberal politics based on race rather than common economic goals, the New York ideal is in part one of building upon ethnic identity to become part of a larger cosmopolitan community. The fraying of that ideal, he says, began in the confrontations over school decentralization in 1968, in which Sonny Carson and other black radicals were involved in hard-edged confrontations with teachers in Ocean Hill-Brownsville, who were white and usually Jewish.
"The whole city sort of collectively gasped because what they were saying is your civic ideal is dead," said Mr. Sleeper, an editorial writer for New York Newsday.
 
Skirting of Issues
 But preceding this was a monumental confrontation over establishment of a police civilian complaint review board in which thinly veiled anti-black statements were commonplace. A few years later white opposition to a low-income housing project in a mostly Jewish section, Forest Hills, Queens, continued a dissipation from every side.
The result, said Denis DeLeon, the city's Commissioner of Human Rights, was a skirting of issues involving integroup relations on the part of city government for years. Canarsie, he said, was re-enforced as an all-white enclave through a post-Forest Hills policy of having housing projects ethnically reflect the neighborhoods they were in, in the name of "neighborhood integrity."
"What passed for good intergroup relations were problems that were kept quiet," he said. "You would be handling intergroup relations well if no one heard about it. They didn't want to hear the Puerto Ricans and the Dominicans don't get along or that the Hasidic Jews and Caribbean blacks weren't getting along. We're having to pay for that and we will be for quite some time."
If this summer's problems in Canarsie followed a pattern that touched countless neighborhoods in which new ethnic groups emerged, one repeated since at least the days of "West Side Story," the Crown Heights situation is a special one. Here, on frequently lush streets of handsome town houses, private homes and low-slung apartment buildings, the Lubavitcher Hasidim have established their worldwide headquarters in a community that was the historic site of the first neighborhood of free blacks in the city and that had also become a storied Jewish neighborhood that was host to families in the generational journey from the slums and the suburbs.
While the edge of ethnic tension in other neighborhoods eventually eased as whites gave way to blacks, Hispanics and later Asians, the Lubavitcher community, which largely arrived after surviving Hitler's camps, grew under the powerful gaze of its Grand Rabbi, Menachem M. Schneerson. The religion required Lubavitchers to be within walking distance of their synagogues on the Sabbath and other holidays. To be near the rebbe, whose picture is evident in every Lubavitcher store and home, was an honor. And to keep a synagogue in operation after its congregation has withered, as many had in Crown Heights, is considered a "mitzvah," or good deed.
As the Lubavitcher community grew -- it numbers perhaps 15,00 in and around Crown Heights -- the black population grew as well. In the part of Crown Heights closest to the Lubavitchers alone, it numbers more than 85,000, according to the census, the majority now from many islands in the Caribbean.
In the neighborhood this week, there are Hasidim who point to boards they serve on with blacks as evidence of their willingness to work with their neighbors. However, among many leading blacks, the refrain is often the same -- that the Lubavitchers have shut themselves off from everyone else and used their political power to win housing money, poverty grants and other forms of government largesse far in excess of what their numbers would warrant.
 
Undercurrent of Bitterness
 Dr. Vernal G. Cave, a black physician who has lived and practiced on an exquisite block of President Street since 1955, recalled a successful drive by the Hasidim in 1976 to split the proposed Crown Heights community board district in two so the Lubavitchers would have great influence over the part of the neighborhood in which they lived.
How could a car accident involving a Hasidic driver and the death of a 7-year-old black boy trigger such black animosity toward the Lubavitchers?
"It goes back at least as far as 1976," Dr. Cave said. For many Lubavitchers, however, the eruption following the accident, in which a visiting Hasidic scholar from Australia was stabbed to death in what authorities say was an act of revenge, is unexplainable by anything other than misdirected prejudice.
"I think it goes beyond anti-Semitism," said Baruch Bush, an associate professor of law at Hofstra University. "This community, Hasidic Jews generally and Jews generally, have been made the butt and the direct target of all the anger that has arisen against the harms of white America to the black people. It's a kind of scapegoating. It happened in the European countryside. I think its happening here."
 
Sporadic Confrontations
 The last three decades have been dotted with other confrontations between the Lubavitchers and their black neighbors. The most pointed came in 1978, and it resonates eerily today. A black businessman named Arthur Miller died in a fight with the police after a traffic dispute, and, at about the same time, a black youth named Victor Rhodes was beaten by a mob of Hasidic youths who said he had knocked a hat from an elderly rabbi's head. Huge demonstrations by blacks ensued, covering the same streets as last week's protests and led by some of the same leaders.
For the moment, the situation seems frozen. Any hope for change involves the kindling of old ideals that have long been scarce in Crown Heights.
Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., who has done political battle with the Lubavitchers and who now deals with them more amicably as Brooklyn Democratic leader, looked back at a week marked by death and disruption and concluded, "We have two communities living side by side, but there's no social intercourse. If we want a different result, we on both sides have got to start doing something different."

As tension subsides after a week of racial unrest between blacks and Hasidic Jews, the police presence there remains in evidence. (Angel Franco/The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Fell 0.1 Percent In Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The economy contracted during the second quarter instead of expanding, revised Government figures showed today, suggesting that the recession lasted longer than had previously been thought.
Total output of goods and services edged down at an annual rate of a tenth of 1 percent, a tiny decline that nevertheless contrasted with the Commerce Department's estimate a month ago that output rose at a pace of four-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June period. 
 Most analysts tended to dismiss the fact that gross national product has now shrunk for the latest three quarters and remained confident that the recovery from recession, although almost certainly a desultory recovery, is now under way.
 
President Is Optimistic
 "It doesn't change the outlook very much -- and might even improve it," said Robert H. Chandross, the chief economist for Lloyds Bank North America in New York.
President Bush, when asked in Kennebunkport, Me., whether today's report meant continued recession, said he did not think so. "I feel all right about things," he said. "There are some statistics up and some down, but basically I think it's doing all right."
Most reports on economic activity so far this summer have portrayed an economic rebound, and even skeptics regard growth in G.N.P. for the third quarter to be a near certainty. A number of analysts said they did not expect the Federal Reserve to relax monetary policy further in response to today's revisions of the spring-quarter performance.
Traders in the financial markets, however, grasped at the prospect that signs of economic weakness might yet mean a new cut in interest rates by the Fed, which also trimmed rates earlier this month to give the economy a lift. That hope helped to inspire the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average gained 29.07 points to reach a new high of 3,055.23. [Page D8.] The G.N.P. report, coupled with a successful auction of new five-year Treasury notes, also helped to push up prices for Treasury securities in the credit market. [Page D18.]
 
Shattering an Illusion
 A minority of private analysts pointed to the latest G.N.P. figures as evidence of lingering weakness that to some implies no significant growth until next year.
"Today's downward revision of the second-quarter G.N.P. should shatter any remaining illusion of an economic recovery," said Lawrence A. Hunter, deputy chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "This third consecutive quarter of economic contraction removes all doubt about the continuing economic stagnation."
A prominent reason for caution, some analysts say, is a wavering of confidence among consumers, the source of two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The ABC News/ Money Magazine Consumer Index was calculated today at minus 38 on a scale ranging from plus 100 to minus 100. The index, based on consumer ratings of the economy, consumers' personal finances and the buying climate, is down one point for the week and within five points of its record low of minus 43, set on Oct. 28.
Albert Sindlinger, a longtime pollster, said today that consumer incomes had slumped to a 36-year low, in part because of taxes not included in Government inflation statistics.
 
Depleted Inventories
 The main factors dragging the G.N.P. into negative territory were more rapid reductions in business inventories and lower personal spending. Analysts noted, however, that depleted inventories represent a positive factor for gauging future economic activity, since any increase in demand will quickly require stepped-up production.
"This sets up the possibility of significant economic growth in the second half of the year," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist a Merrill Lynch & Company.
Businesses cut inventories at a $27.7 billion rate in the April-June quarter instead of the $21.2 billion pace initially estimated, a difference of $6.5 billion, the Commerce Department report showed.
Analysts also tended to playdown the $5.1 billion downward revision in personal spending, which shrank the annual growth rate to 2.8 percent from 3.6 percent. Much of the reduction reflected what were, in effect, accounting changes that shifted car purchases from individuals to businesses.
 
Daunting Task for Auto Makers
 Even optimists, however, cautioned that the automobile business faced a daunting sales task in coming months, since it has imposed significant price increases that exceed current rebate programs.
The biggest upward revisions in today's G.N.P. report were a $4.1 billion improvement in foreign trade -- imports were $3.1 billion lower than first estimated and exports $1 billion higher -- and a $3.4 billion rise in the output of producers' durable equipment.
Over all, analysts said that while they did not consider the half-point revision in G.N.P. to be large, it was somewhat surprising that it was downward and into negative territory. Based on experience, the department said the chances were two out of three that in the future, revisions of second-quarter G.N.P. would not be worse than a four-tenths of 1 percent rate of decline or better than a five-tenths of 1 percent rate of advance.
The G.N.P. declined at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the first quarter of 1991 and 1.6 percent in the fourth quarter of last year.
 
Inflation at 3 Percent
 Inflation, as gauged by the fixed-weight G.N.P. price index that assumes the composition of output does not change, ran at 3 percent during the quarter, the same pace as estimated in late July. The nation's savings rate, however, is now seen as remaining at 4.2 percent instead of falling a half point as initially estimated in July's advance report.
G.N.P. in current dollars rather than 1982 dollars fell to a 4.2 annual percent rate of increase in the second quarter from 4.6 percent in last month's report.
Today's report also included the Government's first calculation of corporate profits for the spring quarter.
Profits from current production -- before tax with inventory valuation and capital consumption adjustments -- rose $1.7 billion, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to $287.9 billion at an annual rate. This compared with a decline of $2.7 billion, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, in the first quarter.
Increases were posted in manufacturing, trade and the transportation and public utilities group, while profits fell in other nonmanufacturing industries, the department stated.
Profits before taxes, but without adjustments, rose seven-tenths of 1 percent after falling 7.4 percent in the first quarter, and profits after taxes fell 1.6 percent, compared with a 6.3 percent drop during the winter. But current-production cash flow, a measure of a company's ability to finance projects internally, edged up only a tenth of 1 percent after rising 3.5 percent in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Court Backs Trump's Plan To Shed Half of Taj Mahal

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 28

 BODY:
A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge today approved a plan by Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort to restructure its giant debt by surrendering half the developer's equity in the Atlantic City property.
The plan, which gives bondholders the equity in exchange for their acceptance of lower interest rates, was approved after a 4 1/2-hour hearing by Bankruptcy Judge Rosemary Gambardella. The approval came just six weeks after the Taj Mahal filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors. 
 Most bankruptcies drag on for months or even years. But the casino expedited the process by securing the necessary bondholder approvals beforehand.
 
Delay Is Averted
 The only potential delay was averted late in the day when Dixie-Narco Inc., a Williston, S.C.-based company, settled its claim against the casino.
Dixie-Narco had demanded payment for 1,350 bill-changing machines it supplied the Taj Mahal. The company contended that Mr. Trump solicited the bondholders improperly because he had said Dixie-Narco's $6 million claim was worthless.
Lawyers for Dixie-Narco withdrew their objections after reaching a settlement for $2.4 million to be paid in increasing installments through December 1994. The casino will also give back 500 of the machines it has stored. Mr. Trump, who did not attend the bankruptcy hearing, had contended that the change machines frequently broke down at the casino's April 1990 opening, dealing the casino a setback from which it is only now recovering.
The only testimony today came from Henry Hornbostel, the casino's senior vice president of finance, and Wilbur Ross, the main adviser to the bondholder steering committee.
Mr. Hornbostel testified that the restructuring should be approved because creditors -- including bondholders with $675 million in notes -- would fare worse in a liquidation. A casino prospectus estimated that they would receive 43.4 percent of their money.
 
A Cushion Against Downturns
 Mr. Ross testified that the casino's debt-service requirements under the restructuring would total roughly $70 million, leaving it a cushion against unexpected downturns. Failure to approve the plan quickly would prove costly, Mr. Ross said.
"I think it would be a disaster," he said. "It would have tragic consequences for the secured creditors and probably end up wiping out the unsecured creditors.
The Taj Mahal's emergence from bankruptcy does not end Mr. Trump's casino problems. His Trump Castle Casino Resort hopes to file a plan similar to the Taj Mahal by the fall to restructure its debt-laden finances.

HEADLINE: 29.07 Gain Lifts Dow to a Record of 3,055.23

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Stock prices jumped sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average surging past the record it set last week. Traders were cheered by what they saw as a growing prospect of declining interest rates in the wake of new Government economic data.
After slipping 14 points in the week's first two sessions, the Dow gained 29.07 yesterday, or 1 percent, to close at 3,055.23, erasing the record set on Friday, 3,040.25. 
 The market reacted to a Commerce Department report that the gross national product, adjusted for inflation, declined in the second quarter at an annual rate of a tenth of 1 percent. That figure came as a surprise after the Government's earlier estimate that the economy had grown at a rate of four-tenths of 1 percent.
"The G.N.P. figures along with other data foretell the possibility of a bigger increase in unemployment," said Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research for Gruntal & Company. "So the Federal Reserve has something to worry about. And with the economy having been starved by high interest rates, there is great anticipation that the Fed will do something about interest rates."
Also, analysts suggested that the Commerce figures on lower second- quarter inventories were likely to stimulate economic growth in the third quarter.
The Dow moved decisively all day, apart from a brief decline after 10 A.M. Of the Dow's 30 stocks, 25 posted increases.
Advancing issues outpaced declining ones by a margin of more than 2 to 1, with 1,063 up and 519 down. Volume on the Big Board totaled 172 million shares, up from 144.7 million on Tuesday.
 
Merck Leads Advance
 Leading the Dow's rise was Merck, up 2 3/4, to 127 7/8. The company said it would create a worldwide manufacturing division next week. Other big movers on the Dow were Coca-Cola, up 1 3/4, to 66 3/8, and Boeing, up 1 1/8, to 50 1/8. The three accounted for more than a third of the Dow's rise.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.54 points, to 526.29, a gain of nearly nine-tenths of 1 percent. The American Stock Exchange's composite index was up 1, to 370.62. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 3.58, to 396.64. And the New York Stock Exchange's composite index was up 1.91, to 217.17.
The most active issue on the Big Board was Telefono de Mexico, the national telecommunications company. The Mexican Government had owned a majority of the company, but it has been privatized in the last year, with the Government continuing to sell small blocks of shares in recent months. The stock was up 5/8, to 37 3/8, with 2.7 million shares changing hands.
A big gainer on the New York Stock Exchange was McDonnell Douglas, up 3 1/2, to 54 1/2. Analysts said the stock rose on speculation that the company would not be significantly affected by proposed cuts in military spending.
The biggest percentage gainer was Manhattan National, a holding company for life insurers. The stock rose nearly 37 percent, gaining 2 1/8, to 7 7/8, after the company announced that it was considering a plan to spin off its Manhattan Life subsidiary and liquidate the company's remaining assets.
The most active Amex issue was Bolar Pharmaceutical, up 2 3/4, to 8 1/4, on 2.2 million shares. The company agreed Tuesday to pay SmithKline Beecham $40 million to settle a lawsuit involving a generic version of a SmithKline blood presure drug. The payment was lower than had been expected.
In over-the-counter trading, the most-active issue was Seagate Technology, a computer company. The stock was up 3/4, to 10 5/8 on 2.5 million shares. The company's Japanese subsidiary said yesterday that it would build a plant in central Japan to produce hard-disk drives.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
LITHUANIANS FREE OF SOVIET DRAFT

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The Soviet Government has agreed to stop conscripting Lithuanian youths and to release those now serving in the Soviet Army, further indicating Soviet moves toward acceptance of Lithuania's independence, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania announced today.
Mr. Landsbergis spoke after meeting with the new Soviet military commander for the Baltic region, Lieut. Gen. Vladislav Mironov, who was appointed on Sunday. 
 Although no announcement was made about conscription in the two other Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia, aides to Mr. Landsbergis said they presumed that the same policy would be applied there.
Lithuania declared its independence from the Soviet Union more than a year ago, but only in the wake of the failed coup in Moscow last week has the Soviet Government started to acknowledge that the declaration is irreversible.
This week, foreign nations began granting diplomatic recognition to Lithuania as a sovereign state. According to official figures, 23 nations have thus far extended formal recognition to Lithuania, which was annexed by the Soviet Union with Latvia and Estonia as a consequence of a secret Stalin-Hitler pact on the eve of World War II.
Asked about the reluctance of the United States to extend immediate recognition, Mr. Landsbergis replied, "We can wait a little longer."
 
Delegations Pour In
 Delegations from foreign countries are pouring into Lithuania and the other Baltic republics. Italians and Norwegians have been in Vilnius seeking to rent space for a diplomatic mission, and a group of Danish legislative specialists is here for meetings with local political leaders. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France is scheduled to tour the region on Thursday.
At Lithuanian border crossings, Soviet guards have begun giving way to Lithuanians, although the situation at some crossings is still confused. Mr. Landsbergis acknowledged today that he did not know who was in control of all border posts.
Despite the rapid moves toward independence after more than half a century of Soviet rule, there is no euphoria on the streets of Vilnius. Much of the world's attention may be focused here, but for Lithuanians today was just another normal day.
"At the beginning, when we first got the sense that we were really going to be free, people were very excited," one shopkeeper said. "Now we are starting to realize the trouble that is ahead. We are all happy that this is happening, but we are also worried."
Lithuania imports nearly all of its raw materials from the Soviet Union, and most of its manufactured goods have been sold there or in Soviet-bloc countries.
Two generations of farmers have lived and worked on collective farms, and many are worried about having to make the transition to private farming. In the cities, fear of unemployment is widespread.
 
Lithuanian Tension
 When Soviet hard-liners orchestrated a coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last week, Lithuanians feared that their hopes for peaceful secession might be crushed.
The tension that has ruled in Lithuania, especially since a crackdown by Soviet forces in January, was still visible today at the barricaded Parliament building here. Militiamen guard all entrances, and no one may enter without a written invitation from someone inside. Journalists assigned there must obtain new accreditation every day.
Inside the building, sandbags block most staircases. Soldiers armed with single-shot carbines patrol the corridors. President Landsbergis is heavily guarded, and many government officials have been sleeping in their offices for the last week.
"Some people think the barricades should stay up until the last Soviet soldier is gone," said Rita Dapkus, a government spokeswoman who is among those officials now sleeping in their offices.
At his news conference today, Mr. Landsbergis said he hoped that the withdrawal of the estimated 80,000 Soviet soldiers from Lithuania would begin this year, and be completed by 1994.
The Soviet Government has not announced a timetable for withdrawing its troops from the Baltic republics. Mr. Landsbergis said General Mironov had told him he was not yet authorized to negotiate that question.
Mr. Landsbergis said he was satisfied with the position of the Soviet Union's new military commanders.
"General Mironov told me that the mood is changing in Moscow," Mr. Landsbergis said. "According to him, Soviet soldiers posted in the Baltic republics are being educated in the new realities here."
"This is very important, because it shows the new attitude of the military command," he said. "There is now a basis for mutual understanding, and it is growing stronger. Soviet military leaders are now willing to negotiate the return of buildings and documents."
Mr. Landsbergis said he had been assured that the conscription of Lithuanian youths into the Soviet Army would end immediately. He said the question of releasing Lithuanians now in the army, who officials here said are believed to number less than 1,000, "is being resolved, and will be resolved very soon."
Among Soviet soldiers posted here are members of elite units trained in counterterrorism. Lithuanian leaders consider their presence threatening, and have asked that they be the first to be withdrawn.

Germany Recognizes Baltics
 BONN, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Germany granted official diplomatic recognition today to Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, 52 years after Nazi Germany signed over their freedom to the Soviet Union.
[New Zealand also recognized the three, Reuters reported.]
"From our point of view, it is only today that the last consequences of World War II have been done away with," Lennart Meri, Estonia's Foreign Minister, said before he, his two Baltic counterparts and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany signed papers establishing diplomatic ties.
"For us, the war lasted about eight times longer than in Germany and Europe," Mr. Meri said.

 BODY:

Soviet Turmoil A18-23
An urgent mission to the Ukraine was undertaken by delegates from the Russian republic and Soviet Parliament. They are searching for common ground with the nation's second most populous republic, which, like many other republics, is seized with secessionist fervor. Page A1 
 Ukraine and Russia trying to heal their injured ties A18
Lithuanians free of Soviet draft A19
Debates over aid to the Soviet Union -- whether to send it, how much to send, when to send it, what kind to send -- are developing rapidly within the Western alliance and among politicians in Washington. A1
U.S. swords into plowshares for Soviets? A22 The reaction to the coup in Klin, a provincial city about 50 miles from Moscow, bordered on indifference, a feeling that little that matters will change as a result. It's a reaction that is probably typical of how most Russians weathered the upheavals. A1

HEADLINE: Economic Reform Aiding Peronist Campaign

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28

 BODY:
For Peronist party candidates seeking office on Sept. 8 in Argentina's mid-term elections, the hottest product they have to offer voters is the Economy Minister, Domingo Felipe Cavallo.
The situation is certainly unusual. Mr. Cavallo, who is not a member of the Peronist or any other party, has been taking to the hustings for the last two weeks, pleading with voters to vote Peronist so his plan to rejuvenate the economy will have a chance to succeed. 
 "We've never had an Economy Minister active in a campaign, but there is such a wave of confidence right now in Cavallo's economic plan," said Manuel Mora y Araujo, one of the country's leading polltakers. "Cavallo is the principal representative of that plan and has become very, very popular."
So popular, according to Mr. Mora y Araujo's lastest polls, that Mr. Cavallo's approval ratings, at 52 percent, are about the same as those of the country's Peronist President, Carlos Saul Menem, at 53 percent.
The popularity of the plan itself, which has lowered tariffs, stabilized the country's currency, halted the printing of money by the central bank and mandated a budget surplus, is soaring, with 62 percent of those polled saying they support it.
After bouts with inflation that exceeded 6,000 percent from 1989 through 1990, Mr. Cavallo has over the last four months produced the lowest inflation level here in almost two decades.
"It's a tremendous asset for this Government that people can put their money in the bank on Friday and not worry that it's lost value on Monday," said Robert Cortes Conde, a prominent economist.
For the last six months, President Menem has been plagued by a host of personal scandals, including charges that his in-laws and top aides were involved in money laundering.
But Mr. Menem's ratings, which reached their lowest point in March, have risen steadily since, as the Cavallo plan has gained credibility.
For many here, though Mr. Cavallo protests that he does not like politicking, his willingness to go on the campaign trail is seen as offering himself as a credible figure to succeed Mr. Menem as President in 1994.
His international stature has soared since he introduced his economic plan in March and successfully negotiated a $1 billion standby loan from the International Monetary Fund.
Many candidates of the Radical Party, the primary opposition to the Peronists, have adopted an "if you can't beat them, join them" attitude. In the provinces of Santa Fe and Cordoba, Radical Party candidates are openly supporting the Cavallo plan.
Analysts here predict that the mid-term congressional, gubernatorial and municipal elections could represent a big victory for Mr. Menem and his policies of orienting the country toward the industrialized nations, especially the United States.
Three provinces held early elections this month, with the Personists scoring a upset victory in San Juan. Also in next month's elections, Eduardo Angeloz, the Radical Party's most prominent politician and Mr. Menem's opponent in the 1989 presidential elections, is struggling to win a third term as Governor of Cordoba, the country's second most important industrial center. There, the Peronist candidate, Jose Manuel de la Sota, has shown a surprising increase in popularity and is running almost even with Mr. Angeloz.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Taylor Finally Signs And Hits the Big Time

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
Final details had finally been settled and Brien Taylor's historic $1.55 million contract was finally signed. Taylor had officially become a Yankee.
Scott Boras, who had operated under the title of adviser in the semantics of baseball economics, was officially becoming an agent. Bettie Taylor, whose resoluteness had led directly to her son's wealth, now wore the hat of the team she had rooted for as a child in Beaufort, N.C. There appeared to be more than enough happily-ever-after for everyone yesterday at Yankee Stadium. 
 The business of baseball was transformed into the ceremony of sport, complete with hot lights, a baseball hat and a jersey for the Yankee future.
 
Meet No. 19
 Once the procession of deal-makers moved slowly through the mob, Taylor stood behind a podium and microphone and clutched the pinstriped jersey to his chest with both hands. It was an old jersey, No. 19, with the name "Righetti" stitched on the inside collar under Taylor's chin.
"He told me, 'I never saw this many cameras,' " said Gene Michael, the Yankee vice president and general manager. "I never saw that many myself."
Taylor's first professional moment in the bright lights completed a dizzying five-day period of rapidly spiraling offers, intense negotiations, an arrival and departure from junior college, a trip to New York, and a lifetime of financial security.
Two days before, he stood in a quiet gymnasium on the campus of Louisburg College, holding a class schedule in his hands. One day before, there were two people wearing Yankee hats on an airplane from North Carolina to New York, and neither fan recognized Taylor.
Those days may be gone forever. Yesterday afternoon, at the start of Taylor's first visit to a big-league ball park, the people waiting at the entrance called his name.
"It was quite amazing," Taylor said, still clutching the jersey to his chest. "I stopped and looked around. I heard people hollering and screaming at me. It kind of intimidated me."
That was an uncharacteristic but understandable response from a 19-year-old who became the first high school pitcher taken as the first choice in the June baseball draft in 18 years. Once his contract was completed, he took a tour of the stadium he hopes to reach within two years.
"It was quite amazing," he said. "I'm used to fields with a little fence around them."
His competitive career will not begin until mid-September, when Taylor pitches for the Yankee team in the instructional league. Taylor, who has not competed since the end of his high school season at the beginning of June, has worked with his father, Ray, a brick mason, and pitched to a cousin or friends in the evening.
Michael said that he hoped that Taylor would be able to report to the organization's complex in Tampa, Fla., as soon as next week to begin preparing for the instructional league and make up for the time lost during the 12 weeks of negotiations.
When Taylor was asked when he hoped to reach the Bronx, it seemed as if 1993 had become a goal. "It should be two years," Taylor said. "I want to make it in two years."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Steinbrenner's Role In Signing of Taylor Perturbs McMullen

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Not much is heard from George Steinbrenner these days, but he spoke up just in time for the Yankees to surrender to a 19-year-old high school pitcher from North Carolina, who never wanted to go to college but used the threat as an effective negotiating ploy.
Now others are beginning to speak out angrily about the Yankees' decision. The signing of Brien Taylor to a $1.55 million contract instantly outraged other clubs because of the impact it will have on current and future negotiations with amateur draft picks. 
 "These big tycoons in New York let a 19-year-old kid from North Carolina snooker them out of a million dollars," an angry John McMullen, owner of the Houston Astros, said yesterday. "It's total sheer irresponsibility. Every time you think it can't get worse, it does. It's a complete outrage."
Saying publicly what he is not permitted to do privately, Steinbrenner sent a clear message to the incumbent decision-makers that he wanted them to sign Taylor, the No. 1 selection in the June draft, whatever the cost. He added a tag line, through a reporter, that in his mind would rationalize the remarkable expenditure.
It was the Oakland Athletics, the owner said, who set the standard for a top draft choice by giving Todd Van Poppel $1.2 million last year. When he was allowed to make the decisions and spent lavishly on free agents, Steinbrenner always blamed other clubs for establishing the market. Although he spent more money on free agents than anyone, he was always reluctantly keeping pace but never forging new economic territory. Or so he said.
McMullen, for one, doesn't buy that. He and other baseball people see the Van Poppel signing as an aberration because that high school pitcher legitimately was intent on going to college and the Athletics had to buy his change of mind. Now, with the $1.55 million payment to Taylor, who never expressed interest in becoming a doctor or a lawyer or even a college freshman, the Yankees have established the standard for the next draft and those that will follow, not to mention this year's draft choices who have yet to sign.
Discussing the Van Poppel deal, McMullen said, "I know the Yankees blame it on Oakland, but two wrongs don't make a right."
The Taylor signing affects McMullen and the Astros immediately. They have the No. 6 pick, John Burke, also a pitcher, and McMullen said they have offered him a signing bonus in the area established by the bonuses given the fourth ($385,000) and seventh ($345,000) selections. (The fifth pick, Kenny Henderson, is unsigned.)
But on Tuesday, McMullen said, Scott Boras, the agent who advised Taylor and is advising Burke, called the Astros and asked for $1 million.
"This has killed Milwaukee and San Diego and ourselves," McMullen said, referring to the teams that have the other unsigned pitchers whom Boras is advising.
 
Strawberry's Impact
 As a Christian, Darryl Strawberry says he was reborn last winter. As a member of the Los Angeles Dodgers, he appears to have been reborn six weeks ago. That's when he hit a three-run home run against David Cone of the Mets, triggering a personal surge in which he hit 14 home runs and drove in 40 runs in 36 games. It was by far Strawberry's finest, most productive period of the first season of his five-year, $20.25 million contract.
"Darryl pretty much has come around," Gary Carter, his teammate with the Mets and the Dodgers, said. "He is capable of carrying a team, and I feel he'll do that in September. If there's a time to rise to the occasion, it's now. He's been tremendous since the All-Star Game break. I foresee bigger and better things out of Darryl the rest of season."
But those things may have to be significantly bigger and better if Strawberry is to carry the Dodgers to the National League West championship. Despite his most productive period, which ran from July 18 through last Sunday, the Dodgers emerged from a 36-game span with 19 victories and 17 defeats and a lead over the Atlanta Braves that shrank from three and a half games to one.
In other words, Strawberry's best has not been good enough to propel the Dodgers away from the surprising upstart, the relentless Braves, who were tied for first entering last night's games.
When Strawberry was languishing with a .232 batting average, 8 home runs and 31 runs batted in his first 65 games, the Dodgers, even with a seven-game losing streak immediately after the All-Star Game break, had a 49-38 record. That record was better than the Dodgers have done since Strawberry started hitting. They have not been able to capitalize on his rebirth and have lost ground in the division race instead of pulling away.
The reduced output of Juan Samuel, Eddie Murray and Kal Daniels has diluted the effect of Strawberry's revival.
Samuel has batted .231 since reaching a season-high .340 June 10. In a combined 223 games before the break, Murray, Daniels and Samuel combined for 27 home runs and 135 runs batted in, an average of one home run every 8.3 games and one r.b.i. every 1.7 games. In 117 games since the break, they have 8 home runs and 42 r.b.i., an average of one home run every 14.6 games and one r.b.i. every 2.8 games.
Seeing that his bat wasn't helping enough, Strawberry last weekend decided to try his mouth. He told reporters that impending free agency for a sizable group of Dodgers, including Murray and Orel Hershiser, has been a distraction. It puts pressure on the whole team, he said. It weighs on players' minds when the focus should be on winning.
Is this the same Darryl Strawberry who last year approached his free agency during the Mets' pennant chase by alternately saying he wanted to go to Los Angeles and he wanted to stay in New York? Is he now speaking from experience, offering a wisdom he didn't have a year ago, or does he forget his role in the Mets' failure?
 
Mound Chores
 Wally Whitehurst, whom the Mets chose over Ron Darling as their fifth starter, has not won a game since July 4, making seven unsuccessful starts since. But he is only second in the major leagues among starting pitchers who have labored the longest and most often without a victory.
Chris Nabholz of Montreal last won a game May 27. He has started nine times since without emerging with a victory. He has had shoulder trouble in that period of drought, missing seven weeks and many more starts he might not have won.
On the same night, Tuesday, that Whitehurst and Nabholz failed to win once more, Pascual Perez of the Yankees extended his personal drought to six starts. Also plagued by a shoulder ailment, Perez has not won since his first start, May 14. Danny Jackson of the Chicago Cubs and Bobby Witt of Texas, both of whom also have been hurt this season, each have made six starts without winning, Jackson last having gained a victory June 14 and Witt May 26.
Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd has not won any of the six starts he has made for the Rangers since they acquired him from Montreal last month.

HEADLINE: Santa Fe Journal;
Atomic Age Interrupts A Dance With the Sun

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Pueblo Indians called this city "the dancing ground of the sun." D. H. Lawrence memorialized the looming Sangre de Cristo Mountains. And this summer, residents and visitors to Santa Fe, a city in which the night can still be pierced by howling coyotes, have been routinely treated to sound and light shows as thunderstorms flashed across northern New Mexico, extending the white-water rafting season on the Rio Grande.
Yet for all the awesome power that nature routinely displays, many people in the nation's oldest state capital seem more concerned with the potential consequences of a force unleashed by humans at nearby Los Alamos National Laboratory, home of the atom bomb. 
 As early as next week, the United States Department of Energy is expected to certify that it is ready to begin testing the nation's first repository for military-related radioactive wastes from around the country. The $900 million underground dump in salt beds just east of Carlsbad is to store plutonium-contaminated tools, clothing and other debris.
Debris from Los Alamos could eventually pass through Santa Fe on a main street, St. Francis Drive.
Federal officials maintain that any threat to Santa Fe residents would be further diminished if a bypass road contemplated by state and Federal officials is finished before the department completes several years of test runs, shipping less dangerous wastes from Colorado and another national laboratory in Idaho over other routes.
But opponents from the Citizens Concerned for Nuclear Safety and other groups predict that the opening of the repository will be indefinitely delayed by legal hurdles and by Congressional intervention.
For a century, the dancing light of the skies of northern New Mexico and the splendid isolation have lured artists. More recently, people have come to escape congestion and pollution elsewhere. They have no pride of ownership in the atomic bomb. In contrast to the secrecy that surrounded the bomb project and partly as a consequence, the proposed nuclear repository has become a hot subject.
Opposition to the the repository, the Waste Isolation Pilot Project, or WIPP, is suggested by the sparse graffiti that mars Santa Fe's ubiquitous adobe. One message warns, "WIPP Is the Final Shaft."
But what is striking is the degree to which local businesses have been organized in opposition. Dozens of stores and restaurants display signs that identify them as "Another Business Against Wipp."
Katharine Kagel, a 43-year-old who moved here from California and runs the trendy Cafe Pasqual, said her opposition was based mostly on environmental concerns. "It's health, it's tourism, it's safety." she said. "We all chose to move here because it's primitive and wonderful, but this goes beyond not-in-my-backyard. It has to do with common sense."
Richard L. Johnson, the 42-year-old owner of the Cognito clothing store and director of the business opposition, agreed. "This is more than an environmental issue," said Mr. Johnson, another former Californian. "It's a health and safety issue. It's a tourism and economic issue. An accident has the tendency to turn tourist towns into ghost towns."
Tourism remains Santa Fe's dominant industry. The annual Indian Market weekend earlier this month attracted thousands of customers to stalls stocked with pottery and with silver and turquoise trinkets.
Santa Fe's chic informality contrasts with the bleaker conditions on the pueblos and elsewhere in the state that propelled New Mexico's welfare caseload to a record high last month. Poverty also accounts for some of the support for the radioactive waste dump in communities where it has generated jobs.
"They look to needy states where people will do anything for jobs," said Ira Estin, a river guide for the Southwest Adventure Group.
Thomas Lett, the state Department of Public Safety's WIPP coordinator, said he was not worried about the chance of an accident. But he expressed other reservations about the prospect of trucks loaded with radioactive waste passing by his home.
"The darn things are going to be weighing 80,000 pounds and will tear up the street," Mr. Lett complained.

HEADLINE: Study Shows Passing AIDS in Breast Milk Is Easier Than Thought

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Mothers can transmit AIDS to their infants through breast milk at a far higher rate than previously believed, researchers have found.
The study raises the question of whether infected mothers in developing countries should continue to breast-feed. The World Health Organization says they should because the risks of not breast-feeding are even greater. But in developed countries, the advice has long been the opposite: infected mothers are advised not to breast-feed. 
 In the study, carried out in Kigali, the capital of the Central African nation of Rwanda, researchers found that among 16 mothers who apparently were infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, between a quarter and a half passed the infection on to their infants through breast-feeding.
Until now, preliminary studies indicated that infants could but were not likely to become infected through breast-feeding.
 
'Dangerous to Ignore'
 The report, in Thursday's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, was the largest and most careful study of the subject yet published.
Dr. Michael Merson, director of the World Health Organization's Global Program on AIDS, said today that while the news was discouraging, the organization believed that women who did not have access to clean water and affordable infant formula should continue to breast-feed regardless of their infection.
Dr. Jonathan Mann, director of the Harvard AIDS Institute and former the chief of the health organization's global program on AIDS, said today that the study raised serious questions but that advising women in developing countries not to breast-feed would be a mistake now.
"I think the danger today would be to overreact and overinterpret this study," he said. "I also think it would be dangerous to ignore it."
He said more work should be done to determine whether it was riskier to an infant for an infected woman to breast-feed or for her to switch to possibly contaminated water and infant formula.
Dr. Susan Holck, chief of policy and planning at the health organization's Global Program on AIDS, said the risk of infant death from using contaminated water in making infant formula was several times higher than the risk of death from AIDS transmitted by breast-feeding even if the new, higher rates were taken into account.
In addition, formula is so expensive for the people of many countries that its use could be an economic catastrophe for the woman and her family as well.
 
9 of 16 Babies Infected
 In the United States, where clean water is generally available and infant formula relatively inexpensive, the federal Centers for Disease Control recommended in a policy established in 1985 that women infected with the AIDS virus should not breast-feed in most cases.
The study enrolled 212 pregnant women who came to the Hospital Center of Kigali, each of whom tested negative for the AIDS virus through the time of birth. Among those, 16 women tested positive for HIV antibodies three months or more after giving birth. It was believed that they became infected after birth either through sex or transfusions.
Nine of these women passed the infection on to their children. The authors of the study said it was possible that several of the nine women were actually infected during their pregnancy but did not appear positive in the first tests after birth. In those cases the babies could have been infected in the womb.
But four infants were most likely to have been infected by breast-feeding and four more may have been, wrote Dr. Phillipe Van de Perre, chief author of the study and a researcher at the National AIDS Control Program in Rwanda.
 
Results Are Hailed
 Dr. Holck hailed the results, "even though they don't change our minds about the recommendations we have for women."
"They show that the rate of transmission is much higher than we thought by this route, maybe as high as 50 percent chance of infants becoming infected."
It was an important finding for at least two other reasons.
First, the AIDS virus was already known to occur in breast milk but it was not known how efficiently the virus was transmitted to infants. The new results, Dr. Holck said, are encouraging, at least in showing that not all infected women transmit the virus through their milk."
Second, if the risk of infection is higher than thought, it may be more urgent for women to know whether they are infected or not in case they should become pregnant.
In a study published earlier this year, the Institute of Medicine at the National Academy of Sciences recommended against mandatory screening of pregnant women for the AIDS virus. The report encouraged women to get tested, however.
The authors of the new study said they may have found an especially high rate of passing the disease by breast-feeding because the women in this study, like all people who have just been infected, had very high numbers of viruses in their bodies and thus may be more infectious than at other times in the course of the disease.
Thus, if a woman is infected long before becoming pregnant, her chance of passing the disease along by breast-feeding may be smaller than that for a women infected at or just after pregnancy.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Schools Cost More but Achieve Less

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The Education Department today made public a back-to-school report that Education Secretary Lamar Alexander said would give a "heightened sense of urgency" to passage of President Bush's proposed education legislation.
The report predicted record spending on education at all levels and an increased enrollment of children in preschool programs. But Government officials said increased expenditures for each pupil had not translated into better educated students. 
 "Enrollment is up, spending is up, achievement is down," said Diane Ravitch, Assistant Secretary for the Office of Educational Research and Improvement.
Dr. Ravitch, David T. Kearns, the Deputy Secretary of Education, and Emerson Elliott, acting commissioner of the National Center for Education Statistics, attended a meeting with reporters at the Education Department's headquarters, where Mr. Alexander made public the annual report.
The report showed that the number of 3- and 4-year-old children enrolled in 56 preschool programs rose to 3.3 million in the 1990-91 school year from 2.3 million in 1980-81, a 44 percent increase.
Total education spending in the United States is expected to reach $414 billion in the 1990-91 school year, up 5.5 percent from the previous year and a record high. But when adjusted for inflation, the spending on education rose only slightly, to $395.7 billion in 1991 dollars. In the 1989-90 school year education spending was $385.1 billion after adjustment for inflation.
The report said elementary and high schools were expected to spend $249 billion in the 1991-92 school year, up 5 percent from $237 billion in 1990-91. Colleges and universities will spend about $165 billion in 1991-92, up from $155.4 billion last year.
But Dr. Ravitch, a former professor at Columbia University's Teacher's College, said increased spending and educational staff at the elementary and secondary level had not halted declines in student achievement noted in a survey by the National Assessment of Educational Progress released last year.
Dr. Ravitch also said studies showed that reading skills were improved when children read and were read to by their parents, but that such improvements were not finding their way into the classroom.
"The things we know that are contributing to achievement aren't happening," she said.
Asked whether the attempts by some communities to improve their schools through schools limited to students of one sex, as Detroit unsuccessfully proposed with an all-black male school, Mr. Alexander endorsed the 1954 Supreme Court decision in the Brown v. Board of Education case, which found that segregated schools are inherently unequal.
 
Lobbying Efforts Planned
 "Fortunately, we're returning to school this year with a national strategy for improving education and for helping the nation reach its education goals," the Secretary said, referring to the Bush Administration's education legislation, known as the America 2000 education plan.
Mr. Alexander said there would be some "stepped-up activities" around the country by the President and Mrs. Bush next month and in October to press for passage of the Administration's package of education legislation, which includes a plan to allow parents to have a choice of which school their children would attend.
Mr. Bush will visit Lewiston, Me., on Sept. 3 to talk about the proposal, Mr. Alexander said. And beginning on Sept. 4, the President will hold a conference call each day at 11:55 A.M. with the mayors and governors from areas that have designated themselves as America 2000 communities.
The Secretary also said that on Oct. 1 Mr. Bush plans to address the nation's children about the importance of education.

HEADLINE: St. Louis Rebuilding a Once-Grand Theater Area

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Once called the Broadway of the Midwest, the long-neglected midtown theater district in St. Louis is undergoing a renovation that may make it a model redevelopment project to rival Playhouse Square in Cleveland, the Music Center in Los Angeles and Lincoln Center in New York.
The $125 million Grand Center redevelopment project, which is expected to be completed by the turn of the century, is to include the construction of up to six new performing spaces for dance, theater, opera and chamber music, created in existing and new buildings, as well as restaurants, art galleries, craft stores and artists' studios and support facilities like prop and scenery building shops and rehearsal spaces. And Grand Center is hoping to lure KETC, the public broadcasting station in St. Louis, to planned new video facilities that could make the city a major advertising center. 
 Richard Gaddes and Thom Digman, two prime movers in the Grand Center project, laughingly describe themselves as "missionaries and parking lot kings." And that sums up the balance between artistic vision and commercial instinct that informs the project, which covers a once rundown and abandoned eight-block area in midtown St. Louis.
 
14 Theaters in Area Once
 From the 1920's through the 1940's, the section bisected by North Grand Boulevard between Delmar Boulevard and Olive Street boasted 14 theaters for movies, vaudeville and Broadway-bound plays and musicals. "It was a textbook of architecture," Mr. Gaddes said. But by the mid-1960's the district had become dingy and dispirited. St. Louis had become a national symbol of urban decay, with the flight of businesses and private citizens to the suburbs, though Eero Saarinen's soaring new Gateway Arch was beginning to serve as a symbol of hope and a thriving tourist attraction.
A revitalization effort was begun, led by the Rev. Paul Reinert, chancellor emeritus of St. Louis University, a major institution in the area. In 1966, the St. Louis Symphony moved into a refurbished Powell Symphony Hall, a former movie and vaudeville house built in the mid-1920's. The decaying 4,500-seat Fox Theater, a glittering neo-Byzantine movie palace built in 1929, was privately purchased in 1981 and restored to its former glory, re-opening as a theater for Broadway-style shows, ballet and popular music concerts. And the modernized Sheldon Concert Hall, a prim little chamber music hall famous for acoustics that rivaled those of Carnegie Hall, was once more in the business of presenting concerts.
Redevelopment faltered in the mid-1980's when tax changes reduced investment incentives. But the fact that the three theaters were selling over a million tickets a year suggested that the reclamation of the area was commercially viable. In 1987, Grand Center Inc. was formed. Mr. Gaddes, an arts administrator and opera impresario, was enlisted as president of the non-profit institution, which will own and operate the district's theaters, and of City Center Redevelopment, its subsidiary, whose functions include the acquisition and management of the properties. Mr. Digman became the vice president of City Center Redevelopment.
"This is all I've ever really wanted to do," Mr. Digman said. "I've known and loved this neighborhood for a long time."
 
Support for the Project
 Over $14 million of the $24 million needed for the first phase has been raised. Support for the project has come primarily from Civic Progress, an organization of leaders of major St. Louis corporations, from the city of St. Louis and from the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Trust for Historic Preservation, local arts commissions and private contributors.
In the first phase, one of the city's major galleries has purchased a building and opened a new gallery in the area. Seven arts organizations have relocated to an arts administration complex in the old Missouri Theater Building. As Mr. Gaddes expected, the groups can now share ideas and information -- and save money -- in hard and competitive economic times.
Work has begun on the Grandel Square Theater, a handsome 1883 limestone building that was once a church and that will now serve as a home theater for the St. Louis Black Repertory Company, the Theater Project Company and other performing groups. The 1907 Medinah Temple building is to be renovated to provide rehearsal and education spaces. And the former Block Brothers Photography Studio on Grandel Square, which has the sturdy grandeur of an H. H. Richardson building, is being renovated to serve as a patrons' center.
The vivid history of the area is exemplified in the Sheldon, which was designed by Louis C. Spiering, one of the principal architects of the 1904 World's Fair. The classical Greek building was erected as the headquarters of the Ethical Society of St. Louis, as a memorial to Walter Sheldon, its founder and a music lover. Every acoustical detail was carefully worked out, with slightly less attention paid to the comfort of the audience, seated in wooden seats in an interior that resembles that of a spare-looking New England church. "What you lose in the gluteals you gain in the aurals," Walter Gunn, the Sheldon's director, said.
 
A Church in Hot Pink
 The building was put up for sale in the late 1970's, after the Ethical Society had moved away. One tenant, called St. Michael's Church of the Expanded Mind, stapled vinyl zebra skin to the seats and painted the church hot pink and white, with a huge rainbow over the proscenium proclaiming "Love Is the Answer." An impresario bought the building in 1984, and it was purchased this year by a foundation headed by Leigh Gerdine, former president of Webster University in St. Louis. The foundation has embarked on a $3.5 million campaign to pay off the mortgage, make improvements and establish the theater as a self-sustaining institution.
The Grandel Square Theater, the project's first new performance space, exemplifies the area's promise. Through dust and construction debris, it is possible to pick out its woodbeam arches, huge old marble and wood mantel and rosette window, and to envision the 450-seat theater and elegant cafe scheduled to be completed by September 1992.
There has been some criticism by local arts groups that fund raising and construction have been slow. But the St. Louis project is not likely to be faced with the public outcry that greeted the demolition of business and residential buildings to make way for Lincoln Center in the late 1950's.
 
Gentrification a Concern
 "We were worried about gentrification," Mr. Gaddes said. "Thom, in particular, has worked hard to build bridges." Grand Center has consulted local institutions like the Urban League and, in the area, the Third Baptist Church, St. Louis University and the Veterans' Hospital. New lighting installed by Grand Center in the Blumeyer public housing complex to the north inspired new tenant participation in stemming its decline. Circus Flora, a European-style circus with offices in the administration building, has trained neighborhood children to perform with the group.
"We've only acquired one property that required relocation," Mr. Digman said. "And we relocated them in the district. Everything else was abandoned, or a vacant lot." A residential building in the district has become the home of a violin maker and an organization for black artists. "We see a large part of our role as helping stabilize the neighborhood and these arts groups," Mr. Gaddes said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Fox Theater in St. Louis, built in 1929, was recently restored. (Bill Stover for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:

Promotions and Packages
 Autumn is a time of big new packages and promotions, some of them in many parts and with high price tags. Next week, for example, Paramount begins to celebrate the 25th anniversary of "Star Trek" with tapes of the first three episodes of "Star Trek: The Next Generation," the television series. (Seventy-nine episodes of the original series are in circulation.) The price is $19.95 each. In addition, the five "Star Trek" feature films will be reissued in two different boxed sets. One will come in a slipcase and sell for $74.75; the other, with the five films in the letter-box format (bars across the top and bottom of the picture), will be sold in a cloth-bound box for $100. Individually, the five are still available at $14.95 each. 
 On Oct. 10, Paramount will present its "Godfather Collector's Edition" as well as "The Godfather Part III" alone. In the collector's package one gets "Part III" ( Francis Ford Coppola has added nine minutes to the original theatrical version), the first two "Godfather" films and a 73-minute documentary about the making of all three. The price will be $150 for the seven cassettes.
One may still rent "Part III" by itself, of course, and perhaps buy a copy for $15 or so during the used-cassette sale that often begins after the initial heavy-rental period of a month or more. Paramount is backing that promotion, too.
 
Helping the Blind
 "We hit the stores the same day as 'Dances With Wolves,' " said Robert Perrone, the assistant director of student training at the Braille Institute in Los Angeles. Yesterday the institute, which works with the blind and visually impaired, released its "Insight Series," five tapes of support and instruction for the afflicted and their families. "The blind population is increasing," said Mr. Perrone, who cited advancing age and the fact that cures for childhood illness sometimes impair sight. "The tapes are both educational and inspirational," Mr. Perrone said. "We provide direction."
The videos are introduced by Sidney Poitier, Charlton Heston and other Hollywood celebrities. "Bright Beginnings" instructs and encourages parents of preschool children; "Brighter Visions" addresses the elderly; "Touch and Go" examines the techniques of moving about outside the home; "Work Sight" talks about successful work experiences, and "Bridges to Independence" looks at the needs of blind or visually impaired teen-agers.
The videos, which are distributed by RCA/Columbia, are offered rent free at participating stores, or they can be bought for $25 each. Proceeds go the Braille Institute. Information: (800) 272-4553.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 
 
 
Dances With Wolves
1990. Orion. $99.98. 3 hours. Closed captioned. PG-13.
 During the Civil War a lone Union cavalry officer (Kevin Costner) rides west to the Dakota Territory and establishes personal ties with a tribe of Lakota Sioux. If Mr. Costner's film, which earned $180 million at the box office, has a weakness, it is that it sometimes takes itself a bit too seriously. Open spaces are grand, motives noble and scenes exciting, but at times the effort seems a bit too clean and admirable. Often the vistas seem more suited to a travelogue, and when the officer sticks a feather in his hair and struts around the village, "the movie teeters on the edge of Boy's Life literature, that is, on the brink of earnest silliness" (Vincent Canby).
 
La Femme Nikita
1991. Vidmark. $89.95. 1:57. French with English subtitles. R.
 A tough French street girl (Anne Parillaud) with a flair for killing is recruited by the Government to be an assassin. To perform the assignment she is made over into a wily, sleekly turned-out operative who somewhat incongruously falls in love with a supermarket clerk. Luc Besson's film is best appreciated for the high-gloss effectiveness of its pumped-up violence and sumptuous settings as well as "Miss Parillaud herself, a nimble and dangerous-looking actress with a fashion model's leggy cachet" (Janet Maslin).
 
Icicle Thief
1989. Fox Lorber. $79.95. 1:30. Italian with English subtitles. No rating.
 Maurizio Nichetti's film includes a film within a film and Mr. Nichetti playing two parts. In the first role he is the director of a movie called "The Icicle Thief," a black-and-white film with men on bicycles closely modeled after Vittorio de Sica's classic of nearly the same name. In the second role he is an unemployed father at home watching the movie, which is constantly interrupted by commercials. Rapid convolutions and role switches ensue in a story that sounds too contrived for its own good but that survives to "become an energetic and congenial farce" (Caryn James).
 
The Emperor's New Clothes and Other Folk Tales
Danny and the Dinosaur and Other Stories
1991. CC Studios. Two cassettes, $19.95 each. 30 minutes each.
 Seven tales for small children are accompanied by illustrations either from their books or commissioned for these tapes. Nadine Bernard Wescott's drawings, for example, turn out a splendiferous wardrobe for the emperor until swindlers produce the more basic outfit, and various provocative creatures gambol and ruminate in such tales as "Suho and the White Horse," "Why Mosquitoes Buzz in People's Ears" and "The Island of the Skog."
 
 
 
FRENCH THRILLERS
 Thrillers are a distinct genre of French film making, if not the best known. Here are a few of the better examples.
RIFIFI -- In Jules Dassin's seminal caper film, four thieves bring off a brilliant heist in total silence, then run afoul of each other. 1954. Video Yesteryear and various distributors. $29.95. 1:55. Subtitles. No rating.
DIABOLIQUE -- His wife (Vera Clouzot) and his mistress (Simone Signoret) kill a domineering schoolteacher -- or think they have until the fellow apparently keeps turning up alive. 1955. Video Yesteryear and various distributors. $29.95. 1:47. Subtitles. No rating.
THE WAGES OF FEAR -- Yves Montand and three other desperate characters are on a bumpy road to nowhere with a very skittish truckload of nitroglycerin. 1955. Video Yesteryear and various distributors. $29.95. 2:11. Subtitles. No rating.
Z -- Costa Gavras's classic examines the killing of a Greek political leader (Yves Montand). 1969. RCA/Columbia recently stopped distribution but copies are available. $29.95. 2:07. Subtitles. PG.
RIDER ON THE RAIN -- Charles Bronson stars in Rene Clement's taut, twisting film about an American who takes advantage of a rape victim. 1970. Monterey. $29.95. 1:59. Dubbed. No rating.
THIS MAN MUST DIE -- The father of a hit-and-run victim schemes to avenge his son's death. Claude Chabrol directed. 1970. CBS/Fox. $59.98. 1:52. Dubbed. No rating.
WEDDING IN BLOOD -- Mr. Chabrol turns up the suspense when two lovers plot to kill their spouses. 1973. RCA/Columbia. $69.95. 1:38. Subtitles. No rating.

HEADLINE: A GARDENER'S WORLD;
Blue Rose? Why, of All Bloomin' Things?
Because of Its 'Mystery'

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER

 BODY:
GENETIC engineers in Australia say they have isolated the gene that controls the color blue -- and stuck it into the red red rose.
The quest, which has taken four years, is likened to the search for the Holy Grail by Michael Dalling, president of Calgene Pacific Proprietary Ltd., a genetic engineering concern in Melbourne. But the blue rose is still a test-tube baby. 
 "We've isolated the gene that controls the synthesis of the pigment delphinidum, which was originally extracted from blue delphinium, but we're taking it out of a blue petunia," Mr. Dalling said. "And now we have to insert this gene into a single cell of the rose plant, and get it to regenerate into a fully functioning plant: leaves, stem, buds, the whole thing."
After growing in the lab for a couple years, it will have to prove itself in the field, doing basic tasks like blooming and not losing its petals. Not to mention blooming a true blue, rather than those muddy blues and lavenders so many hybridizers have touted under the names of Blue Skies and Blue Girl and so forth.
Calgene's partner in this venture is Suntory Ltd., a Japanese conglomerate best known for its whisky. "A lot of liquor companies are interested in the uses of biotechnology in the fermentation process," Mr. Dalling said.
Rose growers in the United States compare the blue rose to the black orchid. You long for what you don't have. Until you get it.
"It's got a mystery to it," said Robert Griesbach, a geneticist for the United States Department of Agriculture. "Gardeners want them, but it's not a large constituency. On Valentine's Day, people are not going to buy blue roses."
But the Japanese will, Mr. Dalling insists, "because it's unique." And the Japanese are also ritualistic gift-givers. "It's important to their whole social being," he said, adding that giving a dozen of blue roses, which are expected to sell for almost $1,000, would "mean you thought very highly of someone."
And sure, men give women red roses on Valentine's Day to say, "I love you." "But why couldn't women say the same thing with blue roses?" Mr. Dalling said. (Like those sinuous women in the Bailey's Bristol Cream ads, who can invite men over for drinks without appearing macho.)
The rose, economically, is nothing to be sniffed at. "We consumed over a billion roses in this country last year," said Alvi Voight, an agricultural economist at Pennsylvania State University. And that added up to about $1.5 billion, he estimated.
But as for the blue rose, well, some experts are skeptical.
"I gave a snicker when I heard about it," said Michael Ruggiero, the rose curator for the New York Botanical Garden. "Hybridizers have come up with a lot of 'blue' roses, but they're lavender, not blue."
Mr. Ruggiero pulled out his catalogue from Interstate Nurseries in Missouri. "Blue Skies is supposed to have lobelia-blue buds," he said. "Here it is, in bold print: 'The Bluest Rose Ever.' But it looks lavender to me."
Although breeders are intrigued by Calgene's claim, they say that simply isolating a gene and inserting it into another plant is only one stage of a complex, little-understood game.
"Flower color is a very complex phenomenon," Mr. Griesbach said. "Most people on the street think that one pigment gives you one flower color, but that is simply not true."
Cyanidin is the pigment in the red rose, for example. But it's also the pigment in blue cornflowers.
"One of the modifying factors in flower color is pH," Mr. Griesbach said. "In red flowers, the pH is acidic; in blue flowers, it's alkaline. And there are other modifying factors like co-pigments and metals."
It's the interaction of all these compounds that makes a red rose or a blue rose, he said; there is no such thing as a blue gene or a red gene.
Calgene agrees that flower color is a complex process, but the company says its isolation of the gene is the key to the blue rose. "We're hoping to produce a whole range of colors," said Mr. Dalling said. "Pastel blue for the Japanese, and a deeper, darker blue for the Americans."
And the hybridizers will probably make sure that the petals don't fall off. And that the blue rose blooms in the first place.
"If Calgene creates a rose that expresses the color blue, more than likely it will not be a good variety," said Keith Zary, director of research for Jackson & Perkins, an Oregon rose company that has already talked to Calgene. "It may be disease-prone, or it may not flower enough. So we conventional breeders will cross the original to get better plants."
And Calgene has applied for a patent for the gene they isolated, he said. "So anybody who wants to use that gene will have to be licensed by the owner," Mr. Zary said. "And I'm sure it won't be cheap."
Genetic engineering could turn the garden into a new wild frontier.
"I think it's great," said Leonard Veasey, the rosarian at the American Rose Society in Louisianna. "I can't remember how long ago it was that there weren't any orange roses. And now I hear somebody's working on extracting a gene from marine plants that will make roses glow in the dark."
Mr. Ruggiero, the curator, calls it "spooky." The very idea. Mixing plant families. "I'd like to see them do a day lily with an oak tree," he said. "Imagine a 40-foot plant that bloomed for one day."
