HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Big Tickets Revisited

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
The continuing collapse of the Soviet Union, despite Mikhail Gorbachev's effort to preserve its vestiges, raises hard questions about the U.S. Senate's decision to spend $10 billion reviving an anti-missile defense abandoned 20 years ago.
A defense against whom? The hard-liners in Moscow have been shown to be bumblers, rather than a threat to take power. If one of the dissident republics got control of an ICBM, it might more likely fire it at the Kremlin than the U.S. And whatever shreds of the former superpower that survive will need aid from the West, not war with it. 
 Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, a main sponsor of the ABM revival, cited "C.I.A. estimates that 15 to 20 third-world countries will have them [missiles] by the turn of the century."
"What 'them' is he talking about?" asked Sherman Frankel, a physics professor at the University of Pennsylvania, in a letter to the editor of The New York Times. "There is a huge difference between a Scud with a few hundred mile range, barely capable of reaching Israel from Iraq, and an ICBM that must travel thousands of miles . . . and be powerful enough to carry a nuclear weapon."
Mr. Frankel further argued that, if the threat is from accidental launches, defense efforts would be better focused on providing funds for deploying a "post-launch control system" to render harmless a mistaken or unauthorized missile firing. He is an authority on such a system.
In a letter to me, Sydney D. Drell, deputy director of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, also questioned the threat: "Is it theatre missiles? Is it intercontinental range ballistic missiles from Third World countries? Very different technical challenges are presented by these radically different potential threats," including remaining Soviet ICBM's.
Mr. Drell pointed out, moreover, that "before embarking on new deployments or ABM Treaty modifications" (both required by the Senate plan), the U.S. "must seriously think through the arms control and security implications." But, he added: "Theatre defense against shorter range missiles can proceed sensibly without impact on the ABM Treaty."
Therefore, he suggested, the Senate had "put the cart before the horse" because "a strong R&D program emphasizing ground-based technology is what is called for."
On Aug. 1, in this space, an objection was registered to the anti-missile program as one of several unneeded "big ticket" items, including the Superconducting Supercollider. Mr. Frankel and Mr. Drell took vigorous exception to describing the supercollider as a useless "monstrosity" that would cost $11 billion better devoted to "smaller science programs."
"You simply have goofed," Mr. Frankel wrote me, and defended the device's high cost: "The last high energy accelerator built in this country is about 20 years old and it is unlikely that after the [supercollider] is built that there will be another step before about a quarter of a century. So the yearly cost is not so high."
Mr. Drell strongly defended "the importance, as well as the practicality" of the supercollider, which he termed "crucially important to our efforts to further our understanding of the basic forces and the elementary particles of nature and how they unify [Einstein's lifelong dream]."
The physics community, he wrote, had developed a "strong consensus" on the supercollider's "unique importance." Physicists' "very limited understanding of the origin of the masses of what we today call 'elementary particles' has given us confidence that there must be fundamental new phenomena to be discovered when we probe nature at the collision energies designed for the [supercollider]."
A third physicist's voice, that of Terrence L. Watts of Rutgers, suggested that the supercollider would be a "great place" with "excellent physics" for training students. It would, he contended, make "a good contribution to the education of scientists and to the strengths of our universities," rather than swallowing funds needed elsewhere.
All U.S. science, "not just the workers in small science," he insisted, suffer from "barely adequate funding" -- but not because of big-ticket items. Rather, the deficiency "is a general aspect of the excess military buildup of the recent decade and the reduction in growth of our economy."
Mr. Watts thinks he can help reverse economic decline "by training scientists at the [supercollider]." If he can, more power to him.

HEADLINE: Essay;
After the Fall

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I've been out of touch for a few weeks; anything happen while I was on vacation?
No Rip Van Winkle could be more delighted: Communism is dead. The Soviet empire is breaking up. This is a glorious moment for human freedom. 
 We should savor that moment, thanking God, NATO, the heroic dissidents in Russia and the internal empire, and the two-generation sacrifice of the American people to protect themselves and the world from despotic domination.
We should seize the moment, too, to urge our new comrades in freedom to use counter-coup momentum to destroy the institutions and bring down the elite that oppressed them.
Mr. Gorbachev is still half-measuring: the K.G.B. chief has been arrested and some top brass demoted, while its troops are reassigned to the Defense Ministry and much fuss is made over the tearing down of the statue of Iron Feliks Dzerzhinsky.
But that means the secret police is intact, awaiting the moment for new leaders and a reassignment of assets to seize power. Free people need no secret police; the K.G.B.'s entire budget should be seized and used to buy food to help people get through the winter. Unpaid agents and bureaucrats will have an incentive -- hunger -- to go out into the fields and bring in the harvest.
And who needs a huge Red Army? Nobody is threatening Russia or the other republics. The soldiers proved their heroism by refusing to fire on the people; the Red Army can serve most honorably by demobilizatsiya on a vast scale, now.
Needed throughout the societies is a good witch hunt, not for Communist-style repression so universally tut-tutted but to ferret out the assets of the "new class" of corrupt officials and to force parasitic apparatchiks to do an honest day's work.
The shrinking center should sell the land and shares in the factories to the people (they'll do a land-office business), and turn over the natural resources to the republics, letting the profit motive of free enterprise -- not welfare handouts disguised as loan guarantees -- save the lands that Communism failed.
Why isn't the President of the United States on the air welcoming the Russians, Ukrainians and all to the free world, urging the dissolution of the police and cutbacks in the army, showing the path to prosperity?
Part of the answer: He does not want to make another foreign-affairs mistake. This spring Mr. Bush blundered grievously in the giveback of Iraq; this summer, in his dismaying "Chicken Kiev speech," he lectured Ukrainians against self-determination, foolishly placing Washington on the side of Moscow centralism and against the tide of history.
The rest of the answer is that Mr. Bush and his advisers have long feared the breakup of the empire that calls itself a union. The scare words are "disunion, dismemberment, disintegration." The fear is not irrational: tight central control of the Soviet nuclear command "football" is in our vital national interest. We are also rightly concerned about the local pogroms and border clashes that disunion may bring.
But the strategic advantage to an end to imperialism is compelling. With the Soviet monolith broken up and a commonwealth established to negotiate arms reductions, the world will be a far safer place.
The moral advantage to disunion is overlooked by diplomats hung up on tidiness. Personal freedom is often aligned with self-determination; diverse cultures that want to assert independence should have America's support, not finger-wagging at ethnic hatreds to conceal our preference for foreign central control.
The argument is moot; disunion is a fact. Democrats from Bill Bradley in Washington to Gary Hart in Moscow are spelling out serious responses, while Mr. Bush, in a policy paralysis he calls prudence, is barking "not so fast" from a golf cart.
Two and a half years ago, the first of the "Free the Baltics" columns appeared in this space. Those three small nations were the key to imperial disunion, and the Landsbergis stand against tanks in the Vilnius parliament led to the Yeltsin stand at the Russian parliament last week.
In a day or two, Mr. Bush is expected to follow the world in sending envoys to the Baltics. The freed pioneers of the breakup will then help the Soviet Economic Union get on its feet. These are great days.

HEADLINE: Delve Deeper Into C.I.A.-Bank Connection;
Pakistan Bias as Usual

 BODY:
Yo the Editor:
Recent anti-Semitic remarks by a Pakistani official made while defending the founder of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International (Business Day, Aug. 1) should be condemned by the world community. 
 The highest elected official in the Pakistani province of Sindh, Jam Sadiq Ali, stated that "B.C.C.I. was a third world bank, and it took to the challenge of breaking a hegemonistic control of the Jewish lobby on the world's financial institutions."
This is hardly the first time Pakistanis have spewed anti-Semitic canards and engaged in blatant discrimination. In the early 1980's the Pakistan-based World Muslim Congress sent anti-Semitic, Holocaust revisionist material to British members of Parliament and the United States Congress; in 1982 the Pakistani Government denied entry to a European Parliamentary Commission seeking to meet with Afghan refugees on the grounds it was headed by a Jew; in 1983 Pakistan's information minister said "the international media are surely and securely in the hands of the Jews."
Only last year the Pakistani film "International Guerrillas," which depicted Salman Rushdie as a decadent and evil leader of a worldwide Jewish conspiracy against Islam, played to record audiences across Pakistan.
Once again, a Pakistani has scapegoated the Jews for the nefarious activities of others. That such canards continue to emanate from Government officials is all the more outrageous.
 
ABRAHAM H. FOXMAN
Natl. Director, Anti-Defamation
League of B'nai B'rith
New York, Aug. 9, 1991

HEADLINE: Lessons in Ignorance Breed Prejudice

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your front-page article "Afrocentrism: Balancing or Skewing History?" (Aug. 11) brought back painful memories of a particular lesson I remember from my sixth-grade geography book. 
 This was 1953-54, and the book was my school's authorized text from which the students learned about the world. My sister was a year behind me, and she too remembers this lesson about Africa: the text described how many, many years ago, when a great fire had swept the plains of Africa, the natives escaped from it by jumping feet-first into holes in the ground.
Because the holes were not very deep, when the fire crossed over the hideouts of the Africans, the heat singed their hair. And that, according to this text, was why Africans had kinky hair.
Reading that passage brought terrible visions of flames and horror to my mind. For a brief time after that I even believed that, unlike my classmates whose hair was straight, that really was why my hair was kinky.
Racial tensions have increased in the United States, as well as in countries like France, Germany and Britain. The lack of understanding or knowing about others who are red or black or brown or yellow or white rips at the fabric of humanity.
Count the times that you have heard people say, "They should go back where they came from." It is a statement that is born of fear and fed by ignorance.
Other times the statement is economic: to improve their quality of living, immigrants often work two and three jobs -- jobs Americans refuse -- only to be hated by their neighbors when they buy a house or a car. As people migrate from one continent to another, America loses its place as the melting pot. Earth is the melting pot.
Scholars will probably never agree on the absolute history of other colors, but by debating it in public we can hope that they will find the best way to teach it.
 
DOREEN SPELTS
Doylestown, Pa., Aug. 11, 1991

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Disney Theme Parks Get a New President

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Judson C. Green has been named president of Walt Disney Attractions, assuming responsibility for running the company's theme parks in California, Florida and Europe.
Mr. Green, previously senior vice president and chief financial officer of the parent, the Walt Disney Company, succeeds Richard A. Nunis, who has been promoted to chairman of Walt Disney Attractions. 
 The changes come at a difficult time in the theme park business because the recession has reduced attendance. "It's been a horrendous year for discretionary travel in general, and more specifically for relatively high-ticket items such as trips to Disney World in Florida," said Harold Vogel, who follows Disney for Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
At Disney World, for example, which also faces competition from the new Universal Studio Tour in Orlando, Mr. Vogel estimated that attendence in the quarter ending Sept. 30 would be down about 14 percent.
Although "it is a hard time for anyone involved in the hospitality industry," Mr. Green said in an interview, "we have our sights on the long term and we won't stop pursuing those plans."
Mr. Green, who will be based in Burbank, Calif., said he expected to spend about half his time overseas for a while in preparation for the opening of Euro Disney, near Paris, in April 1992.
Mr. Green, 39 years old, joined Disney in 1981 and has served in positions that include vice president for finance and planning for the Walt Disney World Resorts before becoming chief financial officer in 1989.
"This promotion would suggest that Judson is being groomed for higher positions, since he is getting exposure to both the financial and operating sides of the business," said Harold Vogel, an analyst at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Ever since joining the company in 1955, Mr. Nunis, 59, has worked in the theme parks division, holding such positions as director of park operations and vice president for operations before becoming president of Walt Disney Attractions in 1980.
Mr. Green attended Depauw University and received a master's degree in business administration from the Universtiy of Chicago in 1976. He and his wife, Joyce, have two children.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1192 words

HEADLINE: New York State Weighs Canceling A Huge Canadian Power Contract

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
The future of a giant hydroelectric construction project in northern Quebec, already under siege from environmentalists, faces a new threat: a move by New York State to back away from a $17 billion, 21-year contract to buy power.
On Tuesday night, the New York Power Authority said it had reached an agreement with Hydro-Quebec to delay until Nov. 30, 1992, a decision on whether to buy one million kilowatts of hydroelectricity from the Canadian utility. The New York authority had originally said it would decide by the end of this year and, if it agreed to the sale, begin buying the power in 1995. 
 It said on Tuesday that it was reconsidering the Canadian deal because conservation efforts, among other factors, had improved the state's energy outlook since 1989, when the original agreement was reached. The Power Authority, a state agency that resells electricity to utilities at no profit, has been Hydro-Quebec's largest customer outside of Canada. It supplies about a quarter of the state's electricity.
If the authority decides against going ahead with the contract, Hydro-Quebec would be likely to delay its sprawling Great Whale hydroelectric project near James Bay, utility officials and environmentalists say.
If the contract is ratified, the Power Authority would buy one million kilowatts year-round, enough for one million households at any given moment. It would sell about 80 percent of the power to three utilities in the New York metropolitan area: Consolidated Edison, the Long Island Lighting Company and Orange and Rockland Utilities.
Con Edison, which serves New York City, would buy almost half of the Canadian power for $6.1 billion over 21 years. If the contract falls through, the utilities would have to find additional power through further conservation or from greater reliance on independent power producers.
The Great Whale project, 650 miles north of Montreal, is at the heart of Hydro-Quebec's plans to expand its northern Quebec operations, already among the world's largest sources of hydroelectric power.
Environmentalists as well as the people in the region, chiefly the Cree Indians and the Inuit, have fought to stop the project. They say the utility's plan to dam the Great Whale River to generate the power, thereby flooding hundreds of square miles, would doom the hunting, trapping and fishing that have defined a way of life there.
Environmentalists say that if New York cancels its agreement, the Great Whale project could be delayed for many years. The utility, which is owned by the province of Quebec, agrees there would be a delay but says it would be for only two or three years.
Lining up big export customers like New York State is an important step if Hydro-Quebec is to obtain financing from Wall Street investors for the James Bay expansion, which the utility says is necessary to meet Quebec's growing energy demand.
 
Second Thoughts
 The Power Authority's move to extend the deadline for a decision suggests that it is having second thoughts about the economics of the deal. In 1984, hydroelectric power from Hydro-Quebec met 8.8 percent of New York State's needs. But the total has dropped substantially in the last few years because of low water levels in Quebec.
"These are signs that the deal is beginning to unravel," said State Senator Franz S. Leichter, Democrat of Manhattan, who has been a leading political opponent to the contract.
In an interview, the authority's chairman, Richard M. Flynn, denied that the authority was smoothing the way for a contract cancellation. Instead, he said, the 11-month delay would be spent reviewing the cheapest ways to provide power to the state as well as the environmental costs of dependence on fossil fuels like oil.
A draft of a New York State energy plan released this month found that a new contract with Hydro-Quebec could raise electricity rates slightly for New Yorkers. But it also noted that alternative power sources like oil- and coal-fueled plants could increase air pollution in parts of the state where pollution levels already exceed Federal standards.
Mr. Flynn said the authority could decide to go ahead with the Hydro-Quebec contract but negotiate for a lower price or delay its 1995 starting date.
In a statement Tuesday night, Mr. Flynn said that since 1989, when the tentative contract was signed, projections of the state's energy needs had changed because of progress in utility conservation programs and an increasing use of independent suppliers.
"Now it's appropriate to re-evaluate the contract in light of these changed conditions," Mr. Flynn said.
 
Cuomo Says Option Open
 In recent weeks, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has said in meetings with opponents of the contract that cancellation remained an option, said Frank Murray Jr., a spokesman for the Governor. But the state has yet to conclude that the Canadian power is uneconomical, he said. The Power Authority chairman is appointed by the Governor and confirmed by the State Senate.
A spokesman for Hydro-Quebec said he did not know what the Power Authority would conclude.
"Frankly, I don't know. Every option is open," said the spokesman, Pierre Bolduc, executive vice president for external markets, in a telephone interview from Montreal. "We are aware that there are second thoughts about the contract in New York."
Mr. Bolduc said Great Whale would be built with or without the New York State contract because the Quebec economy would eventually require the power. He said the loss of the contract would probably delay the project's start-up, but only for perhaps two years, from 1998 or 1999 to 2000 or 2001.
 
Big Setback Seen
 But people who have followed Hydro-Quebec's strategy say cancellation of the New York contract would be a major blow to the utility.
"If New York pulls out, then Hydro-Quebec has to go back to the drawing board," said Jan Beyea, chief scientist for the National Audubon Society, which has been fighting the Great Whale project for five years.
The society and other environmental groups have apparently been heard. Assemblyman William B. Hoyt, a Democrat of Buffalo and a leading opponent, said that a "ferocious environmental movement" had arisen in the last year in New York State and that the Power Authority's decision shows that Governor Cuomo "doesn't want to be painted into a corner" on the issue.
This month, Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York wrote to the Power Authority chairman, Mr. Flynn, asking the agency to further study the economic value of the new hydropower.
Hydro-Quebec's plan has also created a jurisdictional dispute in Canada; the province of Quebec is battling the Federal Government in Ottawa over who has final say on environmental review.
James A. Dumont, a lawyer for several environmental groups as well as the Cree Indians, compared the fight against the new hydroelectric power to the long battle against nuclear energy, in which construction of many nuclear plants has been too costly to continue.
"We may not have convinced the skeptics about the environmental problems," he said, "but for financial reasons the contracts will die."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 6, 1991, Friday

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Urgent Question On Aid to Soviets

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AS the Soviet Union struggles on the brink of economic collapse and political dissolution, the urgent question facing the United States and its partners in the Group of Seven industrialized countries is what posture to take on foreign aid to the nation and its seceding republics.
President Bush is still holding to the cautious approach to Soviet aid that Western leaders agreed to during the London economic summit conference in July. In the midst of the incredible events that began 10 days ago with the attempted coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Bush said he had "seen nothing to make me change my mind" about the group's agreement not to give Moscow direct financial aid until more fundamental steps are taken to establish a market economy. The Western leaders also agreed to offer the Soviet Union only technical assistance and associate membership in the International Monetary Fund. 
 These 10 days have been the obverse of the "10 days that shook the world" during the Russian Revolution in November 1917, and have reversed that revolution. Yet, the Bush Administration is holding firm, waiting for the dust to settle. Prime Minister John Major of Britain, visiting Mr. Bush at Kennebunkport, Me., said he sided with Mr. Bush on the aid issue. But the leaders of Germany, France and Italy are calling for a big package of money to help speed Soviet economic reform and recovery.
Some Congressional leaders are also pressing Mr. Bush for a more forthcoming response to the Soviet crisis. Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, proposed this week to cut $1 billion from weapons spending to provide humanitarian aid, declaring, "We do not want the first winter of freedom after 70 years of Communism to be a disaster for the Soviet Union." Mr. Bush told reporters on Wednesday that he had not yet considered the question of food aid but added, "We want to do our part on that." The Group of Seven yesterday pledged urgent help to prevent famine this winter but held to its cautious line on other aid for the sinking Soviet economy.
The question of providing long-term aid to help rescue that economy is far more difficult. Prof. Abram Bergson, a distinguished Sovietologist at the Russian Research Center of Harvard University, said in an interview, "The situation is too fluid to permit the construction of meaningful plans for long-term aid." But he favors immediate aid with food, medicine and spare parts for factories.
The Soviet gross national product dropped 10 percent in the first six months of this year, and before the attempted coup, the Soviet Statistical Office predicted that G.N.P. would fall 6 percent further before the end of the year.
"The disorder of the coup is likely to compound the decline, rather than offset it," Professor Bergson said. Hunger looms, he warned, not only because of falling farm production but also because of the broken-down distribution system. He characterized the Bush Administration as being "prudent to the point of stultification."
And Robert D. Hormats, a former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs who is vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International, urged the United States and other Western countries to do more to reward the democratic forces in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe by opening Western markets wider to their exports. He said a successful completion of the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations would help the East greatly by liberalizing trade in agriculture, textiles and other manufactured goods.
The economic problems in Eastern Europe have been aggravated by the splitting up of the Comecon trade bloc -- and the inability of the ex-Communist countries to export to the West. A breakup of the Soviet Union into separate republics, with no center to hold their economies together, could have like effects.
None of the republics, Mr. Hormats said, have yet developed economic plans. Yesterday, Russia and the Ukraine, the two most populous republics, agreed to form a temporary economic and military alliance and invited other "former subjects of the U.S.S.R." to join them.
But if such efforts at sustaining integration fail and the economy collapses, there could be devastating political consequences -- even civil war.
Hard-pressed on every side, Mr. Gorbachev is struggling to hold the Soviet Union together. Some may see parallels to the American Civil War -- in the issues of saving the union, preserving economic strength and winning the struggle for freedom.
But there are vast differences, too: Mr. Gorbachev is no Lincoln; he is unsure of his direction, and as he made clear when he returned to Moscow from the Crimea after the coup, he was still trying to save the Communist Party and the Marxist-Leninist revolution. He speaks in the name of political and economic freedom, but the republics oppose him, demanding their own freedom.
Still, there are opportunities as well as hazards for the West in this tumultuous and complex situation. The possibility of helping rescue the Soviet Union and its constituent republics from economic collapse and of achieving democracy, arms reductions and a secure peace are of vital importance to the world.
A safe transition from Communism to democracy and economic freedom could be the greatest benefit of the end of the cold war. For the United States, it would save the "peace dividend" and help provide the budgetary relief, savings and investment capital needed to establish the basis for stronger and more stable economic growth, both at home and abroad.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains After Report That Fed Won't Cut Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher against most leading currencies yesterday, bolstered by reports that the Federal Reserve would not immediately lower interest rates.
Currency analysts said the dollar initially fell in response to two reports that underscored the economy's weakness. The Government reported that in July, Americans' incomes fell for the first time in six months and new-home sales slumped 8.5 percent. 
 But markets bounced off opening lows after the central bank denied a rumor circulating in Europe that it was preparing to ease interest rates.
There had been speculation in recent weeks that the Fed was moving toward lower rates amid growing evidence of an anemic economic recovery. Lower interest rates, while considered good for economic growth, can hurt the dollar because they decrease the value of dollar-denominated investments.
 
Purchase Seen in Switzerland
 Also increasing demand were reports of a large dollar purchase by a currency fund manager out of Switzerland, said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer for Barclays Bank P.L.C. in New York.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 136.73 yen, down 0.40 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 136.95 yen, and in New York, it finished at 137.15, up from late Wednesday's 136.55.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6805, compared with $1.6900 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound settled at $1.6835, down from late Wednesday's $1.6900.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.7440 German marks, up from 1.7395; 1.5240 Swiss francs, up from 1.5171; 5.9195 French francs, up from 5.9025; 1,301.50 Italian lire, up from 1,297.50, and 1.14045 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14075.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metal Prices Drop On Fears of Soviet Selloff

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver futures prices fell to six-month lows yesterday and other precious metals also dropped on fears that political upheaval in the Soviet Union could cause a huge selloff of gold.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for September delivery was $3 lower, at $350.90 an ounce, and September silver was 10.1 cents lower, at $3.82 an ounce. 
 Traders were reluctant to hold positions in gold amid speculation that independence-minded Soviet republics could seize stores of gold and sell large amounts to raise cash to aid their crumbling economies.
"There's plenty of Soviet jitters on the market right now," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures in New York. "The market seems to be highly fearful that there could be sales from other" Soviet states.
The leader of the Russian federation, Boris Yeltsin, reversed his position yesterday and agreed to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's request that gold be handled by a central Soviet agency, but that did little to calm the market fears, Mr. O'Neill said.
Investors also fear the Soviet Union could default on loans held by big Swiss banks, and they in turn could sell the gold they hold as collateral, he said.
Silver followed gold lower, slipping to six-month lows on most contracts. Prices also fell on word of significant selling in the Middle East and selling before the end of the near-term contract. The December silver contract fell to $3.89 an ounce, a level not seen since Feb. 28.
Yet, Peter Cardillo, the director of research at Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York, said the demand for both gold and silver remains fairly strong, and the market fell for technical reasons.
Energy futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange gained on word of a minor disruption of output in the North Sea.
October crude was 23 cents higher, at $21.97 a barrel; September heating oil was 0.95 cent higher, at 63.19 cents a gallon; September unleaded gasoline was 0.62 cent higher, at 65.96 cents a gallon, and October natural gas was 0.07 cents higher, at $1.571 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grains and soybeans futures prices ended mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade on prospects of widespread thundershowers helping parched crops. Prices also were under pressure because of the lack of solid developments in the Soviet Union's credit situation.
September wheat futures settled 3/4 cent lower, at $3.04 1/2 a bushel; September corn settled 3 cents lower, at $2.47 a bushel; September oats were 1 1/4 cents lower, at $1.21 1/2 a bushel; September soybeans were 2 cents lower, at $5.68 1/2 a bushel.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle prices slipped after gaining early in the session on word that twice the normal number of cattle transactions had not cleared. Pork futures were mixed.
October cattle were 0.25 cent lower, at 69.70 cents a pound; August feeder cattle were 0.10 cent higher, at 87.25 cents a pound; October hogs were 0.18 cent lower, at 43.77 cents a pound; February pork bellies were 0.18 cent lower, at 47.62 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Remarks by Bush and Briton: Unity on Reforms Reaffirmed

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 29

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference today by President Bush and Prime Minister John Major of Britain:

 	 	 		OPENING STATEMENTS	 	 	 	 		President Bush	 	We stand united, as do other Western partners, in our commitment to help Soviet reform. The industrial democracies have already undertaken steps to aid the economic process. . . . But we must remember that the Soviet Union is undergoing a major political change. 
 And the Prime Minister and I also had a discussion about the Baltics. The U.S. is a strong supporter of Baltic independence. We've so notified the Soviet Union, and we've urged the Soviet leadership not to stand against the will of the inevitable, the winds of this inevitable change. The Baltics want freedom; clearly the United States and the U.K. want them to have freedom, and clearly the Baltics will have freedom. . . .
 
Prime Minister Major

. . . We certainly agree absolutely on our objectives in responding to the collapse of Communism in the Soviet Union. We need to support democracy; we need to encourage the economic reform that they so badly need in the Soviet Union, and we need also to respond compassionately to the urgent needs that the Soviet people have at the present time.
We will go on talking to the Soviet authorities, the central authorities, and also building on the existing relationships and the developing relationships with the new leaders in the republics. We're already in touch with the leaders of the Baltic states, and I hope, when I visit Moscow on Sunday, that I will be able to meet some if not all of them, as well as Presidents Gorbachev and Yeltsin and some of the other key figures. . . .
We agreed this morning on the principles governing aid to the Soviet Union. There is a window of opportunity at present for the speeding up of the economic reform process, and that is absolutely vital for the Soviet Union. The need to speed that is urgent, and we agreed this morning that we need to support the effort.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Our judgment is that what the Soviet Union and the republics most need is emergency humanitarian assistance, practical help in converting their economy into one that works. And that means that aid must be linked to a clear and comprehensive and practical reform plan, that it must go to those people who are in need, including directly to the individual republics, and that it needs to be linked to the Soviet commitment to further reduce defense spending.
And we were able to identify in our discussions this morning six particular points worthy of action.
The first is to implement existing food credits. The second is to assess the need for food aid during this winter. The third is to produce lifeline teams, teams to travel to the Soviet Union to help achieve efficient food production and food distribution; that may well be a public-private partnership, and it's an area where we and the United States will be moving ahead in the days and weeks. . . .
We agreed also we needed to implement the knowhow programs and the technical assistance that we discussed at the G-7 and the bilateral agreements we already have to assist the Soviets on that front. We also felt that the time was right to get the [International Monetary Fund] and the World Bank involved urgently in helping to work out practical structural reform plans and technical assistance for the Soviet Union.
And, sixth, we agreed that it would be right to accelerate implementation of special association for the Soviet Union with the IMF, with a view to full membership in due course for those who qualify, and by qualify I mean as well in terms of effective reform plans.

 	 	 		QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS	 	
 
The Pace of Change
 Q. The Supreme Soviet has been meeting most of this week. . . . Yet things seem about as confused today as they did 48 or 72 hours ago. Are things moving a little bit too slowly on that front for you or do you see things falling into place?
BUSH: No, I think the changes are so monumental that it is going to take time to sort it all out with finality. Every day there are new announcements of some new dramatic step taking place. So that's for them to sort out. We can't affect it particularly. I think the Prime Minister is right on target when he says we want to help; we're not just bystanders. We have a tremendous stake in what's taking place. But no, these changes have moved with such rapidity that -- well, put it this way: if two weeks ago somebody had predicted this, everybody would have said he had lost it.
. . . All the cards are not on the table when it comes to what the United States role should be or the U.K. role in further assistance of one kind or another. . . . We are watching. . . . learning. And we stand ready to be of assistance because what's at stake here is democracy and freedom. . . .
 
Western Policies
 Q. Most of the measures that you say you've discussed today involve speeding up things that were already in train. Do you not have any sense that given the momentous changes that we have seen in the Soviet Union, some more fundamental reconsideration of Western policy might be necessary?
MAJOR: We identified some time ago what was most practical and of most assistance to the Soviets. That hasn't changed. The dimensions of that have changed. The need, the speed for it has changed. Perhaps the volume of it has changed. What we've actually done this morning is agree a very practical way forward. People are suggesting all sorts of things that ought to be done, but the priorities are to deal with the problems of food and food distribution, to deal with the ways in which we can help the Soviets maximize their own capacity to produce both food and other mechanistic and hardware produce, and we need a good deal of information in order to do that. There's no point in going beyond that until we can see precisely what the need is. . . .
 
Nuclear Safety
 Q. Does the breakup of the Soviet empire raise any concerns . . . about who controls the Soviet nuclear arsenal? . . .
BUSH. I want to have it disposed of in a way that nuclear weapons safety is totally guaranteed and to date, we feel very comfortable about that . . . I want to reassure the American people that at no time has there been any . . . official concern about inadvertent use of . . . nuclear weapons, or something going awry. But that is a matter that needs to be sorted out, and I'm confident that everybody in the republics and everybody in the center understands that the last thing that the world needs is some kind of nuclear scare, to say nothing of a nuclear confrontation. . . . We feel comfortable now that whoever is in charge will do the right thing in terms of safeguarding these nuclear weapons. . . .

 	 	 		. ..	 	Q.: Les Aspin has recommended . . . to Congress that they take $1 billion out of the defense budget and put it into some kind of Soviet aid program. What do you think? . . .
BUSH.: . . . It's ironic that just a few, few days ago when this coup was under way, there started a debate about are we spending enough on defense. . . . Now the debate comes, well, maybe we've got too much in defense. I'd say let's take a little time and sort this thing out intelligently. . . . Right now I simply cannot endorse that and I notice so many people are jumping up and saying what we must do now is cut defense spending more. I think we've cut defense spending a lot and I want to be sure that our forces are properly structured to meet the needs that we were talking about just 12 months ago, standing in this very same place. . . .
 
Suspending the Party
 Q. The Supreme Soviet just announced within the past half hour that they are suspending the Communist Party through the Soviet Union. . . . How do you assess it?
BUSH. . . . I frankly rejoice in that. I don't see anything but good news in that for terms of the West and certainly in terms of America. The demise, the fall, of a totalitarian nondemocratic party effort -- I think that's a good thing. So I don't see any bad news in that at all. Rejoice, cheer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Statement On Unity From Kiev

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KIEV, U.S.S.R., Aug. 29

 BODY:
Following is the text of a communique released early today by leaders of the Ukrainian and Russian republics, as translated by The Associated Press:
As a result of the liquidation of the state coup in the U.S.S.R., a new political situation has arisen, opening the possibility of accelerating democratic transformations and realizing the sovereign rights of republics to the fullest extent. 
 Taking into account the fact of the resignation of the U.S.S.R. Cabinet of Ministers and the inability of Union state structures to provide for the vital interests of the peoples, recognizing the inalienable right of the Ukraine and the Russian Federation to have state independence and confirming their adherence to the treaty between the R.S.F.S.R. and the Ukraine on Nov. 19, 1990, the sides agreed to the following:
1. To undertake joint actions with the goal of preventing the uncontrolled disintegration of the Union state, bearing in mind that during the transitional period, in order to support the systems providing vital necessities for the population and the functioning of the economy, it is expedient to create temporary interstate structures with the participation of interested states-subjects of the former U.S.S.R., regardless of their current status, on a representative and equal basis.
2. To propose to the states-subjects of the former U.S.S.R., regardless of their present status, that they immediately start preparations and signing of an economic agreement between them.
3. To confirm the special significance of military-strategic problems, to consider it necessary to implement a reform of the Armed Forces of the U.S.S.R. and to create a system of collective security, not to adopt unilateral decisions on military-strategic issues.
4. During the transitional period to avoid steps that affect the mutual interests of the sides without preliminary consultations.
5. To confirm articles 2 and 6, set out in the bilateral treaty of Nov. 19, 1990, on the rights of the citizens and the territorial integrity of the sides.
6. To emphasize the resolve to continue democratic transformations and to pursue a coordinated policy of radical economic reforms together with other states-subjects of the former Union.
7. To confirm the adherence to commitments by the U.S.S.R. in international relations, including agreements on arms reduction and arms control and responsibility for supporting international peace and stability, to express readiness to solve in the transitional period all the problems stemming from the previously adopted international commitments, on the basis of talks with both states-subjects of the former Union and members of the international community.
8. Immediately to exchange plenipotentiary representatives of the Russian federated republic and the Ukraine for continuous consultations.
 
Vice President of the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic -- A. Rutskoi
 
Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of the Ukraine -- L. Kravchuk
 
28-29 August, 1991.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Fell 8.5% in July

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Sales of new single-family homes fell sharply and unexpectedly in July, the Commerce Department said today, in a troubling sign that consumers lack confidence in the economic recovery.
Sales plunged 8.5 percent from the previous month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 472,000 homes, distressing some analysts, who had expected sales to jump to 530,000 units. In June, new-home sales had surged 7.4 percent. 
 In a second report that raised concern about whether the economy would successfully pull itself out of the first recession in eight years, the department said that the incomes of Americans fell in July for the first time in six months, edging down one-tenth of 1 percent. The drop was accompanied by an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in consumer spending, suggesting people had been dipping into their savings. [Page D8.]
Both reports helped push prices of Treasury bonds up and yields down as traders bet that the new signs of weakness would encourage the Federal Reserve to give the economy a lift by easing interest rates. Concerns about the economy also contributed to a dip in stock prices, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 5.59 points yesterday from its record-high close on Wednesday. [Pages D14 and D8.]
 
Only Northeast Shows a Gain
 Declines in home sales were reported in all areas of the country, except the Northeast, which had the most extreme sales slump last year.
In addition, the June sales figure was revised downward to an increase of 4 percent from the 7.4 percent rise that the department originally estimated.
Tom Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, called the sales report disturbing because it suggested the steam was going out of the housing sector, which had been leading the economy out of recession.
"All in all, this is a very distressing report," Mr. Holloway said. "It's discouraging for housing, and it's discouraging for the overall economy.
"The economic recovery is pretty flimsy anyway," he added, "and the one sector that had been giving it support was housing."
Dave Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said the latest sales figures point to trouble for the economy, when considered alongside surveys from builders that show buyer interest has weakened in August.
"This is really shaky," Mr. Seiders said. "The Fed has to be alarmed."
The Federal Reserve Board, the nation's central bank, sets interest-rate strategy and can lower rates to try to encourage more borrowing and spending by businesses and consumers.
 
Midwest Sales Off 27.4%
 The falloff in new-home sales last month was widespread, with the biggest plunge coming in the Midwest, where sales fell 27.4 percent to 69,000 units.
Throughout the recession, the Midwest has been one of the most stable regions of the country, so industry analysts singled out the big July drop as a special cause for concern.
Mr. Holloway did note that the magnitude of the fall in the Midwest affected the overall report, and next month's revisions might make the picture less gloomy. He also noted that average interest rates on 30-year mortgages had fallen to around 9 percent from 9.58 percent in July, which should prompt some revival in buying interest.
But, he said, better growth in jobs and in consumer income would be required over the long term to sustain rising home sales.
Mr. Seiders said reports from builders in the Midwest showed that demand for new homes remained weak all through July and into August.
In the South, sales fell 8.2 percent in July, to 191,000 units. They were down 4 percent in the West, to 144,000 units.
In the Northeast, sales were up 6.3 percent, to 67,000 units.
Nationally, new-home sales in July were a steep 12.7 percent lower than in July 1990, when they were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 541,000.
The median price of a new home in July was $120,200, a gain of 1.3 percent from a year earlier.
The national economy's recovery seems weak, and the housing figures partly reflect a lack of consumer confidence and difficulty for potential buyers in finding job opportunities, Mr. Seiders said. "The Fed has to move quickly," he added.
The overall weakness in home sales -- an important measure of consumers' willingness to make long-term financial commitments -- was underlined by a report earlier this week that showed a parallel 6.7 percent drop in July sales of existing homes.
In that report, the steepest regional decline was in the South, where existing-home sales dropped by 14.8 percent, to 1.27 million units. The Northeast, however, posted its fourth consecutive monthly increase, 1.8 percent, to 580,000 units.

HEADLINE: Dip in Personal Incomes Is First in 6 Months

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Americans' incomes fell in July for the first time in six months, the Government said today in a report underscoring the economy's fragility.
Personal incomes edged down 0.1 percent, or $5.6 billion, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.81 trillion. That broke a string of five monthly advances, the Commerce Department said. 
 The drop, even though it was small and accompanied by a 0.4 percent increase in consumer spending, raised concern about whether the economy would successfully pull itself out of the first recession in eight years.
"It's like a bicycle," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "If you don't have enough forward momentum, you fall off."
 
No 'Jump Start' Seen Soon
 Consumer spending, representing two-thirds of the gross national product, is considered the key to any sustained economic revival.
"Consumers are not going to give the recovery the jump start it needs any time soon," said John M. Albertine, a Washington-based economic consultant. "In past recoveries, consumers have led the way. But today it appears that they have grown conservative."
Despite the income drop, consumer spending rose 0.4 percent in July after hefty gains of 0.7 percent in June and 0.8 percent in May. Spending rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $16.5 billion to $3.84 trillion.
The income and spending figures were not adjusted for inflation. But adjusting creates no real change because inflation was low in July. Adjusted disposable income fell the same 0.1 percent and consumer spending rose the same 0.4 percent.
Because income was so sluggish, consumers in effect maintained their living standards by dipping into their savings. The personal savings rate was 3.7 percent last month, down from 4.1 percent in June.
Disposable income -- income after taxes -- was unchanged from June to July after rising 0.6 percent in June.
Wages and salaries, which are key components of the income data, fell 0.3 percent in July, even more than income generally. According to Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group, a Washington consulting firm, the wage-and-salary data reflect employers' caution about expanding payrolls.
"Employers are still laying off and they're very, very reluctant to start hiring again," she said. "There has to be an improvement in the job market and wages and salaries before consumers start to spend again."
 
Auto Sales Lifted Spending Data
 On the spending side, much of the strength came from a July increase in automobile sales, which have been falling this month. Spending for durable goods -- big-ticket items that include autos -- rose 1.8 percent. Spending on nondurable goods like food and clothing rose 0.2 percent, and spending on services increased 0.3 percent.
Ms. Shaber contended that a reluctance by banks to finance consumers' major purchases was restraining spending. But a survey of senior bank officers released today by the Federal Reserve found "little indication that banks had changed their willingness to provide consumer credit."
The survey, taken Aug. 9-13, did indicate, however, that banks continued to tighten their criteria for commercial real estate loans. They also were slightly stricter on home mortgage loans and business loans, the survey said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Continue to Rally

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The rally in the credit markets continued yesterday, as a fresh series of weak economic reports helped to push Treasury bond prices up and interest rates down.
The increasing signs of a limp recovery from the recession is likely to put more pressure on the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates further to stimulate economic activity. 
 Traders said they focused on a Government report showing an 8.5 percent slump in new home sales in July and a sharp downward revision in the number sold during June.
And they said a Commerce Department report showing that personal income fell by a tenth of 1 percent last month raised concerns about whether consumers have the wherewithal to bolster what already seems to be a tepid recovery.
 
New Jobless Claims Fall
 By contrast, traders shrugged off a report from the Labor Department that showed that initial unemployment claims fell by 9,000 during the week ended Aug. 17, to a seasonally adjusted 421,000. The decline in initial claims was larger than expected by many economists and followed two straight weeks of increases.
The housing statistics were consistent with a report earlier this week that sales of existing homes fell by 6.7 percent during July.
Nevertheless, "we were disappointed" with yesterday's numbers, said Michael Carliner, an economist at the National Association of Homebuilders. He said recent surveys of builders showed that "fewer people are coming around to look at homes."
"I think we will see some positive impact from the drop in mortgage rates we have seen over the last month or so," he said. "But we need to have them fall further. These numbers are further evidence that the recovery is very fragile and pathetic."
 
'No Momentum Building'
 The slump in home sales was considered especially disappointing because housing, along with exports, had been one of the more promising spots for an economic rebound.
But recent statistics seem to show that the economy is taking "one step forward, but then two steps back," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh.
"There is no momentum building" in the recovery, he said.
The numbers "reinforce the impression that the Fed will cut the funds rate and the discount rate," he said. "But one wonders whether monetary policy will be able to turn the economy around."
Rumors that the Federal Reserve Board governors were meeting yesterday to lower the discount rate, currently at 5.5 percent, circulated through the market yesterday. The Fed denied the reports.
All of these events were seen as good news by credit market participants, who continued to bid up prices of fixed-income securities.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 12/32 late yesterday, up 18/32, to yield 8.00 percent, compared with 8.05 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 100 28/32, up 12/32, to yield 7.75 percent.
 
Gains for the New Notes
 The new two-year and five-year notes auctioned earlier this week continued to fare well. By late yesterday, the 6 3/8 percent two-year notes traded at a price of 100 6/32, up 1/32, for a yield of 6.27, down from 6.29 percent late Wednesday. Meanwhile, the 7 1/4 percent five-year notes traded at par late Thursday, up 8/32, to yield 7.25 percent, down from 7.31 percent late Wednesday.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were virtually unchanged in light trading. Three-month bills were offered at a rate of 5.30 percent, unchanged from the previous day, and the six-month bill rate was also unchanged at a rate of 5.32 percent in late trading.
The Treasury also sold $5 billion worth of 16-day cash management bills yesterday at an average discount rate of 5.38 percent.
 
Money Supply Increases
 In other developments, the Fed reported that its measure of the money supply known as M-2 rose $3.7 billion, to $3,387.4 billion, for the week ending Aug. 23. The Fed said the four-week moving average of M-2 was $3,385.6 billion. The broader measure known as M-3 rose $3.9 billion, to $4,146.2 billion. And the narrower measure known as M-1 rose $2.1 billion, to $864.9 billion.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said the prices of most issues rose about a quarter of a point in quiet pre-holiday trading.
There was little activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, where prices of the most widely quoted issues rose about an eighth of a point, dealers said. Most of the trading activity was in New York State Thruway bonds.
